content.description: Whether its lunchtime or late at night, this steak-and-a-beer standby captures a classic Chicago feel in a far more subtle manner than most. It could be the bartender with his slick vest and tie or the towering walls of signed photos from satisfied Chicago sports and entertainment celebs. But we like to think that classicness is mainly due to the straight-talking clientele that likes its whiskey on the rocks and its ties loose.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Green, Orange, Purple (rush hrs) to Adams; Blue, Red to Monroe
content.property: No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Classic Chicago spot Good for groups Late Night Food served

content.description: The glowing neon signs in the windows of this middlebrow supper club proclaim: steak, ribs and fish. But after 2am, they could just as easily declare transvestites, eastern european mafia and drunken frat boys. That all of these demographics and more can comfortably mingle is a testament to the friendly staff, a surprisingly good jukebox and the shared belief that the first eight vodka tonics just werent enough.
content.property: Late Night Food served No steps at entrance

content.description: This well-lit bar doesnt have any beers on tap but serves ahi tuna. In short, it will never truly be a dive. But we dont care, because we feel at home among the concert posters on the walls and the red-velvet booths. And if were going to drink out of bottles, it might as well be from this 27 beerstrong selection.
content.property: Video/pinball games No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Food served Extensive beer selection Good for groups

content.description: Owned by the folks behind bachelorette-party bar Baton Show Lounge, this likable venue (formerly Annex 3) is now a piano bar similar to Gentry (think cabaret cuties and the 40-and-older crowd who loves them). Recent nights were a bit barren, but the flickering candles, fresh-cut flowers, friendly staff and quality entertainment should bring in the crowds once the words out.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 8, 22, 77
content.property: Darts Pool table Video/pinball games Live bands Piano bar No steps at entrance Good for over-40 crowd

content.description: Is it a bar? A breakfast place? A deli? A dinner spot? This newbie is supposed to be all four, but a mural of nasty, red-eyed bats is only suited for a sinister school cafeteria. Luckily, the sandwiches and pastries justify overlooking this places identity crisis: The thick, crusty bread is from Evanstons Bennisons Bakery and sweets come from Ann Arbor, Mich.s Zingermans Bakery. From the sandwich menu, we liked the Tabu Club (chicken breast, Muenster, bacon, lettuce and rmoulade on seven-grain) and the Blue Lightning (chicken breast, hot sauce, Muenster, blue-cheese dressing and lettuce on sourdough). Stop by in the morning for free coffeejust avert your eyes from the painting of flying rodents.
content.public-transport: El: Purple to Davis. Bus: 93, 201, 205, Pace 208
content.property: Good for dining at bar Private party room(s) Vegetarian-friendly Outdoor seating Suburban

content.description: Around the corner from Division Streets jack-ass bar scene is this cozy one-room saloon tucked inside the Canterbury Court Hotel. Singles, socialites, cigar smokers and even sexagenarians pack themselves in on busy weekends. The zebra theme is a bit reckless, but distinctive. The ultrared lighting, on the other hand, makes you wonder if students from the Art Institute are going to emerge from behind the bar with developed film. A nightly piano player keeps the Zebra refreshingly unhip with old-school faves like Do You Know the Way to San Jose.
content.property: Piano bar No stairs to bathroom No steps at entrance Wheelchair-accessible bathroom

content.description: The guys behind Grand Central and Union Park won't quit: Their latest bar, described as "Grand Central's little sister," boasts 20 plasma screens and a emphasis on domestic beer. Come baseball season, they're hoping to be the next home-away-from-home for Cubs fans, but for now, Bears fans can soak up their misery just the same.
content.property: No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Sports bar Food served Private party room(s)

content.description: A policy of pouring generously means that the cocktails you get at this new hangout will be smooth and potent. But more than that, it keeps this genericalbeit bright, casual and friendlyhangout from getting lost in Southports waves of homogeny.
content.property: No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Sports bar Food served

address.street: Four Seasons Hotel Chicago, 120 E Delaware Pl
Four Seasons Hotel Chicago, 120 E Delaware Pl

content.description: Cloth napkins, linen doilies and exceptional cocktails like the ginger martini (with fresh ginger shavings collected at the bottom of the glass): Would you expect anything less from the Four Seasons? And would you expect to pay anything less than ten bucks per drink? Good. Then be prepared to have your expectations met.
content.property: Notable for cocktails Dress sharp Good for over-40 crowd Conversation friendly Views Food served Dress code

content.description: Nearly every square inch of wall space at this fireman-themed, triangle-shaped corner pub is plastered with surprisingly arresting black-and-white photographs of burning houses and heroic rescues, antique fire alarms, vintage axes and several flat-screen TVs with a Fighting Irish bias. Daily discounts, including half-price everything on Tuesdays, make this an attractive option for down-and-out DePaul kids.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 8, 11, 74

content.description: Starched shirts get unbuttoned at this River North after-work hangout, where friends sip beer and wine in long booths by the windows or at the handful of tables outside on Wells. Exposed brick walls, an intricate tin ceiling and a reddish glow are reminders that not all Irish pubs have to be plastered with shamrocks.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Merchandise Mart; Red to Grand. Bus: 11, 65, 125

content.description: Enjoy tropical relaxation courtesy of Brazilian native and former Urban She waxing goddess Cleise Gomes at her Lincoln Park outpost. Facials, nail services, body wraps and scrubs are all on the menu, but bikini waxing is the spa’s specialty. Choose from the regular ($35), the flirtatious ($50) or the Carecona ($65 and up)—a bare–all bikini bonanza.

content.public-transport: El: Red, Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Fullerton. Bus: 8, 11, 74

content.description: Cant snag a bleacher seat at the Friendly Confines? Dont fret. Bathed in dark woods and brimming with beer, burgers, apps and wraps, this surprisingly friendly bar just a stones throw north is the next-best place to park your tush on game day. With 25 HD plasma-screen TVs, youll catch every angle without catching a single harmful UV ray.
content.property: Sports bar Good for groups Private party room(s) Outdoor seating Food served

content.public-transport: El: Green to Oak Park. Pace bus: 309 Lake, 311 North

content.description: This spa has elected to focus entirely on the art of massage, and the approach has worked famously. The offerings are broad and largely Eastern-based, though the standby Swedish and sports massages are available. If you’ve never put your feet in the hands of an experienced reflexologist, do yourself a favor. Each part of the foot correlates to a part of the body, and the reflexologist can “read” your feet as though she is reviewing your medical chart. After each inch of the foot is massaged to release toxins, you’ll be sent on your way a little more respectful of the power your tootsies wield.

content.public-transport: El: Brown, Red, Purple (rush hrs) to Fullerton. Bus: 8, 11, 74
El: Blue to Logan Square. Bus: 74, 82

content.description: This adorable Wicker Park spa focuses on facials. Your treatment begins with questions about how often you’re outside, and what hair, skin-care and makeup products you use. Your therapist uses this info to blend products from the all-natural skin-care line from Hungary called Éminence. For example, sweat-clogged pores are cleansed with a Lime Stimulating Masque; sunburned skin benefits from Sour Cherry Whip Moisturizer. The products smell delicious and feel luxurious going on. But the real fun comes when you look in the mirror afterward: Your face is firm and glowing, and feels soft and supple. There is some extracting, but calming creams are used so you can even hit the town that night, sans redness.

A peek at the treatment menu reveals that Shen Shen Health & Harmony is more than just another massage and beauty hotspot, it's a medicinal destination armed with skilled practitioners who want to relieve whatever is ailing you—whether it's back pain, indiegestion, a smoking addiction or a running injury. The signature treatment is a combo of Tui Na (rigorous Chinese massage) and acpuncture, but guasha (skin-scraping), cupping, Shiatsu (Japanese pressure point therapy), Reiki (chakra healing) and the Trager Approach (subtle energetic touch) are also popular options. And don't be surprised if your therapist recommends an herb or supplement to continue the healing process after your treatment—she'll slowly and thoughtfully discuss how she arrived at her prescription and how it should benefit your body. If you're looking for a natural approach to wellness, this place is for you.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Red to Fullerton. Bus: 11, 76

content.description: With waiting lists to get into the Cheesecake Factory longer than an hour on most days, we’re glad that fingers & toes—located just inside the John Hancock building—is a mere 10 steps away from the madness. Stop in for a mani($15) or pedi ($30), and you’ll receive quick service, a serene salon with really comfortably pedicure couches and a decent nail job—although we’d prefer if our nail tech were a little more thorough.

Comfortable, casual and a little quirky, this neighborhood spa is the kind of place where you would feel at ease showing up in old sweats for salt-glow rejuvenation or a sun-glow jolt. The cucumber water is familiar enough, but all the Chiclets you can chew? You don’t get that everywhere. The spa provides robe and slippers as well as primping creams and tonics for your after-treatment use. The friendly staff dotes on men and women equally.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 8, 76

content.description: Contrary to dining trends, the Depot is not a contemporary take on or an upscale version of a diner; its simply the real thing. Everything on the menu is simple and excellently seasoned: Golden breakfast potatoes get a sprinkling of paprika, big bowls of chili have enough bite to wake your taste buds up (but not burn them off) and the juicy pieces of turkey on the open-faced sandwich are covered in thick, peppery gravyso much that you may have trouble finding the bread underneath it all. Housemade desserts tempt from behind the counter; sadly, they look better than they taste, so stick with coffee.
content.public-transport: El: Blue to Austin Lombard (Forest Park). Bus: 12, 91, Pace 305, Pace 315
El: Red, Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Belmont. Bus: 9, 77

content.description: It may be nestled in a new condo monolith, but theres a casual working-class neighborhood bar hiding beneath the surface. The bartenders are friendly types who pour with a heavy hand, and while the bar is a case study in Uptowns gentrification, everybody gets along fine over a drink. The pool table and darts provide nice diversions, and two little seating alcoves offer the feeling of a private party.
content.property: Darts Pool table Video/pinball games No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Sports bar

content.description: The main event at this Vietnamese hole-in-the-wall is, as the name would suggest, the steaming bowls of pho (pronounced fuh), a Vietnamese beef noodle soup that is the perfect elixir on a cold and snowy Chicago day. When bleak weather subsides, switch gears with something bright and springy, like the citrus-kissed beef salad piled with crunchy bits of peanuts, fresh mint and green chiles that add just the right amount of heat.

Walking into this wine barso warm with wood tones yet impeccably contemporary, a meat-and-cheesemonger working passionately to complete orders, a wall of well-chosen, well-priced winesis like walking into the coolest wine bar in London, or the coolest wine bar in New Yorkonly guess what? It just happens to be the coolest wine bar in Chicago.
content.property: Wine bar Dress sharp Date place Conversation friendly Food served Surprisingly good wine list Outdoor seating

content.description: The weathers cooled off, which means this Italian spot from two Coco Pazzo vetschef Tony Priolo and wine guru Ciro Longobardois getting cozy with its newly unveiled fall menu. Priolo is taking the cue and infiltrating his menu of regional Italian pastas, pizzas and antipasti with fall flavors: Take, for instance, oven-dried tomatoes served with basil and buffalo mozzarella; chickpea-flour fries with Parmesan; mushroom-topped pizza; and braised short ribs over soft polenta.
content.property: Outdoor seating Vegetarian-friendly Notable wine list

content.description: This upscale Andersonville martini lounge has been burning through olives and vermouth faster than a steakhouse since it opened. But dont expect to rub elbows with homos all night. Straight folk tend to show up first for a predinner cocktail, and the gay crowd comes later. Like gentrification, but in reverse.
content.property: No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Outdoor seating Gay Lesbian

content.description: A dark room. A long wooden bar. A couple of middle-aged guys playing video trivia in the corner. A staff who couldnt care less. Who would guess thered be lines around the corner to get in here come 2am? Guess thats what a 4am license gets ya.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Armitage. Bus: 8, 11, 73
content.property: No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Late Night Private party room(s) Video/pinball games

content.description: This tiny Ukrainian Village dining room is tight on tables and menu itemsthere are about a dozen of eachbut what it lacks in size is made up for with charm. The simple Italian fare has absolutely no bells or whistles, but, luckily, most dishes dont need any. A duo of meaty mushroomsperfectly roasted portobello and sauted oysteris dressed only with balsamic and thyme. For more intricate dishes, look to seasonal specialties like juniper and clovebraised pork shanks over Tuscan white beans, or grilled marinated leg of lamb with roasted parsnip puree and toasted garlic spinach.
content.property: Notable wine list Vegetarian-friendly Outdoor seating

content.description: Quite possibly the straightest bar in Andersonville, this place gets packed on the weekends with breeders who stop by to drink Goose Island 312, shoot pool, watch some sports, and, sometimes, get drunk by themselves near the patio doors and yell things at passersby.

content.public-transport: El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 80

content.description: This bilevel Wrigleyville joint draws a strange crowd: a mix of ball-capped football fans paying full attention to the wall-size TV behind the bar and aspiring improv comics from nearby I.O. who love to rehash favorite bits and revel in their ironic choice of destination. No group pays any heed to the other, particularly when the orders of Tater Tots arrive.
content.property: No steps at entrance Good for groups Darts No stairs to bathroom Sports bar Outdoor seating Food served Video/pinball games Private party room(s)

entry.name: Lion Head Pub and the Apartment

version.name: Lion Head Pub and the Apartment

content.description: DePaul students, hospital staff and neighborhood urban professionals alike belly up at this combo spot. Decent bar food, foosball, pool and darts dominate downstairs at the Lion Head, where its impossible not to find yourself facing one of the two dozen plasma and big-screen TVs. Upstairs, the Apartment sports a corny (yet comfy) club atmosphere with its beds, couches and recliners, which get plenty of use on weekends when the place is packed assholes-to-elbows with singles.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 8, 11, 74
content.property: No stairs to bathroom No steps at entrance Pool table Darts Good for groups Fireplace Food served Sports bar

content.description: At this tiny Pilsen storefront, regulars get special treatment (a.k.a. refried beans, not always on offer), newcomers just get blank stares and everybody gets the carnitas. Ordered by the pound (our server recommended a half-pound per person, but we think thats a little stingy), the juicy pork (choose between just meat or everything, which includes skin, ribs, etc.) is served to you on a platter with nothing but a side of corn tortillas and a spicy salsa verde so that you can concoct your own tacos. Not leaving any part of the pig to waste, the limited menu also includes fresh, warm, delicious pork rinds.

This Lincoln Square spot is never crowded, and we cant figure out why. The ambience (exposed brick and chocolate hues) is classy, the drinks are strong enough and the food (typical pub grub) fills us up, but for some reason 42 just doesnt pack em in. Come to think of it, we kind of like having the big space all to ourselves.
content.property: No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Sports bar Outdoor seating

content.description: Befitting its conventional-yet-cozy decor, this classic steakhouse/brewpub has a menu that holds few surprises: a little chicken, a little fish and a whole lotta meat. Skip apps like so-so shrimp DeJonghe and tough mussels and go straight for the wet-aged steaks, expertly cooked beneath a 1,400-degree infrared broiler that caramelizes the exterior and locks in the juices. Our massive porterhouse was ridiculously tender and juicy, while our rib eye was just as good (although it could have used a little judicious fat trimming). Brockway also brews its own beer, and our caramelly Grossvater Erlbecker Amber Lager was worth the Metra ride there.
content.public-transport: Metra: Union Pacific NW to Palatine
content.property: Private party room(s) Outdoor seating Fireplace Suburban

content.description: Gay men and straight women can create their own luck by popping into this pleasant Boystown stalwart. After all, its easy to get lucky at a place where go-go boys dance in the middle of the horseshoe-shaped bar: Just bring enough dollar bills.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 8, 22, 77
content.property: No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Gay Extensive beer selection Good for groups

content.description: We heard rumors that this late-night hookup haven gets packed with sweaty grinders around 1am, so we settled on a more mellow afternoon drink instead. Which turned out to be just fine. The chatty bartender helped us pick from the dozen beers on tap, the pool table was open and despite our best efforts, nobody hit on us. Once area bars close down, however, its a seedier story.

The real draw of this small, Little Italy storefront is the Maghrebin food. Taking influences from Moroccan, Algerian and Tunisian fare, its a mash-up of cuisines resulting in delicious tagines, cheesy souffls stuffed with beef or chicken that arent cooked in tagines but are tasty nonetheless. Or go for the comforting plates of couscous sporting huge chunks of potatoes, carrots and zucchini surrounding flavorful cuts of lamb. Come on, you can pass up pasta for a night, cant you?

Venturing into the famous Tip Top Tap building (a.k.a. the Allerton Hotel), we expected to find a bar that harkens back to the good old days: jazz quintets doing Armstrong, flappers dancing the Charlestonthat sort of thing. But in fact, this is a quiet, sophisticated spot where one can have a cocktail by himself, and if not relive the old days, at least think about them in peace.
content.property: No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Food served Live bands Date place

content.description: Nestled on a tree-lined street in Lincoln Park, this watering hole is the epitome of neighborly drinking. A friendly bartender will chat you up and introduce you to the locals as he mixes your Hendricks and tonic. Ask about beer and you might just get schooled, and youll definitely get something tossed your way thats better than that MGD you almost ordered.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 73, 74
content.property: Video/pinball games No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Food served Extensive beer selection

content.description: Sometimes one of those grumpy old-timers takes a seat among the younger Lincoln Park buttoned-down crowd here. But once the geezers settle into plush leather booths, or the year-round beer garden, and chat with the impeccable bartender and sip a beer, even they cant stay in a bad mood.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 73 Armitage, 74 Fullerton

content.property: Darts No stairs to bathroom Outdoor seating Food served Pool table Extensive beer selection

content.description: This bar sits high above Michigan Ave, just north of the fountain in the 12th floor atrium lobby of the Ritz-Carlton. And as could be expected from a bar inside one of the citys most luxurious hotels, this place is swanksville. Chairs upholstered in soft leather and plush velvet surround ornate tables in the copper-tinted room that, after a couple martinis, youll never want to leave.
content.property: Notable wine list Private party room(s) Vegetarian-friendly

content.description: Thanks to a metal-clad exterior that sticks out like a Clockwork Orange thumb in this ho-hum stretch of west Belmont Central, this hot, young Polish haunt is impossible to miss. Less Weed Street nightclub and more Exit metal dude hangout, the bar has an interior covered with intricate, high-quality metalwork from a local Polish artist. Add pool and foosball tables, a great jukebox and cheap drinks, and you might just start checking out real estate in the area.

The paints chipping off the walls here and there, the bathroom is a claustrophobes nightmare, and if its busy you might be forced to belly up to a folding table. Then again, this surprisingly spacious bar is filled with so many flat-screen and projection TVs and fills our stomachs with enough yummy bar food that we almost didnt notice.
content.property: Pool table Video/pinball games No stairs to bathroom Sports bar Food served

content.description: This Wicker Park spot is the JetBlue of bodywork. It’s the same pricing structure used by airlines: Walk-ins willing to pay a premium for convenience subsidize those who plan ahead. Owner Mike Flatley is on a mission to bring massage, essential oil therapy, reiki and acupuncture to the masses by using some good old-fashioned business sense. The basic rate for a walk-in who wants a 50-minute session is a respectable $75; call at least one hour ahead and you’ll pay only $50, or book one or more days in advance and pay just $45. For those looking to upgrade, a tandem massage—four hands working at once for 50 minutes—is a bargain at $85 (about half of what you’d pay elsewhere), while the 50-minute, nine-oil Raindrop Therapy is only $65. (You can add a boost of essential oils to any treatment for an additional $1–$15.) Customers who buy in bulk get the best deal of all: a prepaid ten-pack of 50-minute massages for a very Zen $360.

content.public-transport: El: Blue to LaSalle; Red to Harrison. Bus: 12, 24, 36

content.description: Tell your friends you went to this Gold Coast spot just to make fun of the old rich people all you want. But the truth is you cant sit among the sparkling fountain and oversized flower arrangements, slowly sipping your perfectly shaken martini, without thinking that your mom was right all along: You are special.
content.property: Food served Live bands Dress code

content.description: Since opening its doors in 87, Frontera Grill has been the spot for an intensely flavorful, impeccably fresh slice of Mexico, courtesy of Celebrity Chef and winner of Top Chef Masters Rick Bayless. With the help of Chef Richard James, the menu changes often but the flavors are always full, punchy and bright. No matter the weather, the ceviche selection is always spot-on and although tweaked every two weeks, expect stellar versions of Mexican classics like enchiladas, mole and flautas.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Merchandise Mart; Red to Grand. Bus: 22, 29, 36, 65
content.property: Good for dining at bar Vegetarian-friendly Outdoor seating

content.description: This new Lincoln Park pub is in the old Lindo Mexico place, but those in mourning can still get their quesadilla fix. Youd better get it now, though: This place is quickly morphing into a sports bar, and tequila and quesadillas might soon be replaced by Bud Light and burgers.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 11, 76
content.property: Food served Pool table Video/pinball games Darts

content.description: We’ll speak for the many “mature” residents of the tony Gold Coast neighborhood by saying Christopher Charles has certainly done its demographic homework. The posh spa, featuring stunning views of Michigan Avenue and the lake from its comfy mani/pedi room, offers antiaging skin care via an extensive menu of facials, from preventative care (the Vita-C Anti-Aging, $145, promotes collagen synthesis) to corrective (the Lighten and Resurface, $165, evens out sun-damage spots) and clinical (an on-staff M.D. gives Botox injections). But don’t miss the fantastic body treatments: The Scentao massage ($150) is 90 minutes of heaven, incorporating hot stones and acupressure. You’ll leave the spa feeling as giddy as a little kid.
content.public-transport: El: Red to Chicago. Bus: 151, 156, 146 Walton

content.description: What does it say about our city that this small, enclosed rooftop bar above the W Hotel Lakeshore is still one of the most popular haunts on the North Side? That we really like hotel bars? That we appreciate a good view of Navy Pier? None of the above. We simply know a good bar when we see it, and were not about to let the tourists have all the fun.
content.property: Dress sharp Private party room(s) New Views
Dress sharp Private party room(s) Views

content.description: Is this an upscale tavern or a friendly neighborhood bar? The six TVs and thirtysomething dudes in baseball caps represent the latter. But then there are wooden tables topped with fresh flowers and a menu that includes cognac-soaked dates, delicious bratwurst slathered in Sierra Nevada mustard and an extensive wine list. The recent launch of Witts weekend brunch of pork-belly sandwiches and salami-accessorized Bloody Marys means theres one more excuse to stop in and deliberate.
content.property: Food served Outdoor seating Sports bar No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Conversation friendly Good for groups

content.description: Congress Plaza hotel employees have been on strike for five years now, and it shows: We had to instruct our tipsy bartender how to mix our cocktail, and dirty glasses were scattered on every table. Its not exactly what we look for in a hotel bar, but if youre looking for a locale to shoot your next B movie, this may be your place.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Orange to Library; Red to Harrison. Bus: 1, 3, 4, 6, 7, 10, 14, 26, 28, 126, 144, 145, 146, 147
content.property: Darts Pool table Video/pinball games No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Sports bar

content.description: As the saying goes, big things come in small packages, and the big flavors that spill out of the kitchen of this tiny diner may open some eyes. The menu is wildly erratic: Classic American greasy spoon standbys make an appearance, but the bread-and-butter, so to speak, of this place is Asian-influenced dishes that can transport you from China to Thailand to Korea in a single bite.
content.public-transport: El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 9, 22, 80

content.description: You wouldnt believe the brand of tie-loosened debauchery that happens at this fantastic dive on a nightly basis. Unless, of course, you climb the carpeted stairwayfollowing the thumping bass and uninhibited laughter coming from behind the heavy, unmarked doorand step inside. Once you see this place, youll believe anything.

With hundreds of Mexican joints to choose from in the city, why do we love this one? Maybe its because we dream about the Huatulco torta, a huge sandwich that layers spicy housemade chorizo, caramelized onions, a slather of pinto beans and fresh avocado atop amazing cecina, thin beef thats marinated for two days in lemon, salt and oregano and then grilled. Or maybe its the roasted Cornish hen smothered in Oaxacan mole or the crispy red snapper hiding under pickled red onions. Maybe there are too many reasons to count.
content.public-transport: El: Blue to Irving Park. Bus: 53, 56

content.description: This speakeasy-esque spacea vacuous room, lined with booths and sprinkled with tables and chairsis a nightly respite for local artists. The Tater Tots are a greasy must-have, and the menu hides gems like killer fried chicken. Wash everything down with a $2 Pabst, and dont miss the photo booth tucked in the back corner before heading out.
content.property: Video/pinball games No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Food served Conversation friendly Live bands

content.public-transport: El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 50, 80.

content.description: Every Tuesday night, jazz legend Von Freeman attracts a crowd of admirers from all over the city, along with a cabal of eager beaver instrument-toting youngsters who hope to get in on the end-of-the-show jam session. The rest of the week, the crowd thins to a group of neighborhood regulars.

As a sibling of Mystic Celt and Vaughans Pub, this popular Old Town pub knows how to get Irish. On any given night, youll find the place packed with pre and postSecond City fans digging on pints of beer, pub grub, and a mix of Lou Reed and Guns N Roses blaring from the speakers.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Sedgwick. Bus: 72, 156
content.property: Wheelchair-accessible bathroom No stairs to bathroom Outdoor seating Food served

content.description: Expect to walk into a rambunctious and cheerful open room that oozes goodwill and Irish charm. Bartender Claire will serve your Magners hard cider with ice, and the black and tan is poured so beautifully youd swear you were at the Temple Bar in Dublin. A stone fireplace adds an authentic Irish cottagelike ambience, even though the menu includes some British fare. Live bands pep up the joint even more on the weekends.
content.property: Fireplace Food served Live bands Private party room(s)

content.description: First impressions are not this spots strong suit. When we entered the dusty old dive with silver tinsel in its two tiny windows, we thought it would be the kind of joint where knife fights are as common as games of eight ball. Boy, were we wrong. After we ordered a beer and complimented a dude on his jukebox Beatles block, the bartender offered us free pizza and, later, the parting words Be careful out there.
content.property: Pool table No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom
Darts Video/pinball games Private party room(s) Wheelchair-accessible bathroom No stairs to bathroom No steps at entrance Live bands Karaoke Fireplace Food served

content.description: The best of this bars detailsa stone fireplace, stained-glass windows and the dark wood bar itselfwere imported from Ireland, which should win it some kind of an award for most authentic Irish pub in Wrigleyville. It also gets points for serving a killer burger with champ (mashed potatoes and green onions), but loses points for its unfortunate seating arrangements. Hard, wooden booths, with accompanying low tables, are barely padded; daddy longlegs will be in pain.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 11, 22, 36, 77
content.property: Sports bar Private party room(s) Live bands Wheelchair-accessible bathroom No stairs to bathroom No steps at entrance Outdoor seating Fireplace Food served After-work crowd Conversation friendly Good for over-40 crowd

content.description: There are no other words that describe the clientele here better than dudes and chicks. Similarly, theres nothing that can describe the bar, with its plethora of flatscreens and loud (but good) sound system blaring football, other than sports pub. And when its 3am on Saturday night and the dudes and chicks are still wide awake, this 5am bar is the go-to, if only because its one of the few places in the hood still serving.

Ryan LaRoche (Tru, DeLaCosta) replaced Andrew Zimmerman (whos now leading the kitchen at Sepia) as the chef de cuisine collaborating with Exec Chef Christophe David in this stunningif a bit chillydining room. The chefs wrap crab so neatly in thin slivers of gorgeous beets that it resembles a maki roll, and cook meats expertly, such as the lamb, given a Morrocan treatment, which was as tender as brioche. End on a high note with pastry chef Frederic Moreaus fantastic, slightly molecular versions of crme brule and mille-feuille.
content.property: Views Private party room(s) Notable wine list Good for groups Outdoor seating

content.description: If the city were flooded with Persian joints tomorrow, this spot would still be packed. Theres something about the casual room brightened with colorful tile murals, the smoky baba ghanoush, the cinnamon-and-tomatobraised lamb shank and those tender chicken kebabs, charred outside but still juicy inside, plopped down on deliciously fluffy rice alongside charbroiled tomatoes and onions. A cup of Persian tea to follow, and were in heaven.

Youll never know how relaxing Celtic music can be until you spend an afternoon at this Scottish ale house. Listen closely as you hang out on the serene outdoor patio, eating fish and chips (its all-you-can-eat on Wednesdays and Fridays) and drinking from one of the best Scotch whiskey lists in the citysoon youll be humming along.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 8, 22, 76

content.description: Michael Jordans West Loop restaurant is off the path and plagued with a slightly stodgy reputation. So its up to chef Michael McDonald and his pastry chef, Hillary Blanchard, to change peoples minds and fill the seats. They do that by putting out dependably delicious riffs of new American food, such as McDonalds veal scallopini with tropical-fruit chutney, and Blanchards key lime baked Alaska, which features yuzu curd. And if that doesnt change peoples minds about what the restaurant is all about, lounge specials like $4 burgers (and $4 craft beers) on Thursday nights will.
content.public-transport: El: Green, Pink to Ashland. Bus: 9, 20, 65
content.property: Good for groups Notable wine list Private party room(s)

content.description: There arent many outdoor options in Boystown, so if the chic upper deck at Sidetrack isnt your thing, try this more peaceful patio. Weave through the front of the joint (with, yes, dead animal heads on the walls) to emerge on the back porch where, except for the bar, it feels just like youre hanging out at an older gay guys backyard barbecue with beer guzzlers in frayed jean-shorts.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 8, 22, 77
content.property: Darts Pool table Video/pinball games No stairs to bathroom Outdoor seating Food served Gay

content.description: How did one of the best sports bars end up in Ravenswood? A dozen beers on tap, almost that many plasma screens (42 inches, and size does matter) and 10-cent wings on Mondaysbeats the sticky floors and drunken screaming at your current spot.
content.property: Darts Video/pinball games No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Outdoor seating Fireplace Food served Sports bar Good for groups Private party room(s)

content.description: This is the perfect spot for an evening of miniburgers (hand-formed patties with melted cheese and a pickle slice), onion rings and a domestic beer or two. Families are welcome, but later at night booster chairs give way to friendly singles from the neighborhood.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 9 Ashland, 74 Fullerton
content.property: Outdoor seating Fireplace Food served Live bands Date place

content.description: Three things reign supreme at this long-standing good-times spot: karaoke, board games (from Scrabble to Operation) and electric-hued cocktails that the matronly bartender claims will mess you up. Dont believe her? The signature Blue Frog has vodka, gin, rum, melon liqueur, blue curacao, sour and Sprite, enough crap to convince you the patio is floating.
content.property: No stairs to bathroom Karaoke Outdoor seating Food served

content.description: A self-described old man, Cal himself no longer slings Old Style at this Loop dive bar. But the handful of stools are still warmed by bike messengers, construction workers and the occasional gritty punk coming to check out bands like Urinal Mints and Rabid Rabbit that bang out music from a tiny corner of the room.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to LaSalle
content.property: No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Live bands Food served Wheelchair-accessible bathroom

content.description: A honky-tonk in Sheridan Park with $1.50 domestics on Mondays, country-western karaoke on Thursdays and the house band Diamondback on weekends, featuring sassy little Reba singin and strummin rhythm with a darn good gee-tar picker on lead. A pool table in back, greasy grill turning out late-night burgers and Hank-filled jukebox round out the grit fest.
content.property: No stairs to bathroom Pool table Karaoke Live bands Food served No steps at entrance

content.description: Weve seen people at this dim, homey, Near North pub hang out without ever ordering a drink, but we just cant follow suit. We envy the friendly neighbors who drop onto wooden stools just to chat up the bartender. But when we spy two dozen beers on tapmostly domestic gems like Great Lakes Brewing Companys Elliot Nesswe feel like settling in and getting our drink on.
content.property: Outdoor seating Extensive beer selection Classic Chicago spot Conversation friendly Good for over-40 crowd Video/pinball games

content.description: Fans of VH1s I Love the 80s will be in heaven surrounded by walls plastered with vintage concert tees and glass cases jam-packed with every collectible toy created in that era. During the week, theres room to take it all in, but weekends get crammed with locals rocking white belts playing pool to a DJs mix of punk, indie rock and occasional polka. Yes, polka. After all, this is Ukrainian Village.
content.public-transport: El: Blue to Division. Bus: 50 Damen, 70 Division
content.property: No stairs to bathroom Pool table Video/pinball games

content.description: Whether youre hungry for baseball, football, rugby or just beer, this straight-friendly gay sports bar will definitely work. Forty beers on tap (75 total), tasty (and even healthy) pub grub, lots of TVs and a rah-rah decor make this a fun place to cheer for your team, whatever team youre on.
content.property: No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Darts Pool table Karaoke Gay Outdoor seating Food served Sports bar

content.description: The floors of this converted Bucktown house shake so much from the weight of hot-footed trendsetters youd think the place is seconds from caving in. Most of the dancing is set to a mix of hip-hop, electro and rock on the weekends (and the insanely popular first-Wednesday-of-the-month funk party called Sheer Magic), but there are plenty of nooks and crannies to sit back, relax and people-watch.
content.public-transport: El: Blue to Damen. Bus: 50 Damen, 73 Armitage
content.property: Live bands Extensive beer selection Conversation friendly

content.description: One of the citys best spots for rock & roll doesnt even have a stage. Instead, this Lincoln Park favorite has one of the best jukeboxes in town for the main room (so you can play DJ Fridays and Saturdays) and hires DJs for Sunday through Thursday who know their Buzzcocks from their Bullocks. Add an insane whiskey selection, more than 200 beers (Belgian, microbrews, seasonals) and frequent free movie nights, and you have a bar to call home.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 11, 76
content.property: No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Video/pinball games Pool table Extensive beer selection Surprisingly good wine list Classic Chicago spot

content.description: Thursday is fetish night and Monday its punk rock, but pretty much any night you stumble upon this haunt for the black-clad youll see that the freaks indeed do come out at night. Like any clique, it tends to have an insider feel, but brave souls looking for their Ministry and PBR fix have to start somewhere. Beware that theres a $5 cover on weekends.
content.public-transport: El: Red to North/Clybourn. Bus: 9 Ashland, 72 North

content.description: As its name suggests, McCools is an Irish-style pub, but as its location suggests, the emphasis is on flash rather than authenticity. Not that theres anything wrong with that, especially if youre looking for a big crowd where fake brogues can go unnoticed and cheaper drinks than the surrounding spots.
content.property: Video/pinball games Karaoke No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Late Night Food served Darts Fireplace

content.description: Truly a neighborhood hangout, this tried-and-true East Village bar is frequented by those who appreciate Claudio the tamale guy, a jukebox that stocks both white-hot jazz and doom metal, a cheap pool table, equally cheap drinks and a crowd who could care less if you show up in sweats.
content.property: Pool table No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom

content.description: This charming Lincoln Square cottage bar offers a huge selection of German drafts. Sadly, most of the traditional German tunes on the jukebox are gone, but couples still slow-dance to classic pop. Check out the fetching portrait of Irma, the owner, behind the front bar.
content.property: No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Conversation friendly

content.description: Young and old, dregs and misfits, singers and drunkardsall break out their best shower voice at this Ravenswood spot for karaoke seven nights a week. Youre as likely to hear Young MCs Bust a Move as you are Sinatras It Was a Very Good Year. The same kind of juxtaposition puts watermelon shots next to Manhattans on the weekly specials board. Deee-lish.
content.property: No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Karaoke Video/pinball games Late Night

content.description: Escort a date to the Peninsulas dark, clubby cocktail bar and you wont go home alone. All the manly bases have been covereda glowing fireplace, a stogie-stocked humidor and high-backed bar stools or cozy couched conversation nooks. Sip well-crafted cocktails, bubbly by the glass or whiskeys from obscure distillers.
content.property: Notable for cocktails Surprisingly good wine list Dress sharp Conversation friendly Good for over-40 crowd Food served No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Private party room(s) Fireplace

content.description: The conflicting vibes (and Irish name) confused the hell out us. With a crunchy guitar duo belting acoustic versions of Radiohead and waitresses in short, plaid skirts, we didnt know if we were at summer camp or a Britney Spears concert. It aint Irish but it aint all that bad.
content.property: Video/pinball games Karaoke No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Food served Outdoor seating

content.description: Just off the U. of C. campus, Jimmys (as its affectionately called by those in the know, after dearly departed original owner Jimmy Wilson) is the favored spot for the scholars to rub elbows with undergrads and working-class neighborhood regulars. Cheap burgers are washed down with even cheaper beer and the air is thick with decades worth of smoke.
content.property: Wheelchair-accessible bathroom No stairs to bathroom Video/pinball games No steps at entrance Food served

content.description: The Clark and Belmont hood is a unique mix of runaway trannies, wasted Cubs fans and local renters who love a bargain. This no-frills Lakeview tavern keeps the madness at bay in favor of friendly bartenders who buy rounds during afternoon Jeopardy!, a $2 beer-of-the-month and a great collection of two-dozen Irish whiskeys.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 7, 22, 77, 151, 156
content.property: No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Video/pinball games

content.description: If the thought of being crammed in this tiny boxcar of a bar makes you nervous, relax. The patio practically doubles the capacity of the place, and its the perfect spot to throw back one of its margaritas, made with fresh lemon and lime juice, top-shelf liquors and powdered sugar, and poured with a heavy hand.
content.property: No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Notable for cocktails Outdoor seating

content.description: The fabulous outdoor patio may be closed for the season, but this joint (a venture owned by the guys behind Lumen and chef Michael Taus) isnt letting the cold weather get it down. Instead, its putting out cool-weather dishes like sweet-potato-and-truffle risotto with a brown butter vinaigrette and a phyllo-encrusted escargot with Camembert fondue. Miss the elbow rubbing of the outdoor space? No worriestheres plenty of elbow rubbing to be had at the communal tables indoors.
content.property: Good for dining at bar Outdoor seating Private party room(s)

content.description: The bittersweet reality of great little dives is that they often lose charm when overrun by masses of clingers-on. Somehow, this Ukrainian Village spot has managed to remain an underground favorite. The local artists and musicians who frequent it hold on to terra firma with cheap drink in hand, awaiting a turn in the photo booth while nodding to everything from Aesop Rock to Black Sabbath.
content.public-transport: El: Blue to Division. Bus: 50 Damen, 70 Division
content.property: Video/pinball games No stairs to bathroom Live bands

content.description: Weve missed many a movie because we stopped by this funky wine bar next to Webster Place theater. When tasting pours are this affordable (and interesting), we pretend its for educational purposes and stay all night, soaking up the dark, Bohemian vibe and munching on tasty cheese plates.
content.property: No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Live bands Wine bar Outdoor seating Fireplace Food served Surprisingly good wine list

content.description: The bartender has a pompadour and a pistol tattooed on his arm, Old Styles are $2, Sloppy Joes are on the menu and DJs are indie-rock happy. But this spot is far from being too cool for school; theres a nice mix of locals from the neighborhood and industry folk from Divisions Restaurant Row who head for the downstairs pool room after work.

content.description: Even when it gets packed with the typical Division Street crowd, this Irish pub has an old soul. Antique beer paraphernalia and model ships hang from the ceiling, framed paintings of Chicagos past dot the walls and beers are served in frosted glass mugs.

content.description: The black-on-black decor here is only interrupted by streaks of blue neon, a look so 80s that youll expect RoboCop to walk in at any moment. Early in the night, local boozehounds have the place to themselves, but around 2am, the spillover from early-to-bed clubs squeezes in to sweat to hip-hop and house beats. The DJ calendar is anything-goes, but expect periodic house and techno marathons. The cover is usually low.

content.description: This rock & rollthemed, late-night Lincoln Park spot is known simply as the Vu to the DePaul students and other liquored-up twentysomethings who can be found queued up outside after 2am. Inside, youll find lighting ranging from eclectic to gaudy, comfy armchairs and couches, checkerboard floors, and all manner of rock swag (from guitars to a gigantic framed Sgt. Peppersera Beatles poster hanging on the walls.

content.property: No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Dress sharp Late Night

content.description: By day its home to dedicated regulars, by night its packed with rock & rollers drinking $5 half pitchers and nodding to free live bands. Pool, darts and Golden Tee are all free, and so is the chance to mark your territory by painting a ceiling tile. If youre in search of (semitarnished) gold, this is your treasure.

content.description: Brits have taken over the former Lyons Den in North Center, cleaned it up and added plenty of dark-wood high tables; a menu of U.K. pub grub; a digital jukebox with thousands of tunes; a couple of dozen bitter-style drafts; and a small stage in back for Monday-night improv comedy.

content.description: Because this lounge hasnt fallen prey to the sporty, fratty trappings of most DePaul-area bars, it has become the place for the mellow, martini-sipping Lincoln Park set to find a mate. Deep red walls and dim crimson lighting surround moveable black leather blocks and a small stage that plays host to acoustic guitarists on Mondays, a jazz trio on Tuesdays, rock bands on Wednesdays and DJs the rest of the week.

content.description: Dont let the name fool you. Its practically all guys in here and calling them big could get you slapped. Andersonvilles queer den mother Michelle Fire decks out her bar with choice selections from her impressive art collection, a good back-up plan in case theres a lack of other eye candy.
content.public-transport: El: Red to Argyle. Bus: 151 Sheridan
content.property: Pool table Video/pinball games No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Gay Outdoor seating Food served

content.description: The sign still says NORTH PARK TAP, but trust us, this place has a new name. Almost everything else remains unchanged from its former life: the casual vibe, the friendly bartenders, the big outdoor patio. But if you liked those wings, you may want to get some before you arrive: The menu has been revamped to feature more upscale fare.

A wine bar this charming has no business being hidden on a quiet residential street. The location might be why youll often have the place to yourself. The wine list has some tasty values (both New and Old World) and the small-plates menu has bites like artisan cheeses to offset a nasty wine hangover.
content.property: No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Wine bar Outdoor seating Lesbian Food served Surprisingly good wine list

content.description: In colder months, the attention here turns to the more sophisticated picks on the beer list, as well as to the slabs of ribs (which go a long way toward warming the belly). But now you have the option of turning your attention to the recently launched Tuesday trivia nights (they begin at 7pm). Somethings on special every night, whether its half-price wine and whiskey on Wednesdays or all-you-can-eat BBQ on Thursdaysfor those who simply want to get drunk on pig.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 8, 22, 77
content.property: No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Outdoor seating Food served Fireplace Good for groups Private party room(s) No steps at entrance Sports bar

content.description: Despite its name, this Viagra Triangle spot is no more Irish than a string of green lights and its corned beef and cabbage. It is, however, a low-key destination for hearty (but pricey) late-night grub; the menu boasts a plethora of chicken, seafood and steak dishes. The bar itself occupies most of the interior real estate, but allows for a stool-side view of the neighborhood regulars and the open-style kitchen.

This spots a typical, charming, pool-table dive distinguished by its namesake: the tiny woman who pours the drinks. Certain nights can be a real sausage fest, including some baldies from the CPD, and every one of them gives her a huge bear hug. Tip her right and you might start getting hugs, too.

With checkerboard floors, an oak forests worth of dark wood and more than two dozen sportscentric TVs, this is a quintessential neighborhood bar. While University of Kansas alums are busy gulping Miller Lite and downing burgers with their former Jayhawk frat brothers, the ladies who love them do a fine job standing bysome looking pretty and bored, and some just pretty bored.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Armitage. Bus: 8, 73
content.property: Private party room(s) Pool table Good for groups Wheelchair-accessible bathroom No stairs to bathroom No steps at entrance Sports bar Food served

content.description: This Logan Square watering hole glows with charmor is it the string of Christmas lights behind the bar? Either way, retired rock stars put away beers next to their disciples under the soft lights, snapshots of regulars and the warm smile of the maternal owner-bartender, Maria.
content.public-transport: El: Blue to Logan Square. Bus: 74, 82
content.property: No stairs to bathroom Conversation friendly

content.description: This converted theater kept its artsy charm with thrift-store finds galore. An old piano, couches and a coffee table sit on the small stage (which gets occasional use for one-night shows). Art-school dropouts flank the Ms. Pac-Man/Galaga game and great jukebox and friendly bartenders serve up cheap beers with a smile.

When you start and end every day at the same bar, you have a problem. Unless that bar is Logan Squares Green Eye. Intelligentsia coffee and Red Hen pastries in the morning, Goose Island draft at night and a prime spot right next to the Blue Line makes this place easier to drop into your routine than sleep.
content.property: No stairs to bathroom Outdoor seating

content.description: The DJs here alternate between spinning house and indie rock, but either way, it doesnt change the vibe. When you combine two fireplaces, plenty of room to spread out, a handful of weary Logan Square locals and a Ms. Pac Man game, everythings nice and chill.
content.property: Video/pinball games No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Fireplace Food served Outdoor seating

content.description: This place is more Cheers than English pub, and the bartender seems to know the name of every Bucktown local who munches pub grub to the tunes of the Flaming Lips. Spend a few nights here with a pint of 312 and youll become as recognizable as the portraits of Elvis behind the bar.
content.property: Darts Video/pinball games No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Food served Outdoor seating

content.description: Nothing brings together the hip kids and blue-collar Chicagoans better than cheap alcoholand this no-frills Logan Square dive across from Fireside Bowl is living proof. Watch as the earnest mustaches of Blackhawks and Sox fans mingle amiably with ironically bearded Black Keys and White Stripes fans. And if that gets dull, just head to the back for a 75-cent game of pool.
content.property: Darts Pool table No stairs to bathroom Video/pinball games
Darts Live bands Video/pinball games No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Food served

content.description: One look at the "Liquid Lounge" rooftop patio here and it seems like the people at Goodbar took the term watering hole literally. The turquoise paint treatment is meant to give the effect of shimmering blue water to the hoards of barely dressed boys and girls who crowd the place to whet their whistles.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 8, 11, 74

content.description: Sarge did two tours in Vietnam, and this Rogers Park bar, which hes owned for more than 17 years, is a shrine to his Marine Corps roots. Hes plastered military pictures, flak jackets, packs and other paraphernalia on the walls, while camouflage netting hangs from the ceiling and above the pool table. After buying you a shot of jungle juice, Sarge will pull up a stool and fill your ear with stories about chasing Charlies and keeping out the Rogers Park riffraff. Semper fi!

Its amazing what a difference an hour or two makes at this corner tap. Before 11pm, conversational buzz and the sounds of the Cure dominate, but the place gets packed as soon as midnight strikespicture some sort of reverse-Cinderella storyand the music begins a transition into upbeat territory. Those first few minutes are the most entertaining for people-watching, as cramped, confused bargoers struggle to get down to Just Like Heaven.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 11
content.property: Live bands Video/pinball games No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom

content.description: If size matters, theres no better bar in Boystown than this well-hung hot spot. Six big roomswe like the smoke-free Glass Barare all packed with cute, frisky boys distracting themselves with the same three things: the videos on the wall, the drink in their hand and the ass in your jeans.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 8, 22, 77
content.property: No steps at entrance Wheelchair-accessible bathroom No stairs to bathroom Gay Outdoor seating Good for groups

content.description: The interiordominated by earth tones, comfy brown leather armchairs and a forests worth of wood tables and stoolsisnt particularly Celtic, but it is cozy. The clientele of post-college, pre-kids bros and broads will sing along just as passionately to Since Youve Been Gone as they will to Springsteens Glory Days.
content.property: Good for groups No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Private party room(s) Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Outdoor seating Food served

content.description: As its name implies (and its location next to the El tracks underscores), the feel here is that of a bar inside a Depression-era train station. Stained-glass ceiling lights emit an amber glow; fringe dangles from the faux smoke-stained lampshades; and small black-and-white ceramic tiles line the floor. But the centerpiecedespite the prevalence of flat-screen TVs and crazy-drunk locals on weekendsis the piano that sits on a round stage behind the long front bar.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 8, 11, 74

content.description: Scenesters havent ruined this honky-tonk Logan Square joint, named for its dual entryways, yet, so when you see those banjos and fiddles above the bar and witness the ladies square-dancing with each other to the tunes of Johnny Cash and Hank Williams, you can bet this shit aint ironic.
content.property: Pool table Video/pinball games No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom

content.description: Singles looking for a classy spot love getting spiffed up in their slinkiest summer gear for a night here, where theres always going to be plenty of green: on the outdoor patio and in their wallets. Pink martinis are de rigueur for the ladies, while the guys go for cocktails and the occasional Jager shot to work up the nerve to chat up the hotties.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Armitage. Bus: 8 Halsted, 73 Armitage

content.description: Max is actually a woman (Maxine), and her Uptown establishment is a seminar in Dive Bar 101: The pours are dangerously strong, the drinks are ridiculously cheap, the bartenders are gloriously mulleted, and the regulars are, uh, very regular. In other words, dont ruffle any blue collars, dont sit in anyones seat and keep those eyes on the bottom of that Old Style.
content.property: Conversation friendly Darts Good for over-40 crowd No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Sports bar Video/pinball games

content.description: With its gigantic metal chandeliers, leaded glass cabinetry and old-time lever-operated cash register, this bar has a turn-of-the-century feel (the one before last) that may just make you feel a little transported. Prices arent quite pre-Prohibition, but you will find generously poured mixed drinks for five bucks, $3 bottled domestic beer (no drafts available) and friendly people (sometimes overly friendly, if youre a gals gal).
content.property: Pool table Darts Private party room(s) Conversation friendly Good for groups Good for over-40 crowd Live bands

content.description: The twentysomethings in the back room playing board games are missing out. The real action is at the bar, where silver-haired ladies flirt with ex-frat boys and the occasional indie-rock couple. Its tough to find a place in Wrigleyville where worlds collide and all are welcome for a mildly drunken kumbaya vibe, but thats exactly what this is.
content.public-transport: El: Red, Purple (rush hrs) to Addison. Bus: 152
content.property: No stairs to bathroom Food served

content.description: Considering its proximity to Wrigley Field, its the next-best thing to being in the stands. Cubs fans pack the sticky floor before and during the game, but its postgame that people are packed in this place like sardines in a tin can.
content.property: Video/pinball games Live bands Sports bar Wheelchair-accessible bathroom No stairs to bathroom Food served Private party room(s) Good for groups

content.description: Looking to play pool, remain anonymous and buy a beer from a bartender who isnt snobby but isnt looking to become your best friend? Head here, where groups of post-college friends relax and split time between glancing up at the game and choosing between Prince and David Allen Coe on the juke.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 8, 22, 36, 76
content.property: Pool table No stairs to bathroom Video/pinball games Darts No steps at entrance Food served Good for groups

content.description: Black walls, wiry chandeliers and more guyliner than a My Chemical Romance concert make this place the angstiest addition to Matt Eislers trifecta of bars. The scene can get a little overwhelming in front, but if you can snag a seat in the private(ish) room in back, youll be goldenor at least as golden as a goth kid can get.

Newspaper articles declaring the end of Prohibition hang on the walls and the clock is graced with Mayor Daleys mugthe first Mayor Daley. So its no surprise that this place is as friendly, neighborly and comfortable (did we mention the La-Z-Boys?) as bars used to be back in the day, you know, before velvet ropes and vodka Red Bulls.
content.property: Pool table No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom

content.description: The Hard Rock Hotel has remodeled its old bar, Base, and rechristened it ROCKS. So what has changed? Not much, so expect to lounge on low-slung leather chairs and couches among a young after-work crowd, sipping a Bellini to the tunes of the Killers and such. Inasmuch, also expect a tourist mom in a hot-pink T-shirt barrels through pushing a ginormous stroller. But as the night wears on, the crowd gets hipper, the beats get louder and the touriststhey get some sleep.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to State/Lake; Red to Lake
content.property: Sports bar Wheelchair-accessible bathroom No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Food served After-work crowd Good for groups Outdoor seating

content.description: Clarkes diner used to be the place youd go after the party was over, the place to sober up with some pancakes, a burger or a cup of coffee after striking out. But with this Miami Viceesque lounge and bar areadominated by silver high-backed leather booths and neon lightsClarkes is finally giving you a second at bat with your side of fries.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 8, 22, 77
content.property: Date place Dress sharp No stairs to bathroom No steps at entrance Food served

content.description: A few blocks from Lyric Opera and just off the river, this beautifully setup bar is a primo spot if you need a little you time after dark. Stop by around 9pm, when most of the after-work crowd has headed home. When scarcely populated, the polished wood and brass decor, high ceilings and old-time photographs evoke a Chicago-of-yesteryear feel thats hard to find.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Green, Orange, Purple (rush hrs), Pink, Blue to Clark/Lake

entry.name: Time Out Sports Bar and Grill

version.name: Time Out Sports Bar and Grill

content.description: No hipsters, no yuppies, no class-drawing lines herejust regular neighborhood folks in this one-room watering hole taking turns on the pool table or playing games like Scrabble and Connect Four. The scatterbrained decor (old movie posters, sports crap, beer memorabilia) is as random as the jukebox, which offers pre-90s tunes from the Pretenders to Michael Jackson.
content.property: Pool table No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Video/pinball games

content.description: Ribsthe hickory-smoked variety, to be specificare the specialty of this Hyde Park house. Choose from The Boss (a whole slab) or smaller portions such as The Ranch Hand and Jr. Ranch Handeach which come with fries, cole slaw and bread. For a little variety, opt for one of the Chuck Wagon Combosthe chix n ribs combo gives you two pieces of fried or barbecued chicken and a half-order of ribs for less than $11.

Its easy to dismiss this place as a scenester sipping spot, but the food is surprisingly worth a visit, even if slick digs arent your bag. The South American/Southeast Asian menu comes from co-owner Maripa Abella (also owner of Thai Lagoon), whose Sunday brunch has been such a hit, its been expanded to Saturdays. So glide past the line of lemmings at Bongo Room, grab a seat here, and start off with the Vietnamese coffee with powdered sugartopped, beignetlike doughnuts and the coconut-milk rice pudding with fresh fruit. Pan-Latin classics like black bean arepas and huevos rancheros are delicious, especially with a spicy Bloody Mary to wash it down.
content.property: Food served Private party room(s) Live bands
Good for dining at bar Vegetarian-friendly Late-night dining

content.description: Beware the poison sauce. It sits there in a bowl on the table, beckoning innocently as if it were just another salsa verde. But its a fire that is tough to put out, and theres no guarantee youll be able to taste anything afterward. And that would be a shame, because with a menu offering tangy ceviche on crispy tostadas; hand-shaped shrimp empanadas; fish tacos slathered with seasoned crema; and juicy shrimp tossed in copious amounts of garlic, theres a lot youre going to want to taste.

This North Center joint may look like a upscale lounge at first glance, but it's really just a friendly neighborhood bar. Locals get cozy in the sleek, red dcor while electro-pop is piped from the sound system and Vh1 plays on the televisions. Food is served, but hungry patrons should arrive early to eat because the kitchen's closing hours can be unpredictable.
content.property: No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Outdoor seating Food served

content.description: If Sinatra and steakhouses are your scene, try this Loop chophouse-wine bar. Poised professionals line the mahogany bar, sipping their way through a list of 40 (mostly domestic) wines by the glass while Rat Pack standards play in the background.
content.public-transport: El: Blue, Red to Monroe; Brown, Green, Orange, Purple (rush hrs) to Madison
content.property: No stairs to bathroom No steps at entrance Wheelchair-accessible bathroom

entry.name: Old Irving Park Sports Bar & Grill

version.name: Old Irving Park Sports Bar & Grill

content.public-transport: El: Blue to Irving Park. Bus: 53, 56, 80
content.property: Sports bar Video/pinball games Pool table Food served

content.description: For more than 30 years, this cavernous Loop tavern has cornered the market on medieval dives. Beyond the heavy doors that seem to hide a monastery, youll find an after-work crowd of mostly suits and occasional skirts downing beer and adding to the piles of peanut shells littering the floor.
content.public-transport: El: Blue, Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Clark
content.property: No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom After-work crowd Food served Good for groups

content.description: This swanky Mexican spot is known for perfect margaritas and chef Priscila Satkoffs traditional salsas, queso fundido and earthy mole served with handmade tortillas. A weekly specials menu highlights seasonal ingredients, but you can pretty much always count on the trio of small tamales, the lamb chops in garlic-pasilla chile sauce and one of the best tequila selections in town.

content.property: Sports bar Wheelchair-accessible bathroom No stairs to bathroom No steps at entrance Outdoor seating Food served

content.description:
This 144-room boutique hotel on Jewelers Row is an architectural gem. The late 19th-century Arts and Crafts style is evident outside and in, with wrought-iron pieces adding accents to the comfortable (if slightly dated) decorations in each room. Guests can get their sweet fix during the complimentary dessert hour.
*High-speed internet (free wireless in lobby & via cable in rooms).

In summer, this beer garden is one of the best in Chicago (as long as you can deal with ass-to-elbow crowds). But its just a great in the winter, when you can snag a table at this beer-and-burger haven and get cozy with your date. Just remember to bring a flashlight to read the menu; the place is dark enough that you could carry on an affair while your spouse is sitting across the room.
content.public-transport: El: Red to Thorndale. Bus: 36 Broadway, 84 Peterson
content.property: No stairs to bathroom Outdoor seating Fireplace Food served

content.description: This low-key lounge boasts the best sangria in town, and while we wouldnt go that far, we do think their $15 pitchers of red and white are a good antidote for a bad day at work ($2 burgers and fries on Mondays and $2.50 Coronas on Tuesdays dont hurt, either). This spot is especially good for those who have experienced sports bar fatigue: Here, theres not a single game in sight.
content.property: Conversation friendly Good for groups Food served Live bands No steps at entrance

content.description: Early in the evening at this bilevel hangout, the video art on the wall is the rooms main source of light, giving off a cool, sultry cocktail-lounge vibe. But its the calm before the storm: When celebrity DJs stop by, the place gets packed with clubby scenesters and frantic bass linesso if youre here for the quiet, enjoy it while you can.
content.openingtimes: MonFri 9pm2am; Sat noon6pm and 9pm3am; Sun noon6 pm and 9pm2am
content.property: Food served Outdoor seating Live bands Private party room(s)

content.description: One can only assume the name refers to petite bartender Eva, the sole blond at this working-class neighborhood joint. The primarily male clientele ranges from undershirt-clad young Latinos playing pool to an elderly gentleman with his walker parked next to the bar. Order an Okocim and Eva will top it off Polish-style with a shot of sour-cherry syrup and a straw, and serve up some fresh popcorn alongside.
content.property: Pool table Conversation friendly Good for over-40 crowd No stairs to bathroom No steps at entrance Video/pinball games

content.description: Most weekends youll find a crowd of people spilling onto this breakfast spots sidewalk, watching servers carry plates toppling from the weight of sweet-milk biscuits and bone-in ham. Those who stick it out will be rewarded with staples like housemade muffins; vegetable hash with copious amounts of sauted onions and peppers; soft scrambled eggs; thick, crunchy bacon; and pancakes with sweet pockets of banana. Dont miss the Southern-inspired dishes like the fried catfish, grits and compact, crispy salmon cakes, all of which are served up on the weekends only.

This space was created for the slightly older, slightly tamer crowd. To that end, this West Loop lounge is cool, sophisticated and filled with designer midcentury furniture. Cocktails and upscale apps are the order of the early-bird, while night owls come to groove to hip-hop and neo-soul with the occasional house, techno and fashion show thrown in.
content.property: No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Dress sharp Food served Dress code Good for groups Conversation friendly

content.description: Visiting FLOR's first retail space is like walking into its popular website. Graphics on the wall near the front door explain the modular tile concept (20-inch recycled squares—starting at $7—allow you to design area rugs, runners, or wall-to-wall carpeting), and the rest of the store brims with more than 400 carpet samples and swatches, along with plenty of inspiration to get you started.

entry.name: International House at the University of Chicago

version.name: International House at the University of Chicago

content.public-transport: Bus: 2, 6, 15, 28, 59. Metra: Elec Main to 59th St

content.description: Saturday nights at this Fulton warehouse district hot spot are packed, so expect to wait to get in and again at the bar. Opt for a weekday when theres space to take in the charming bookshelves, exposed brick walls and diverse crowd. Now you can see what all the fuss is about.
content.property: No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Notable for cocktails Conversation friendly Fireplace Food served

content.description: The address is different (the original location was a few blocks east), but the booking policy remains the same at this pioneering venue and informal showcase for members of Chicagos trailblazing Association for the Advancement of Creative Musicians. Run by veteran saxophonist Fred Anderson (an AACM forerunner himself), the club concentrates on free jazz, with high-calibre guests such as Henry Grimes and former Chicagoan Matana Roberts joining the locals.
content.openingtimes: Wed, Thu 8pm2am; Fri 9pm2am; Sat 9pm2am (or later); Sun 7pm2am

content.description: A wood-paneled ceiling, pool table, Texas longhorn skulls, scattered vintage beer memorabilia and a jukebox stocked with jazz, standards and bluegrass make for a nice spot to cool your heels in Roscoe Village. Well-made cocktails and regional beers like Goose Islands awesome 312 are the norm. Staff and patrons dabble in theater, so look for local play postings.
content.property: Pool table No stairs to bathroom Sports bar Food served Outdoor seating Private party room(s)

content.description: Hold on to your Bud Light as tight as you can, because it doesnt matter what day of the week it is in this enormous, quintessential Lincoln Park sports bar, there will always be lots of drunken screaming, drunken tumbles, drunken hugs and drunken tongues in your drunken mouth.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton
content.property: Video/pinball games Live bands No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Food served

content.description: After establishing itself as a popular sushi lunch spot in the South Loop, this budget-minded restaurant expanded with a swankier locale. Sashimi is still the way to gobig, thick cuts of fresh, cool standards are dependable and tasty, and richer indulgences like fatty tuna and sea urchin are equally good and almost always available. Interestingly, the cooked menu is offered as small plates, making it easy to try a handful of unique dishes like roasted chickenstuffed lotus root in crispy tempura batter and baked sesame-crusted scallops with wasabi mayo.
content.public-transport: El: Green, Orange, Red to Roosevelt. Bus: 1, 3, 4
content.property: Good for dining at bar Outdoor seating

content.description: Want one of the best fine-dining experiences in town? Splurge here. Executive chef Tony Mantuano and chef de cucina Sarah Grueneberg) step into spring with bright dishes like yellowfin tuna with fresh chickpeas, radishes and shallots; pasta pockets filled with crescenza cheese and Umbrian black truffles, tossed with ramps; risotto with fresh artichokes; and dry-aged strip steak with Piemontese white truffle essence, lemon and celery. As usual, pastas and gelati are made fresh every day. Toss in a two-dozen-choice cheese cave and perfect service, and youve got a night thats worth the hefty tab.
content.property: Notable wine list Views Private party room(s)
Pool table Video/pinball games Sports bar Wheelchair-accessible bathroom No stairs to bathroom No steps at entrance

content.description: Sure, the Tiffany-style light fixtures and Victorian-era decor are classy, and the drinks are just fine. But the real reason to keep coming back heredespite the weekend crowds of former frat bros and their penchant for Def Leppardis the sugar-comainducing cookie skillet.
content.public-transport: El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 11, 50, 80
content.property: No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Outdoor seating Food served

content.description: This Andersonville spa serves the city’s dandies and dudes with the bodywork, skin care and grooming services that they and their admirers increasingly demand. The interior is handsome— the locker and shower room is done with subway tiles and neutral tones and all around—soothing, well-appointed and notably clean. We don’t need ESPN Classic 24/7—but there is a 50-inch screen in the grooming club room just in case. They offer everything the most metrosexual man could ever want—pedis, facials and various types of massage (our favorite is the Ashiatsu Deep Tissue massage—the therapist literally steps on top of you for this one).It also offers several comprehensive total body packages ($200 and up) and Date Night options ($160-$230 per couple). It’s been a winner with both gays and straights and we wouldn’t be surprised to see another location pop up.

content.public-transport: El: Purple to Davis. Bus: 93, Pace 208, Pace 250

content.description: Something doesnt add up: If every other Lincoln Avenue pub is packed sweaty ass to sweaty crotch, why is it that Sterchs pulls in only a handful of drinkers? It must suck, right?
