Well, given this venerable bar (in its forties) is inviting to newbies, loyal to its regulars (old photos on the wall, house bowling leagues, etc.) and plenty spacious for the two to mingle, thats probably not the case. Just be thankful this friendly drinking relic is still around.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 8, 11, 74
content.property: Conversation friendly After-work crowd No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom

content.description: Chef Erwin Drechsler has a knack for the kind of good, solid food people want to eat, and hes been delivering that food to hungry Chicagoans for almost two decades. Drechslers still doing his well-loved standbys, like his burger and liver and onions, but he brightens the menu with seasonal finds. Simple dishes like pan-roasted Great Lakes whitefish with local asparagus, spring lamb chops with fava beans and strawberry-rhubarb crisp are the kind of things you aspire to make at homebut dont.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 8, 76

content.description: Posters of Muddy Waters and other music legends speak to this bars history as a former blues club, but these days youre more likely to hear a DePaul student strumming a Jason Mrazish version of Radioheads Fake Plastic Trees than anything with Delta roots. Disappointed? Then stay close to the long, unpolished bar and try to drown out the collegiate crooners with nightly beer specials like $3 Berghoff bottles.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 8, 11, 74
content.property: Live bands No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Extensive beer selection

content.description: If you’ve ever vacationed in Ibiza, Spain, and noticed the green heart stickers all over the island, you’ll encounter a case of déjà vu. The stickers are sold in the über–eco-friendly GreenHeart Shop. The group behind this River North store is the Center for Cultural Interchange, a nonprofit that offers environmental volunteer and education programs throughout the world. In addition to stocking the typical gifts and home accessories that are safe for the environment (you know, made from bamboo or other sustainable materials), the shop also sells handmade and fairly traded items by artists from all over the globe. There’s women’s jewelry ($10–$50) from India, Indonesia and Nepal; ceramic mugs, bowls and umbrella stands from Vietnam ($9–$70); and exclusive green heart-shaped bath soaps produced locally ($3). Now, the next time you’re in Ibiza, you can just go for the partying and leave your shopping at home.

Theres nothing fancy going on here, just a welcoming neighborhood bar with regulars who wouldnt have it any other way. The camaraderie is a bit Cheers-ish, but the extended fam seems amiable to welcoming newbies to the group. Keep the burgers and beer comingweve just found our new hangout.
content.property: Darts Video/pinball games No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Food served

content.description: Are times tough for River North bars or something? This place gives away a shot for a penny with every drink you buy, possibly to make you forget that when you walked in here they were blasting Billy Joel, but also to give you the confidence to talk to that honey you have your eye on.
content.property: Pool table No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Darts Video/pinball games Wheelchair-accessible bathroom

content.description: Theres an electronic countdown to St. Patricks Day and a bar made out of Irish pennies. Do we really need to spell out for you what this place is all about? On Sunday nights its as sleepy as an Irish hamlet, but on Fridays and Saturdays its as raucous as Dublin.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 8, 76
content.openingtimes: MonThu 4pm2am; Fri, Sun noon2am; Sat noon3am
content.property: Food served Darts Video/pinball games Live bands

content.description: Okay, so this place isnt as trendy as the name (short for Southport) might suggest, but we wouldnt have it any other way. The drinks are strong and the crowd is fun. And with drink and food specials ($2 burgers, $3 drafts on Mondays, for example) every day of the week, its possible to leave the bar feeling richer than when you went in.
content.property: No stairs to bathroom No steps at entrance Outdoor seating Food served

content.description: Pop into any bar boasting seven days of karaoke and youre likely to hear more than your fair share of Bon Jovi. Thankfully, this Lakeview parrot-head hangout offers ample patio space (heated in the winter) to escape juiced-up choruses of Sweet Caroline. This place is good for satiating drunk American Idol desires, but bad for house cocktails. Stick to your beer of choice over Todds odd concoctions.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 8, 22, 77
content.property: No stairs to bathroom Karaoke Outdoor seating Food served

content.description: It may be named after a crucial infield position, but the night we were there, Wife Swap was on instead of the Cubs gameon all seven TVs! And thison Belmont? That may be due to the feisty female bartender (No martinis, no margaritas, no nothing but what I know how to make!). Take your chance on gratis pretzels that look like they remember the Reagan era and tack up any complaints to the community-friendly bulletin board.
content.property: Conversation friendly Darts Good for groups Good for over-40 crowd Pool table Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Food served

content.description: Its a tiny space and its packed with Merch Mart employees looking to drink their workday away, so it might take the luck of one of the four-leaf clovers that decorate the place to get a seat. Strangers are regarded with suspicion here, so keep away from the regulars until you become one yourself.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Merchandise Mart. Bus: 65, 125

content.description: If you dont know who Marilyn and Joan are, dont bother. This slick nightspot only gets campier with age, so prepare to be entertained by black-and-white Hollywood glamour movies and performances by female impersonators of Hollywood icons. The 100-martini-strong drink list is a draw, and the recent arrival of Sixteen alum chef Mark Kasper has put the focus on dishes like bacon mac-and-cheese and mango-infused pork loin. But you didnt actually come here for the food, did you?
content.property: Gay Food served Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Outdoor seating

content.description: Are we a bunch of suckers or what? The hours here are completely undependable, the crowds a crapshoot (punks on the weekdays, prepsters on weekends) and theres no sink in the mens room. But something about this place charms our socks off. But only during the week. Were not about to pay a coverwed rather spend our money in the photo booth.
content.property: Pool table Video/pinball games Live bands Karaoke
Live bands Pool table Darts Video/pinball games

content.description: Ties may be loosened and the blazers may come off, but its still pretty much business class during the week at this Ravenswood boys room. Hanging plants and holiday-themed decorations add to the office-party vibe, but make no mistake: These guys are champion softball players, so they know how to play the game.
content.property: Darts Video/pinball games No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom

content.description: Like a gay Cheers, everybody knows everybodys name here. A long winding bar, amber lighting, dark wood and green leather booths make for a tavern-y spot to sip one of the gajillion beers or two dozen wines by the glass. TVs show sports, but older locals are focused on their grilled chicken Caesars, and the lesbians are too busy flirting to notice.
content.property: Video/pinball games No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Outdoor seating Fireplace Food served Gay Lesbian

content.description: Locals descend upon The Dunnes from their condos in Roscoe Villages Pencil Factory, soaking up the sports theme dominated by support for Boston College and Dayton. Golden Tee Live is a big source of entertainment, and the camaraderie among the regulars would make Finley Peter Dunne (columnist for the Chicago Evening Post in the late 1800s) proud.
content.property: Food served Video/pinball games Sports bar Live bands Karaoke

content.description: This place is primarily a restaurant, but we like just stopping in for a Peroni at the bar. Youll probably rub elbows with old Italian locals who remember Chinatown before it was Chinatown. The joints been around since 33, and the regulars whose mugs hang from the ceiling are long gone, but theyre immortalized in a dusty photo hanging behind the bar. Hungry? Hearty pastas or sausage and peppers will work.

On the weekends, this polished Roscoe Village hangout is filled with local singles awkwardly trying to get some, and its sort of like watching a too-good-to-be-true episode of Blind Date. Go during the week when theres nary a horndog in sight. Sampling the extensive list of Irish beers and whiskeys is best done in the backa cool, open space with couches, a fireplace and old-school board games.
content.openingtimes: MonThu 5:30pm2am; Fri 5pm2am; Sat noon3am; Sun noon2am
content.property: Sports bar No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Fireplace Food served

content.description: Theres nothing particularly inventive about this corner tap, both levels of which are usually inhabited by your run-of-the-mill, shaggy-haired, middle-aged whiskey sippersnothing, that is, unless youre here on a Friday night. Thats when the place fills up with a mix of yuppies, hipsters and everybody in between for a few friendly rounds of turtle racing. (Sounds like a euphemism, we know, but we assure you its not.)
content.property: Pool table Darts Live bands Outdoor seating
Pool table Wheelchair-accessible bathroom No stairs to bathroom No steps at entrance Food served

content.description: Theres a big sign on the wall here with a rendering of Wrigley Field that reads: Believe or leave. That pretty much sums up the attitude of the people who belly up here, but it only extends to baseball. On all other matters, the people at this spotless neighborhood dive are as friendly as can be. (That is, as long as the Cubs are winning.)

If youve never made the pilgrimage to this River Grove tiki bar, go now. The winding maze of rooms are covered in 50s tiki tchotchkes and for some reason, theyre always packed with young Russian hotties. Take your ultrastrong, umbrella-topped Scorpions to the tropical garden patio, lush with flowers, plants, fountains and glowing palm trees.
content.property: No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Outdoor seating Suburban

content.description: Watching beer ferment in tanks is about as exciting as C-SPAN, so were pretty sure its brewmaster Greg Halls concoctions like Matilda and Sofie beers that bring in the crowds. Recently, Goose flipped its reputation from a great bar that serves food to a dining destination with excellent beer, but with the rollout of Halls latestthe sustainably brewed Green Line Pale Aleits a toss-up which parts more exciting.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Armitage; Red to North/Clybourn. Bus: 8, 72, 73
content.property: Pool table Video/pinball games No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Food served

content.description: The decor of this bars former tenant, the kitschy Leopard Lounge, has been stripped down to inoffensive exposed-brick walls and high-top tables. But that just means theres less distraction when youre listening to the Top 40 remixes and hypnotized by the bright-blue martinisor, more likely, the people holding them.

The Chatham residents who mill about inside this tiny, smoke-scented, Jamaican carryout spot are all waiting on the same thing: the best jerk chicken around. Members of the Grant family work in tandem, taking orders for rich, allspice-laced oxtails and heaving jerk-rubbed chickens out of foggy smokers before packaging them in Styrofoam containers along with sides of cinnamon-candied yams and buttery braised greens. Ask for an extra side of the lappable jerk sauce to dip your chicken in, order wings for the juicy dark-meat factor, and be prepared to either make do with one of only two rickety tables or eat in your carthe killer scents make waiting until you get home unbearable.

We know its a chain, but we like it. All three floors of this dark, wood-filled, slightly over-stylized Irish pub are packed with young professionals getting sloshed and loosening their ties and tongues. After trying the black velveteen, a smooth and sweet blend of Guinness and cider, were inclined to join them.
content.property: Live bands No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Food served After-work crowd Good for groups Private party room(s)

content.description: Theres a serious contingent of regulars calling this bar home, including newly legal DePaul students who pack the place late at night. But it serves our purposes perfectly for an early spot to grab a beer and catch the game. We get 20 screens all to ourselves? Score.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 9 Ashland, 74 Fullerton
content.property: Pool table Video/pinball games No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Food served Darts Live bands Private party room(s) Sports bar Good for groups

content.description: This large Irish pubs marquee announces its daily specials to the neighborhood; time your visit based on the signage and you may find yourself with a bill for $1 burgers or 25-cent wings. Even at full price, Celtic Crown is still worth a visit for better-than-average bar food. As youd expect at an Irish pub, the corned-beef sandwich is satisfying, as is the barbecue-rib plate (note to true cue fans: Theyre baked, not smoked), and you can indulge your inner grammar-school student with Tater Tots. With TVs blaring and bar patrons quaffing another one, the atmosphere is loud, but the waitstaff never overlooks the diners for the drinkers.
content.property: Pool table Darts Karaoke Video/pinball games No steps at entrance Fireplace Food served Private party room(s) Outdoor seating

content.description: Wed like to keep the most unpretentious spot on this scene-obsessed stretch of Wells Street to ourselves. But were afraid that if we dont spread the word, this Irish sports barwhere you can actually drink your Guinness, have a bite and watch the game in peacemay not be around much longer.
content.property: Video/pinball games No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Sports bar Food served

content.description: The bartender, Kevin, is a bowling man himself, but the dart team is always looking for players, so he may encourage you to join. Other than that, the only pressure youll feel at this Roscoe Village sports bar is deciding which of the 14 TV screens to look at if youre not back in the tournament-quality dart room.
content.property: Darts Video/pinball games No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom

content.description: At first glance, it didnt seem any different from other dark-wood neighborhood taverns. But then we noticed the psychedelic posters lining the walls, the bottomless baskets of free popcorn and the old man in the corner laughing his ass off at nothing. Is this bar high?
content.property: Video/pinball games Karaoke No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Outdoor seating

content.description: So youre wondering how a sports bar with a crowd of screaming coeds and an impressive list of drinkable bombs (when Jger alone just wont cut it anymore) found its way into Bucktown. But youre sucking down the 32-oz schooners like theyre holy water and hogging the pool table, so the frat-mentality invasion cant be all that bad. Winter means you can trade Blue Bombs for a Hot Apple Cider, Hot Toddie or Rumplestillsken (Rumple Minze and hot chocolate), and the bar also now serves pizzas ($11.50$17).
content.property: Darts Video/pinball games No stairs to bathroom Sports bar Food served Outdoor seating Private party room(s)

content.description: Out of the way? Yeah. Still a great wine bar? For sure. Youd be hard-pressed to find another wine bar with a better list. And even harder-pressed to find one with as great a view of the skyline. Roll into spring with something from mixologist Nick Leuddes new batch of cocktails; Sleeping Single in a Double Bed combines honeydew-infused rum with fresh basil and wildflower honey.
content.public-transport: El: Green, Pink to Ashland. Bus: 9
content.property: Surprisingly good wine list Wine bar Views Dress sharp Date place Conversation friendly Private party room(s) Food served Wheelchair-accessible bathroom

content.description: Were not complaining about $1.25 drafts of MGD and Lite in this cozy little barits just that, for a place called Brewery, youd think the beer selection would be a little more broad. But never mind that. With Sinatra and Tony Bennett crooning away and a pack of serious pool players huddled around the pool table, theres plenty to distract you from the lackluster beer selection. You must be 25 to enter, and the ID checking is nothing short of fanatical. But if youre old enough, stop by on October 28th for a Chili Cook-off that should be rather spirited, as several regulars have the beans to claim that their homemade recipes score highest on the chili-o-meter.
content.property: After-work crowd Conversation friendly Good for over-40 crowd Pool table Video/pinball games Wheelchair-accessible bathroom

content.description: Brudder is Hawaiian for hang loose, and this isnt a bad place to do exactly that, especially if youre sports-inclined. The bar is a hop, skip and drive down Addison from Wrigley, so you can count on Cubs games being broadcast on all eight TVs. Theres a separate room for the pool table, which gets plenty of use with the dough saved on dollar drafts of PBR and Old Style.

The name makes it pretty clear: This is a simple joint where you can grab a cool pint of your favorite brew while cheering for your favorite team. The awesome flat screens and big screen are being put to good use with satellite TV tuned in to games around the globe. Add some of the coldest brews around served up by the cuties behind the bar, and they might have finally scored.
content.property: Video/pinball games No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Outdoor seating Sports bar Food served Fireplace

content.description: The theme at this cozy Wicker Park diner is old-school railroad dining car, which is fitting considering its underneath the Damen stop on the Blue Line. And although the menu has plenty of choices (pork chops, mussels, burgers), dont blow your money on dinner. Opt for a snack and keep the drinks coming.
content.property: No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Food served

content.description: The giant video screen hints cheesy club and the location might suggest yuppie crowd, but dont be fooled: Vida is a nuevo-Latino lounge serving tapas and signature martinis for all your sassy-drink needs. And if the spirit ever moves you to learn tango and salsa dancing, then Thursdays your night and this is your place.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 11, 76
content.property: Live bands Food served Private party room(s)

content.description: What do you get when you put a sign on your door stating that nobody under the age of 23 can enter? A lot of college kids pissed off that they cant hang out on the mod furniture under the faux stars, listening to the sing-along-friendly soundtrack of Prince and Lenny Kravitz.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Wellington. Bus: 8, 76, 77
content.property: No stairs to bathroom Food served Private party room(s) Fireplace

content.public-transport: El: Blue to Jefferson Park. Bus: 85, 85A, 92

content.description: This Douglas Park joint is as casual as they come, with a mighty heavy pour and a neighboring car wash that hoses down your wheels while you imbibe. The dark bar is peppered with a randy batch of city employees and bedraggled hospital second-shifters stumble in for a turn at the free jukebox.

As the name suggests, Beat Kitchen slings out above-average bar nosh (sandwiches, pizzas, salads, soup), and the back room hosts regional rock bands nightly for a cover that averages $8. Comedian-musician Pat McCurdy belts out such classic tunes as Thankless Bastard and Big Porno Hair Monday nights for a $6 cover.
content.property: Live bands No stairs to bathroom No steps at entrance Food served

content.description: The rumble of the train drowns out your conversation in the beer garden every five minutes, but thats a small price to pay for a laid-back day sipping beer in the sun. Servers are attentive, and the crowd outside is pretty chillthe only shit-talking going on is at the Golden Tee or at the pool table. That is until the rest of the neighborhoods bars close at 2 and the line outside waiting to get in gets unruly.
content.property: Pool table Video/pinball games Live bands No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Outdoor seating Late Night

content.description: True dive bars are a rarity in this high-rent, hotel and wine bardominated section of River North, and thats exactly what makes this Greek-owned beer-and-gyro joint a gem. Inside, 50-year-old union laborers with leathery skin, gold necklaces and curly chest hair sip domestics and shoot pool beside their younger blond wives, while the Croatian bartender regales her customers with stories about Christmas back home.
content.property: After-work crowd Conversation friendly Darts Pool table Good for over-40 crowd No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Food served

content.description: Small touches of Irish bric-a-braca leprechaun napkin holder and an erin go bragh flagare the only concessions to the Old Sod. Otherwise, this shot-and-beer tap room is heavy on local sports teams past and present, with its framed pics of faded Bears heroes. Beer selections are standard American brews, like Sam Adams and Bud longnecks, but still, its an accommodating 18-seat bar and a good dark room to duck into when its blazing hot outside.
content.property: Karaoke Sports bar Darts Wheelchair-accessible bathroom No stairs to bathroom No steps at entrance Conversation friendly Good for over-40 crowd

content.description: Traders fight frat boys for a seat at this expansive Loop watering hole, where the beach-bum decor makes them feel as if theyve died and gone to spring break. Cigars, Coronas and shots of tequila add to the Cancn vibe, but dont expect to see any girls in bikinis.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to LaSalle
content.property: Pool table Live bands Video/pinball games No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Food served

content.public-transport: El: Red to Grand; Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Chicago. Bus: 22, 65, 156

content.description: This family-run, two-room bar thats known as a dart-tournament host now fancies itself something of a rock venue for local punk and folk acts getting their feet wet. Theres an open mike that Old Town School students favor, and cheap cover charges indicate that things are still below pro-level. The mostly bottled beers are unfortunately no bargain, but this place might be the best spot in town to play your first gig.
content.public-transport: El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 11, 50, 80
content.property: Pool table Darts Live bands Wheelchair-accessible bathroom

content.description: Is it a gay bar? Is it straight? Do we care? Scattered about this sexually ambiguous barwhere a long list of bottles makes up for the lack of beer on tapare decorations from holidays long gone (a witch and her broomstick hangs overhead). The old relics are like the regularstheyll stick around as long as they can.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 36, 77, 152
content.property: Darts No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom

content.description: The menu boasts 30 martinis, but dont be surprised when the bartender thumbs through Mr. Bostons crib sheets to concoct them. The Mag Mile Manhattan features smoky and silky 18-year-old Elijah Craig bourbon, but beware the heavy-handed buzzkill of sweet vermouth. More than two-dozen professional pool tables fill the bilevel space, and the jukebox is packed with croonersSinatra, Dino and Darinlending an old-school vibe.
content.public-transport: El: Green, Pink to Clinton. Bus: 20 Madison
content.openingtimes: MonFri 11am2am; Sat 5pm3am; Sun 5pm2am (closed Sun during summer)
content.property: After-work crowd Conversation friendly Date place Good for groups Good for over-40 crowd Pool table Private party room(s) Sports bar Video/pinball games Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Darts Food served

content.description: This Rogers Park cantina offers a little Tijuana flavor right here in the Windy City. The jukebox cranks out Mexican music that couples shuffle along to, but if dancing isnt your thing, theres a pool table and Mexican soap operas on the television to entertain. Even cans of Bud come with a lime slice, adding to the overall flavor of both the beer and the bar.

The most important thing you need to know about this newish wine bar/small plates joint (its name is inspired by its sister restaurant, Dunlays on Clark, and Italys D.O.C. wine laws) is that you seat yourself. In other words, when you see a server carrying a bill folder, follow him and hover over the table until its yours. Because with plenty of bottles costing less than 30 bucks, satisfying snacks like grilled shrimp and pesto pizza, and generous plates of fresh charcuterie and cheese, people tend to linger.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 11, 22, 36
content.property: No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Wine bar Fireplace Food served Date place Private party room(s)

content.description: We know, we knowyou already have Susan and Drew Gosss incomparable neighborhood joint on your calendar for Mondays killer buttermilk biscuitandfried chicken platter, and Tuesdays Wagyu beef burger. But if you can tear yourself away from those weekly specials, you might find that the seasonal stuff Susan is currently putting out is pretty good, too: slow-smoked lamb riblets with molasses-mustard barbecue saucea cheddar-corn souffle with crushed tomatoeswarm pumpkin bread pudding. Still thinking about that Wagyu burger? We didnt think so.
content.property: Good for dining at bar Outdoor seating

content.public-transport: El: Red or Brown line to Belmont. Bus: 22, 77.

content.description: Perhaps one of the most active and random stages in the city can be found at this eclectic, art-filled corner tavern, where nightly performances can range from poetry readings to jam bands to a recent musical tribute to a famous deceased racehorse (seriously). More reliable is the beer menu: 17 bottles and 16 draft beers, including the venerable Alpha King.
content.property: Video/pinball games Live bands No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Piano bar

content.description: A Colombian bakery is rare in Chicago, so we can see why this tiny gem is usually packed with devout regulars. Stopping by for the heavenly variety of sweet baked goods is the norm (try the flan de leche and the caramel napoleon), but we make a meal out of the rotating tins of meaty snacks that pile up in the hot case. Beef and chickenstuffed empanadas, flavorful palito de queso (cheese-stuffed pretzel sticks), and wildly rich chorizo roll out of the kitchen every few hours, so arrive early for a choice bar stool and you can pluck your picks from the freshest batch while sipping turbo-strength Colombian coffee.

Dont take the name literally: Theres a nice crowd here, but the joint isnt packed with followers, so you can usually find a seat to soak up the comforting vibe. We want to keep this place low-key, and were almost hesitant to tell you about it, but were running out of competition on the Ms. Pac-Man and the pool table.
content.property: Pool table Video/pinball games Sports bar

content.description: Tucked away in back off of the main dining room of the restaurant, the outdoor space handles overflow diners and then turns into a beer garden at around 9:30pm, complete with its own cabana-style bar. Theres one TV outside, but more are rolled out for big games.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 9, 11, 74

content.description: Dozens of bras hang from the ceiling inside, but the rustic, fenced-in beer garden has a vibe all its own, with its covered gazebo and its funky yellow lightbulbs hanging overhead. If youre new to the bar, and proprietor Sergio Mayora notices you, be prepared for a free shot of tequila.
content.property: Pool table Live bands Video/pinball games No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Outdoor seating Food served
Sports bar Wheelchair-accessible bathroom No stairs to bathroom No steps at entrance Pool table Video/pinball games

content.description: Michelle Fires theory for her restaurant is good food for nice people. Her popular brunch is constantly evolving, and recent specials include Bib im Bop, a play on bibimbap, the Korean casserole of rice, veggies and egg; organic corn arepas topped with organic eggs and avocado; and biscuits and gravy made with Amish sausages from Michigan and Indiana. As dedicated to art as she is to organic ingredients, Fire features brunch dishes made from recipes from artists, whose work covers the walls.

Its not that this old Bucktown standby feels like somebodys living room; its that it basically is one. Jeans been here for 55 years, and in that time shes accumulated more knickknacks than a flea market. Its her second home, and after a few minutes chatting with her over a cheap bottle of beer, it starts feeling like yours, too.

There are two types of people who drink in this classic bar, which is full of dark wood and brass: tourists staying in the Talbott Hotel who dont know anywhere else to drink, and locals who know that anywhere else isnt half as classy.
content.property: No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Conversation friendly Good for over-40 crowd Dress sharp Food served Outdoor seating

content.description: Its got the requisite menu of fried food and burgers, televisions in every corner and a shot-and-beerloving clientele. But the surroundingsstone walls, glass facadelend this Lakeview sports bar a sensibility so laid-back and inviting that even the least sports-enthusiastic people can get into it.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 22, 36, 76
content.property: Video/pinball games Karaoke No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Food served Outdoor seating

content.description: Pops is sleeker, shinier and more grown-up than its old Lincoln Park location, and thats a good thing for their older, jazz-loving crowd (the intimate jazz club in the basement should please those folks, too). The young Lincoln Parkers who used to stop by for a glass of wine may be out of luck, however. Not only is this not their crowd anymoreits also out of their price range.
content.property: Live bands Dress sharp Date place No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Wine bar Classic Chicago spot Outdoor seating Food served

content.description: This small neighborhood favorites menu changes seasonally, with an emphasis on locally grown ingredients, and the results are typically good. The goat cheese, vegetable and tofu burrito isnt something youll find elsewhere, and the burger with grilled onions and bacon is one of the best around. Dont bother with the pasta dishesyou can do just as well at home. Brunch favorites include the banana-nut-bread French toast and the apple and apricot pancakes. Not low carb, but who cares?

After more than 15 years in business, Michael Tauss baby remains as innovative as ever. His creative menu, offset by the minimalist dcor, showcases seasonal ingredients in new ways. Look for vegetarian-friendly dishes packed with signatures such as truffled sweet potato risotto, Asian crab cakes with mango-basil emulsion and macadamia nutcrusted grouper with rock shrimptaro root hash. Dont forget to pair your meal with one of the 750 wines from the breathtaking wine cellar.
content.property: Private party room(s) Notable wine list Vegetarian-friendly

content.description: A little older and a little wiser, the after-work crowd here doesnt have the patience for the plastic cups of beer and sticky floors of other area bars. So patrons pack this new, slick, contemporary version of an Irish pub to flirt with fellow classy pint-drinkers.
content.property: Live bands No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Sports bar Food served

content.description: Though the name is a head-scratcher, this no-frills pub is a friendly Jefferson Park retreat. A faded mural promises 101 beers, but even though that number has dwindled to a modest 15, the regularsmiddle-aged dudes and their frosted-hair babesprobably couldnt care less. The trees in the adjacent beer garden dont bear any ham, but they will make for a shady spot come summertime.
content.public-transport: El: Blue to Jefferson Park. Bus: 56, 81, 85
content.property: Outdoor seating Good for over-40 crowd

content.description: Whoever you are, Pearl, thank you. You must be pretty special to have inspired this Creole-influenced soul food restaurant in your name. Weve learned the hard way to be patient with the long waits. But dont worry: the fried chicken is so damn juicy and sealed in a crunchy, pepper-flecked exterior; the collard greens so tender and flavorful with pork bits; and the sweet-potato pie so fragrant with cinnamon and nutmeg (fluffy near the middle and caramelized where the filling meets the flaky crust) that wed wait forever.

When the South Shore location of this charming caf closed recently, the owners moved all operations into the comparably cute South Side space that formerly housed the morning-only 5 Loaves Breakfast Caf. The menu has expanded to include more sandwiches (buffalo chicken, country-fried steak) and salads, but the main attraction is still the thick, crispy po boys, the tender filets of pan-seared tilapia and the creamy sides of horseradish-and-dill-packed coleslaw. Saturdays and Sundays offer the Soulful Weekend ($10.95)an all-you-can-eat affair that includes more soul-food classics than you can shake a stick at.

One of Wicker Parks first spots for live music refuses to go the way of cover bands, instead booking local acts that play original rock. Theyre not always great, but the garden patio is. A scrappy mix of chairs and tables, a basketball hoop and groups of friends shooting the shit over cheap drinks makes for a classic summer night.
content.property: Live bands No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Outdoor seating

content.description: This modest Northwest Side shot-and-beer joint takes its name from the first capital of Polandan indicator of the clientele and serving staff. Vodkas big here, and you can get a generous ice-cold pour for $3.25 and pretend its a very dry martini (vermouth is overrated anyway). Theres a full-color photo of Polish hero and icon Pope John Paul II on the back bar, several Elvis CDs on the jukebox and an old-fashioned cigarette machine dispensing smokes at retro prices.
content.property: Conversation friendly Good for over-40 crowd Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Pool table
Pool table Video/pinball games Wheelchair-accessible bathroom No stairs to bathroom No steps at entrance

content.description: A few months ago La Tache shuttered and put up the kiss of death: a sign saying it was closed for renovations. The renovation line was no joke, though, and now the bistro has reopened with new life. Its the slick look of the place thats refreshing, but its also the food. New chef Andrew Alcid and his sous Jordan Rose are knocking out bistro staples as if they just got off the boat from Normandy: French onion soup with an acidic punch of cider; roasted chicken with fava beans and a skin that crackles like Pop Rocks; steak frites with a deliriously rich blue-cheese sauce. The profiterolesa La Tache staplestill end meals here on a note of disappointment. But with the way things are changing around here, they might not be around for long.

The treatment rooms have names like, “Relax me,” “Nurture me” and “Revitalize me.” But the truth is, they ought to go ahead and put a sign on the front door that says, “Spoil me” at this Lincoln Park spa. That's how you feel from the moment a cheerful host and the powerful scent of flickering aromatherapy candles welcomes you into the clean, modern space decked out in warm blue and brown tones and dark wood. Try the signature treatment, a hydrotherapy bath, before a service from the full menu of massages, facials, manicures, waxing and salt scrubs. A tub imported from Australia and outfitted with 77 ahh-inducing jet streams melts the stress out of every muscle in your body ($50 for 30 minutes). When—sigh—it's time to leave, don't be surprised if you feel like you're floating out the door.

Who the hell are all these people? Late at night, this place attracts a curiously diverse pack of frat boys, cowboys, corporate suits and the occasional hippie. Its a far cry from the upper-crust crowd wed expect, which is precisely why we like this Gold Coast rebel.
content.property: Video/pinball games No stairs to bathroom Outdoor seating Late Night Food served

content.description: Like a secret underground community of sexy, friendly people and cheap drinks (specials include $2 sangria on Tuesdays, $3 chocolate martinis on Wednesdays and half-price drinks on Thursdays), this dim and cavernous basement bar seems to attract people youd actually want to get to know.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 22, 36, 76
content.property: Video/pinball games No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Outdoor seating Fireplace Food served

content.description: Its somewhat ironic that in police-heavy Jefferson Park, this simple neighborhood pub is located next to an attorney specializing in DUI cases. Inside, unpretentious regulars drink beer to the country tunes coming from the jukebox, while we were impressed by the amazing collection of Elvis figurines and model cars and the friendly bartender Michelle, who brought us popcorn and gave us hairstyling tips.
content.property: Conversation friendly Darts Good for over-40 crowd Pool table Wheelchair-accessible bathroom No steps at entrance Video/pinball games

content.description: For one of the best tavern burgers in town (try the blue cheese, medium-rare) and a classy beer garden, this is the spot. Umbrella-topped tables, a wooden privacy fence, ivy-covered brick and a superbly stocked bar complete the package.
content.property: No stairs to bathroom Outdoor seating Food served

content.description: Even with 120 TV screens, its mind-boggling that this quintessential sports bar manages to pack all 20,000 feet of its warehouselike space with peopleon nights when the Illini are playing, you cant even move. When the games not on, musical acts (Tone-Loc is still considered music, right?) and an outdoor patio keep the place buzzing.
content.openingtimes: MonThu 5pm2am; Fri 5pm4am; Sat noon5am; Sun varies (call ahead)
content.property: Live bands No stairs to bathroom No steps at entrance Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Food served Outdoor seating

content.description: Peg Leg Sullivans has morphed from a grungy Lincoln Park chug fest into a three-story mecca of dark polished wood and working fireplaces. But the changes dont stop there: A no-smoking policy will likely draw some of the older locals out of their condos, where theyll have to fight the frat boys (body-shot contest, perhaps?) for a seat.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 8, 74, 76
content.property: Video/pinball games No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Sports bar Fireplace Food served

content.description: If youre the type of parent who includes your bambino in your extracurricular activities, weve got the quintessential neighborhood bar for you. Enjoy superb pub grub, killer Bloody Marys, $10 weekend breakfast buffets and a cheerful patio, all while watching your kiddies tumble themselves cockeyed on the beer-stained floor.
content.property: No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Outdoor seating Food served

content.description: With more clutter than your eccentric aunts house, this former speakeasy in Ukie Village serves up cheap booze (most shots are $3.50) in true dive fashion. Indie rockers on their way to the nearby Empty Bottle shows take advantage of free pool, while a smattering of toothless old-timers keep it gritty with war stories and phlegmy coughs.
content.property: Pool table Video/pinball games No stairs to bathroom

content.description: Come for the pitchers, stay for the pizzaor something like that. Hawkeye's doesn't really impress in either department (unless you like your Miller lite and your pies plain), but when you're rolling deep in a pack ofPhi Kappa Psis out on the prowl and you've managed to catch the eye of one of the well-endowed waitresses, it doesn't really matter what she's carrying to your table, now does it?
content.property: Private party room(s) Sports bar Outdoor seating Food served

content.description: This Japanese-inspired spa is for women, run by women. Take off your shoes at the door and wind your way around rice–paper screens leading to spa bath facilities. Submit to an herbal wrap, which begins with a dry sauna, eucalyptus steam and Jacuzzi, or try head-to-toe tranquility in the massage therapy room (massage and wraps average $80). Swathed in a kimono, you can put up your feet and sip tea undisturbed (for up to three hours) in the relaxation room. It gets busy, so call ahead on weekends.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Red, Purple (rush hrs) to Belmont. Bus: 77

content.description: Hotel lobbies arent our dining rooms of choice, but we make an exception for the sultry vibe of this low-lit Mediterranean spot with a lake view from the patio. Chef Kristine Subido updates her menu for warm weather with pan-roasted sea scallops over pea pure; hanger steak tossed on the grill with spring onions; and roasted artichoke croquettes served with a lemon aioli. The menu breakdown is a little mystifying, but three small plates or two large feed a group of four just fine.

Now that chef Erick Williams is comfortable in his role as executive chef at Michael Kornicks River North stalwart, hes constantly tweaking his menu. These days, those tweaks involve an ode to fall ingredients: pumpkin soup with toasted coconut; pan-roasted black bass with Nichols Farm red bell peppers, fingerling potatoes, fennel and saffron-scented nage; and roasted, farm-raised squab served with sweet potatoes, wilted greens and housemade bacon. Pastry chef Tony Galzin gets into the autumn spirit with a warm maple pound cake with roasted figs and crme frache sorbet.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Chicago. Bus: 66, 156
content.property: Private party room(s) Notable wine list Vegetarian-friendly

content.description: Roscoe Village has gentrified over the last few years, and the same goes for its watering holes, especially this one. These days its yuppie central, but its still one of the best places in town to grab a beer from the extensive list, chat with the friendly bartenders and test your alcohol-addled vocabulary with a game of Scrabble.
content.property: Video/pinball games No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Outdoor seating Fireplace Food served

content.description: Its kind of like riding the El: The wait at this always-packed tapas joint can be long and annoying, but once you get inside, things go pretty quickly. Cheap plates of patatas bravas (soft, habit-forming cubes of potatoes immersed in a spicy tomato sauce) and croquetas de pollo (creamy chicken and ham fritters) arrive at the table almost immediately, dropped like afterthoughts by overworked servers. A plate of Manchego and a pitcher of sangria to tide you over, and you wont even notice the wait.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Chicago. Bus: 22, 66, 156

content.description: Dim and vaguely tinted green (likely due to the MSU Spartan memorabilia that covers nearly everything), this worn, yet welcoming, Lakeview watering hole boasts more than 30 bottled beers. Its the kind of simple tavern where the bartender wont hesitate to top off your drink a couple times just for ordering some of the tasty pub grub.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 22, 77
content.property: Conversation friendly No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Extensive beer selection Sports bar Food served Video/pinball games

content.description: Most of the guys who go to this sporty, sceney homage to stainless steel dont seem to care what the food tastes likeits more of a tits and beer thing for them. But if theyd pay attention, theyd find that most of the menu is much better than the chewy, cardboardish pizzas. As counter-intuitive as it may seem, the antibar food is where the gems are, like the mildly spicy braised lamb lettuce wraps and the perfectly golden roasted chicken.
content.property: Food served Pool table Outdoor seating Good for groups
Private party room(s) Outdoor seating Late-night dining

content.description: West Loop residents have this comfy place to escape their condos, lofts and loft-condos. The owners say theyre trying to capture old-school Chicago, which to them means 14-foot exposed-brick walls, warm earth-tone lighting, a beautiful antique bar and well-dressed clientelenot rusty Old Style signage and sepia-toned photos from the 1893 Worlds Fair.
content.property: Sports bar Wheelchair-accessible bathroom No stairs to bathroom After-work crowd No steps at entrance Food served

content.description: From the standard look of the place youd never suspect this bars anything special. But we call it McGees Lite for a reason: For those who raged when they were younger but cant hack it anymore, this (supposedly) Irish joint perfectly walks the fine line between chill neighborhood spot and rowdy sports bar.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 8, 73, 74
content.property: Pool table Video/pinball games Live bands Outdoor seating

content.description: On a corner of lonesome desolation lies this neogothic den of inequity. Is it a moody, clean-as-a-whistle lounge or a haunt for I-coulda-been-Bo-Bice metal heads? Early, this low-key nightclub spills out sweet European tunes, and then right at dusk, watch out: Here come the Polish headbangers. Techno and even industrial-focused blowouts make an appearance from time to time.

It usually takes nothing but a four-leaf-clover cut out of construction paper to make a bar Irish, but this tchotchke-filled River North pub is different. Its certified by the James Joyce Society and full of real, live Irish people. So throw down that Guinness (or Boddingtons) with confidence: This is the real thing.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Chicago. Bus: 22, 66
content.property: Wheelchair-accessible bathroom No stairs to bathroom No steps at entrance Video/pinball games Fireplace Live bands

content.description: The hour-long wait is laborious, but in the case of this blink-and-youll-miss-it Mexican grill that sits in a strip mall, its worth it. Usually, the word rustic is saved for earthy European fare, but thats the only way to describe the flavor of piping hot tortilla soup thickened with blended tortillas; buttermilk-tinged, slawlike house salad; and caramel-colored, chargrilled chicken perched on a pile of smoky chipotle mashed potatoes. Well be back, no matter how much gas it takes to get there, especially for the mango cheesecake (a breathtaking mix between flan and mousse) topped with fresh mango and raspberry puree.

After establishing themselves as a popular sushi lunch spot in the South Loop, this budget-minded biz recently expanded with this new, swankier locale. Sashimi is still the way to gobig, thick cuts of very fresh, cool standards are dependable and tasty, and richer indulgences like fatty tuna and sea urchin are equally good and almost always available. Interestingly, the cooked menu is offered as small plates, making it easy to try a handful of unique dishes like roasted chicken-stuffed lotus root in crispy tempura batter and baked sesame-crusted scallops with wasabi mayo.
content.property: Good for dining at bar Vegetarian-friendly Outdoor seating Late-night dining

content.description: Neighborhood bars are as rampant as drunks in Wrigleyville, right? So why make this one your new spot? Because your hoodie doesnt have exposed wood beams and brick walls, wrought-iron chandeliers, or a downstairs lounge with leather banquettes and a black-felt pool table. The menu alone, which offers a good selection of nicely presented salads, sandwiches and steaks, is well worth becoming a regular.
content.property: Pool table Video/pinball games Private party room(s) Wheelchair-accessible bathroom No stairs to bathroom No steps at entrance Outdoor seating Food served Karaoke

content.description: You might expect a place that has a 70% vegetarian menu to have boring dishes made with soy milk and flaxseeds. But this coffee shop/bar/restaurant/performance space will surprise you with dishes like the grilled quail with caramelized salsify. During brunch, the winners keep coming: The huevos rancheros are gooey, cheesy and substitute black-bean cakes for tortillas; and the fruit plate sometimes comes with passion-fruit sorbet and a slice of white-chocolate banana bread. Its all so heavenly it may make carnivores think about going veghead. (Or at least 70%).
content.property: Vegetarian-friendly Outdoor seating Late-night dining Fireplace

content.description: A bistro in France it aint, but curiously enough, this tidy, dark dive takes a few traditions from across the Atlantic. The bartendera skinny, older gentlemandresses in an immaculately crisp white button-down, and you can buy hard-boiled eggs for 75 cents. The larger-than-life posters of De Niro on the wall, however, are completely American.
content.property: Video/pinball games Good for over-40 crowd

content.description: Of course its crazy on the weekends, but even on weekend afternoons, regulars gather at this bilevel, wood-heavy pub to watch the game andjudging from the bottles of Jameson suspended upside-down above the bar (all the easier to pour)drink a lot of Irish whiskey.
content.property: No steps at entrance Sports bar Wheelchair-accessible bathroom No stairs to bathroom Food served

content.description: Suckers for free food eat well at this family-run Persian spot: Order the village salad of tomato, cucumber, pepper, stuffed grape leaves, basil, olives and feta and youll also get a bowl of lentil soup. Choose entres such as the baby lamb shank simmered in walnut-pomegranate sauce or the lemon-honey chicken breast with currants, and youll not only get soup but a perfectly dressed house salad as well. And the vanilla ice cream topped with honey and cinnamon? You wont find that on your check, either. Thirty years of business result in a room thats a bit dim and weathered, but the service is extra attentive; complimentary roses are handed to departing women. Cheesy, but cute.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 22, 36, 76, 151, 156

content.description: Who knew the Irish and the Greeks got along so well? Early in the evening, this friendly watering hole seems to be filled with people waiting for a table at Greek Islands. Later, off-duty cops start filing in, not so much to keep the peace, but to grab a beer and a handful of free popcorn.

One could do a lot worse than grabbing a bucket of beer and a cheeseburger as big as a sofa cushion at this sports pubespecially when said burger comes with grilled onions and hand-cut fries. This is the flagship joint (one of three locations in and around Chicago), and its a comfortable spot, with an old-fashioned tin ceiling, brick walls and plenty of flirty UIC students.
content.property: After-work crowd Conversation friendly Good for groups Good for over-40 crowd Pool table Private party room(s) Sports bar Video/pinball games Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Food served

content.description: Newcomers can expect the same hairy-eyeball treatment we received upon entering this working-class bar. (Waiting on a Metra train, are ya? was the Irish-accented owner-bartenders greeting.) Once his right eyebrow lowered and the $1 MGD drafts started flowing, though, we felt almost as welcome as any of the regulars watching the game and enjoying well-deserved whiskey shots after quitting time.
content.public-transport: El: Blue to Irving Park. Bus: 54, 56, 80, 152
content.property: No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom

content.description: The bartender, Victoria, is happy to brighten up this dark and musty bar by pouring old-fashioned cocktails like the Tequila Sunrise, Harvey Wallbanger or Sea Breeze. This place used to be the G&L Lounge (in fact, its still on the sign outside) although George (the G) is no longer in the picture. Theres a comfortable, aging lounge feel that makes for a good neighborhood bar experience, plus free pool Monday through Thursday.
content.property: Conversation friendly Darts Good for over-40 crowd Pool table Wheelchair-accessible bathroom

content.description: An extreme makeover rendered this bar, nestled riverside in the Sheraton Hotel, a lot hipper than the rest of the hotel would suggest. The cocktails follow suit: The L mixes vodka, Chambord, guava juice and fresh sour mix to sweet-and-tart perfection. The tourist clientele doesnt always match the contemporary vibe, but the drinks make the trade-off worth it.f
content.property: No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Notable for cocktails Good for groups Views Food served

content.description: The hike to this suburban backwoods institution is worth it if you love icy-cold Polish beers, frenzied jukebox sing-alongs (complete with pool-stick air guitar) and skewers of made-from-scratch smoked Polish sausages being grilled on raging bonfires in the adorable, flower-filled backyard. Buy four drinks and the sausages are free.
content.property: Pool table Video/pinball games Wheelchair-accessible bathroom No stairs to bathroom No steps at entrance Outdoor seating Food served

content.description: The multiple bike racks out back are packed with every kind of two-wheeler imaginable no matter the time of year at this biker bar (and by biker, we mean bicycle-r). Eco-minded folks chat over tasty vegan fare (the barbecue seitan is great), check out each other's rides and sample from the ample list of diverse drafts.
content.property: Outdoor seating Food served Conversation friendly

content.description: When youre sick of beer and tired of the same jukebox tunes, head to this 40-year-old Little Village bar, known for its Latin jazz acts. There you can switch it up with the house signature Michelada, a spicy, refreshing combination of lime juice, Tabasco, Worcestershire and beer. Sounds bad, tastes good.
content.public-transport: El: Pink to Central Park. Bus: 21, 60, 82

entry.name: La Casa de Isaac Mexican Restaurant

version.name: La Casa de Isaac Mexican Restaurant

content.openingtimes: Breakfast, lunch, dinner (closed from sundown Friday to sundown Saturday)

content.description: If youve ever been to a back-alley caf in Europe, this Bosnian coffeehouse/bar/restaurant will bring back memories. The rabid soccer fans pack the patio slugging martinis and mind-blasting coffee drinks, while ripping into platters of juicy meat specialties; think skinless sausages, thick meat patties and skewers of tender beef.
content.property: No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Outdoor seating Food served

content.description: This bright, sleek, minimalist space brings a cool, collected and slightly clubby option to Division Street. Expect design-types in chunky eyewear drinking gin and discussing the merits of Mies. And keep in mind that if things gets too heady, the rowdier (though slightly less intellectual) crowd is right across the street.
content.property: No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Sports bar Food served Outdoor seating

content.description: Even though its in Wrigleyville, this place feels mileseven hoursaway from the baseball scene. But whats lacking in pendants and face-painted fans is made up for with reggae paraphernalia and lots of rum punch and Red Stripe, so its no wonder that Jamaicans all over the city call this joint their second home.
content.property: Live bands No steps at entrance Wheelchair-accessible bathroom

content.description: A bookstore in the dining section? Yup. But its more than a bookstore; think wine bar with tasty bites in a spot that just happens to be filled with books. While we were sipping delicious Vina Marian (a Spanish blend of verdejo and sauvignon blanc), we tried the soupssweet onion tomato and carrot ginger bisquewhich are so tasty, the snack grew into a full meal. The vegetarian sandwich is a cool, fresh combo of tomato, cucumber, provolone and mixed greens on slices of ciabatta spread with herbed cream cheese. Bookworms can enjoy 1/2 price wine and beer at the store on book club nights, the first Wednesday of each month.

Every Irish bar in the city claims maximum authenticity, but this one has the goods to prove it: The vibe is a nice mix of traditional and contemporary Irish pub culture, the bar was designed and built in Ireland, and most of the waitstaff are real live Irish folks (or just really good at faking accents).
content.property: Live bands No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom

content.description: Couples and small groups flock to this dimly lit Lakeview spot (situated next to 404 Wine Bar; theyre connected inside) to cozy up by the fireplace or in one of the berhigh, black leather booths. Thats not to say you cant go alonejust be prepared to sip your Sam Smith up at the bar.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 9, 11, 76
content.property: Video/pinball games No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Sports bar Conversation friendly Date place Extensive beer selection Good for over-40 crowd Outdoor seating Fireplace Food served

content.description: The cologne of choice at this Gen-Y Romper Room must be Navete, as evidenced by the number of primped-up twentysomething boys clumsily canoodling in the corner or lamenting an ex by crying a river on some drag queens shoulder. Otherwise, this likable saloon is packed to bursting most nights of the week, with events like the wet-boxer contest helping to maintain short attention spans.
content.public-transport: El: Red, Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Belmont. Bus: 8, 77, 152
content.property: Piano bar Karaoke No stairs to bathroom Gay Lesbian Fireplace

content.description: Seasonalcurrently closed. Housed in a former Coast Guard building in Jackson Harbor, this place offers a view and a vibe meant for lazy summer evenings. In proper seaside (okay, lakeside) fashion, the menu is classic American with a taste of the tropics in dishes like blackened catfish and a fried tilapia sandwich. Stick with fried popcorn shrimp and burgers, or just opt for desserts like key lime pie or banana flamb. Dont miss live jazz and an omelette station at Sunday brunch.

Theres tons of room to spread out in this standard Lincoln Park pub, whether its to down some Stella in a booth or play some darts. Space is harder to come by at around 10pm, when the DJ inspires ass-slapping and groin-grindingyoull either have to make a quick escape or join in.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Armitage. Bus: 8, 73

content.description: In case you couldnt guess, this bare-bones dive, known for its constant stream of live bands and for being one of the oldest bars on Halsted, is for breeders. And as the only straight bar in this stretch of increasingly hetero Boystown, itll only get busier.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 8, 22, 77

content.description: This is one friendly bar. We always intend to have one after-work drink, but theres something about this place that keeps us ordering round after round. The welcoming staff, vintage photofilled interior and upscale Irish pub grub make this Garret one talented Mr. Ripley.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Chicago
content.property: No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Private party room(s) Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Food served

content.description: This cocktail lounge is named after Sinatra, so it only makes sense that Ol Blue Eyes songs show up in the jukebox and Rat Pack photos line the walls. But customers feel more like packed rats as this after-hours spot fills up; the crowded room is so narrow that claustrophobic drinkers might only last one round.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 22, 36, 76
content.property: No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Late Night Video/pinball games Karaoke

content.description: Picture a large rectangular bar surrounded by patrons guzzling down Hamms beer and shots of Old Grand Dad. Its the middle of the day, and a guy keeps shouting out, A cowboys life is the fucking life for me! while nearby a boozy couple slow dances to oldies on the jukebox. It may look like an ordinary Chicago house on the outside, but in here, bathed in neon beer signs, its dive city.
content.property: Conversation friendly Darts Good for over-40 crowd Pool table Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Video/pinball games

content.description: Its a concept thats almost impossible to pull off: Serve dishes from India, Brazil, Korea and China, tone it down for American palates and charge anywhere between $20 and $45 an entre. So its no surprise that things here are hit or miss. The tastiest dishes are the free ones: a basket of fresh, warm nan to start with and an indulgent trio of potatoes (sweet, fingerlings, gratin) that arrives with the entres. We like the crab-stuffed sweet-and-sour shrimp, the sophisticated organic beet salad and the subtle roasted cod. But steer clear of the chewy duck and lobster chow mein, and dont blow your money on the steaksthere are steakhouses for that.
content.property: No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Dress sharp Good for over-40 crowd Food served

content.description: If youre wondering what sets this friendly West Loop bar and grill apart from every other pub thats packed tightly with graduate- and law-school types, its the selection of 40 draught beers (including three tasty styles from our Hoosier faves Three Floyds). The large food menu goes beyond the average pub, with eats like baby back ribs, a hummus platter and an assortment of salads.
content.property: Video/pinball games No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Sports bar Extensive beer selection Food served Pool table

content.description: Could anything be more perfect? Its a deli. Its a bar. Its your new favorite pit stop. Spend your mornings at the dinerlike counter with an egg-and-cheese, stop by for a gyro and a beer for lunch and return after work for cocktails. You may never go home again.
content.property: Video/pinball games No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Food served

content.description: Like a secret chamber of debauchery, the red door to this State Street bar reveals no sign of whats inside. Turns out its a dark cabinish space with a mixed crowd of lewd yuppies and bitter locals. Pissed off? Up to no good? Youll fit in just fine.

Guys, dont even bother. This River North hangout has plenty of tables to nosh on a burger and a big, circular bar with plenty of stools to put down your pints. But after work its crowded three-suits-deep with men trying to flirt with the gorgeous bartenders, so only a woman could get lucky here.
content.property: Pool table Video/pinball games No stairs to bathroom No steps at entrance Outdoor seating Late Night Food served

content.description: Across the street from the Jefferson Park CTA station, this wood-paneled neighborhood joint seems like the perfect opportunity for a quick drink while waiting for your bus to arrive. But be careful: When the Bears game is on, that sweet bartender is flirting with you and one Johnny Cash tune gets played after another, its impossible not to get sucked in. You might miss not just your bus, but the rest of your day, too.
content.public-transport: El: Blue to Jefferson Park. Bus: 56, 81, 85, 91

content.description: The name might remind you of the rough-and-tumble bar in that Patrick Swayze flick. On the weekends, youd probably be correct. But during the week, this sports bar filled with car paraphernalia is quiet and laid-back. Sit on the stoolswith all that debauchery, you never know whats hidden in those plush velvet car seats.
content.property: Pool table Video/pinball games Live bands Karaoke No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Late Night Food served

content.description: Modeled after the more-than-a-century-old bar in Manhattan, this River North watering hole channels old-school service and style (read: lots of mahogany, more than 50 bottles of Scotch and polite bartenders). But the best part is something thats completely Chicago and new-school: a trio of mini-burgers, topped with a pickle slice and made for soaking up suds.
content.property: No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Food served

content.description: Underneath a highway and inside a dark, unmarked storefront isnt the first place youd look for kids and dogs. But when a bar opens at 8am, its patronsa diverse mix of guys (yeah, theyre pretty much all guys) from the neighborhood who work all hours of the nighttend to get pretty comfortable, stopping in for a beer (all bottles, no taps) regardless of what theyve got with them.
content.property: After-work crowd Conversation friendly Good for groups Good for over-40 crowd No stairs to bathroom Pool table Video/pinball games No steps at entrance

content.description: The shiny awning and glittery old-Hollywood sign outside may draw us into this Lakeview bar, but the photo booth keeps us staying much later than planned. The 50s diner ambiance is swanky, the food is decent and the bar boasts a friendly crowdso friendly that you may get back your photo strip and spot an unknown face.
content.property: No stairs to bathroom No steps at entrance Pool table Video/pinball games Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Food served Karaoke

content.description: Rumor has it that crooked politicians were busted for taking bribes at this Irish pub in the late 70s, but as far as we can tell, these days the unpretentious spot is packed with the law-abiding and superfriendly. The homey, neighborhood joint has survived a couple dozen St. Patricks Days and probably twice as many Irish impersonators.
content.property: Pool table Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Outdoor seating Food served Video/pinball games No stairs to bathroom Good for groups Private party room(s) After-work crowd

content.description: When it comes to trendy gay bars, this crowd has been there, done that, so theres less cruising and more drinking here. During the week, the jukebox features pop, country and oldies, but weekends are all about karaoke. Expect to hear I Will Survive at least twice a night.
content.property: Darts Karaoke No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Gay

content.description: This neighborhood tap room used to be called the Jefferson Pump, but its new name suits it like a fine Irish tweed cap. Ready at the front of the bar station is a bottle of Powers whiskey, and you dont have to remind amiable bartender Valerie to bring the water-back. Theres an authentic dartboard for the Irish steel darters who assemble here, and the band Finbar Fagans plays on weekends.
content.public-transport: El: Blue to Jefferson Park. Bus: 81
content.property: After-work crowd Conversation friendly Darts Extensive beer selection Good for over-40 crowd Live bands Karaoke No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Sports bar Wheelchair-accessible bathroom

content.description: We cant figure out how this sports bar got such a revered name, but trust us, it doesnt quite fit. Not that its not niceits just that the beer garden is a little campy (very Florida Keys) but nonetheless lovely on a warm day. Those who eschew kitsch can try the patio in front.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 36, 76, 77
content.property: Outdoor seating Food served Darts Live bands Video/pinball games

content.description: You can take the sports fan out of the sports bar and put him in this sophisticated University Village lounge. But even couches covered in faux suede and slick flat-screens in each booth wont take the sports bar out of the fan. For that were thankful because despite the swankiness, this college spot from the folks behind Cans and Evil Olive doesnt have an ounce of attitude.
content.public-transport: El: Blue to UIC-Halsted. Bus: 8 Halsted, 12 Roosevelt
content.property: Pool table Video/pinball games No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Outdoor seating Food served Sports bar

content.description: The corner where this North Center tap sits has been a neighborhood hot spot since Prohibition: The former Schuliens featured a basement speakeasy and a house magician. The hood has changedtodays ODonovans operates as a laid-back hangout for younger couples and small groupsbut the tableside magic shows (and the occasional balloon sculptist) remain on weekends. Escape the crowds in the tucked-away beer garden, heated and enclosed in the winter.
content.public-transport: El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 11, 80
content.property: Outdoor seating Food served After-work crowd Wheelchair-accessible bathroom No stairs to bathroom No steps at entrance Conversation friendly Good for groups

content.description: Youll consider staying in the South Loop forever just to make this bar your local hangout, so make sure you have some time on your hands before you belly up to the beautiful, shiny wood bar. And be prepared to drool when the guy next to you orders a burger on one of the soft pretzel buns.
content.public-transport: El: Green, Orange, Red to Roosevelt. Bus: 1, 4, 12
content.property: No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Food served

content.description: Cheeseheads reserve most of their enthusiasm for pigskins, but they can muster some excitement over curds once in a while, too. At this offshoot of a Green Bay staple, you can do both: Flat screens show football and other sports, and the kitchen puts out authentic dairyland fare. Butter burgerstopped with ketchup, pickles, raw white onions and, of course, a buttered, grilled bunare cutely wrapped up in butcher paper and are indeed de rigueur. Otherwise, thin-crusted pizzas and chewy, golden fried curds make good beer accompaniments. Salads are available, too, but that wouldnt be very Wisconsin of you, now would it?

In a bar with NASCAR plaques on the walls and baseball and Cop Land on the TVs, we were more than surprised to hear Jewels tolerance anthem Pieces of You coming through the speakers. But this place is all about coexistencesports nuts, pool-playing Replacements fans and those dudes slumped over their PBRs are all somehow able to get along at this little Lincoln Square pub.
content.property: Sports bar Darts Pool table Video/pinball games

content.description: Put your money to good use (as in uses other than beer) at this popular, no-frills after-work joint. Every Wednesday night, a guest (i.e., amateur) bartender gets behind the bar, slinging drinks for a good cause (all of the tips go to his or her charity of choice). So drink up, but skip the mediocre bar foodnobody needs to be that generous.
content.public-transport: El: Green, Orange, Red to Roosevelt. Bus: 1, 3, 4, 12, 29, 62
content.property: Darts Pool table Live bands Video/pinball games No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Food served

entry.name: Martini Bar at the Millennium Knickerbocker Hotel

version.name: Martini Bar at the Millennium Knickerbocker Hotel

content.description: Instead of tucking away its bar to the side, this hotel ingeniously puts it in the middle of the lobby. Its the first thing guests see when they walk into the place, so they head right to the stools, creating a scene that, sure, looks like a hotel lobby, but feels like a happening hot spot.

Before the late-night, beer-goggled Wicker Parkians freak out: Just because this newcomer has taken over Borderline doesnt mean its changed the hours. The multiple plasma screens blasting sports may get drinkers in a little earlier than the 2am prime time of the past. And a jukebox means your cash, rather than a DJ, drives the sounds now.
content.property: Video/pinball games No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Late Night

content.description: Whether youre grabbing a meal to go or sitting down to eat at the counter of this bright storefront, expect your food to be served in a Styrofoam container with plastic forks. Carryout packaging is fine by us, because the dinnerssuch as the tender and gamey curried goatare so generous youll probably want to take part of it home. No knives are needed, either, because the oxtail falls from the bone with the touch of a fork. The specialty is excellent jerk chicken (sweet, hot and saucy) and juice concoctions made from fresh fruits and veggies, but the caramel cake is hot on the trail to becoming a signature standout.
content.public-transport: El: Red, Purple (rush hrs), Yellow to Howard. Bus: 22, 97, Pace 215

content.property: Wheelchair-accessible bathroom No stairs to bathroom No steps at entrance Sports bar Video/pinball games Fireplace Food served Outdoor seating

content.description: Doing its part to keep the West Loop from succumbing to all the glitz and glamour of Randolph Street is this tavern, which carries upward of 100 beers, including Dogfish Head 60 Minute IPA and Lindemans Framboise lambic on draftboth of which you can witness guys downing during Sunday-afternoon football.
content.property: No steps at entrance Wheelchair-accessible bathroom No stairs to bathroom Outdoor seating Food served

content.description: This bastion of solid, authentic Vietnamese eats nails consistency and flavor. We like to start with the tiny beef sausages wrapped in la lot leaves (#1), as well as lotus root salad (#18), a sprightly mix of crunchy lotus root and rau ram, also called hot mint. Memorable entres like catfish in a clay pot (#72) and chicken taro yellow curry (#62) match perfectly with a side order of garlic-laden, stir-fried water spinach. Wash it down with a glass of chanh (housemade limeade soda), and finish with the crispy tapioca flourbattered baby bananas.

Were still not sure whats more extensive at this friendly, narrow watering hole: the beer selection or the juke box. The 50 bottled beers (including several Belgians) should satisfy even the fussiest bargoer, but with every Uncle Tupelo album at your fingertips and lots of Dylan and Stones to pick through, your inner DJ might tempt you to invest your bucks in a killer soundtrack instead.
content.property: No stairs to bathroom Extensive beer selection After-work crowd Darts Pool table Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Conversation friendly

content.description: Leather booths with flowing privacy curtains, perky servers with tight T-shirts and a pimped-out penthouse room: When a place drips with this much sex, it takes work not to get some. Got no game? Thats coola list of creative champagne cocktails and martinis will soothe your sexually frustrated soul.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Sedgwick; Red to North/Clybourn
content.property: No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Dress sharp Outdoor seating

entry.name: Storefront Theater, Gallery 37 Center for the Arts

version.name: Storefront Theater, Gallery 37 Center for the Arts

content.public-transport: El: Orange, Green, Brown, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Randolph

content.vendor-category: Sports | What to do | Ultimate Frisbee

content.description: A martini hideaway? Sounds like an oxymoron, but this River North spot manages to marry the two into a union of after-work debauchery. After the nine-to-fivers roll it up on weeknights, industry folks (local bartenders and waitstaff) saddle up a martini and ride off into the dawn. On weekends, the Ranch becomes a hitching postDJs spin house and urbanites try to make room to grind by the pool table.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Chicago. Bus: 66
content.property: After-work crowd Pool table Outdoor seating Fireplace Late Night Food served

content.description: This Wicker Park outpost from the Francescas chain packs in the hungry and hip for small plates of simple Italian fare for dinner, and then again (though to a slightly lesser extent) for Saturday and Sunday brunch. The steak sandwich goes above standard with herb butter on roasted onion bread, plus a handful of pecorino and truffle oillaced fries, while the signature Traviata pizza comes stuffed with herbed robiola cheese, mixed greens and sea salt. And while were not sure why its called panettone French toast, since the Italian cakelike bread isnt used, its a good dish nonetheless, topped with sweet mascarpone cream, fresh berries and thick, aged balsamic vinegar.
content.property: Good for dining at bar Cheap (entrees under $10) Kid-friendly
Private party room(s) Wheelchair-accessible bathroom No stairs to bathroom No steps at entrance Live bands Outdoor seating Fireplace Food served

content.description: Escape to the great outdoors Wisconsin-style with your Leinenkugel, Point or Sprecher and shoot the breeze under the watchful eye of the giant moose that stands sentry. Friends meet at picnic tables, tunes float out from the jukebox (Phish and fowl with Free Bird represented) and the occasional neighborhood Labrador mingles with the regulars.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Wellington. Bus: 11, 76, 77
