content.property: Darts Pool table Live bands Video/pinball games No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Outdoor seating

entry.name: The Galway Tribes Irish Pub and Restaurant

version.name: The Galway Tribes Irish Pub and Restaurant

content.property: Private party room(s) Live bands Wheelchair-accessible bathroom No stairs to bathroom No steps at entrance Outdoor seating Fireplace Food served

content.description: When talk of cholesterol and arthritis meds tops the conversational buzz inside a restaurant, its a pretty good indication the menu is tailored to the AARP set. The steakhouse-style lineup includes prime rib, Dover sole almondine and calves liverexactly what youd imagine being served in the themed, but still elegant, dining rooms (the Garden Room, the Tack Room). Lobster Bently, a house specialty of breaded lobster swimming in garlic butter, should be a menu no-no for the impact it could have in thinning out the clientele. The real draw of this sprawling restaurant is the beer garden, a spacious outside spot where locals convene over steak sandwiches and burgers and play cornhole (a.k.a. beanbag toss).
content.public-transport: El: Orange to Midway. Bus: Pace 390

content.description: Situated in the heart of the Loop, this no-frills basement bar draws a thirsty after-work crowd. While the bar itself can get cramped, theres ample booth seating all around. Our favorite activity here is listening to dudes in suits whip one-liners at each other, which sounds like a preppy Sopranos episode.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Orange, Purple (rush hrs) to Washington/Wells; Blue to Clark/Lake; Red to Monroe

content.description: If you think the Monadnock building only slings Intelligentsia coffee, it would behoove you to check out this joint (which has such a classic saloon look that it seems to be as old as the Monadnock itself). Here, the beer starts flowing at 11amso should your 2pm coffee break fail to cut it, now you know where to go instead.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to LaSalle
content.property: Food served After-work crowd Conversation friendly

content.description: Au courant bands like Bloc Party provide the soundtrack at this posh Lakeview spot, where martinis are made with Hendricks gin and sipped while lounging in big, circular, black leather booths. The vibe is class without attitude, and we cant for the life of us figure out why its not packed.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Wellington. Bus: 9, 11, 77

entry.name: Information booth at 1821 S Halsted St

version.name: Information booth at 1821 S Halsted St

content.description: If 9:30pm seems a little early for alcohol-fueled anticsand by antics we mean a drunken regular named James wholl likely hit you up (twice) for a dollar for the jukeboxkeep in mind that this slashy closes at 11pm. And its clear that everybodys got a lot of beer drinking, chips eating and lottery-ticket scratching to do before then.
content.property: Wheelchair-accessible bathroom No steps at entrance Food served

content.description: The decor of this spacious karaoke-and-darts bar is reminiscent of roller rinks circa the 1980s: pink and aqua neon signage, wood paneling, fantastic mullets, and all the nachos and pizza you can handle. Drinks are ridiculously cheap, and the karaoke book is chock-full of corny 70s and 80s hits with a dedicated stage for performing, making this place a natural choice for getting drunk and stupid with large groups of people.
content.property: Karaoke Late Night Food served Conversation friendly Good for groups Good for over-40 crowd No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Video/pinball games Darts

content.description: The coolest and sleekest of Wrigleyville bars can handle spillover from any Metro show, no matter whos been playing. Thats no easy task, but the look and feel of this placeexposed brick walls littered with slick flat-screen TVs and paintings of jazz musiciansis as welcoming to Atmosphere die-hards as Sufjan Stevens fans.
content.property: No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Video/pinball games Sports bar

content.description: Scratch likes to think of itself as a saloon, and that means you get bartenders who care a lot about the way they make your cocktail. The bar is loaded with fresh fruit used in making your drinkno syrup mixes here. Theres a long list of wines by the glass, craft beers and more than 35 whiskeys.
content.property: Live bands No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Notable for cocktails Food served
Private party room(s) Live bands Wheelchair-accessible bathroom No stairs to bathroom No steps at entrance Food served

content.description: We cant resist a bartender who occasionally wears a cowboy hat and hands out buttery nipples like theyre candy. And apparently neither can the neighborhood locals, who gather here to watch the game, eat pizza or let the messages on the LCD screen (e.g., Bill Clinton, we miss you) incite heated debates.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 8, 22, 77
content.property: Pool table Video/pinball games Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Food served

content.description: The slogan says it all: no peeing, no crapping, no barking, lie downand that goes for the dogs, too. Needless to say, this bar is dog-friendly, inside and out. But what really clinches it as one of Chicagos best are the real English darts and the $2 bottles of Schlitz, Pabst, Old Style and Huber.
content.property: Darts Video/pinball games No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Outdoor seating Pool table

content.description: The deep-red walls and friendly service make this charming Ravenswood spot as warm and comforting as the food. And because its BYOB, its hard to beat the value. Bring a bottle of Sangiovese to match with the soft grilled polenta topped with the chunky house rag. The housemade tricolored rotolo is our favorite of the pastas, stuffed with ricotta and spinach, then baked to hot, hearty perfection. Specials like chicken parmigiana baked in a cream-based red sauce are winnersbut so are most of the dishes on the menu, so order with confidence.

content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Sedgwick. Bus: 11, 22, 36, 72, 156
Metra: Union Pacific N to Glencoe

content.description: Try ordering a simple cocktail in this laid-back Mexican dive, and you may have to resort to high school Spanish. A lone gin and tonic usually involves jerky pantomiming and the full involvement of half of the patrons, so switch to something easy to order like Corona and add this cool, dimly lit, sportscentric bar to your list of pit stops.
content.openingtimes: MonThu noon1am; Fri, Sun noon2am; Sat noon3am

content.description: This overlooked Lincoln Park hang is noted for its mellow vibe, in contrast to the meatmarkets surrounding it. The bartenders are friendly, the flat-panels numerous and the patrons toss peanut shells onto the floor while trying to spot their alma mater from a banner display that would make the United Nations jealous.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 11, 22, 36

content.description: Now that its a too nippy to make use of the stellar sidewalk caf, head inside where the diner look has yielded to blue suede booths and flat panel TVs. Mojitos and the house version of Sliders are the specialties, and nostalgia for Wrigley Field is induced upon every visit to the metal trough in the mens room.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 11, 22, 36
content.property: Outdoor seating Food served Sports bar Good for groups

content.description: A tasteful renovation has replaced the creepy stonework facade, but Goldies still remains strangely unknown. The cork dartboards and pool table offer better distraction than the sports-tuned TVs that are jammed into the rest of the hood, and the affordable beer selection ($1 PBR and $3 Guinness drafts) is a refreshing back-to-basics approach to inebriation.
content.public-transport: El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 11, 50, 80
El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Sedgwick. Bus: 11, 22, 36, 72, 156

content.description: Youve probably passed up this place a million times, but the core group of regulars at this brick-and-wood-filled, tavernlike Italian joint have kept the place afloat for more than a decade. We cant vouch for the regular menu, but its brunch buffet is tough to beat. For $12 you can have your fill of fresh fruit, mixed greens, baked goods, all the porky breakfast standards plus delicious brown sugarsmoked ham (carved-to-order alongside roasted turkey and sometimes brisket), onion-flecked potato chunks, and chilaquiles. Dont miss the fluffy made-to-order omelettes, blueberry-studded pancakes and French toast.

A blend of cozy bohemian hangout and hoppin breakfast haunt, this spots sun-splashed walls inspire all-day coffee sipping while leafing through the menu. Try the tasty frittatas (really just open-face omelettes) and the French toast, a gooey mayhem of three-inch-thick brioche slices stuffed with sweet cream, covered with fresh strawberries and bananas, and smothered in raspberry sauce. Lunch lightens the ingredient load, with perfectly crisp panini (the pesto caprese features homegrown tomatoes and freshly picked basil), made-from-scratch tuna and egg-salad sandwiches and a few huge salads.
content.openingtimes: TueFri 6:30am3pm; Sat, Sun 7:30am2:30pm (closed Mon). Brunch (Sat, Sun).

content.description: Loosely translated, vicinato is Italian for neighborhood, and though this corner tavern may not be in yours, its worth a trip to eat good in the Heart of Italy. Expect big plates of traditional fare, including bianco nero (white black), a wide bowl of tasty mussels and clams in garlicky broth, and pillow-y potato gnocchi made in-house and topped with a meaty ragu. Service is understated but helpful, though try to sit in the paneled bar instead of the rather bright dining roomsmoking is permitted there but adds atmosphere, as does the clientele. For dessert, share a dark chocolate ice cream tartufo the size of Tony Sopranos fist.

A cozy orange glow and horizontal lines inspired by Frank Lloyd Wright draw a hip, laid-back Lakeview crowd. Formerly a dive with urinals chained to the wall, the hot spot now boasts a trendy vibe with DJ-delivered music and an intriguing selection of brew/martinisthe phenomenal Pumpkintini is served through Thanksgiving.
content.property: No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Fireplace Extensive beer selection

content.description: Its all old-world charm at this Downtown Bar with a Neighborhood Atmosphere, even if it took raiding grandmas attic to pull it off. Somehow faded leopard carpeting, mismatched Tiffany-style lamps and a cash register from 1912 all gel together. Grab a stool at the bar or sprawl out at one of the many open booths. Either way, youll be looking at the same faces night after night; that is, if you can see them behind the sloppy ribs theyre scarfing.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Merchandise Mart. Bus: 22, 36, 65, 125, 156
content.property: Pool table Wheelchair-accessible bathroom No stairs to bathroom No steps at entrance Outdoor seating Late Night Food served Conversation friendly Good for groups Good for over-40 crowd

content.description: Downstairs from the fictitious pool hall in The Color of Money, this joint keeps it real with Hamms in cans, two dozen taps, free pool on Wednesdays and an old-school photo booth. A laid-back, dark and funky vibe attracts an indie-rock crowd clad in bowling shirts.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Wellington. Bus: 9, 11, 77
content.property: Pool table Video/pinball games No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom

content.description: Frank Lloyd Wright called this Hyde Park home “the cornerstone of modern architecture.” Though it fell into disrepair and was slated for demolition on more than one occasion, it’s now in the midst of a ten-year, $8-million restoration overhaul. One of the last buildings conceived in Wright’s Oak Park studio, it’s considered a prime example of the Prairie-style.
content.public-transport: El: Red, Green to Garfield. Bus: 6, 55, 59, 170

content.description: Situated in the Allegro Hotel, which itself is situated next to the Palace Theater, Encore attracts a clientele of tourists, more tourists and theater fans. Settle into one of the booths, and you should be able to suss out who falls into which category. That is, until you start in on one of the strong, neon martinis. In which case you wont even know which category you fall into anymore.
content.property: No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom

content.description: Custom House Tavern is ultimately not so different from what Custom House used to be: Its still fairly upscale, andsave the sometimes comically casual musicnot very tavernish. But you wont care about that when you get your hands on chef Aaron Deals food. Dishes not to miss: his duck rice, a sublime combination of duck confit, al dente rice and foie gras mousse; the white fish croquette, an herbacious and very pleasant item from the restaurants new bar menu; and pretty much any of pastry chef Bryce Carons desserts.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Library; Red to Harrison. Bus: 6, 29, 36
content.property: Notable wine list Private party room(s) Good for dining at bar Kid-friendly

content.description: You could easily make a meal of wine and cheese here, but you may have a hard time resisting going further. Especially in summer, when the sidewalk patio invites lingering over chef John Caputos global small plates. Recent dishes include escolar with bacon and swiss chard with a white wine sauce; a pizza topped with wild mushrooms, garlic and pecorino cheese; and a Asian-inspired crispy duck confit with sweet peas, mushrooms and spring onions in a sherry vinaigrette. No matter the season, gelato is always our preferred ending.
content.property: Good for dining at bar Vegetarian-friendly Outdoor seating Late-night dining Notable wine list

content.description: Ravenswood locals flock to this bar for its namesakes warmth and coziness. Bartenders tend to pour heavy herewe ordered a Scotch on the rocks and found ourselves drinking from a full highball glassso some food from the adjoining restaurant will be in order to soak it all up.
content.public-transport: El: Red to Bryn Mawr. Bus: 22, 36, 50
content.property: Darts Video/pinball games No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Fireplace Late Night Food served Outdoor seating

content.description: You won’t find day-spa luxuries such as gourmet nibbles and gratis wine. But what you will get makes up for the lack of frills: Thorough facials, medical-grade chemical peels and surprisingly gentle microdermabrasion provide all of the essentials needed for beautiful skin. The medical spa focuses on result-driven treatments such as photorejuvenation, a noninvasive light therapy that improves skin tone and texture ($499 and up). And while you could opt for waxing services, don’t be surprised if you’re tempted to splurge on laser hair removal. Unlike other laser treatments, Avanti’s machine zaps the fuzz completely, without pain. It’s enough to brighten your mood along with your complexion.
content.public-transport: El: Brown to Sedgwick. Bus: 73 North. Average service $100

content.description: This grungy shot-and-beer joint wont commit to the Cubs or Sox (both are represented equally) and the fake Tiffany lights could use a good Windexing. But for all its mismatched barstools and lack of draft beer, the big neon martini glass behind the bar puts things into perspective. It reads: YEAH, THE PLACE IS A DIVE...SO?
content.property: Conversation friendly Darts Good for over-40 crowd Private party room(s) Video/pinball games Wheelchair-accessible bathroom
Pool table Live bands No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom

content.description: Located in the Renaissance OHare hotel, youll find hearty buffet fare, as well as an a la carte menu, served up throughout the day. Expect a range of Mediterranean influences combined with American classics from chef John DiMartini.
content.property: After-work crowd Live bands Karaoke Good for groups Food served

content.description: Art Deco decor and (pricey) hand-crafted cocktails bring just a touch of class to your bowling outing.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 11, 76

content.description: Less of a frat-boy-meets-tourist scene than many Rush and Division bars, Leg Room is the classiest place on this strip to get a drink. But dont expect a low-key neighborhood bar. Youll get animal-print stools, a free-floating bar and a free jukebox with your martinis.
content.property: No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Dress sharp Fireplace Late Night Food served

content.description: Rockabilly couples swing to live DJs while black-and-white movies and other oddities play on a projector at this violet-hued lounge. Avondale hoodies keep the place busy on weeknights, but the real actions on Saturdays, when the owners spin new wave club classics till 5am as part of their long-running Planet Earth dance party.
content.property: Good for groups Late Night Live bands No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom

content.vendor-category: Cocktail bars Pick-up joints Swank spots
Cocktail bars Pick-up joints Swank spots
Cocktail bars Pick-up joints Swank spots
Cocktail bars Pick-up joints Swank spots
Cocktail bars Pick-up joints Swank spots
content.description: After closing in 2004, this loungethe laid-back counterpart to the high-energy club Circuit next doorhas made a comeback with a 60s-inspired remodel. The former drag bingo has bit the dust, but in its place is Saturdays new Wiggin Out, a drag-queen contest emceed by ubiquitous B-town personality Miss Foozie. If Rehab remains a relaxing cocktail lounge where we can kick back with a martini in a way Mad Mens closeted Sal Romano can only dream of, we say, Welcome back to the gayborhood.

When Boystowns minibar opened in 2005 as a Lilliputian lounge with classy cocktails, its diminutive size seemed ideally suited to late-night conversing and canoodling. But in 2007, it purchased the space next door, and earlier this year, it expanded yet again. Now, minibar is really anything butand it has the Las Vegas nightclub vibe to prove it. Chef Brian Merel tries to compensate for the lack of dining-room vibe with a menu of artful, upscale comfort foodbut in Boystown, the food rarely comes first.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 8, 22, 77
content.property: No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Notable for cocktails Food served Gay Private party room(s) Good for groups

content.description: So the subterranean dining room is jarringly large, the staff generally outnumbers the patrons, and the mulligatawny soup is chicken broth while the tomato smacks of Campbells. Chalk up the few oddities to Gaylord being the only Indian spot sandwiched between boutiques that sell ostrich-feathered boots, and opt to take advantage of the impressive lunch buffet. DIY chaat by smothering samosas in raita, chutneys, chickpeas and crunchy sev, then move on to flavorful yellow lentils, stewed cumin-spiced cabbage and tender chicken in buttery makhani sauce. Save room for fluffy rose-scented pillows of sweet ras malai.

The stage is literally set for this Middle Eastern restaurant to become a vivacious nightclub in the wee hours: Tables are arranged around a small dance floor, and instruments for a full band (drum set, etc.) are on display. Yet the food is no afterthought. Care is obviously taken with the meze, which includes a piquant eggplant salad, herbaceous tabouli and golden cheese borek. Entres like the chilifried (a spicy lamb stew) and the grilled quail are slightly less successful. But dont worry: If you dont feel like singing the foods praises, one of the band members soon will.

content.public-transport: El: Red, Blue to Jackson; Orange, Green, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Adams. Bus: 3, 6, 26, 145, 147, 151

content.description: Just because cake is in the name, that doesnt tie this new shop down to just classicslook for fresh fruitpacked breakfast cupcakes and dollar frosting shots in flavors like milk-chocolate buttercream, strawberry cream-cheese and chocolate toffee.

content.vendor-category: Sports | What to do | Rock climbing

content.description: Screws and nuts below, bowling pins above. This second-story bowling alley/dive barwhich sits above a hardware storeused to be one of the best hidden gems in the city. Now that the masses have caught on, you can bide your time while waiting for a lane by downing cheap beer, heckling ball-tossers and doing your best Dude impersonation.
content.openingtimes: MonThu 5pm2am; FriSun noon2am (closed MonWed during summer)
content.property: Video/pinball games No stairs to bathroom Good for groups Darts

content.public-transport: Metra: Union Pacific NW to Edison Park

entry.name: Frank Lloyd Wright Home and Studio

version.name: Frank Lloyd Wright Home and Studio

content.description: During the heyday of frilly Victorian architectural styles, Wright designed and lived in this structure that still looks modern by today's standards. He continuously changed its interior to test his theories, and from that work came his legendary Prairie-style, characterized by nature-inspired elements, horizontal lines and low-pitched roofs.

A restaurant and jazz venue, Green Dolphin turns into a dance club several nights a week with salsa one night and house another. The legendary and long-running Boom Boom Room house night on Mondays draws a diverse clientele for polysexual dancing in several rooms that continues into the wee hours.

True to its Prohibition-era theme, this bar serves its beer in mason jars. But theres nothing redneck about seven booths that are outfitted with individual plasma TVs. Those are likely to get more use during quieter weeknights when couples and small groups stop in for beers, burgers and televised games. Weekends can be a madhouse, with blaring music and scoping singles taking over the massive space.
content.property: Fireplace Food served Outdoor seating Good for groups

content.description: Its harder to pair wine and cheese than you thinkso stop thinking about it and let the people at this sophisticated wine-cheese-chocolate bar do it for you. Experts flutter around the warm, dark woodridden room, expounding on the carefully handled wines and artisanal cheeses. Its the kind of service (and diet) a person could really get used toif it werent so damn expensive.
content.property: Wine bar Food served Surprisingly good wine list Outdoor seating

content.description: After ten years at Atwood Caf, chef Heather Terhune has moved a couple of blocks north. Alongside Terhunes gastropub dishes (buttermilk-fried quail, short-rib sliders), Violet Hour vet Mike Ryan is behind the bar, slinging drinks from the enormous cocktail menu.

content.public-transport: El: Red, Orange, Green to Roosevelt. Bus: 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 10, 12, 14, 26, 28, 146

entry.name: 16th Street Theater at Berwyn Cultural Center

version.name: 16th Street Theater at Berwyn Cultural Center

content.public-transport: El: Red to Lake; Blue to Washington; Orange, Green, Brown, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Randolph

content.description: Those not paying attention risk stumbling past the subtle neon signage and buzzer-protected door of this Ukrainian Village dive. To feel like a regular inside, simply nab a Miller Lite, lend an ear at the bar stools and shamelessly belt Van Halens Top of the World between dart tosses. A tip to the wanna-be sharks: Pool is taken very seriously.
content.property: Darts Pool table No stairs to bathroom Conversation friendly After-work crowd

content.description: Wed never advocate being crocked on the clock, but if you must get your breakfast buzz, nuzzle up to the bosom of this well-worn, wood-paneled bar/diner in the Loop. Seating choices include the sliced-up stools or one of many vinyl booths. The grizzled waitresses have more than an ounce of attitude and wont think twice about dropping a little more Hennessy in your coffee as you scarf down a Denver omelette.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Green, Purple (rush hrs), Orange, Pink to State
content.property: Conversation friendly No stairs to bathroom Food served

content.description: Theres a lot more Gaelic cheer at this bar than just the Guinness on tap. The yummy pub grub is authentic, most of the staff is actually Irish and its never too crowded to nab a table (choose between the vintage woodwork inside and the expansive, open-air patio). Just dont spread the word too muchwed hate to wind up ass-to-elbow like at most Lincoln Park McPubs.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 22, 36, 74
content.property: Live bands No steps at entrance Outdoor seating Food served Darts Fireplace

content.description: If youre that vegetarian who feels dissed every time you dine out (how many times have you heard Well, I guess we could take the bacon off the cobb salad?), this place will be your nirvana. The 26-page, global, meatless menu takes awhile to navigate, with choices inspired from cuisines of America, Italy, Mexico, the Middle East and, most notably, India. Given that the owners of this 25-year-old veg haven are Indian, we suggest sticking to the filled crpelike dosas, the rice-lentil pancakes dubbed uttapam, any of the veggie-packed curries and the addictive crunchy-sweet-spicy bhel chaats. Unlike Devon Avenue, a 1-to-7 spice meter ensures personalized heat levels, but also unlike Devon, prices are relatively steep across the board.

This minimalist bar, decked out in sleek red and gray tones, might seem pretentious. But dont let the sophisticated look fool you. As the name suggests, the vibe here is warm and welcoming and makes you feel as if you belong, especially during the summer, when crowds pack its expansive deck. Join Jimmy D (the bars owner) for ladies poker school on Tuesday nights, or hit the rooftop when you can most enjoy it: Sunday morning for a brunch of steak and eggs or amaretto French toast.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Chicago. Bus: 66, 125
content.openingtimes: SunFri 11am2am; Sat noon3am. Patio closes at 10:30pm weeknights and 11:30pm weekends.
content.property: No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Good for over-40 crowd Outdoor seating Food served

content.description: This bar certainly leans toward frat-tastic, but its patrons seem oddly subdued. Perhaps the spots three-room layout provides ample high-top tables and bartenders to avoid the usual drink-order clamor. Or maybe the sociable crowd hates abrasiveness, too. Whatever the case may be, this is one frat party that wont leave you feeling like youre in a scene in Revenge of the Nerds.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 8, 22, 36, 76
content.property: Video/pinball games No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Food served Sports bar

content.description: At this Shanghai-style Chinese restaurant, the xiao long bao, or soup dumplings, are a magical creation of hot soup broth and pork or crab encased in dough. The restaurant also offers Beijing specialties like cumin-coated grilled lamb skewers, millet congee and the classic Chinese hot pot, which has been somewhat successful in luring diners seeking the wonders of the fonduelike, do-it-yourself meal. Whether its the soup dumplings that tempt youor the chewy homemade noodles in spicy sesame oil or the fist-size meatballs braised in the house sauce of dark soy, sugar and vinegaronce you get in the door, youll wonder how youve gone without for so long.
content.public-transport: El: Red to Cermak/Chinatown. Bus: 18, 21, 62 (24 hrs)

content.description: Finding an empty chair on Southport on a Saturday night can be like trying to find free parking around Wrigley Field. When you arrive here at 10pm youll think youre out of luck again. But edge past the crowd hanging out at the dark wood bar, and youll very possibly find empty tables, empty chairs and several empty beer glasses from the person who got drunk here before you.
content.property: Good for groups Sports bar Food served

content.description: Thank your lucky stars if you roll into this no-frills, blue-collar Irish pub on a night the endless fount of entertainment known as Crazy Kerry is slinging drinks. Born and raised in Chicago, this funny, tough-talking gal has seen it all, including deadbeats stumbling in without any cash, so dont be offended if she wants to see some dough before she slides a LaCrosse down the bar.
content.public-transport: El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 11, 50, 80

content.description: Regulars at this roadside dive know to call in their orders ahead of time so they dont have to drool for 20-plus minutes waiting for their fresh-from-the-fryer, juicy birds. Youll find a few tables next to the pop machines, but this is mostly a takeout joint that caters to a steady stream of NU students and fried-chicken fanatics who go bonkers for the slightly peppery, battered chicken dinners, complete with fries, cole slaw and bread for sopping the grease. Wingskept whole here, instead of cut at the joint, and served with hot, smoked or honey-barbecue saucerival nearby Buffalo Joes and Heckys BBQ for hometown favorite.

The Hartigans took a sizable risk when, in 1996, they decided to transform their Baskin-Robbins franchise store into a family owned-and-operated ice-cream shop. It seems the gamble has paid off, though. The store now carries more than 50 flavors from Wisconsin-based ice creamery Cedar Crest, and everyone from Northwestern students to stroller-pushing moms and dads can be seen coming in for a double-dip cone and and cup of joe.

The waits at this Bucktown spot are an indication of chef Chris Pandels loyal legion of fansa group that it only takes a few bites of food for you to want to join. The always-changing menu has a few standbys, like the dill-and-sea-salt monkey bread and the devastatingly delicious egg-and-ricotta-filled raviolo. But its Pandels daily specialsalways made with as many local, sustainable vegetables and meats as possiblethat really steal the show.

We doubt Amelias can do for the post-industrial Back of the Yards neighborhood what MundialCocina Mestiza did for Pilsen, but the BYOB is certainly worth a trek. Former Mundial chef Eusevio Garcia serves langoustines over creamy risotto dotted with velvety mushrooms, and makes one hell of a chile rellenoa blistered green-pepper, oozing cheese-covered sweet corn and tender eggplant. But recently, chef Garcia has been focusing on desserts, adding items such as a chocolate tres leches cake, a flourless apple cake and a marscapone cheesecake.

With its three distinct barrooms, this Uptown oasis is custom-made for the indecisive patron. An imposing wine rack and wafting surf-and-turf scents give the ground floor an air of fine dining. But we recommend heading upstairs for all the fun: Mondays martini and a manicure in the lounge, Thursdays improv competition, and Fridays 80s-themed burlesque revue.
content.property: Conversation friendly Darts Date place Good for groups Karaoke No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Notable for cocktails Pool table Sports bar Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Food served Outdoor seating

content.description: If the heavy weekend traffic of thirtysomethings at Huettenbar aint your thing, check out this less refined German spot just down the block. The bare-bones setting makes for a laid-back, chatty evening of drinking drafts of Konig Ludwig or Warsteiner Dunkel. True, the decorative Christmas lights and homemade Jger bombs $6 sign scream tackiness, but theres something refreshing about a place that looks like it hasnt changed since 1975.
content.property: Pool table Video/pinball games No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom

content.description: Pearls? Check. Bright pink lipstick? Check. Cup of coffee? Check. Cigarettes? Well, since the smoking ban, thats the one signature item that namesake owner Nelly is missing, and apparently, so are her Romanian regulars. The crowd has thinned since the ban, but youll still spot occasional handsome expats chowing down on earthy cuisine: platters of mititei (grilled sausages); fried kraut with bits of bacon fat; heaping bowls of polenta with feta; and excellent soups.
content.property: No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Video/pinball games Pool table Live bands Food served

content.description: Before you get schnitzel-faced at this friendly German restaurant, sample the dozen or so ales and lagers on tap. Dont know your Weizen from your Dunkel? The cute, German-accented waitresses are happy to make recommendations in between doling out soft pretzels with mustard and platters of sausages, cheese, pickles and olives. Stick-to-your-ribs entres include sauerbraten, tender, red winebraised beef served with cheesy spaetzle dotted with marjoram and onions. Before you roll out the door, have a bite or two of the housemade Sacher torte or apple strudel.
content.public-transport: El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 11, 80
content.property: Conversation friendly Extensive beer selection Good for groups No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Outdoor seating Food served

content.description: The most distinctive quality of this rather typical Lakeview bar is its shuffleboard table, a distraction hard to find in the big city. Otherwise, it has everything you could expect from a cozy hangout on a condo-lined street: standard liquor lineup, seven beers on tap, lots of dark wood, Golden Tee and a handful of lovey-dovey, brother and sistertype heterosexual couples.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Wellington. Bus: 11, 76, 77
content.property: After-work crowd Conversation friendly Video/pinball games No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom

content.description: On weekends, the gigantic patio is almost always packed to the brim. And everybody from badass bikers, crotch-rocket pretty boys, loud college kids and even normal folks (shocking, we know) apparently wants a seat. It offers about the best people-watching experience in the burbs.

If you think having a dive bar in Naperville is impossible, this spot just off the railroad tracks should change your mind. For the last 20 years, Orazio has been serving cheap brew and grub with a blue-collar, no-nonsense attitude. In this posh burb, the tacky Christmas lights, free popcorn, pitchers and Golden Tee won us over.

This spot claims to be a Korean/Japanese restaurant, but its nods to Korean cuisine include a few bibimbaps and complimentary banchan. The specialty is sushi, and its done well. The house roll takes a kitchen-sink approach, combining asparagus, smoked salmon, unagi, crabmeat, avocado, green onion and teriyaki sauce into one bloated, delicious bite. The Low Carb Makis lettuce, zucchini, avocado and crab was bland (no shock there), but the dragon roll (unagi, avocado, shrimp tempura) was crunchy, sweet and artfully plated. Dont bother with dessertthe Korean touches come full circle with a traditional cinnamon iced tea with the check.

The Solomons cookie warehouse has been on this stretch of Elston Avenue for years, fulfilling orders for its brisk mail-order business. For its first caf, it put a swingers-era spin on the place, pumping jazz into the room and selling custom-made fedoras. Start with a chunky chicken-salad sandwich or the tuna ciabatta with bacon if you must, but be aware that its all about the cookies here: dense raspberry brownies with a buttery cookie base, rich double-chocolate chip cookies that are simultaneously crispy and soft, and adorable thumbprint cookies filled with sweet jams.

Believe it or not, the cult item on this pubbish menu is not fried, greasy or full of cheeseits the salads. The $5 salad special on Tuesday nights (stereotypically dubbed girls night out) has made the big bowls of greens topped with avocado and portobello mushroom the hottest dish on the block. But bar-food aficionados need not worry: A trio of soft pretzels (two of which are filled, respectively, with marinara sauce and mozzarella) and the deep-fried Reuben rolls (a heart attack waiting to happen) fill that niche nicely. We found the pulled-pork sandwich way too sweet, however, so skip it and satisfy your sweet tooth with the warm, gooey skillet cookie.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 74

content.description: The thin-crust pizza at this sporty barwhich masquerades as a pizza parloris respectably flavorful, but for the residents of the surrounding apartment buildings, its just a prelude to other things. And by other things we mean what happens after people hang out on a breezy flower-lined sidewalk patio for hours drinking pitcher after pitcher of cheap beer only to wonder, Whats your place look like?
content.property: Sports bar Outdoor seating Food served

content.description: Every family has a creepy uncle, and we just found his hangout. Part liquor store, part bar, this oddly lit (fluorescent and incandescent lights?), worn-out corner tap has managed to rope in a small but loyal contingent of whiskery, sunken-faced older men. Some of them come to smoke hands-free and pump money into the Cherry Masters game, while the other smarmy fellers shoot pool waiting to ogle the one unfortunate woman who accidentally walks in here once a decade.

Of all the neighborhood bars trying to make rambling Ashland Avenue feel more homey, this gem is among the homiest. Art Deco touches abound, live music kicks up a little dust on the weekends and the mood is consistently upbeat, chatty and sociable. The twenty/thirtysomething regulars live on the cusptheyre not quite Lakeview and not quite Ravenswood, which suits us just fine.
content.public-transport: El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 9, 80

content.description: Sick of sandwiches and salad bars for lunch? If you can head south of the Loop for your midday meal, you can get a pretty tasty dose of Anglo-friendly Thai instead. All of the standards from curries to noodles are dependable, but we recommend starting with the delicate charred-squid salad and the miang sa-wana sweet, limey mess of dried pork, ginger and peanuts meant to be wrapped in lettuce leaves. To feed a fish craving, try the crispy catfish tossed with Thai eggplant and green beans in red-curry paste, and if your idea of curry involves tons of creamy coconut milk, the yellow gari with sweet potatoes and chicken is your fix.

Named for a province in the Mekong Delta, Ben Tre presents authentic, homestyle Vietnamese cooking (aimed at local Vietnamese families) in a bright, lime-green storefront. Pho, the classic beef-noodle soup, arrives properly soulful with a rich, aromatic broth and crunchy fresh herbs to sprinkle on top. The peanutty rice noodles with grilled beef and pork egg rolls (bun bo nuong cha gio) and a coconut-milk crpe studded with streaky pork belly and shrimp (banh xeo) exemplify the kitchens skill with traditional dishes, and the spot-on green-papaya salad (goi du du tom tit) sent us straight to the tropics.

Do you really need us to explain what the focus of this new bar is? We didnt think so. But just so you know, this enormous nightspot also offers food such as crab cake corn dogs and buffalo chicken lollipops.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Chicago. Bus: 11, 66, 156
content.property: After-work crowd Date place Good for groups Good for over-40 crowd Live bands Outdoor seating Food served Dress code Surprisingly good wine list Notable for cocktails Wheelchair-accessible bathroom No stairs to bathroom

content.description: Its hard to keep up with the back-of-the-house changes at this sultry lounge: First, chef Radhika Rad Desai took her Top Chef fame and hit the pavement. Then, after a brief and promising stint at the helm, her former sous chef Noah Sandoval peaced out, too. Now chef-consultant Jose Victorio has introduced a menu of contemporary American food with Peruvian and Asian twists such as tilapia ceviche dotted with Andean corn kernels and ahi tunatopped flatbread with wasabi aioli.

It takes balls for a wine bar to put a bottle from Ohio on its opening list, but as an extension of Boystown favorite minibar, balls are exactly what this bar will be full of. Its not that the beautiful, dimly lit room is something only gay guys can appreciaterather, its the puppy-dog eyes of the bartender that will pack them in.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 8, 22, 77
content.property: Wine bar Good for over-40 crowd Date place No steps at entrance Gay Food served Outdoor seating

content.description: While its name literally mirrors Moto, Otoms menu doesnt exactly reflect the extraterrestrial creations or sky-high prices of its adjacent sibling. Instead, exec chef Thomas Elliot Bowman looks to offer creative spins on comforting classics. A recent menu overhaul injected some flair in the form of pork chops with bacon bread pudding, coffee-crusted ribs and Bowmans answer to Roscoes: a chicken breast paired with a purple yam waffle. The bar staff goes toe-to-toe with local cocktail clubs, turning housemade bitters, fruit purees and infused liquors into the perfect precursor to an interesting meal.
content.public-transport: El: Green, Pink to Clinton. Bus: 8, 20

content.description: The payoff from the nautical theme hinted at by this blue-collar hangouts name is decidedly small. Aside from a light fixture made from a ships wheel and anchor-shaped coat hooks, this is your standard shot-and-a-beer dive. The crowd here is composed primarily of townies, with a bit of overflow from the U. of C. studentheavy crowd at nearby Jimmys.
content.property: Video/pinball games Darts No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Sports bar

content.description: Though the sign outside Uptowns newest bar and grill gets the vintage, 40s-ish feeling just right, you might want to keep your zoot suit at home: Inside, Rihanna is singing about um-ber-ellas and martinis are made with pomegranate juice. Skip the Reuben bites and goat cheese appetizer (the goat cheese, which claims to be seasoned with harissa, is particularly disappointing). Instead, head straight for the braised pork belly Cuban sandwich, the rich meat mingling with vinegary pickles to great success, or the chicken fried steak, which arrives topped with a thick gravy thats hard to stop eating (even though its clear that if you dont stop soon, its going to kill you).
content.property: Pool table Food served Video/pinball games
Good for dining at bar Outdoor seating

content.description: Of course the musicblues provided by live bands every nightis too loud to talk over; youre not supposed to talk over it. But you are supposed to drink, and if you want to have an easier time getting served, be nice to the ladies behind the barthey dont take any bullshit.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Red, Purple (rush hrs) to Fullerton. Bus: 8 Halsted, 74 Fullerton

content.description: This small, simple and slightly upscale BYOB is proving that creative and contemporary food isnt happening on just the North Side. Opening chef Thomas Eckert has moved on, but Rob Kurecki looks to fill the void with recent nods to fall that include poached pear salad with cranberry-bacon vinaigrette, brined pork chop with apple-cider sauce and sweet-potato polenta, and grilled walleye with roasted artichokes and spaghetti squash. Clean your plate and youve earned the seasonal sundae of spiced caramel-apple gelato topped with pumpkin and sauted apples.
content.public-transport: Bus: 9, 103, 112. Metra: Rock Island to 103rd St

content.description: Though this bar would undoubtedly like to think of itself as badass, we found nothing villainous about it. In fact, considering its proximity to the Loop, their penchant for playing good music (such as low-key indie-rockers the Good Life), and impressive eye for decor (note the Andy Warhol wallpaper), we thought this place was pretty sweet.
content.public-transport: El: Blue to LaSalle, Red to Harrison. Bus: 12, 24, 36

content.description: While this West Town bar is marketed as a hipster rock club, the slick design is much more West Elm than CBGB. But were not complaining; it turns out that partying like older, more affluent and slightly more sophisticated rock veterans is just as fun. Plus, anybody who favors seared duck over DJs can head over any Thursday night for a pop-up three-course dinner from Top Chef Dale Levitski.

This inconspicuous bar is equal parts after-work dive and Antiques Roadshow. Amid dusty knickknacks and bric-a-brac, the family who runs the place will pour you a stiff drink and then try to sell you a Civil Warera revolver, a set of buffalo-themed shot glasses or anything else lying aroundanything except for the patriarchs wall-mounted marlin and the Hamms sign hanging out front.

Although the redesign of the former Heaven on Seven into a traditional German beer hall is respectable, the fratesque Wrigleyville clientele works against its authenticity. There was plenty of imported Hofbrau to fill our mugs, but we couldnt shake the feeling we were on the abandoned set of The Man Show. If youre looking a spot to escape those Kimmel-esque ziggy zaggy chants, wed recommend the more tolerable biergarten.
content.property: Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Extensive beer selection No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Outdoor seating Food served

content.description: If youre having a severe case of Wrigleyville sports bar dj vu, this place wont cure what ails you. But if youre near the Friendly Confines and just looking for an exponentially more laid-back version of Hi-Tops, this is your place. The large, dimly lit, concrete-and-tile space may not be any more comfortable, but the slightly older, less annoyingly boisterous crowd is more interested in the score of the game than scoring.

Theres nothing really special about this Wrigleyville spot, but the daily deals draw us in like flies. With $1 domestic drafts on Mondays and $1 burgers on Thursdays (and plenty of other specials in between), its no wonder why this place is always packed.
content.property: Darts Karaoke Video/pinball games No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Sports bar Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Fireplace

content.description: DJs spinning and customers dancing in the dining room may not be for everyone, but if youre into that, youre in for a treat with this pan-Latin restaurants food. Much of the menus built for sharing, from combo platters of empanadas or ceviches to a four-course menu available to groups of four or more that offers grilled seafood paella, chimichurri-crusted beef tenderloin and more. Shared plates are all well and good, but as for the mojitosyoull want one (or three) of your own.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Chicago. Bus: 66
content.property: Notable wine list Good for groups Good for dining at bar Outdoor seating Private party room(s)

content.description: Youll want to stick around for a while here because the vibe is exactly right: classic old school but retro hip at the same time. To increase your hang time, order a bucket of domestics from bartender Nancy for $10, sidle up to the big padded bar, or snag a house stick and shoot some free pool.
content.public-transport: El: Blue to Irving Park. Bus: 53, 54A, 80
content.property: Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Video/pinball games Private party room(s) Pool table Karaoke Good for over-40 crowd Good for groups Conversation friendly After-work crowd Outdoor seating Late Night

content.description: Restaurants may come and go, but the Bagel never closes...it just moves locations. In its latest spot (the third since 1950), the deli has managed to bring a little Jewish curmudgeonliness to Boystown. So when youre at the take-away counter ordering your potato knish, or sitting in one of the booths dipping a fluffy roll into the magnificent, housemade chicken soup, you might have a brusque comment or two thrown your way. But this is to be expected. After all, the Bagel hasnt survived all these years by being nice.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 36, 77, 145, 146, 151

content.description: Owner Malcolm Molloy has that fresh-off-the-boat brogue that could charm the pants off your own mother. But please dont take this for one of your run-of-the-mill McIrish pubs. Bluegrass bands pluck away and locals might lift a Cosmo just as soon as a pint. So compared with most other pubs laying claim to the Emerald Isle, its a sea of tranquility.
content.property: Live bands No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Fireplace After-work crowd Food served Private party room(s) Good for groups

content.description: Yes, this is really happening: Youre sitting in a cheesy lounge named after the Threes Company hangout, on ugly office furniture, and youre listening to the theme from The Love Boat. The televisions really are showing programs (and commercials) from the early 80s, and your drink truly is called the Tony Danza Extravaganza. We know, we knowit feels like youre in some bad Reagan-era sitcoms. But youre not. Youre simply in a bar dedicated to them.
content.property: After-work crowd Food served Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Fireplace

content.description: Started by CEO Gregg Majewskia man who was instrumental in the Jimmy Johns chainthis local burger shack hopes to bring its Black Angus burgers, soft brioche buns and thick chocolate-peanut-butter shakes to all corners of the country. Maybe that accounts for the streamlined menu burgers, fries, shakes, and breakfast egg sandwiches are the only items on offer. But though the restaurant may not be cooking very many items, the things they are cooking theyre cooking well: burgers are thick and juicy, piled with fresh toppings and flanked by tasty (if McDonalds-ish) fries. So if this outpost isnt convenient, just waitwe have a feeling therell be one near you soon.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Adams

content.description: This former prepared foods shop is now a full-fledged restaurant thats carved out a niche with its reservation-only Saturday night underground dinners and tasting menuonly format (five courses for $55, eight for $85, 13 for $135). Value comes via the spots BYOB status, and dishes that put season at the forefront but are also consistently creative. The menu changes according to the chefs whim, but recent seasonal dishes include veal and coffee consomme with bittersweet chocolate, winter mushrooms and vichyssoise dumpling, marinated beets and poached fennel with cranberry, endive, Treviso, roasted pear and pomegranate dressing.

If you want to get a preview of the spot thats slated to open in December in West Town, head to the western burbs where chef Andy Park (of Starfish and Sushi Ai) unveils the menu that will eventually run at both spots. Per usual for Park, specialty maki with names like King Kong, Black Light and Firecracker dominate the menu, while a dozen cooked Japanese entrees and raw bar make up the rest.

This stalwart Pilsen hole-in-the-wall has moved into bigger, brighter digs, making it even more of an appealing alternative to the often long lines elsewhere in the neighborhood. The menu touts (with good reason) the toothsome, satisfyingly steamy tamales filled with tender stewed pork. But nearly everything is easy to like at these low prices, including carne asada with nice char flavor and a rich and complex poblano mole thats dished out over chicken or enchiladas.

Considering that this place is financially backed by a hip-hop entrepreneur, it should come as no surprise that the hip-hoppers who hang out at the former Dragon Room are hustling in everything from the music to fashion biz. The Zen monasteryinspired decor makes a chic backdrop, but a good portion of the club is often given over to VIP areas.
content.property: Private party room(s) Good for groups Late Night

content.description: Looking for an after-hours hetero hookup? When Wrigleyvilles bars begin to close, every inch of this cavernous, woody space attached to 1000 Liquors teems with an eager twentysomething crowd looking to maintain a domestic-beer buzz, down a couple $1 Jell-O shots (Fridays and Saturdays) and make that last-ditch effort to take home a hottie. Big Citys rowdy rep belies its late-night kitchen that serves better-than-average bar fare till 3am.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 22, 77
content.property: Good for groups No stairs to bathroom Late Night Food served

content.description: Connected to the populist Excalibur in a castlelike former churchbut marketed separatelythe expansive Vision has multiple rooms of varying size (the dome, sky and the penthouse) where DJs pump out different styles, from trance to techno to hip-hop. Celeb-connected promotions alternate with visits from big-name electronic stars.
content.property: Good for groups Private party room(s) Dress sharp Food served Fireplace Dress code

content.description: Just off of one of the busiest intersections in hipland, this multilevel venue has survived a few noise violations to become more relevant than ever. The upstairs is devoted to a live stage (viewable from a third-floor balcony), which features indie, garage, hip-hop and jammy acts nightly. The downstairs bar serves as a cozy dance den for locals to let loose. The weekly lineup includes hip-hop, reggae and some very fine mod and soul nights.

The wise-cracking wait staff is as much a part of the gimmick as the memorabilia and music dating from the 1950s to 1970s at this Disney-esque diner, which is a particularly fun visit for families but not necessarily anyone else. The foods almost an afterthought, but you cant go wrong with classic burger, French fries and gravy, and kitschy-cool desserts like the worlds smallest ice cream sundae (basically a shot glasssized portion).
content.property: Private party room(s) Cheap (entrees under $10) Kid-friendly

content.description: This slick, modern, multilevel Euro-style club in River North opened to much fanfare in 2004 and has kept clubbers busy ever since. On weekends, resident DJs, costumed dancers and powerful sound create a spectacular scene in the multiroom venue. Touring big-name DJs in techno and progressive house usually play Friday nights with residents spinning house and electro on Saturdays.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Chicago. Bus: 37, 66

content.description: Just a few years ago, this joint was raver HQ, but its since been transformed several times over. As of mid-2006, it features an Old World luxury feel, stunning bartenders and a glamorous, bottle serviceloving crowd. Upstairs, DJs accompanied by live percussion and tantalizing platformed dancers create a seductive if familiar playlist of hip-hop grinders.
content.property: Live bands Private party room(s) Dress sharp Dress code Good for groups

content.description: The legendary Cubs announcer may be gone, but his spirit lives on at his popular namesake eatery. These days Carays widow, Dutchie, greets patrons who continue to crowd the place during Cubs games as well as the off-season for gargantuan steaks (23-ounce poterhouse, anyone?) and classic Italian dishes like chicken Vesuvio, sausage and peppers and veal picatta. The walls are awash in memorabilia that will keep sports fans entertained for ages.
content.property: Food served No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Private party room(s) Good for groups

content.description: You cant judge a bar by its chipped glass brick veneer. Inside what seems like a total dive, youll be pleasantly surprised to find a clean, well-lit and friendly place. The barkeep in a cowgirl getup recently was kind enough to call the wife of a regular from Derry, Ireland, to come scoop up her sauced old man. Rows of aged look-alikes in flannel shirts huddle around Old Styles, while younger dudes play video games and foosball. Choose from the usual drafts or go for the damn fine Bloody Mary.
content.property: Darts Conversation friendly Good for over-40 crowd Video/pinball games Wheelchair-accessible bathroom

content.description: Awash in underwater blue-green hues and pulsing with ambient techno (lest we forget were in Boystown), this spot is a neighborhood draw for older gay couples and even older Lakeview lifers. While the solid menu offers few surprises, what Jacks does, it does well: a grilled calamari starter with spicy tomato-pesto thats as simple as it is delicious; and a four-inch-high ice-cream turtle pie thats a gut-busting ender.
content.public-transport: El: Red, Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Belmont. Bus: 8, 22, 77

content.description: It may not be as high up as other rooftop hotel barsits on the fifth floorbut this alfresco lounge has something else to help set it above the crowd: a thoughtful cocktail list, substantial bar snacks (like mini samosas) and, most important, open seats. Moviegoers should stop by on Sundays and Mondays for sundown screenings of pop culture classics like Ferris Buellers Day Off.
content.property: Notable for cocktails Outdoor seating Food served Date place

content.description: An Old Style sign in front? Thats a good omen. And half-pints to go? Thats a boozers paradise! Mix that in with a bartender who not only seems to know the regulars but also knows their drinks, and youve got a level of comfort and goodwill that makes for an excellent outing. A nod to the Irish name comes in the form of green walls and a neon shamrockand thats it. Still, well take hospitality over exaggerated brogues any day.
content.property: Conversation friendly Darts Good for over-40 crowd Pool table Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Food served

content.description: The menu at this sprawling, festive Mexican joint is comprised of page after page of enchiladas, fajitas and nachos. But all that food plays second fiddle to their boozy, signature swirl magaritas.

Laying claim to being Lincoln Parks oldest Irish pub isnt what made us fall for this bar. Instead, it was the charming, airy space with exposed brick, roaring fireplace and original artwork. Of course, having 17 taps (two dedicated to Guinness) on hand didnt hurt either. If you can, pop in on a slower night when the joint isnt overrun with Trixies.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus 8, 76
content.property: Pool table Live bands No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Sports bar Fireplace Food served

content.description: Not only is the plush rooftop patio with a 40-foot bar, sharp sound system, sofas and stools perfect for a nightcap (or night-starter), its great for sashimi as well. Were not crazy about the mushy rice, so skip the nigiri in favor of slick cuts of the days fresh catch. For a break from the mundane happy-hour rituals that abound downtown, the $10 bento box promo offered from 5 to 7pm is a good deal, but its on Wednesdays after 10pm that this slick spot turns booty-rific for Favela Nights, a weekly party driven by Rio rhythms and a rotating cast of performance artists.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Merchandise Mart. Bus: 65, 125, 156
content.property: Food served Outdoor seating Views Notable for cocktails Date place Live bands No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Private party room(s) Good for groups
Private party room(s) Vegetarian-friendly Outdoor seating Views Good for dining at bar Good for groups Late-night dining

content.description: When young college grads move to the city, this Wrigleyville sports bar/dance club is their first stop. The TVs blasting sports, greasy bar food and weekend dancing upstairs can rival any campus bar on a good Thursday night. In fact, the only thing missing is the line for keg stands.
content.openingtimes: WedFri 5pm2am; Sat 5pm3am. Opens two hours before Cubs home games MonSun and one hour before Bears games Sun.
content.property: No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Sports bar Good for groups Food served

content.description: Nothings changed much in the 76 years since this Old Town rib institution first startedpacking in the crowds, and thats okay with us. Once in a while, well still cram our way into the old tavern to wait among the masses (no reservations are taken) for the falling-off-the-bone, baked-then-grilled babybacks with a side of the zesty (really tangy) sauce. Add a side of the pork-flecked baked beans and an Old Style, and its a perfect Chicago meal.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Sedgwick. Bus: 72, 156

content.description: Perhaps best known for its wine list, this quiet restaurant on the first floor of the Margarita European Inn may still be Evanstons best-kept secret. Because in addition to the extensive, all-Italian wine list, theres also a list of well-executed, appetite-inducing apertivos. And theres even food to go with itdishes like stalks of spring asparagus paired with a nutty Parmesan and lively tomato fonduta; housemade ravioli stuffed with a sweet-and-savory combination of caramelized onions, pancetta and spring peas; and perfectly juicy slices of lamb lined with dark, flavorful char marks from the grill.
content.public-transport: El: Purple to Davis. Bus: 93, 201, 205, Pace 213
content.property: Notable wine list Vegetarian-friendly Outdoor seating Fireplace Suburban

content.description: The namesake chef behind this 12-year-old restaurant knows a thing or two about tapasthe Spaniard was the opening chef for Caf Ba-Ba-Reeba!, Chicagos first tapas spot. Here at his solo venture (where Saturdays are raucous and Sundays are serene), little has changed in a city thats in the grips of small-plates mania. The classics still rule the show: salty-sweet bacon-wrapped dates in roasted red-pepper sauce, killer garlic potatoes, crusty bread topped with tangy tomatoes and whisper-thin jamn serrano, and perfectly grilled shrimp in garlic butter. Skip the too-rich goat cheeseeggplant rolls and the oversauced spicy potatoes, but dont miss the velvety flan.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 22, 36, 74

content.description: There are endless Irish pubs in the city to choose from, and this one, with its dark wood interior and menu of typical pub grub (fish-and-chips, corned beef and cabbage) blends in with the rest of them. So why patronize this one over the others? Because its in the Chicago Hilton. You never know when a visiting Irishman from the Old Country is going to walk inside.
content.property: Live bands No stairs to bathroom No steps at entrance Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Food served

content.description: This warm, casual Edgewater hangout (formerly known as Sizzle on Broadway) is a great place to cozy up to a fireplace with a brewski and a plate of cheese fries during the winter months, but the beer garden also packs em in during the dog days. And despite the hard-rock hits of the 80s soundtrack, the eclectic clientelewhose attire during our last visit ranged from chunky glasses and pompadours to jerseys and Afrosis refreshingly chill.
content.property: Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Sports bar No stairs to bathroom No steps at entrance Fireplace Food served Outdoor seating

content.description: Most people dont end up at this hard-to-get-to music venue unless theyre seeing a live show, but the adjacent pub is actually worth a visit on its own. Sunday nights traditional Irish jam session lends support to the woody pubs Emerald Isle vibe; ditto for the respectable shepherds pie. Cheapskates can seek out a spot on the patio and hear the indoor shows for free.
content.public-transport: El: Blue to Addison. Bus: 82 Kimball/Homan, 152 Addison
content.property: Live bands Private party room(s) Wheelchair-accessible bathroom No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Outdoor seating Food served

content.description: If youve been searching for a hideout, this shadowy, windowless bar crammed between the Sheridan Red Line station and a liquor store is virtually invisible. Theres no deli to speak of, so the scant, mostly Latino clientele divide their attention between the pool table in the back and the shrill telenovelas playing on the TV at the bar. Invisibility has its price.
content.property: No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Pool table
Sports bar Wheelchair-accessible bathroom No stairs to bathroom No steps at entrance Darts Food served

content.description: This new sporty-chic hot spot is hardly recognizable as the location that only recently housed Pops for Champagne. Even though the left side of the dual bar setup may be packed with loud, flat-screenfocused Colts and Hoosiers fans, the earth-tone stained-glass lighting and large windows in front give the surroundings a calm, open feel. If thats still too much to handle, the clientele on the less-rowdy right side is (just slightly) older, better dressed and wants to know more about you than just your sports loyalties.
content.property: No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Sports bar Outdoor seating Fireplace Food served

content.description: Theres very little about this classic tavern thats, well, little. Hordes of sports fans fill the cavernous indoor space to watch the game on several jumbo screens, drooling for the heaping burger-and-fries platters, generously cut steaks and big salads. And when the weather allows, tables are available outdoors and on the expansive, scenic rooftop, where bands occasionally perform.
content.property: Views Sports bar Live bands Video/pinball games Wheelchair-accessible bathroom No stairs to bathroom No steps at entrance Outdoor seating Food served

content.description: Quintessential Chicago, this narrow 35-year-old storefront is a perfect pit stop on the other type of pub crawl. You know, the one where you just want cheap liquor ($2 bottles of beer), cool jukebox tunes (the bartender will happily match you dollar for dollar) and a relaxing place to rest your weary head (try a picnic table on the outdoor patio).
content.property: Classic Chicago spot Outdoor seating Pool table Video/pinball games Darts

content.description: Banking on its buildings supposed history as a former Capone speakeasy, this Loop joint draws its share of hungry tourists whoalong with their beer, burger and friesget a lunchtime eyeful of Chicago history via the photos and newspaper clippings plastered on the walls. Its downtown location situated beside the elevated tracks also makes this a great place for a little heel kicking and tie loosening after work.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Adams
content.property: No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Good for groups Classic Chicago spot Food served

content.description: This spotless bar has been a Rogers Park fixture for ten years, and were thinking its due to the free barbecue doled out 58pm daily during the summer and the $1.25 drafts. Dont be surprised to see a blue-collar regular stroll in with 20 pounds of raw chicken and commence grillingits just a help-yourself kinda joint.

The torchbearers for authentic indie eateries are recommending an LEYE Chinese spot? Well, yes, but with caveats. As opposed to the pan-Asian Big Bowl, the theme here is regional Chinese, with renditions of Mongolian, Cantonese, Shanghai and Szechuan dishes. The menu is massive, so sip on the slusheelike, citrus vodkaspiked, frozen ginger ale while perusing. Best bets include crispy cubes of sesame-coated tofu drizzled with garlic sauce; salty-sweet star anisebraised pork with scallion pancakes for wrapping; and shrimp with wheat noodles and mushrooms in a spicy chile sauce. Skip the fried rice and beef dishes unless you want to regret not making it to Chinatown.

Whether you play sports or just watch them on TV, this Beverly institution has got you covered. Youd probably have to become a die-hard regular to join the bar-sponsored rec teams, but if youre just looking to play some darts and catch the game, everyones welcomeso long as you dont start talking smack about the Sox.
content.property: Sports bar Darts No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Food served Private party room(s)

content.description: Smack in the middle of Indo/Pak territory, this tiny German-style hideaway has been plugging away since 72. Bartenders flip the TV channels back and forth between basketball games and The Simpsons, but if that doesnt interest you, theres free pool, karaoke on random nights and a stash of frisky regulars to keep you occupied.
content.property: Pool table Darts Video/pinball games No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Live bands

content.description: Just like every other Lakeview bar, this one caters to the young professional crowd; hence, the menu is full of better-than-typical pub food, including a grilled tuna-steak sandwich and filet mignon. But it isnt until the warmer months, when the outdoor beer garden is opened, that Fizz really starts sizzling.
content.property: Live bands Karaoke No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Video/pinball games Sports bar Outdoor seating Food served

content.description: Theres something endearing about a bar named for a 1908 New York version of Steve Bartman; Fred Merkle wrecked a victory for New York by failing to touch base in a playoff game against the Cubs. Not surprisingly, this watering hole bleeds true Cubby blue, complete with pennants and pics of old-time ballplayers. The taps lack heartier brews, focusing on the lighter lagers for drink-em-down sports fans. The best deal is the $2 Honey Weisse Leinies on Thursdays.
content.property: Good for over-40 crowd Live bands Sports bar Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Food served Video/pinball games

content.description: Dude, are you working on Friday night? Because were coming back here and totally getting sloshed, we overheard one dude say to his friend at this bar attached to the Pasta Bowl. And thats what happens here. College kids get wasted and eat cheap bar food while Franz Ferdinand and the Killers blast from the jukebox.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 22, 36, 151
content.property: Video/pinball games Sports bar No steps at entrance Wheelchair-accessible bathroom No stairs to bathroom Food served

address.street: Leo Burnett Bldg, 35 W Wacker Dr
Leo Burnett Bldg, 35 W Wacker Dr

content.public-transport: El: Brown, Green, Orange, Purple (rush hrs) to State.

content.description: Grab a stool and make an Irish lass or lad of yourself. The friendly staff, warmly-lit room, and Dublin brews on tap are worth a visit alone, but even better is the lightly beer-battered catch of the day. Wash it down with a few proper pints that should get you swaying if the live bluegrass doesnt.
content.property: Conversation friendly Extensive beer selection Good for groups Good for over-40 crowd Live bands No steps at entrance Private party room(s) Outdoor seating Food served

content.description: Picture the Exit regulars from the good old days (before the Golden Tee and sparkle tops showed up), add a sleeker red and black decor, one of the best jukeboxes in town, and a separate plush room for dining and youve just about got this industrial-outskirts rock bar. The grub isnt worth a separate trip, but the bar scene is a preferred meet-up spot for the ink-and-metal crowd.
content.public-transport: El: Green, Pink to Ashland. Bus: 9 Ashland, 65 Grand
content.property: Live bands No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Food served

content.description: On weekends, the small crowd at this dodgy, dimly lit mans bar can make it feel downright convivial. Otherwise the faded watering hole is surely where Edgewaters gentrification will hold its last stand. Lonely? Drop a few quarters in the jukebox and pour your heart out along with Dolly as she begs Jolene not to take her man.

With the waitresses brandishing brogues along with the shepherds pie and Guinness pints, you know this Lakeview Irish pub is the real deal. Besides potpies, fish and chips, and other Emerald Isle imports, everyone from neighborhood families to tipsy Cubs fans stops in for the above-par bar grub. You cant go wrong with the char-grilled skirt-steak sandwich, turkey-and-corned-beef Reubens, and Bass Alebattered onion rings the size of your head.
content.property: Good for dining at bar Cheap (entrees under $10) Outdoor seating

content.description: The doors arent open as late as its subterranean sibling on Diversey, but the amenities of this location trump its truncated hours. Located just one block north of the Friendly Confines, the dual bars and large patio draw out the pre- and postgame Cubs fanatics who take comfort knowing that no matter which glazed-wood table at which they choose to eat hot wings, theyll be just feet away from at least one of the two-dozen TVs.
content.property: Good for groups No steps at entrance Wheelchair-accessible bathroom No stairs to bathroom Sports bar Outdoor seating Food served

content.description: Skip the mediocre food and the worse service at the Heartland Caf and head straight to this Rogers Park institutions bar. If the extensive selection of $4 import beersincluding Hoegaardens perfect-for-summer white aleis too overwhelming, the bartender is happy to make recommendations. Its enough to overlook the constantly wafting incense. Eh, hippies.
content.property: Live bands No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Sports bar Food served

content.description: Although it has such a prime Chicago locationthe windows look out on Michigan Avenueits hard to think of this newly face-lifted bar inside China Grill as global. Even the enormous half globe that hovers above diners in the bar doesnt do it. But then youll get the steep bill for all those delicious cocktails (we like the Orange Blossom mojito) and youll get it: Its the prices that are out of this world.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Green, Orange, Purple (rush hrs), Red to State/Lake. Bus: 2, 3, 10, 26, 143, 144, 145, 146, 147, 151, 157
content.property: No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Food served

content.description: In as much as T.G.I. Fridays has the ridiculously misguided intention of creating an atmosphere as carefree as a Friday night, this bilevel Loop joint (known to some as the Demon Den because of its location on DePauls downtown campus) simply provides a friendly environment for evading your responsibilities on that oh-so-dreaded first day of the workweek. Ease back into the 9-to-5 routine with a few Millers and some solid pub grub.
content.public-transport: El: Red, Blue to Jackson. Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Adams
content.property: After-work crowd No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Conversation friendly Sports bar Food served

entry.name: The Lobby Court Bar at the Renaissance Chicago Hotel

version.name: The Lobby Court Bar at the Renaissance Chicago Hotel

content.description: Want to keep your seat on that comfortable couch? Want to keep on taking in the view of the river while enjoying this bars impeccable service? Fine. But in case anybody asks, youre a guest of the hotel, room 2213, and youd like another gin and tonic.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Green, Orange Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to State; Red to Lake

content.description: The idea behind this second location of the Chicago Avenue classic was to follow the regulars who relocated to Bucktown. But now there are so many new people watching the game, nursing a Point Pale Ale and hanging out the garage window to harass passersby, that the old regulars may have a hard time finding a seat.

This amber-tinted lounge is certainly chic and a bit upscale, but somehow lacks the stuffiness usually associated with those spots. Its restaurant-worthy menu is enhanced by the attentive, conversational staff and colorful paintings by local artists that dot the bars exposed brick walls. The result is a laid-back atmosphere that draws an eclectic mix of artists and nine-to-fivers.
content.property: After-work crowd Extensive beer selection Dress sharp No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Outdoor seating Food served

content.description: Years from now, cultural historians will try to pinpoint the moment when Wicker Park finally gave in to all the sparkly tank tops. And when they do, this palindrome-obsessed, bilevel barwith its drink list by mixologist Bridget Albert and stuffed olive plateswill be the bar theyll finger.
content.openingtimes: Mon, Wed, Thu, Fri 9pm4am; Sat 9pm5am (closed Sun, Tue)
content.property: Pool table Notable for cocktails Late Night Food served

content.description: The sign out front has a shamrock where the apostrophe is supposed to be, hinting that its an Irish dive bar where locals linger and the bartender is loose with free shots. If thats not compelling enough, you could always come here for inspiration for your next novel, Shooting the Shit in Chicago.
content.public-transport: El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 9, 50, 80

content.description: Pop into any bar boasting seven days of karaoke and youre likely to hear more than your fair share of Bon Jovi. Thankfully, this Lakeview parrot-head hangout offers ample patio space (heated in the winter) to escape juiced-up choruses of Sweet Caroline. This place is good for satiating drunk American Idol desires, but bad for house cocktails. Stick to your beer of choice over Todds odd concoctions.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 8, 22, 77
content.property: No stairs to bathroom Karaoke Outdoor seating Food served

content.description: A college campus is hardly complete without a comfortable pub where the overworked and underpaid can reliably find their friends. Luckily for students living in Loyolas downtown dorms, this sporty, high-ceilinged watering hole just a books throw north of campus offers about 20 beers and a menu of burgers, thin-crust pizzas and a build-your-own sub sandwich that beats the hell out of any cafeteria.
content.property: Wheelchair-accessible bathroom No stairs to bathroom No steps at entrance Sports bar Good for groups Private party room(s) Food served Fireplace

content.description: The Dude himself would appreciate the sizable White Russian served at this new Polish-American bar in the former, fabled Brick & Beam. The price is right for a clean, well-lit, smoke-free space, with exposed brick walls, two large flat-screens, plenty of Old World charm, and sweet-potato fries and pierogi to satiate the munchies.
content.public-transport: El: Blue to Jefferson Park. Bus: 54A, 81
