content.property: Conversation friendly Good for groups Good for over-40 crowd Live bands No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Notable for cocktails Private party room(s) Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Food served

content.description: The name of this new bi-level lounge suggests its a place youd go only after youve exhausted your first choice. But to us, the warm wood tones and comfortable leather club chairs seem ripe for the nights first stop, a place to grab a cocktail and get out before the crowds set in.

These four levels of 4am debauchery in the heart of Old Town yield exactly the kind of crowd you would expect on the weekends: young, loud and drunk, with shots spilled on their shirts. But on weeknights its a gathering spot for older gentlemen hoping to grab a Scotch, a good seat to watch the game and possibly a little bit of that weekend energy.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Sedgwick. Bus: 11, 72, 156
content.property: Pool table Video/pinball games Sports bar Late Night Food served Karaoke

content.openingtimes: Sun, TueFri 4pm2am; Sat 11am3am; Mon 5pm2am (opens at 11am if the Cubs are at home)
content.property: Darts Pool table Video/pinball games No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Sports bar

content.description: This Sox Side Bridgeport dive is about as polar opposite from a Cubby bar as it gets; pre-game revelry typically consists of a couple of dusty-jeans locals holding a burping contest while regaling each other with slurred jokes. But the TVs are always on sports, pitchers are cheap, and you can always find a table for post-game celebration. Plus, theres a dandy little stage (occasionally used for blues jams on Thursdays) should inspiration strike.

At this garden-level watering hole, the brown leather couches and bar-side high chairs are where young locals plop down, whereas the pure-blooded Irish set up camp over by the back bar and its adjacent pub games. The line between crowds gets blurrier when overloads of Harp and U2 are thrown into the mixtwo things on which both crowds can agree.
content.property: Darts Pool table Video/pinball games Sports bar No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom

content.description: This laid back River North pub boasts Seriously. Ridiculously. Over-the-Top Hot Wings, two big patios, and now, a humble reverence for the locals that made the bar the neighborhood joint it is. Every Tuesday night, Jakes is offering $2 burgers for customers living in the 60610 and 60611 zip codes. Even if your place isnt around the corner, $2 PBR and Old Style cans are also available Tuesday nights, for drinkers from every zip code.
content.property: Private party room(s) Darts Video/pinball games Wheelchair-accessible bathroom No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Outdoor seating Fireplace Food served

content.description: When you begin brunch by showing your ID at the door, you know youre in the right place for a Bloody Mary. Spicy and sweet, garnished with salami and completed with a beer back, its practically a meal in itself. Dont let that distract you from the food, however. Corned-beef hash is packed with onionsadd a little salt and the flavors jump off the fork. Breakfast tacos are a good way to spice up your egg intake. And the Spokes signature fatboy burgers are thick, juicy and perfectly tender. Take it down with a pile of those fantastic fries and youll be living proof that you are what you eat.

This long, modern room is decked out with sleek, low-lying furniture, and is the perfect spot for bottle service and canoodling with other Euro-minded audiophiles. Guys would be smart to wait until Thursday to drop by, thoughthats when models get in for free. If youre going to press your luck, it might as well be with a model.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Chicago. Bus: 66, 125
content.property: Dress code No stairs to bathroom Private party room(s)

content.description: If youre not familiar with the glorious convenience of the slashy (a.k.a. liquor store/bar), this old-man haunt is a good introduction. Sure, it looks like your average corner store: Cases of beer, liquor and cheap wine surround retail shelves stocked with junk food in a fluorescent-lit room. But wander toward the dimly lit back of the store and youll find yourself in bar country wondering whether or not you should have a couple before heading home with a fresh six-pack.

Sure, it might look like any other neopub replete with a half-dozen flat-screens, more than ten brewskies on tap (including the much ballyhooed Holy Grail Ale) and Golden Tee for the armchair-athlete set. But look past that for the friendly vibe coming from the barkeep and crispy wings and cheese curds (!) coming from the kitchen. And no one from this hoods gonna argue with $5 Jger Bombs.
content.property: Video/pinball games No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Sports bar Outdoor seating

content.description: This entry-level club in Lincoln Park benefits from the postcollegiate and young professional crowd thats bored with bars and pubs. It looks like a classy bar up front and a Miami hot spot in back (think typical Irish pub meets Nate Berkus). DJs spin surefire hip-hop party music to fun-loving young folks. The clubbing thing happens in the back, but you cant hear or see it from the front, leaving you free to enjoy your gin and tonic in peace if you wish.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 8 Halsted, 11 Lincoln/Sedgwick
content.property: Late Night Private party room(s) Good for groups

content.description: South Loop Boys Club is more like it. This is the place where local bachelors and jocks from surrounding universities come to get hammered on one of the 80 kinds of beer, scarf down a pile of greasy food, watch the game and, of course, try to snag the waitresss phone number.
content.property: Darts Video/pinball games No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Sports bar Late Night Food served

content.description: Part garden patio, part sidewalk cafe, the outdoor space at this stalwart is a visual reminder of Wicker Park's shifting population. Artsy musician types and new parents rub elbows early, but once the sun sets, it's prime territory for picking up virtually any kind of local. The surprisingly tasty pub grub is served late, and regardless of the Golden Tee and sports-tuned TVs, the meathead quotient remains low.

You get your moneys worth at this Southport sports bar and grillbut considering that every dish here costs five bucks, thats not really saying much. We give the place props for their marketing skillsthe menu is a great way to get people in the door and spend money on drinks. Their cooking skills, on the other hand, could use some work. No matter how simple (decently spiced tilapia tacos) or ambitious (rotisserie pork), the food tastes, well, cheap. But most of it provides a solid base for drinking, and at the end of the day its only a few dollars...so how can we complain about that?

As in a middle-school art classroom, youll find row upon row of paintings on butcher paper covering the bars bronze-plated, mosaic-tile walls. Hood-dwelling thirtysomethings are free to venture over to the easel and, with in-house supplies, create a work of their own twisted genius. Whether its Surrealist, Abstract, Cubist or Impressionist, the more you drink, the better it will look.
content.property: Conversation friendly Date place Good for groups No stairs to bathroom Pool table Outdoor seating

content.description: Just a drunken stumble from the Grand Red Line station, this sporty brewpub offers six house-brewed beers to sip while watching your team on more than a dozen TVs. Perhaps jealous of its new, fancier sibling RB Grille, the Brewery recently underwent renovations, replacing tube TVs and pool tables with flatscreens and a live-music stage.
content.property: Private party room(s) Pool table Sports bar Wheelchair-accessible bathroom No stairs to bathroom No steps at entrance Outdoor seating Food served Video/pinball games Karaoke

content.description: If you can ignore the chain-mail curtains on the windows, we highly recommend this Omni Hotel lounge for its cocktails. The cucumber gimlet and pink grapefruit Cosmo are both deliciousand strong enough that youll cease to care that they cost twice the amount they should.
content.openingtimes: MonThu noonmidnight; Fri noon1am; Sat 11am1am; Sun 11ammidnight
content.property: Private party room(s) Notable for cocktails Food served

content.description: R.I.P. Rose and Crown, viva Bridget McNeill's. Sitting at the ground level of the Bel Harbor condominiums is this facelifted version of its English pub predecessor. The owners have replicated the look and feel of an actual Emerald Isle tavern just fine, but without any shit-faced Irishmen passed out at the bar, it never quite feels like the real deal.
content.property: Pool table Video/pinball games No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Sports bar Fireplace Food served

content.description: Our favorite part of this Bucktown corner dive is Dawn, the superfriendly bar maid and confidant. She can effortlessly toss out Leinies Honey Weiss and get the days gossip handed down from her faithful barflies. When you hop in to wind the evening down with some not-so-competitive darts, be sure to say hi.
content.property: Darts Video/pinball games No stairs to bathroom Sports bar

content.description: There is a time and a place for nearly everything; it's just too bad that the time and place for Fearon's is in the rearview mirror by about 10 years. Can we please stop relying on the McIrish pub mold, people? Guinness on tap? Check. Dark wood tones and plasma-screen TVs? Check. "Juke Box Hero" on the juke and a barmaid that sits on the other side of the bar instead of asking about your next one? WTF?!
content.property: Video/pinball games No stairs to bathroom Sports bar Outdoor seating Food served

content.description: Luca Corazzina has taken over the reins at this Italian stalwart now that chef Dean Zanella has moved on. While the changes have been minimal on paper, a recent visit yielded an unremarkable dinner, revealing that the real draws now are the cocktails and the desserts. At the bar, cucumber pure makes a Tom Collins even more refreshing and muddled navel oranges transport a mint julep from the South to southern Italy. Meanwhile, pastry chef Kimberly Schwenke keeps season in mind without losing creativity by topping brandied fig crostata with pistachio gelato and a rich chocolate fig sauce and pairing silky ricotta cheesecake with roasted pears, rum raisins and polenta cookies.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Pink, Orange, Purple (rush hrs) to Washington/Wells. Bus: 14, 20, 56, 60, 124, 157
content.property: Private party room(s) Vegetarian-friendly Outdoor seating

content.description: No, youre not seeing things. The food coming out of the kitchen at this Devon eatery is indeed heading two ways: Tandoor-grilled meat kebabs and other Northern Indian classics beeline through a hallway to the adjacent sibling spot Viceroy, while vegetarian South Indian eats are showcased here under the newer moniker Sagar. Technically, you can order Viceroys menu here as well, but the draw is really the impressive dosas, from the spinach-slathered, three-foot-long palak masala dosa to the lacy cream-of-wheat version dubbed rava. With the excellent coconut chutney and vegetable-dal sambar soup alongside, its a meal in itself.

The original cro in the dance-club franchise (there are now crobar outposts in Miami, New York and South America) was remodeled a few years ago with a South Beachmeetsindustrial materials look. These days, the club hosts everything from a midweek Latin night to visits from big-name techno, house and trance DJs. But a typical weekend night features residents hammering with au courant dance tracks while girls on platforms demonstrate the finer points of deca dancing.
content.public-transport: El: Red to North/Clybourn. Bus: 8 Halsted, 72 North
content.property: Private party room(s) Late Night Wheelchair-accessible bathroom No stairs to bathroom No steps at entrance

entry.name: The Drawing Room at Le Passage

version.name: The Drawing Room at Le Passage

content.description: Now that Three-Headed Productions has successfully made Le Passage relevant again, chef Nick Lacasse intends to keep it that way. Hes ushering in the warm weather with seasonal dishes like a pasta with morels, ramps and chvre, while halibut gets smoked potato puree, creamed arugula and grilled zucchini. Mixologist Charles Joly has adjusted his culinary cocktail menu to be just as bright, with drinks like the Lost in Translation, a mix of Yamazaki 12-year whiskey, green-tea ginger syrup, yuzu, grapefruit and fresh basil. Drink up.
content.property: Good for dining at bar Late-night dining

content.description: It can get pretty crazy inside this long-running piano barbig spenders in loosened ties trading Sinatra verses with wide-eyed tourists while fierce cougars prowl the room looking for a boy toy to sink their claws into. Skip all that, or at least cut it down to a low roar, by grabbing one of the few tables on the sidewalk patio. The people-watching is well worth the tab for pricey cocktails.
content.property: Piano bar Private party room(s) Live bands Outdoor seating Food served

content.description: Ten years from now, when this strip of Armitage is populated with coffee shops and vintage clothing stores, this old-school, soul recordplaying, classic cocktailmixing bar will be overrun with hipsters vying for their turn in the photo booth. Start hanging out here now so you can say you knew it in the good old days.
content.property: Notable for cocktails Outdoor seating Extensive beer selection

content.description: If the nearby Globe Pub and Silvies Lounge are headquarters for soccer hooligans and indie rockers, respectively, then this spot, with its postwar charm, is a nest for frisky fortysomethings. You wouldnt believe how many singles we saw talking over tinis in the low light, with a live laid-back jazz trio filling in those otherwise uncomfortable getting-to-know-you silences.
content.public-transport: El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 11, 50, 80
content.property: Food served Good for over-40 crowd Conversation friendly

content.description: You can still see the hole in the floor where the drum circle used to be, but this place has shed all the Kumbaya leftover from previous tenant, Rhythm. Instead of hippies and patchouli, the place is home to urban couples savoring the dim, mod interior and DJ-driven beats as they get ready to continue their night somewhere on Fulton Street.
content.property: Food served Surprisingly good wine list Extensive beer selection

content.description: The primary purpose of a wine bar is to drink, of course. But because drinking on an empty stomach is a one-way ticket to drunk-dialing your ex, falling asleep in the bathroom or other drunken drama, were thankful this spot puts just as much focus on the food. The housemade empanada hides earthy mushrooms inside its flaky crust; hefty crab cakes get a golden exterior of panko crumbs; a caprese salad gets a twist by using blue cheese instead of mozz; and a pizza topped with caramelized onions and pears goes perfectly with an off-dry riesling (while also creating a base to soak it up).
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Merchandise Mart; Red to Grand. Bus: 22, 36, 62, 65
content.property: Wine bar Food served Outdoor seating Late Night Private party room(s) Wheelchair-accessible bathroom
Live bands Wheelchair-accessible bathroom No steps at entrance Fireplace Food served

content.description: This rustic, knotty-pine joint has such a high degree of patriotism on display that it not only has two large American flags up, but a boycott France sign, too. Its pretty much a shot-and-beer venue, with domestic bottles for $2.50, imports for $3. Specialty drinks are not a specialty, but the bartender aims to please, so dont be shy about asking. Theres an interesting old-fashioned phone booth with a light that goes on when you open the door, but better bring your cell; the phone itself is out of service.
content.property: Conversation friendly Good for over-40 crowd Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Food served

content.description: This Far North Side chapter of the Mullens fraternity is for those who want their bench-pressed, score-obsessed sports bar, but dont want to jockey for a seat in the jockstrap that is Wrigleyville. With eight TVs and an abundance of booths, theres plenty of sight lines and legroom for the medley of postgame softball leaguers and dart-lobbing locals, who all enjoy a more civilized type of testosterone.
content.property: Darts Conversation friendly Extensive beer selection Good for groups Good for over-40 crowd Karaoke No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Pool table Sports bar Video/pinball games Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Food served
Live bands Wheelchair-accessible bathroom No stairs to bathroom No steps at entrance

content.description: No, this bare-bones boozery doesnt ooze cuddly as its name would suggest. But for the blue-collar folk from this industrial nabe and the ostensibly unemployed who line the dimly lit bar by noon, perhaps a cheap mug of Old Style and the open ear of a familiar bartender is as comforting as any stuffed animal.

Many a North Side hipster calls this friendly, laid-back bastion of bargain booze a second home. Little here is touched by time: The 50s-era sign still hangs outside, a jukebox is packed with British Invasion gems, and its one of the few places where you can still grab a six-pack on your way out the door.
content.property: No stairs to bathroom Pool table Video/pinball games No steps at entrance

content.public-transport: El: Blue to Jefferson Park. Bus: 54A, 81

content.property: Pool table Darts Sports bar Food served

content.description: Stretching the northerly boundaries of Cubbie territory nearly to Irving Park Road, this dive-among-dives has only one thing characteristically Wrigleyville about it: its name. The first sign: the bartenders missing her four front teeth. The second sign: The low, garage bandready stage with cowboy hats atop the amplifiers. The final clue: the refreshing absence of loud, red-faced bros and their stumbling Botox broads.
content.property: After-work crowd Conversation friendly No stairs to bathroom No steps at entrance Live bands Darts

content.description: Way out west but looking east, Club Euro fills with Eastern Europeans during live rock and dance parties. Singles sweat it out on the dance floor in their swank duds, scoping the scene for kindred spirits. The banging techno nights bring in a more diverse cross-section of beat lovers.

Order up a bucks worth of nuts from the stylized nut hut behind the bar, but be warned that some assertive squirrels might be hanging around the back door looking for offerings. While youre being entertained at whats surely the only bar in town where you might come across live squirrels, take down $3 domestics and chat with the bartender about that glass-enclosed 1873 Winchester rifle behind the bar or those two dozen hanging ceramic steins. If you luck out, the owner might be serving her Texas-style chili or juicy chicken.
content.property: Wheelchair-accessible bathroom No stairs to bathroom No steps at entrance Conversation friendly Darts Good for over-40 crowd Pool table Video/pinball games Food served

content.description: Not to be confused with the Underground, the much buzzed-about River North bunker bar, this no-less-subterranean spot is more about the stage than the scene. Thursday through Saturday, local and touring acts of all musical stripesfrom jazz to punktake the small, barely elevated stage, and on the off nights, theres always pool.
content.property: Pool table Live bands Sports bar

content.description: A deserted stretch of Northwest Highway isnt what you would call charming surroundings, but it is the kind of stretch that needs a cozy escape. Raised booths flanking a fireplace facilitate intimate conversations over pints of imported ale, while the battered old bar encourages drinking with the friendly blue-collar crowd. That Guinness getcha hungry? Dig into menu highlights like shepherds pie.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Wellington. Bus: 8, 11, 76
content.property: Conversation friendly No stairs to bathroom Extensive beer selection Food served Video/pinball games

content.description: For a pretty modest place, youll find a decent selection of pilsners on tap here (including Urquell, Stella Artois and Dab), and for only a quarter more than the $2.50 domestic price. Stout fans will appreciate that the tenders also know how to pour a velvety smooth Guinness. Beer aside, another draw is the lively and friendly crowd bellying up to quaff a few while the Sox or Cubs battle it out on five TVs.
content.property: Wheelchair-accessible bathroom No stairs to bathroom No steps at entrance Darts Pool table Video/pinball games Sports bar

content.description: Under framed pictures of smiling customers, a sweet old bartender pours you cheap PBR ($5 pitchers, $1.50 glasses) and asks how youve been. And next to you, a college kid visits with his old neighbor. Nice, right? Its easy to relax at this homey spot (the retro bowling game was the clincher for us), which feels as comforting as your grandparents basementwith the added perk of booze.

A more appropriate name for this cozy neighborhood tavern might be simply Rock, because thats exactly what youre given when you order a drink on ice: one enormous cube. We found the pours here to be very generous, which might explain why everybody was kissing the bartender as they left.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 11 Lincoln/Sedgwick, 76 Diversey
content.property: No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Outdoor seating Food served Video/pinball games Private party room(s)

content.description: Remember when Goldschlager was big? If you want to go retro, youll find no fewer than six bottles of the stuff on the back bar here. Speaking of gold, the jukebox plays golden oldies interspersed with some classic country. Try a Grape Bomber, grape-flavored vodka and Red Bull for the nice price of $2.50.
content.property: Conversation friendly Darts Good for over-40 crowd Wheelchair-accessible bathroom

content.public-transport: El: Green to King Dr. Bus: 3, 59, 63

content.description: On most nights, this cozy space is an after-work stopover for biz-caz yuppies escaping their Old Town high-rises. Brews, yummy comfort food and muted big-screen sports highlights abound. All those things happen on Tuesdays, too, with a little euchre thrown into the fold. League play occupies most of the tables, but youll always have a seat when those really dont feel like cooking evenings roll around.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Sedgwick. Bus: 11, 22, 36, 73
content.property: Extensive beer selection Good for groups Sports bar Conversation friendly No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Food served

entry.name: Bruno and Tims Lounge and Liquor Store

version.name: Bruno and Tims Lounge and Liquor Store

content.description: Note to Loyola kids: If youre old enough, you can drink here. Given that its just across the street from campus, were really surprised the gritty space isnt crawling with students. Then again, maybe the locals here could go without hearing phrases like Thirsty Thursday, Wasted Wednesday and Sloshed Saturday.

We certainly understand why this bar is packed with suits after quitting time. The tall bay windows allow for a fantastic view of the city, there are plenty of beers on tap, and the menu (which is on offer from breakfast through dinner) is an expansive collection of better-than-average pub grub. Just dont come expecting old-school Dublin; its more like an upscale sports lounge, Chicago-style.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Green, Pink, Purple (rush hrs), Orange to State

content.description: At this Edgewater joint, youll find a melting pot of patronsfrom Loyola students to young professionals to blue-collar regularswho all turn up to watch the Cubbies (or Sox or Bulls or Bears) and drink cheap beer. In the back, theres a hidden gem: a sliver of grass with a handful of picnic tables and a charcoal grill, which, weve been told, gets fired up on summer days.
content.public-transport: El: Red to Thorndale. Bus: 36 Broadway, 147 Outer Drive Express

content.description: This bilevel, spa-theme lounge is decorated with carefully lit cherry blossoms and a steady sheet of water cascading down the walls. According to the owners, its the most luxurious, upscale spot in town. So why is every guy dressed like hes at a Cubs game? And why are all the ladies dressed like Fly Girls? We like the hip-hop they play, too (particularly on Tuesday nights, when they get the best crowd in town). But come on, people: You already finagled your way past the doormanyou can at least look like you belong.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Chicago. Bus: 66
content.property: Food served Dress code No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Private party room(s) Late Night

content.description: What used to be the Berghoff bar is now essentially a cleaner version of its former self (with a frilly martini list to boot). The room is a little airier since the wall between restaurant and bar has been taken down, but the century-old German pub was always about that gorgeous, room-length bar. And the mix of tourists, after-work suits and afternoon men wont notice the renovations when theyre bellying up to that wooden monolith.
content.property: No steps at entrance Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Sports bar Food served

content.description: You may stumble in here on a sleepy Sunday night, take a look around and forget youre in a college town. But look closer: Theres Jger on tap. Hell, there are two types of Southern Comfort on tap. And if you wait long enough, youll see a dozen Northwestern football fans come in and start doing shots of all three.
content.property: Sports bar Pool table Food served

content.description: With its friendly staff and polished beer garden, its a shame that such a nice bar is experiencing an identity crisis. No matter what, this place doesnt want to be called a gay bar. But with a high preponderance of single men getting acquainted with each other, divalicious videos playing on the TVs and bundles of neatly stacked queer magazines, its not really giving us a lot of leeway to call it anything else.

It should be no surprise that this bar, decked out in rich wood tones and old chandeliers, comes complete with a billiards room and old-school bowling lanes. But what is surprising is the clientele, which is a hell of a lot less obnoxious than other fratastic bars on this strip. (No, seriouslythis is tame for Southport).
content.openingtimes: MonFri noon2am; Sat noon3am; Sun noon1am
content.property: Pool table Video/pinball games Sports bar Food served Outdoor seating Good for groups Private party room(s) Wheelchair-accessible bathroom

content.description: If youre not sure why Stadium West changed its name to this, start your night at this often-desolate dive by asking owner Sueyoull get an earful. The self-appointed Dragonlady is a straight-shooter, with a sweet side that comes out when she plays den mother Thursdays through Saturdays, cooking up vegan Korean fare for any scraggly twentysomething with $10 for the all-you-can-eat spread.
content.property: Food served Darts Conversation friendly Video/pinball games

content.description: Though its hidden on a side street, this Loop nook isnt the diamond in the rough we wish it were. The traders get rowdy at around 2 or 3pm, and tasteful decor touches are dashed by a tacky mural of a martini glass. But with decent prices and endless martini options that dont skimp on the booze, well hit up this bar around 4pmwhen the traders head home for the day.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to LaSalle

content.description: Polish Pride abounds at this swank and low-lit cocktail lounge: Artful black-and-white photos of Krakows Wawel (historic center) adorn the walls, sugar-sweet Euro pop trickles from the loudspeakers and the spirit of choice is vodka. The booths are comfy and the crowd is friendly, but who cares about that when everything we tried from the martini list was so irresistible?
content.public-transport: El: Blue to Jefferson Park. Bus: 56A, 68, 81, 85, 85A, 91, 92, Pace 225, Pace 226, Pace 270

content.description: Bar owner Michael Jettner has done everything right at this Gladstone Park pub. He stocks a dozen beers on tap (Blue Moon, Woodchuck Cider, etc.), nearly twice that number by the bottle, and keeps on hand all the requisite extras like darts, digital jukebox and a half-dozen TVs. Thankfully, none of it distracts from the floor-to-ceiling brick and exposed beams (not that the malecentric crowd really cares).

Six days a week, this Roscoe Village standbys got a Northwoods Wisconsin feel (think cluttered walls spotlighting the owners fishing triumphs and an authentic Old Milwaukee wooden beer tap) and is chock-full of the hoods youth. But on Saturdays, karaoke distracts from the usual conversational buzz, and brings with it the not-so-sorely missed Lincoln Park party-boy contingent.
content.openingtimes: Mon 4pm2am, TueFri, Sun noon2am; Sat noon3am
content.property: Darts Pool table Video/pinball games Karaoke No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Sports bar

content.description: As one bartender told us from her sounding post at the long wooden bars apex: This is not a place where youll find the pointy-shoe, popped-collar crew. As the neighborhood skews younger, things might change. But for now the space stays true to its homely roots with an old-fashioned jukebox and a back area cluttered with 70s furniture and unused office supplies.
content.openingtimes: MonThu 2pm2am; Fri noon2am; Sat noon3am; Sun noon2am
content.property: Pool table Karaoke No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Sports bar

content.description: On one hand, this Cubs-friendly bar is just the kind of blue-collar, mans-man bar that would make Jim Belushi proud. Regulars sit a few stools apart and, after a few drinks, muse about finding a word or phrase for waking up the next morning and still being drunk. On the other hand, the hefty selection of worldwide brews (like Staropramen and Lowenbrau) and friendly bartenders make its old-timey air more distinctive.
content.public-transport: El: Blue to Irving Park. Bus: 54A
content.property: Darts Pool table Video/pinball games No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Sports bar Food served

content.description: Vodka Collins? No. Margarita? Sorry. Apple martini? Not a chance. Better just grab a beer or a shot of whiskey and sit down. The history of this blue-collar watering hole is told through the flyers and newspaper clippings that clutter the walls. From what we can tell, looks as if the place hasnt changed much at all.
content.property: Pool table Video/pinball games Karaoke No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Sports bar

content.description: Time stands still in this log-cabinish tavernor at least the patrons wish it did. Whereas every other bar on this strip is packed with freshly waxed twentysomethings, this place seems to be popular with the older, wistful Division Street crowd, the ones who are past their prime but just cant let go. Little do they know that their sullen whiskey-drinking makes this the most interesting bar on the strip.
content.openingtimes: MonThu 2pm4am; Fri, Sun noon4am; Sat noon5am
content.property: Video/pinball games No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom

content.description: Take the aesthetic of Rain Forest Cafe, throw in some jungle beats and hire a crew of skinny, modern-day hippies to run the place, and you might have something resembling this sister bar to Funky Buddha Lounge. Concerned with your overall wellness as much as your level of inebriation, the alcohol here is all organic. But you may as well order one of the delicious nonalcoholic drinks (such as the milk shakelike cocoa elixir)you wont need a drink to feel trippy in here.

When the whistle blows, this West Loop hideout turns from desolate dive to serious unwinding joint. The peanuts might be complimentary, but the lap dancers sure arent ($10 a pop, Tuesdays and Thursdays from 5 to 8pm). What these fly-by-night amateurs lack in youthfulness, they overcompensate for with changes of clothes. Its worth it just to chat up a working stiff with a, well, you get it.
content.public-transport: El: Green, Pink to Clinton. Bus: 8, 14, 20, 56
content.property: Darts Video/pinball games Sports bar No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom After-work crowd Food served

content.description: Within seconds of entering this friendly neighborhood sports bar, its pretty obvious theres more to it than just a large selection of high-quality beer on tap. The staff members have pictures of lobsters on their shirts; words like king crab, calamari and mussels are all over the walls; and young couples and families on the lovely sidewalk patio graze on soft-shell crab, oysters and fresh-catch mahi mahi.

Theres nothing fancy going on at this copper-ceilinged pub, but the older crowd of Wisconsin Badgers fans who gathers here wouldnt have it any other way. Big windows open up onto the sidewalk for those who cant find a seat on the small outdoor patio. Like the place itself, the menu is predictable, yet solid with a respectable dozen beers on tap, and a variety of salads, sandwiches and burgers on offer.

Its rare to see the cavernous main room of this bar packed to capacity. It really only happens on St. Patricks Day, according to our tattooed bartender with the pompadour. The rest of the year is spent counting down the days till the drunkenest of holidays while drinking Jger and Newcastle (which are on tap), playing darts in back, and filling up on Guinness beef stew and fish and chips.

Perhaps the dingiest option on the Madison Street strip, this bar is lit and decorated like a cave and smells a bit like a toilet. But that doesnt faze the college kids who come for the fraternal atmosphere, pool table and, of course, the cheap booze.

With 25 plasma screens strategically arranged throughout these two wood-rich rooms, theres absolutely no place to escape the game. Thats good if youre a Notre Dame fan; if youre not, youd better go on a night when the Irish arent fighting. Or just go when the games are overits a better time to turn your game on anyway.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 8, 74, 76
content.property: Karaoke Video/pinball games No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Sports bar Food served

content.description: The museum of antiquated taverns needs to add this place to its collection. It has wall-to-wall original wood paneling, a pool table with matted and faded felt, and a vague race-car theme that seems like it was lovingly put together some 30 years ago. The patrons here look like they showed up in their youth and never left, but they all seem to like the friendly bar matron who smokes Newports in the most desultory fashion.
content.property: Darts Pool table No stairs to bathroom

content.description: The owners behind this tiny corner tavern mustve taken a class called Friendly Neighborhood Bar 101 because theyve nailed down all the requisite perks. Theres a brand-spankin-new digital jukebox on the exposed brick wall, several TVs, cheap pub fare, daily drink specials, ladies night (Tuesday), karaoke night (Saturday), dart competitions and free pool on Sundays.
content.property: Pool table Darts Karaoke Video/pinball games No stairs to bathroom Sports bar Food served

content.description: Sinking the eight ball without scratching and the siren song of a second biscotto are perhaps the only real pressures at this Edgewater caf. Because the only shots this place serves up are espresso (although beer is on offer), it has a neighborhood rec-center vibe. But when you consider the improv comedy on Fridays and free Wi-Fi, you wont miss the booze.
content.property: Pool table No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Conversation friendly Good for groups Food served

content.description: Tucked away in the shadow of the Western Avenue bridge, this cozy, candlelit bar seems (at least early in the night) like a good place to write your long-awaited debut novel while nursing one of 40 eclectic, hard-to-find beers. Just dont get too comfy, Hemingway: The rowdy, late-night rush is this establishments bread and butter. So stay and spot the subject of your next broken-heart tale.
content.property: Extensive beer selection No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Late Night

content.description: This ideal neighborhood dive is somehow still an overlooked gem. The wood paneling is balanced out by exposed brick, a fantastic tin ceiling and stained-glass lamps hanging over the bar. The giant outdoor patio is one of this areas best-kept secretstoss horseshoes, play the bean-bag game, or just drink and smoke. And dont mind the new condo-dwellers across the street complaining about the noise; theyll either move soon or come down to join you.
content.property: Pool table Darts No stairs to bathroom Outdoor seating

content.description: It looks like the owners have sunk a fair amount of dough into this spiffy Irish pub and saloon. A digital juke hangs on the wall, flat-screen TVs abound and the comfy seating in back makes the place feel lounge-y. Though there are plenty of gimmicks (Wednesday, for example, is Get hammered and nailed night, which includes a cocktail and manicure for $12), most people are happiest just chilling out with a beer.

Among the citys collection of gay leather bars, this dimly lit establishmentfree of the usual blinding lights and techno beatsis perhaps the most laid-back and conversation-friendly of them all. Muted porn videos play on four out of seven TVs, while an older crowd drinks cheap beers (50-cent drafts on Sundays). Dont fret if you happen to waltz in on a day when your leathers are at the cleaners: Jeans and a T-shirt are just as common here as chaps and a vest.

Weve bellied up to many Irish pubs, but weve never seen anything quite as striking as this sporty, well-worn pubs wall filled with Irish coats of arms. Tacked up against a green backdrop, those decorations bring an Old-WorldIreland feel to the place, so its all the more puzzling that theres zero Guinness on tap and not one Irish lad in sight.

Drinking here is like getting into the DeLorean and traveling back to 1955sort of like when youre just drunk enough at Green Mill to think its the 40s. Eclectic, mismatched furniture and an old blues-heavy jukebox set the mood for kicking back or rackin em up at the two vintage pool tables. Just be careful, McFly: The bartenders will not hesitate to embarrass you on the felt.
content.public-transport: El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 9, 80
content.property: After-work crowd Conversation friendly Pool table Good for over-40 crowd No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Fireplace

content.description: This hipster cocktail lounge is exactly what youd expect from a bar named after a line of T.S. Eliot poetry: pristine (the carefully constructed cocktails are excellent), pretentious (you wont find a sign on the doorjust look for the long lines) and, ultimately, completely and inarguably gorgeous.
content.property: Dress sharp Conversation friendly Notable for cocktails Date place Food served

content.description: Most great dives look as though they havent seen so much as a pledge-soaked rag since the end of World War II. With that in mind, this little, bottles-only (despite its name) tavern is oddly modern. Its scant decorbeer promo posters of bikini-clad women with dos straight out of a hair-metal video and an aging jukebox with tunes to matchappears to have been updated as recently as the end of the Cold War.

If drinking at a bowling alley seems a little too Roseanne for a posh crew like yours, you obviously havent been to lanes like these before. The rambunctious singles crowd seems more interested in each other (and the neon-bright martinis and enormous screens playing larger-than-life music videos) than they do actually picking up a bowling ball. One way or another, youll probably score.
content.public-transport: El: Red to Grand; Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Merchandise Mart. Bus: 22, 29, 36
content.property: No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Sports bar Good for groups Food served

content.description: This worn-around-the-edges watering hole is the last place youd expect to find old men gathered around a horseshoe bar, glued to reruns of Will & Grace. Then again, weird sightings are de rigueur here: Dearly departed Sally herself allegedly shows up (in ghost form) near the jukebox every now and again. But when a bar is this minimalthe only eye candy here is an attractive female bartender standing against a background of Christmas lights and wood panelingpatrons are happy for something new to look at.
content.property: Pool table No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Darts

content.description: Kind of a cross between Cheers and the bar in The Iceman Cometh, where the foolosopher in residence is 75-year-old regular Mikey Voss (The one thing I know is I know nothing), this shot-and-beer joint seems much-loved by the regulars. Perhaps its the diplomacy on display. The northernmost TV has Cubs games on, while the southernmost TV airs Sox games. Is everybody happy? A few more cheap beers, and any tune you want on the online jukebox, and you will be.
content.property: Conversation friendly Darts Good for over-40 crowd Pool table Video/pinball games

content.description: Although this bar in the former Pepper Lounge space doesnt stray too far from the Wrigleyville mold, its dark woods, exposed brick and sports-memorabilia deficiency seem classier than many of the surrounding drunk dens. The bars namesake half-yard glass can be filled with more than a dozen draft brews and trotted out to the rear beer garden, which sports three old horse stables the owners say will eventually become semiprivate nooks for small groups.
content.openingtimes: MonFri 5pm2am; Sat noon3am; Sun noon2am (opens at 11am on Cubs game days)

content.description: For most of you, this place isnt worth the hike. But for you Far North Siders out there, its an oasis in your own back yard. This 60-year-old gem offers three-dozen beers (including La Fin du Monde, Delirium Tremens and Smithwicks), cracker-thin Chicago barstyle pizza and herb-flecked garlic fries that have quite the loyal local following. Our only hope is that someone fixes the schizo jukebox thats been playing Hall & Oates every other song.
content.property: Conversation friendly No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Good for over-40 crowd Good for groups Food served

content.description: For the piano-bar fiend who likes his joints a little more Grace than Will, this underground spot should hit all the right notes. But even though the guys here arent gay, theyre at least dressed well: Bouncers inspect outfits as well as your ID, and flip-flops and T-shirts dont get through the door.
content.property: Piano bar Dress sharp Live bands No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Late Night Dress code

content.description: Admittedly, we were a little sad when we heard that Lincoln Park stalwart Lawrys Tavern was being replaced by yet another Irish pub. Our period of mourning, however, was short. Sure, Lawrys had character (i.e., shitty beer, laugh-riot regulars and wood-paneled walls), but come on, this place has Lindemans framboise, Three Floyds Alpha King and Deirium Tremens on tap; a digital juke box; and a full menu of burgers and fish-and-chips. We still miss Lawrys pool table, though.

This self-proclaimed bikini bar could best be described as a poor mans Hooters, but instead of having an owl as a mascot, its chosen (egads!) a crab. Surprisingly, it isnt as tawdry as youd expect, although it could stand to lose the plethora of beer-company swag hanging from every inch of the place. If you dont have the balls to go to a real strip club but still want to ogle some ladies, you could do worse. And with the thin crowd most nights, youre highly unlikely to be spotted by anyone you know.
content.property: Darts No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Food served

content.description: Any of this spots divey iniquities can be forgiven with the mugs of Old Style. Rosethe cute, old Eastern European owner-bartenderhasnt changed a thing since the 70s: A shingled awning hangs over the back of the bar, wood paneling lines the walls, and plenty of eclectic grandma knickknacks mingle with the bottles of liquor. And at seven plays for a buck, not even the jukebox prices have changed.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 11, 74, 76
content.property: Conversation friendly No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom

content.description: The windowless front door isnt exactly a welcome mat, but once inside Christinas compact, cozy digs (and after an insanely cheap $2 Guinness) youll feel right at home. The football pennants hanging over the bar and baseball on several TVs scream sports bar, but the Talking Heads and 60s-era Stones on the juke combined with the bartenders Iggy and the Stooges shirt say otherwise.
content.property: After-work crowd Pool table Wheelchair-accessible bathroom No stairs to bathroom Conversation friendly Late Night Video/pinball games Karaoke

content.description: A friendly late-night joint is hard to find. One where off-duty cops, dolled-up hipsters and sporty types drink together in harmony, like this one, is even harder. Inside, the exposed brick wall and candlelit bar makes for a cozy atmosphere. Add some fine picks by the DJ and two of the nicest bartenders around, and youll definitely be back for seconds.
content.property: Live bands Video/pinball games No stairs to bathroom Late Night

content.description: Merry ol England this aint, but its tough to find a sports hub this inviting along Broadway. In the front, kegs are stacked next to a pinball machine; near the back, a disco ball is suspended over the jukebox; and Cubs signs are peppered throughout the narrow space. Yeah, there are some odd decorating choices, but any place where the off-duty bartender buys us a shot gets our vote.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Wellington; Red to Belmont. Bus: 22, 36, 77
content.property: Video/pinball games Karaoke No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Sports bar Fireplace

content.description: A tasty pie in a laid-back atmosphere is the specialty of this cash-only Andersonville joint. We recommend the house pizza, a unique combo of eggplant, jalapeo peppers and garlic on a crispy (but thankfully not cracker-thin) crust. And if youre just in it for the booze, grab a Delirium Tremens and a seat at one of the couches in the back that surround a big-screen TV. But dont try bringing back munchies; like at home, theres a no-eating rule in the living room.
content.property: No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Pool table Conversation friendly Darts No steps at entrance Food served

content.description: Nick Novich (the proprietor of Nicks Uptown and the original Nicks in Wicker Park) must view his newest bar as a long-term investment, but we see it as yet another sign of the inevitable Uptown renaissance. The bartenders admit the place hasnt yet caught on (weary Truman professors being the exception), but with its exposed brick walls, bright red bar, and chic, lofty atmosphere, its only a matter of time before its packed.
content.property: Conversation friendly No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom

content.description: When we strolled into this endearingly tacky Latino holdout tucked into a gentrifying residential block, a tipsy twentysomething swiveled his stool our way, raised his hands to the sky and gleefully announced to the four other people in the place, Finally! Youre here. It was drunk talk all right, but this stranger summed up exactly how this bewitching bar makes you feel: like its been waiting all these years for you to become a regular.

This freak-friendly dance destination in Lakeview built its reputation back in the mid-80s with a mix of German new-wave music, art installations and even transvestite shows. These days, its still quirky but more retro, with Prince-tribute, disco and 80s nostalgia nights. Goths and gays are extra welcome, but the scene here is made up of almost everyone.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 8, 22, 77
content.property: Good for groups Late Night Gay

content.description: This club, in the middle of the Weed Street nightlife strip, has a hookah-bar, Eastern vibe thats fading,but the house orientation is still strong. The main room features specialists in Chicago house with touring DJs of varying renown. Local DJs hone their chops in the lounge rooms. As an alternative to the spectacle of neighboring crobar, its refreshing.
content.property: Private party room(s) Dress sharp Good for groups

content.description: Literally overshadowed by its neighbor, the popular restaurant Hacienda Tecalitlan, its easy to miss this bare-bones Mexican hangout. An open bar stool is tough to come by, but thankfully there are a few tables scattered throughout and pool and foosball to keep you busy. If youre not up for bar sports, heres a game: Count whether there are more posters displaying Mexican pride or women in bikinis.

Briefly a celebrity hot spot, Yowned by the Sound-Bar folks (see above)still looks the part with amber and wood shades, stunning female bar staffers and bottle-service orientation. DJ bookings vary from easygoing house to hip-hop, but the sophisticated crowd it caters to might pack the place one night and go somewhere else another.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Chicago. Bus: 37, 66

content.description: This spacious club under the rumbling El tracks on Lake Street is often the first place new UIC grads go to party. The Latin-focused night has a following, but on a typical evening the mix of hip-hop, house and reggaeton brings in a diverse clientele, some of whom enjoy spinning on the well-placed stripper poles.
content.public-transport: El: Green, Pink to Ashland. Bus: 9

content.description: This spacious Ukrainian Village nightspot has gradually upgraded sound and stage features, turning from rock bar to DJ den (nights for reggae, hip-hop and house predominate). The photo-themed decor features local photogs prints, but somehow, the vibe has never gotten overly arty-hipmight be because it needs a head count of 100 before the huge room starts to get cozy.
content.property: Live bands Private party room(s) Outdoor seating No stairs to bathroom No steps at entrance

content.description: A downtown destination for the past 15 years, this superclub is housed in a historic church and seemingly has a room for everything: Theres a weekly cabaret show, live flamenco music, Latin dance lessons and even a paranormal interactive-theater event. With all the cross-promotion going on, it draws a crowd of enthusiastic out-of-towners and club novices.
content.public-transport: El: Red to Grand. Bus: 36 Broadway, 65 Grand
content.property: Video/pinball games Pool table Late Night Fireplace Karaoke Food served Private party room(s)

content.description: This intimate basement club in the River North gallery district underwent a lot of changes in 2006: The glammy crowd moved on to new places and the big-name house, techno and electro DJs came back. Not to mention, the sound system has gotten beefed up to please audiophiles. On weekends, its a new destination for serious danceheads and budding DJs, while weeknights are ripe for experimentation.
content.property: Dress sharp Private party room(s) Good for groups

content.description: Originally on the fourth floor of the magnificent Wrigleyville building (also home to Metro; see Music venues, Rock, pop & hip-hop), this venerated dance club is now in the basement. A makeover in 2006 slicked up the looks a notch and brought back a vibrant young crowd. But more important, the club boasts a world-class Funktion One sound system, which sounds tremendous on the central dance floor. Cutting-edge DJs from Europe, Detroit and Chicago form the bulk of the weekend bookings with house, techno and electro styles; but local mash-up and indie jocks rule on bargain weekday nights.

When this place was The Note, the focus was on the bands on stage. Now, of course, those bands are gone, and the focus is onnothing. The dark bar, now decorated with street-art murals on the walls, is roomy and a little divey, and its essentially as low-key and basic as a bar can get. And thats exactly what this rapidly yuppifying neighborhood needs.
content.property: Pool table Late Night Video/pinball games

content.description: Break out the ten-hole Doc Martens and the hair products for this goth-punk outpost that hasnt changed much since, well, before you were born. Neo has a small dance floor and a calendar crammed with DJs specializing in everything from metal and industrial to new wave and electro.
content.public-transport: El: Red, Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Fullerton. Bus: 22, 36, 74

content.description: A prime destination for indie rockers for more than a decade, this Ukrainian Village live venue has increasingly turned to booking adventurous electronic, indie hip-hop and experimental-music acts. There are even a few opening DJs and dance parties. Its more about the head bobbing of hipsters than serious dance-floor action.
content.openingtimes: MonWed 5pm2am; Thu, Fri 3pm2am; Sat noon3am; Sun noon2am
content.property: Pool table Live bands Video/pinball games

content.description: The family behind Wicker Parks ultrapopular, ultracasual Middle Eastern stalwart Sultans Market reaches out to the late-night weekend crowd with this second location, serving food until 3am on Fridays and Saturdays. The stellar salad bar, crave-worthy falafel, soups, stuffed pies and imported packaged foods are a near carbon-copy of the originals.

More Tex-Mex than traditional Mex, Pancho Pistolas traffics in locals searching for gringo favorites like fajitas and chimichangas. Youll also find decent standards like carne asada and day-starters like chilaquiles, a perfectly delicious way to recycle day-old tortillas. Most dishes would register negative points on the Scoville scale, but the crowd is festive and the staff seems friendly, so no one will mind if you ask for hot sauce.
content.property: Good for groups Private party room(s) Cheap (entrees under $10)

content.description: When it comes to truth in advertising, this 18th Street counter-service spot is 50% on target. Pollo: check. Express: well, thats debatable. However lackadaisical the service, its serious about the first part: The roasted bird is the only main available, in half or whole size, plain or adobado (the latter, spiced version is the way to go). Legs and thighs are moist, and the drier rest is easily spruced up with fresh, warm tortillas, fluffy rice, porky beans and pickled onions.

Are breakfast baostuffed with egg, bacon and cheese or, more successfully, egg with a peppery crumbled sausagethe new Wheaties? Maybe. But if you arent ready to give up cereal just yet, theres plenty more to try at this outpost of the LEYE chain. Potstickers are fine; better to go with the Thai curry-chicken rice bowl with its mild, yet aromatic and complex, yellow curry. Or just stick with the bao, steamed buns stuffed with fillings such as slightly spicy kung pao chicken or the sweet and rich barbecue pork. A cup of tart fro-yo is a required finish.
content.public-transport: El: Blue, Red to Jackson; Brown, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Quincy. Bus: 1, 7, 126, 151

content.description: There are no seats herejust stools. Theres barely a menu, eitherjust a short list of things youd expect from a place thats straightforward enough to call itself Diner Grill. The burgers are thin little things; but stacked up two or three on a bun, theyre exactly what you come to diners for: food thats hot, greasy, cheesy and cheap. Of course, you may be here for breakfast, in which case the bacon is extra-crispy and the pancakes are substantial enough to get you through the day. (But if, like most people here, youre eating them in the middle of the night, thats beside the point.)
content.public-transport: El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 9, 80

content.description: For a heaping helping of Bridgeport from days gone by, this Edward Hopperesque joint offers reliable renditions of the BLT and freshly griddled hamburgers, all served with a steaming side of sleeves-up, workingmans reality. The chili recipe is allegedly a family secret, but we suspect that family is the Hormel clan; slightly soupy bowls of red are quirkily priced at $2.50 or $2.70 without beans.

Aggressively flavorful, rich mainstays like the Gage burger, dripping with melted onion marmalade and gobs of Camembert, keep this downtown gastropub buzzing. But chef Dirk Flanigans summertime offerings are further amplified by seasonal ingredients: a peppered hanger steak is brightened up with watermelon, basil and mint, while roasted Amish chicken gets green beans tossed with arugula, citrus and goat cheese. Not hungry? Sidewalk seating across from Millennium Park is the perfect place to enjoy a sparkling cocktail like the Forbidden Fruit, made with prosecco and fresh grapefruit juice.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Madison

content.description: Despite new ownership, the underground lounge formerly known as krem retains its white-on-white interior and continues to play host to a crowd of highly coiffed twentysomethings throwing back bottle service. True to the bars new moniker, though, the bartenders in candy-colored wigs serving candy-colored cocktails and the sea of white smiles and shiny outfits illuminated by a saturating black lightadd up to something pretty dreamlike. Or nightmarish, depending on your taste.

This Peruvian spot is still relatively new to Lakeview, and its trying to make a good impression: Sunlight fills the clean dining room, and (plastic) flowers greet you at every table. But even if the dining room werent pleasant, chances are the food would still win you over. Ceviche mixto, full of toothsome shrimp, squid and octopus, sports a bright, tangy flavor; shredded chicken is flavored with a delicious mix of lime juice and cilantro; and pescado a lo macho smothers crispy fried fish in a delectable tomato sauce.

Hang with the Beverly crowd at this Far South Side institution, where Irish brogues are the norm and the staff is among the friendliest in town. The fenced-in, wooden deck has a homey, antique decor (i.e., wagon wheels and hanging plants), along with two bars that serve $1 domestic drafts during Sox and Cubs home games.
content.property: Video/pinball games No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Sports bar Outdoor seating Live bands

content.description: If it looks like a bar, smells like a bar and sounds like a bar, then...you do the math. But two things keep this place from going the route of sports-bar-beer-bong culture: excellent house brews and expertly executed pizzas. The crispy pies hold a lot of weight, so after you choose your pizza stylered, white or New Havenstyle plain (red sauce, no mozzarella)start piling on the goat cheese, spinach, meatballs, anchovies and, if youre really going New Havenstyle, clams or mashed potatoes. Wash it down with a pitcher of the crisp Golden Arm, and youll never disparagingly say pizza and beer joint again.
content.property: Food served Karaoke Extensive beer selection Good for groups Sports bar
Good for dining at bar Good for groups Vegetarian-friendly Kid-friendly

content.description: The largest and most popular bar on Madison Street, this two-story party palace with its infamous Karaoke Idol competitions is the place to be if youre a twentysomething in Forest Park. The main floor, dotted with darts machines and video games, is spacious enough, but we enjoyed heading upstairs and grabbing a seat at one of the picnic benches on the rooftop patio, which also has its own bar.

After a recent makeover, this pub is quite sleek. Exposed brick lines the back of the bar, and amber lighting gives the place a golden glow and the brand-new hardwood floors a distinct shine. A digital juke has replaced a lesser stereo. Two new pool tables sport virgin felt and cues that actually have tips. For Madison Street, thats uncharacteristically classy.

Because its on the outer edge of Madison Street, beyond the throng of deafening bro bars, this warm, inviting place has a little more freedom to be classy. Sure, its still an Irish pub, but that has less to do with shamrocks than Smithwicks and fish and chips. Flickering candles line the dark-wood bar, which sports a full wine rack and a respectable selection of bottled microbrews. Theres also a conversation-friendly outdoor patio with six umbrella-topped tables.

Posters of Jaws, American Graffiti, The Three Stooges and other pop-culture classics line every inch of the exposed-brick walls, adding to the familiar and homey feel of the place. We only have one warning: If loud jazz, blues and rock bands arent your thing, call ahead to see if ones slotted to play that night. A live band playing in such a tight, narrow space isnt exactly friendly on the ears. But if eardrum-bursting sound is your thing, rock on, my friend.

During the week, this spacious, polished, dimly-lit bar/restaurant is perfect for eating with the kiddies or chatting over a beer with friends. Lately its become a hotbed for twentysomethings, so be prepared for a more rowdy crowd on the weekends. If the bar area gets to crowded, though, make sure you check out elegant back patio, which is open all year. Its one of our faves.
content.property: Conversation friendly Outdoor seating Food served

content.description: Contrary to its name, theres little thats unexpected about this smallish yet pleasant sports bar. Fittingly nestled near Wrigley Field, its flat screens are dedicated year-round to ball games. A half-dozen beers are on tap (no out-of-the-ordinary brews, though) and the menu of pub grub is just greasy enough to satisfy the slew of regulars eating burgers and drinking pitchers.
content.property: No steps at entrance Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Sports bar Private party room(s) Darts Outdoor seating Food served

content.description: Despite significant staff shiftsKendal Duque and Peter Vestinos (chef and cocktail master, respectively) have been replaced by Andrew Zimmerman (formerly the chef de cuisine at NoMI) and Joshua Pearsonvery little feels out of step at this acclaimed West Looper. Its newbie sheen worn off, Sepia has taken on the qualities of a stalwart: a classic place serving autumnal standouts like white bean soup with slow-cooked pork; pork cheek salad with pickled pumpkin; a flatiron steak with bone marrow beignets; and a butternut squash-infused Old Fashioned.
content.public-transport: El: Green, Pink to Clinton. Bus: 8, 56, 125
content.property: Notable wine list Outdoor seating Vegetarian-friendly Good for dining at bar

content.description: Tom McDonald of Websters Wine Bar didnt plan for his beer-focused tavern to be such a food destination, but the eats here take center stage. The dinner menu is full of tempting plates such as mussels sauted in Unibroue and duck breast in a port reduction over Israeli couscous. Recent additions to be on the lookout for are a cheddar-and-bacon-laden burger and a plate of German-style sausages, both perfect food for experimenting with the Belgian-heavy beer list.
content.property: Notable wine list Good for dining at bar Fireplace Vegetarian-friendly Cheap (entrees under $10)

content.description: This bright and cheery all-day eatery is a much-needed addition to West Humboldt Park. Chef-owner Charles Armstead starts offering breakfast at the crack of dawn, tempting Grand Avenue commuters with his homey sausage casserole, Lavazza coffee and chill background music help ease you into the day. Lunch and dinner are a whos who of comfort food. Meat loaf is better than Moms, but hold the American cheese. For the star of the show, get the blackened salmon, well-spiced, perfectly seared and plated with delicious garlic mashed potatoes. Follow up with the fantastic banana bread pudding with peanut butter anglaise.

This new Logan Square bar has everything you could ask forthat is, as long as you dont ask for too much. The spare, dim room has plenty of hipster atmosphere (but no hipster snobbery); ample seating at a wood-paneled bar; and a delicious beer on tap that you cant get anywhere else (just point to the unmarked draft handle adorned with antlers and tell the bartender youll have some of that).
content.public-transport: El: Blue to Logan Square. Bus: 56, 74, 82

content.description: When we entered this worn-out old corner tap, the four blue-collar folks at the bar turned from their $2 beers and stared. The gangs all here, so who the hell could this be? they mustve thought. So how do you enter this finicky fold? Order a cheap brew, throw a block of Journey on the juke and challenge the bars stick-slinger to a game of pool. And after you strategically lose, buy that man another beer.

Roland Liccionis departure from this tony brasserie last year was followed by a brief stint from Andy Motto before the latter, too, headed to the burbs. Now out-of-town transplant Christian Phernetton is in the kitchen. Through it all, the room has remained classic, just like the French menu, with its escargots, country pt, salad lyonnaise, and herb-roasted Amish chicken. Except now, these are more like classic deals: A Monday prix fixe brings a three-course menu for $32, Tuesdays take half off the wine list, and Sundays the place goes BYOB with no corkage fee.

Strolling into this posh, cavernous River North nightspot, we can see how it might induce what its name promises. The allure is the peak-of-opulence decora stunning mix of modern touches, plantlife and antique architectural finds. Towering over plush booths and a large dance floor are backlit photos of soaked and scantily clad models. Its a touch outdone only by two ginormous griffin lights that flank the first of three bars.
content.property: Private party room(s) No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Dress code

content.description: Its not much to look at on the outside, but inside this Northwest Side bar, youll find a black lacquered horseshoe bar, comfy stools and a half-dozen Mexican beers served ice cold with a bowl of lime slices and a shaker of salt. Come on Salsa Mondays for a free lesson, $1 tacos and $2 MGDs and Lites. Be sure to try a ceviche (Mexican sushi) specialdelish shrimp, avocado and cilantro in lime juice on a tostada for only two bucks.
content.property: Outdoor seating Late Night Food served

content.description: Just so you know, this place is named after the Texas-Mexico river, not the John Wayne movie. Regardless, were not quibbling, were just here for the Cazadores tequila on the advice of the friendly bartender, Mike (and since hes been the head keep for 27 years, we figure he must know a good drink). As with any good dive worth its semidumpy kitsch, there are breast mugs behind the bar, while a worn rug painting of dogs playing pool presides over the billiards table.

Theres nothing out of the ordinary at this new Loop bar and grill, and that suits the famished financial district clientele just fine. Theyre just happy to have a decent option for an off-the-clock cocktail or a quick lunch thats above bottom-feeder pub grub. The varied menu offers coconut shrimp, several salads, sweet potato fries and a meatloaf sandwich, which can be washed down with one of 18 bottled beers.

From the music on the speakers (Nat King Cole et al.) to the rat-pack decor and carefully shaken martinis, this Logan Square corner bar is surprising all the twentysomething post-hipsters flocking to it. Its not just that the bar is a far cry from the dive that preceded itreally, its a far cry from anything thats been built since 1940. Recent additions to the menu like fish tacos and Cuban sandwiches make it easy to spend summer nights lingering on the walled-in patio.
content.openingtimes: MonThu 4pm2am; Fri, Sun noon2am; Sat noon3am

content.description: Whos gay? Whos straight? Who cares? is the attitude at this new Boystown Irish-themed pub. After all, youre just as likely to see a bunch of frumpy yuppies in Cubs caps washing down burgers with pints of Guinness as you are to spy a gaggle of pretty boys uniting for a drunken chorus of Save a Horse, Ride a Cowboy.

Lets get something out of the way first: Indian food in the Loop isnt held to the same bar as the stuff on Devon Avenue. The lack of options simply dictates that excellent is not the goal; decent is. Having said that, we hit this lunchtime spot to satiate kebab cravings, as the minced beef chapli seems to be the standout item, followed by a respectable chicken boti. Skip the overly sweet, cream-laden chicken mahkani (ditto for the bland vegetarian options), but do opt for a fresh-fruit shake to end on a high note.

This 6,000-square-foot restaurant inside the bustling Ogilvie Transportation Center has convenience and affordability down pat, but is a little hit or miss with quality. Sushiboth nigiri and maki rollsleaves much to be desired, but stick with the $12 two-course Thai lunch and things will be fine. Go with the crispy calamari over miso-dressed greens for a starter and try the massaman curry or the lemongrass dish for your entre (beware that the latter is a scorcher). Basic breakfast is fine and fresh, and if recent visits are any indication, the room will be empty anytime before the lunch rush.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Washington. Bus: 14, 20, 56, 60, 124, 125, 157

content.description: Somehow this bar manages to marry the Hofbrau beer and bench-style seating of a traditional German beer hall with the flat-screens and University of Wisconsin pennants of a familiar college sports bar. So expect to hear as many shouts of touchdown as the bars namesake incantation.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 8, 11, 74

content.description: Just as Clarkes on Belmont spawned After Dark, its sibling on Lincoln Avenue recently begot this neighboring nightspot. It shares a kitchen with the 24-hour diner but offers its own menu of barcentric eats. Black-and-white photos of ballplayers dot the walls, but the dimly lit digs; deep, cushy booths; and mammoth glazed-wood bar make things feel cozier than at most sporty spots in this hood.
content.property: Food served Karaoke Private party room(s) No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom

content.description: With country-style graciousness, the staff here serves up a generous menu of down-home Eastern European entres with simple ingredients in pleasing combinations. Sour cherry soup is a sweet and satisfying starter, pairing perfectly with one of the many Hungarian wines (try the semidry Donausonne Blaufrankisch). Lamb shank Transylvanian style is subtly seasoned and served with nutty egg barley pasta while a nice cut of filet mignon gets delicious sweet pepper, peas and sliced liver. Goulashes, schnitzels and other flavorful, fresh and well-prepared foods are served at reasonable prices and with palpable bonhomie.
content.property: Good for dining at bar Private party room(s) BYOB Vegetarian-friendly Suburban

content.description: With eight TVs (inevitably tuned to Bears, Cubs, and the Fighting Illini) and a plethora of drafts (Fat Tire, Stella, Woodchuck cider) its clear youre waist-deep in jock country here. Test your sports knowledge in the Tuesday night trivia contest, when pints are priced at $3.75, or throw a sports-themed party in the back room with ten (count em) TVs. The feel-good, hangover-friendly foodcrispy Reuben rolls, deep-fried mac-and-cheese bitesis served when you need it most: Saturdays and Sundays from 11am to 2pm.
content.property: After-work crowd Conversation friendly Date place Good for over-40 crowd Sports bar Food served Fireplace Good for groups Private party room(s) Outdoor seating Wheelchair-accessible bathroom

content.description: Tim Ashorian and Maria DiNunzio left IT jobs at Chase Bank to open Bellezza, a gelateria that also serves pastries and a lineup of Turkish and Italian coffees. While many places offering house-made gelati start with factory-made mixes, here they serve their own higher-quality versions prepared off-site. The resulting gelati and sorbetti have a fresh, clean flavor. The Turkish-coffee gelato is an eye-opener and goes well with slightly sweet nazooks, walnut-cinnamon pastries based on Tims Assyrian family recipe. For another jolt, try the affogato, a shot of espresso over gelato.

At first glance, this relatively new storefront might seem like just another Chinese takeout spot with a lo meinlined steam table. But a closer look reveals that the Laotian owners mix in close to a dozen specialties of their homeland. The casual counter-ordering system means you can point and shoot, but trust us and get both the beef and pork sausages (the red-hued plump ones are tart from mild fermenting); the tangy, crispy rice salad (nam sod); the crimson chicken curry; and the sweetish, soy-rich stew of hard-boiled eggs, tofu and pork belly (pa lo). Bring a bottle of pinot noir to match, or try smoothies made with tropical fruits like sapote, which has a custardy sweet flavor.

Opened by the team behind Wrigleyvilles Trace, this enormous new drinkery brings a taste of the prototypical Lincoln Park sports bar to Division Street. The generic tan interior means that your attention will undoubtedly fall to one of three things: the busty bartenders and servers, the football game on the flat screens orand this would be our choicethe 50-bottle-strong beer list.
content.property: Food served Extensive beer selection Fireplace Sports bar Outdoor seating

content.description: The idea at this bustling restaurant-lounge is to present great examples of food from all over Latin America. Thats a tough order to fill, and while the restaurant manages to get the margaritas exactly right, the food is hit-or-miss. Nachos topped with honey-kissed shreds of pot roast are an interesting interplay of sweet and savory, and the juicy Argentine carne asada comes with a piquant chimichurri and tempura green onions. But the bland ceviche Yucateco and California-inspired fish tacos left our taste buds wanting for more, leading us to believe that perhaps Sol should narrow its focus.
content.public-transport: El: Green to Oak Park. Bus: Pace 309, 311, 313

content.description: Legend has it that the Velvet Underground once rocked the stage at Mothers, which opened its doors in 1968. But dont come here looking for avant-garde rock. These days, Mothers is all about pleasing the sweat-drenched, booze-soaked Division Street masses who pack the dance floor into the early morning hours hoping to grind against Mr. or Ms. Rightor at least Mr. or Ms. Tonight.
content.property: Late Night Pool table Video/pinball games Private party room(s) Live bands Good for groups Karaoke

content.description: Free Wi-Fi and friendly service only add to the zen atmosphere patrons of this Japanese tea house can expect. A steaming pot of pine needle tea and a surprisingly affordable selection of sweets and sandwiches make up for somewhat uncomfortable benches and an often empty seating area.

Franconello may be inching norththis, their second location, is a considerable hike from the original in Beverlybut the menu has stayed the same. That means that anybody who has become addicted to Marios meatballs (tender miniature meatballs presented in a cast iron crock of warm marinara), the housemade radiatori pasta with pesto and pine nuts or the chocolate-chip gelato will never have to go without. Unless, of course, theyre too far north even for this new University Village spot, in which case theyll just have to waitanother location cant be far behind.

A motley mix of first-timers and more experienced amateurs hits the lanes and pounds back shots at this hard-rocking riverfront bowling alley. Old-timers love to wax nostalgic about the places dingier past, saying the crowd has become more L.L.Bean than leather-clad and mean, but nightly DJs keep things edgy, spinning everything from Motrhead to Ministry.
content.property: Food served Karaoke Pool table Video/pinball games Classic Chicago spot

content.description: The bar stools at this new sports bar are extra-wide, and the dark room (yes, even in the middle of the day) draws the focus to the game shining brightly from the numerous TVs. It looks like the nearby United Center may have some competition on its hands: Here you see the game better, cheaper and more comfortably than you would if you were actually there.
content.public-transport: El: Green, Pink to Ashland. Bus: 9 Ashland, 20 Madison
content.property: Food served Sports bar Outdoor seating

content.description: Behind its blacked-out windows, this dark, well-worn dive is an unlikely spot for live music. Jazz groups hold court every Thursday, and on Sunday nights, El Gato earns its billing as the hottest spot for T-girls in Chicago, when Latin grooves and an X-rated transgender burlesque show take over.
content.public-transport: El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 9, 22, 80

content.description: A Venus de Milo decanter filled with booze and porcelain fiddles brimming with bourbon may not be your idea of high art, but theyre someones: Said objets darts sit next to an old-timey cigarette machine, which might be to blame for at least some of the burn marks on the wooden bar. Hard-luck tales are spun from grizzled patrons hunching over $2 drafts amid neon signs and come-hither chicks on beer posters.
content.property: Darts Conversation friendly Good for groups Good for over-40 crowd Pool table Video/pinball games

content.description: When the Inn of Chicago revealed its newly renovated space earlier this year, we did a double take: The interior seemed far too slick and sexy for a place called an Inn. Its lounge is much the same: With its cool silver tones, backlit bar and colorful martinis, its thankfully not so much lobby as it is clubby.

Longtime regulars of La Pasadita said goodbye to their beloved watering hole as different owners turned the largely Spanish-speaking spot into this sports bar.
