Theres a new sign, sure, but to call the place new is a bit of an exaggeration: The interior isnt drastically different, and the addition of a few flat-screen TVs only puts its already obvious signs of agingscuffed hardwood, yellowing walls, beat-up tablesfurther into relief.

Ignore the stench of stale cigarettes if you can. And dont worry about those old codgers in the corner; theyre drunk anyway. Just focus on what a time capsule this is80s-era Bud Light posters above the weathered, brown leather booths; the vintage (working) refrigeratorand how cheap the beer is ($2 for Miller Light).

Drunken dining is made berconvenient at this dank, sardine cansize bar attached to the Clark Dog hot-dog stand. Obviously, that means you can get really soused on the cheap, take ten uneasy steps to the counter and order yourself a chili-cheese dog and a steamy basket of fries, which to you will taste like they were handed down from heaven.

An odd blast from the recent past, this spacious sports barwhich recently took over the former Players Bar and Grill spacetransported us back to the mid-90s with music videos from groups such as Rusted Root and Blind Melon flickering on a gigantic projection-screen TV. But wait a second: Werent the beefy, ball-capped boys nodding their heads the same dudes who beat us up in high school for whistling No Rain in the hallway?
content.property: Pool table Sports bar Outdoor seating Food served
After-work crowd Conversation friendly Good for over-40 crowd Food served

content.description: For those experiencing Cubby withdrawal, heres a place to liquor up while looking longingly at Wrigley Field across the street. During baseball season, you could book one of two private rooms, each with a small bar, 15 seats and five TVs, and order some burgers, corn dogs or pulled-pork sandwiches while watching the game. Or do it now and watch a video of winning games.
content.property: After-work crowd Conversation friendly Good for groups Good for over-40 crowd Private party room(s) Sports bar Views Food served Outdoor seating

content.description: We thought wed seen everything when it came to Irish pubs, but no pub in Chicago is quite as lovely and upscale as this. Rooms like the cozy library (complete with fireplace), tile-floored bar and dining area blend seamlessly into one another, yet maintain their own identities. Its named after the poshest zip code in Dublin; before long, it could transform this area into one of the poshest zips in Chicago.
content.property: Fireplace Food served Outdoor seating Private party room(s)

content.description: Offtrack betting has never looked so good: This new bar/restaurant/OTB spot boasts 217 television monitors, a large marble bar and food from chef Gabriel Ortega, a veteran of the Ritz-Carlton. Look for classic American fare such as sliders (made with Kobe beef, no less) and barbecue ribs to sustain your wagers of sin.
content.property: Food served Sports bar Wheelchair-accessible bathroom No stairs to bathroom Video/pinball games Private party room(s) Good for groups

content.description: We know, we know: The last thing Chicago needs is another Irish bar. But once inside this sprawling (yet somehow still inviting) spacewhich has separate areas for eating pub grub, watching the game from the bar and even reading (in the cozy library)you just may find yourself wanting more.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 22, 36, 77

address.street: Macys on State Street, 111 N State St, lower level
Macys on State Street, 111 N State St, lower level

content.description: A bar in a department store may sound like hell (and this place is on the basement floor, so geographically its pretty close). But this baseball-themed stalwart is crucial this time of year, when the maniacal behavior of frantic shoppers can be endlessly nerve-grating. So sit down, drink and dont stop until you feel ready to go out there again.
content.public-transport: El: Blue, Red to Washington; Brown, Green, Orange, Purple (rush hrs) to Randolph

content.description: Its tough to find an eponymous connection to this place, named for the Lerner and Loewe musical about a mythical Scottish town. But there are other charms to be found: Bartender Dawn will open the peanut bag for you and fix you up with an ice-cold Jger from the cooler while the rest of the bar buzzes with pool leagues.

Even after the beer garden closes for the season, youll find plenty of warmth from the friendly clientele at this brick corner barnot to mention a decent bottled-beer selection: 13 domestics and nine imports (no drafts). Serious steel darters from the Windy City Dart League like to hang at Ricky Gs, where playing pool is free and the jukebox offers a serviceable selection of tunes.
content.property: Darts Conversation friendly Outdoor seating Pool table

content.description: Welded to the stools of this cozy corner tap, a loyal contingent of career drinkers elbow up to sip cheap suds and ignore the televised sports. But its the recreational drinkers lured by killer daily specials that really keep the bar in business. On Saturdays, domestic pitchers are five bucks, and on Sundays during Bears season, you can brave the cold to grill up burgers and brats outside.

Emblazoned with shamrocks, a sign near the front reads Drink like a champion today. How could you not want to, what with such heartfelt encouragement? With nine drafts, a comfortable U-shaped bar and a popcorn machine to keep you thirsty, youll find its easy to do just that. This homey pub also puts out free eats on Bears game days and hosts a trivia contest nearly every Friday.
content.property: Conversation friendly Good for over-40 crowd

content.description: The exterior looks like just another generic office space, but inside youll find a clean, rustic room with exposed brick and wood beams, and a genuine steel dartboard that gets plenty of play from the Windy City Steel Darters. The group breaks from practice for the preferred deal of the working-class heroes hanging around the cool pounded-copper bar: a loaded Chicago-style hot dog with fries and a Corona Light for $4.

Gel-haired guys ogle as gaggles of sparkle-topped seoritas pop, lock and drop it to hyperdanceable Top 40 on the main floor of this Latino hot spot. But the real action goes down in the dim, catacomblike basement, where beat-heavy Spanish-language tunes and dirty dancing reign supreme.
content.openingtimes: Mon, Tue, Thu 10pm4am; Sat 10pm5am (closed Wed, Sun)

content.description: To access this new see-and-be-seen contender, you have to take the elevator (whose color-of-envy glow is no accident) to the eighth floor. Well admit that the room does have a viewboth of the skyline and of the well-heeled, bottle serviceseeking clientelebut thats pretty much where this spot stops being distinctive from the bounty of other luxury lounges in River North.
content.property: Outdoor seating Views Wheelchair-accessible bathroom No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Dress code

content.description: Regulars call this place Rogers, because Roger Patricks family has run it for the past 56 years. Its clean and comfortable with that lived-in feel, but dont look for flat screens or any of that yuppie nonsense. Instead, theres character in the form of a dusty piano, a brick from Old Comiskey Park on display, and pics of happy-looking regulars grinning around the World Series trophysomething youll probably never see on the North Side.

When the Hunt Club was revamped (and renamed) a few months ago, the sports-bar feeling was the first thing to go. In its place, three levels of plush, mocha-toned cocktail lounge were installed (the second floor is more suited to dining than the others). But Bears fans need not worry: The plasmas are still here. Its just the sticky floors that left.
content.property: Outdoor seating Late Night Food served Wheelchair-accessible bathroom No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Private party room(s) Dress code Good for groups

content.description: Sitting on one of the tree-stump counter stools at this sleek, designer coffeehouse doesnt really make for an outdoorsy experiencethe room is too influenced by midcentury-modern design to conjure the outdoors. But it is a lovely experience nonetheless, thanks to oversized mugs filled with lavender-scented chai lattes, hot sandwiches and baked goods. A newly added brunch menu includes Milk & Honey granola and other favorites like mascarpone-stuffed brioche French toast, and a new bar area means Little Branch is no longer just a daytime pitstop.
content.public-transport: El: Green, Orange, Red to Roosevelt. Bus: 3, 12, 29, 62, 146

content.description: For its second location, Uncommon Ground went with a perfect space, a room that is so warm, so perfect, so log-cabin chic that, unfortunately, the food cant compete. So if youre going to make a point to visit (and you should, because once here youll never want to leave), go with the basics: salads, meatloaf, its justifiably famous brunch (the Uncommon Breakfast Melt is brilliant). That way, your focus will remain on the real attraction of the place: the room.

From the menu of deep-fried pizza dough, burgers and pulled pork to the well-plucked selection of roots-rock on the stereo, pretty much everything at this friendly pub is plain and simple. Framed black-and-white photos of the owners relatives cover the walls; pints of Guinness are three bucks; and if youre out of smokes, the chatty, pompadoured bartender will gladly hand over his last one like hes known you forever.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 8, 9, 11, 76

address.street: 96th floor, John Hancock Center, 875 N Michigan Ave
96th floor, John Hancock Center, 875 N Michigan Ave

content.description: Instead of paying the $11 to get into the 94th floor Hancock Observatory, take the bullet-fast elevator up to this 96th floor bar in the sky and drop that cash on a cocktail instead. The decora sort of circa-1987 Sharper Imagecatalog lookis in dire need of an overhaul, but the panoramic, vertigo-inducing views of the twinkling city at night never get old.

Flo, the octogenarian namesake of this eclectic polka haven, dishes up storiesalong with servings of homemade South American soup and pierogilike a natural raconteur. Shes a genuine Chicago character in a place that could legitimately lay claim to classic status. Flos could serve as a set for The Petrified Forest, with its big stage for live bands and karaoke, mixed-up furniture that looks like it came from someones attic, and ever-present congenial hostess.
content.property: Food served Classic Chicago spot Karaoke

content.description: When asked if hes the bars namesake, the grizzled barkeep with the gray beard and ponytail might arch a brow and mutter, in a thick Polish accent, Depends on whos asking. Hell warm up eventually, as will the drinkers bellied up to the Formica bar laughing at Polish TV shows. Theyre likely the authors of many clever signs, including this gem: roses are red, violets are blue, Id like to put my penis in you.
content.property: Conversation friendly Darts Good for over-40 crowd Pool table Video/pinball games

content.description: Were told that the passed-out gentleman stretched over a swivel chair near the bar is Chuckie. Something tells us this is not an unusual event at this Portage Park dive. A testament to the strength of the drinks? Perhaps. A Bloody Mary here is simply a glass full of vodka with a splash of premade mix. With its posters of scantily clad women (if bra ads qualify as posters), Henrykas gives off the vibe of a preadolescent boys clubhouseno secret password needed.

Not everything on the menu at this dark corner spot under the El is always available (our request for spinach pie was met with How badly do you want it?). But that doesnt turn out to be a problem, because everything you can get is just as cheap and solid as the next. Of course, there are some standouts: The grilled salmon is perfectly satisfying (save for the out-of-place tartar sauce); the kebabs are particularly delicious; and the steak, chicken and kefta are all succulent, tender andseeing as how theyre the showcase of the restaurantunlikely to be out of stock.
content.public-transport: El: Green, Pink to Clinton. Bus: 9, 20

content.description: In the morning, this Merch Mart food court outpost of the North Shore gourmet grocer lets hungry workers mix in fresh strawberries, almonds and flavored syrups into a half-dozen cold cereals or a steaming container of steel-cut oats. Egg scrambles are simple, delicious tortilla-wrapped omelettes made with ingredients like edamame, goat cheese or sausage. At lunchtime, the place serves uncommon sausages like wild boar, lamb and duck. For nine-to-fivers too busy to make it to Hot Dougs, this is an adequate alternative.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Merchandise Mart. Bus: 65, 125, 156
Brown, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Quincy
content.property: Sports bar After-work crowd Food served Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Karaoke No steps at entrance

content.description: Dirty old men havent gone the way of peep shows; theyve ended up here. On a recent afternoon about a dozen of them lavished attention on the Polish bartender in a skimpy halter top who downs shots with the googly-eyed customers. Competing for attention is Jeopardy! on the TV, which elicits shouted-out answers from the brew crew as it chomps on pretzels served in big bowls. And for those harboring dreams of a better place to be, theres a lotto machine on-site.
content.property: Good for over-40 crowd Conversation friendly Video/pinball games Fireplace

content.description: Every meal at this hidden gem begins and ends with a comforting little touch on the shoulder from the waitress. In between, the Latin-tinged menu offers plenty of other comforts. In the morning, pair fair-trade coffee with the plato tipico, a breakfast plate of carefully cooked free-range eggs topped with vibrant red salsa, refried black beans, slices of avocado, salty cheese and impeccable fried plantains. The daily soups, like the subtle, creamy asparagus, are a highlight at dinner. Juicy skirt steakalong with rice, guacamole and beansproves a delicious filling for warm corn tortillas. A friend of the owners makes all the cakes, including the hulking double-chocolate thats homestyle-good.

Were not sure if these three dark rooms (complete with two sparkly bars, a lit frosted-glass wall that throws shadows and plenty of satin-clad Lincoln Parkers) evokes Paris the way the owners intended. But thats nothing the French-flaired bar menu and a Champagne flight cant fix.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 8, 11, 74
content.property: Date place Private party room(s) Food served

content.description: Bargoers in Schiller Park are, it seems, completely oblivious to the luxury sports bar concept. Proof is this bare-bones strip mall spot, where the ball gamedominated TVs arent the flat-screen variety, and the popular beer isnt microbrewed. In fact, as long as these folks can get in on a game at one of the two coveted pool tables, everyone seems happy to have all extravagance out of sight and out of mind.

If you ask this ill-decorated bars proprietor (a loud, disagreeable Eastern European man) for the beer selection, hes likely to gruffly point you to the refrigerators at his attached Leland Liquors and tell you to take a look for yourself. And if you go to the bathroom, beware: He might falsely accuse you of attempting to pocket a beer mug. In other words, come for the cheap boozenot the conversation.

The story behind this new cupcake caf is sweeter than the goods themselves: Owner John Nicolades named it after his favorite grade-school teacher, who baked cupcakes for students birthdays, whose recipes are behind the shops sweets and whose personal belongings (like vintage ice skates) are fancifully displayed on the walls. In our two favorites of the half-dozen cupcakes, bits of bright carrot mesh with cream-cheese buttercream, and tangy dollops of lemon curd cut a rich vanilla cake. Reenact your own grade-school days by having a cupcake at the swing-style chairs flanking the counter. Look for morning hours featuring breakfast baked goods and coffee drinks to start in a few weeks.
content.public-transport: El: Red, Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Fullerton. Bus: 22, 36, 151
content.openingtimes: Mon noon10pm; TueThu 8am10pm; Fri, Sat 8ammidnight; Sun 8am10pm

content.property: Good for dining at bar Good for groups Notable wine list Private party room(s)

content.description: The Bears season is best expressed by a poster of a three-year-old wearing a Bears sweater and flipping the bird in this conversation-friendly oasis in Rogers Park. Swinging saloon doors open into a vast room where a miniature Dale Earnhardt Jr. No. 8 car revolves in a slow orbit over the Formica bar and pretzel rods in big bowls on the bar beckon the adventurous. Tuck a pint, grab a pack of cigs to go and walk a block or so to Giordanos to pick up your nightcap pizza.

Jock hangout or eclectic short-order haven with booze? Its a tough call when the place is run by a former Sport-O nicknamed Rabbit (we hear he was pretty fast) and the house special of a belt-busting burger with crispy fries and an Old Style is $6.25. Beyond the basics, theres a separate room with tables, a fake slot machine and plenty of rabbit cartoons to give the place some atmosphere.
content.public-transport: El: Blue to Jefferson Park. Bus: 81, 85, 92

content.description: We were willing to forgive the forgettable name emblazoned on an awning out front. Then we realized theres really nothing memorable inside this run-of-the-mill neighborhood bar, either: a half-dozen on-tap beers, a digital juke box and a pool table. Jeez, sounds an awful lot like 133 other bars we can think of.

Maybe when it went by the more prosaic name of The Captains Deck, this place featured nautical decor and lively pirate types, but these days, the only decorative touches are mirrored beer signs, while the conversation drifts to the pedestrian (four grown men arguing about how to spell Pontiac, for example). We were told by one boozer that 25 years ago, the bar was called Richard Craniums (dickhead, get it?). So it may not be the classiest place around, but the beer is cold and cheap, and if you know some good filthy jokes, theyd go over like gangbusters here.
content.public-transport: El: Red to Howard. Bus: 49B, 93, 97, Pace 215
content.property: Conversation friendly Darts Live bands Pool table Video/pinball games

content.description: A Cuban sandwich shop ought to serve an amazing cubano, and here its near perfect, the Swiss cheese and roasted pork sporting deep, rich flavors, the ham and mustard countering with a lively saltiness. (The pickles dont hurt either, but sometimes the shop runs out.) Even better is the pan con bistec, a heroish number boasting a copious supply of tender, aggressively seasoned steak. But dont get overzealous: Some sandwiches here fall flat, and the croqueta preparadaham croquettes, sliced ham, Swiss cheese and ketchupis one of them.

Theres something for everyone at Hamiltons, so long as youre down with going Greek. Saturday nights feel like a tour down fraternity row, all without having to go door to door and with wallet-friendly specials that complete the package (Coors Lights are $2.75, half-pound cheeseburgers are $3). If a sorority sister passes over a snowball shot, take it. You'll need one to brave the 80s music Patrick Swayzeesque dance party in the back room.
content.property: Conversation friendly No stairs to bathroom Extensive beer selection Good for groups Darts No steps at entrance Private party room(s) Sports bar Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Late Night Food served

content.description: If you want to be close to Blackhawk action but prefer to have your own booth, a few cocktails and a kitchen nearby just waiting to pump out buffalo wings, this bar should do fine. Nearly every wall in the spacious two-room pub boasts a handful of flat-screens, so the birds-eye view of the game should keep you busy, but if you do get bored, pick up a pool stick and start some action of your own.
content.property: Food served Good for groups Pool table Sports bar

content.description: The two Korean-Americans behind this new chicken joint have a good product at the core of their operation and seem to genuinely want to make customers happy. The chicken is fresh, of good quality, and comes slathered in three different sauces: a sticky barbecue, a hot saucelaced Buffalo and a sesame-soy glaze dubbed Seoul Sassy. We prefer the latter, but even unadorned the chicken stands out for its juicy meat and crunchy black pepperdotted crust. Theres also a decent bibimbap (best ordered with marinated vegetables, beef, an egg and brown rice) and Korean-style burritos whose fresh vegetables benefit from a liberal slather of sweetish hot sauce, but the chicken is the thing.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 22, 36, 76

content.description: This Loop creperiewith its stainless-steel pendant lamps and black lacquer tablesskews more Sex In the City than Saint Germain Boulevard. But look past the ladies nursing cups of java and slinging gossip and youll find one of Chicagos better creperies. The spongy griddle-caramelized things are cooked to order, with fillings thatll whisk you from Russia (salmon roe and sour cream) to France (coq au vin). During your voyage, stop for the Katmandhu, curried chicken drizzled with spicy-sweet chutney.
content.public-transport: El: Blue, Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Clark/Lake

content.description: This dark, borderline seedy dive actually sports plenty of reasons to make a stop. The regulars are pretty colorful (especially the self-proclaimed Huey, Dewey, and Louie trio who offer up some boozy foolosophy), the drafts are only $2, and theres plenty to look at, whether its the fifty-something bartender making out with her boyfriend or a four-foot wingspan airplane suspended from the ceiling on fishing line.
content.property: Conversation friendly Good for over-40 crowd Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Pool table

content.description: With its Z-brick walls, cast-iron radiators providing some good Chicago-style heat and a decent-enough pool table, Syrenas has the feel of your best Ukrainian buds basement lounge. Kick back and enjoy a zimne piwo (cold beer) for under two bucks while sitting at the lacquered bar and play some tunes on the digital jukebox or just soak up the floor show of an extremely diligent bartender whose cleanliness rivals any suburban housewife we know of.

address.street: Super H Mart, 7801 N Waukegan Rd
Super H Mart, 7801 N Waukegan Rd

content.description: Chicken is the main (okay, only) thing on offer at this fast-food spot in the mega Korean market Super H Mart. The wait is long (15 minutes per order) but its worth it, and theres plenty of people-watching or produce-ogling while you wait. Thanks to patented mixed-grains crust and fryers bubbling with 100% vegetable oil, the finished product is trans fatfree and nearly greaseless, but far from tasteless. Purists should stick with the plain marinated, dipped and fried version, while those game for vaguely odd but addictive flavors should venture out and order half garlic and half sweet-and-spicy; the latters chile kick is tempered by savory cinnamon.

Situated among a long row of boutiques, and just a few blocks from two malls, Litos is in a perfect position to provide that most essential of snacks: the one that provides sustenance for more shopping. The small storefront offers about eight stuffed pastries a day, including a Hawaiian version with mozzarella, ham and pineapple and a hearty version with shredded chicken and rice. One makes a snack; two or three make a mealand since each one only costs a couple of bucks, youll have plenty of money leftover to spend down the street.
content.public-transport: El: Red, Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Fullerton. Bus: 22, 36, 151

content.description: Sometimes its the little things that win over our cocktail-loving hearts. In the case of Bobby Gs, its the nicely chilled vodka that gets poured into frosty martini glasses, the freshly sliced fruit wedges, the flickering candles, the little Snickers bars in a basket in the restroom, and a bartender who takes such time and care in mixing a tasty Bloody Mary that youd think she was making it for herself.
content.property: Conversation friendly Good for over-40 crowd Pool table Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Video/pinball games Outdoor seating

content.description: No, its not some pawnshop in a David Mamet play, but the clutter might remind you of the set of American Buffalo. There are stuffed animals, snow villages, football helmets, bric-a-brac, and a dozen or so living relics sucking down MGD drafts at the green Formica bar. Were told the place is named for the owner, whose nickname was Goofy because he was goofy, but since the doctor told him to stop drinking his nickname is now Crabby.
content.property: Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Pool table Conversation friendly Good for over-40 crowd

content.description: Theres a lot of room around this half hexagon of a bar, and thats a good thing for two reasons: First, it provides lots of space for the bottles that will undoubtedly collect in front of you (there is no beer on tap here), and second, it ensures that when you go to the backroom for a round of pool, your seat will still be there when you return.

Although this place pushes the northern edge of the city limits, a White Sox World Series pennant waves proudly here. Theres also a pic of Babe Ruth behind the bar, and with that big, moony, benevolent face beaming down, how can anyone be in a bad mood? The $2.25 drafts in frosty pints also help with that mood thing, enough to counter the sign that says, beware of attack bartender.
content.public-transport: El: Red, Purple (rush hrs) to Howard. Bus: 49B, 97, Pace 215
content.property: Conversation friendly Darts Good for over-40 crowd Pool table Video/pinball games

content.description: The smoking ban is evident at this neighborly bar in the form of a gum-filled beer pitcher bearing a sign that reads, trying to quit? have a stick of gum on bridgeport inn. Theres also a hand-drawn sign offering Girl Scout cookies for those who like Thin Mints with their Jager or Dr. McGillicuddys schnapps, but the flannel-clad crew prefers MGDs and the same padded stools they held court from yesterday.

Warning: Everything at this high-design pizzeria is tiny except the crowds. The space fits one communal table and a shelf of carefully selected sundries, while the menu consists of only four pizzas (and no, a create-your-own option isnt one of them). Perhaps most important, the pizza oven is also small, and the man in charge prefers for only one pizza to be cooked at a time. Could it be worth the wait? Thanks to the puffy, chewy crust; the house-pulled mozzarella; layers of fresh, earthy mushrooms; and an obsessive eye for detail, the answer, if your mouth isnt already watering, is yes.

Nia Asimiswhose family has a long history of food service on Randolph Streethas opened this small-plates spot, where she attempts to serve food and drinks from every region of the Mediterranean. Its not a bad idea, but the experience can be fairly erratic: For every good move that Nias kitchen makes (a lovely trio of Mediterranean sausages, including a tender, housemade loukanika), there seems to be an equally bad one (piquillo peppers stuffed with chewy braised oxtail). The kitchen seems to do best with lamb, so stick to the juicy lamb-feta meatballs and the braised lamb shoulder, which is so tender it barely requires chewing.
content.public-transport: El: Green, Pink to Clinton. Bus: 8, 20

content.description: Keep your chair in the direction of the view (a 15th-floor vantage point with the river, and all the blinking buildings along it, in clear sight) and a cocktail in your hand (despite the name, the Zentini actually isnt bad). If you do, youll find that youre not in the lobby of the Holiday Inn after allyoure out on the town. (Or, at the very least, out over it.)
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Merchandise Mart. Bus: 65, 125, 156
content.property: Food served Views Date place Conversation friendly

content.description: A Northwest Side Polish hangout where the Okocim runs as cold as the luck of the boozers scratch-off effortssounds typical. Dropped lights, a touch-tunes jukebox, and three flat-screens add a touch of class, but this is still one of those quintessential neighborhood bars where you could disappear into a sea of anonymity.
content.public-transport: El: Blue to Jefferson Park. Bus: 56, 81, 85
content.property: Darts Conversation friendly Good for over-40 crowd Video/pinball games Wheelchair-accessible bathroom

content.description: Morning bars are great for downing an eye-opener, and this Far North spot is where many come to do just that. The bartender says its been around since 1934, starting out as an ice company (during that buzz-kill Prohibition thing). A photo of one of the ice wagons lends a nice nostalgic touch, and the green Formica bar and green linoleum floor make this place look like a movie set for a director trying to capture a real Chicago Irish bar.

Curvy banquettes, neon lamps, sleek granite and a tempting martini list are among this Hotel Orrington bars recent renovations. All would be a lot easier to enjoy without Simons cranked up criticism on American Idol overpowering the jazz soundtrack. Still, if you can tune out the tube, sink into the plush velvet and split a bottle of vino, you might just find your new Evanston escape.
content.public-transport: El: Purple to Davis. Bus: Pace 208, Pace 212

content.description: It could be the great view of Grant Park, or the menu of diner food thats at your beck and call, or maybe the fact that this bar, attached to the Essex Inn hotel, is a place where youll be able to sip your drink in peace and quiet. But we cant help but think that part of the reason people come here is that its one of the only spots around where you can have a drink at 10 am, and nobody will blink an eye.

With a name like this, youd expect this musty old joint to be a hotbed of blue-collar types, but the laconic bartender says only, My husband named it that and then clams up. Its a rather dreary establishment, with the usual worn-out pool table, about 20 barstools, a couple of TVs and nary a draft beer in sight. If you want to nurse the blues without any chipper commentary, this is the place.

Anyone who fears Ukrainian Village is losing its ethnicity can take solace in this caf. Well-heeled women chat over coffee and cake, a handful of sugar-rushing kids scrape the bottom of their fruit parfaits, and neighborhood elders, including men of the cloth, tuck into particularly good bowls of borscht, all to the tune of Ukrainian chatter. The younger of the mother-daughter team behind the classy, casual spot is right to recommend her moms baked goods (the airy, sour creamlayered napoleon cake goes fast for a reason), but the savory crpes, buttery panini and delicious soups are worth a visit on their own.
content.property: Vegetarian-friendly Kid-friendly Outdoor seating Cheap (entrees under $10) BYOB

content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 8,11, 73, 74.

content.description: This small shop front caters only to delivery and pickup, but there are small tables for those that just cant wait to tear into their sesame chicken.

content.property: Vegetarian-friendly Outdoor seating Late-night dining Kid-friendly

content.description: With a Moulin Rougelike cast of weekend entertainersfrom castanet-wielding belly dancers to stoic turban-topped sitar playersyoud figure the fare at this Oak Park Indian restaurant would skew exotic. Yet its the standards like silken spinach dotted with paneer, ginger-and-garlicinfused chicken mukhni and lamb tikka masala that shine. The jalabi dessert, which often suffers a waxy tasteless fate, is pliant and sports a hint of orange, while gulab jaman, bathed in honey and perfumed with rose water, is an airy antidote to the dry dough bombs you find at other spots.
When a fast-food Mexican diner brags about burritos as big as your head, the only question left is chicken or steak?
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (Rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus 8,11,74

content.description: Corporate bookworms and broke college students peacefully coexist at this neighborhood corner-shop cafe. While quality caffeine is the biggest draw, Sienna also has a small menu. Try some of the fresh pastries, or the spinach and feta croissant.
Quick grub for busy travelers staying at the hotel, or any Chicagoan looking for a cheap ($7.95) lunch buffet in the loop.

The L.A. Lucky Strike is a fave on Entourage. Chicagos branch is more local and less celeb. Still, you can feel like one of the beautiful people downing drinks and munching better-than-youd-expect grub in the wine bar. Or make it more casual by playing pool or bowling while you quaff a cold one.
content.openingtimes: MonThu noonmidnight; Fri noon2am; Sat 11am2am; Sun 11ammidnight
content.property: Pool table No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Fireplace Food served Video/pinball games

content.description: The one thing that sets this place apart from every other Lincoln Park Golden Teehosting, free popcornoffering, Black Crowesblasting, postfrat-boys-high-fiving hangout is The Dark Crystal playing on the TVs. But as far as 4am spots on this strip goes, wed rather get loaded on the $3 beer-of-the-month drafts here than deal with the unbearable heaviness of Neo.
content.property: Video/pinball games Sports bar No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Outdoor seating Late Night

content.description: This woody bar has the same investment bankerlook-alike clientele and beer selection as every other Irish-tinged sports bar on this strip of Southport, but a few curiosities remain. The sepia-toned photos of the bars namesake, circa early 20th century, posing victorious in a wide variety of sports (conquering a steep mountainside on skis; winning an auto race) is puzzlingly humorous, while the large aquarium behind the barfull of water and coral, yet entirely fish-freeis just plain puzzling.
content.property: Sports bar Darts Live bands Wheelchair-accessible bathroom No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom

content.description: If this place kind of looks like a dormitory lounge, thats because its a college kids dream come true: lots of industrial, unbreakable furniture; a menu stocked with greasy food; a big pool table in back; and a bar with 60yes, 60beers on tap.
content.property: Extensive beer selection Food served Pool table

content.description: This bar opened in the 1940s, and it seems like time has stood still since the 70s. The bar that adjoins the bowling alley area looks and feels like a wood-paneled rec room, with a pool table, jukebox, and lots of bowling and pool league plaques on the walls. If you dont bowl, you could be just as happy throwing back a few while playing some country or Elvis tunes.
content.openingtimes: TueFri noon to midnight; Sat, Sun noon10pm

content.description: In case you missed all the concert posters, the flat screens showing performance footage or the corner stage (which, more often than not, has a band on it), live music is the theme of this new South Side pub. But with such a good beer selection and a friendly staff, you dont need to be into the music to want to spend your night here.
content.property: Food served Live bands No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom No steps at entrance

content.description: Curiously, theres not one piano in this place. For crissakes, we didnt even hear any Billy Joel piping from the digital juke. So whats the deal with Piano Man? A short jaunt from the Friendly Confines, this corner taps a bare-bones Cubs bar with a bounty of TVs, delightful floor-to-ceiling windows that open up on nice days and one really misleading moniker.
content.property: Sports bar Pool table Food served Fireplace

content.description: If Caesar likes you, feel free to enter. The vigilant dog at the door of this sports bar has freaked out a few would-be customers, but were brave, and Caesar turned out to be cool. Hes just protecting the places characterwhich is helped by exposed brick and old wood, and hindered by buffalo wings and a big screen. The beer selection goes beyond the basics, with three dozen bottles and ten drafts; if the unseasonable warmth keeps up, sample your way through the list in the beer garden.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 8, 11, 76
content.property: Darts Sports bar Conversation friendly Food served Extensive beer selection Outdoor seating

content.description: English is definitely a second language at this lively Polish bar, and while its not much to look at on the outside, the inside is like stepping into an Eastern Euro vacation. Okocim drafts are nicely chilled, Zywiec is on offer for a great session beer, Polish music abounds and even the TVs are tuned to Polish cable. The shiny black lacquered bar and the red, green and yellow lights are throwbacks to the disco era, setting the mood for fruity concoctions like the raspberrytini.
content.property: Conversation friendly Good for groups Good for over-40 crowd No steps at entrance Pool table Private party room(s) Fireplace

content.description: Microbrews, musicians and a kick-ass sound system combine to make you feel like youre in a cool, hippie, music nerds college apartment, minus the patchouli. With portraits of rock & roll heroes lining the walls (along with a shot of De Niro from his cutting-edge Johnny Boy days), comfy sofas for lounging and a collection of bootlegged live concerts on CDR, this place pulls off what every Hard Rock Caf aims to do. All 16 beers on tap, including micros like Rogue Dead Guy ale, run through clean, well-maintained lines and come out frosty.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 8, 11, 74, 76
content.property: Conversation friendly Good for over-40 crowd Pool table Private party room(s) Extensive beer selection

content.description: The scarlet color scheme and overpriced cocktails of Cherry Red have been replaced by this classy spots subtle amber tones, comfy leather banquettes andas its name announcesa comprehensive list of bottled beer. Lots of love is given to highbrow brews, yet the owners seem to be oddly enamored with the Champagne of Beers; bottles of High Life lined up in front of all the light fixtures give the bar a golden glow.

After a fire destroyed much of this ballyhooed Boystown hangout in early 09, Scarlet has risen from the ashes (literally!) in much improved form. The sepia-toned images, stained glass and gaudy red lighting have been replaced by elegant touches including a 13-foot reupholstered couch, a comfy antique chaise and a glittery vintage disco ball. The rebirth also includes a bit more elbow roomperfect for the elements that remained intact, namely the loyal and adorable bar staff and bustling theme nights like Frat House Thursdays and the First Ward Ball.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 8, 22, 77

content.description: Its location inside Evanstons Hotel Orrington may suggest suburban tourist, but yellowing international newspapers plastering the walls give this spacious bar a world-traveler vibe. Despite some bumbling bartending (Remind me, whats in that again?), the place is comfy (beware its nap-conducive leather couches), and since unobtrusive jazz is the only background, a bar stool here is the perfect perch from which to recount all your globe-trotting adventures.
content.public-transport: El: Purple to Davis. Bus: Pace 208, Pace 212

content.description: Chef/owners Greg Mohr and Scott Weiner are under no delusions that the menu here is anything but bar food. But their upscale palates, along with creativity, translate into dishes that take bar food one step further. So the chicken wings are slathered with a housemade hot sauce, mac and cheese is spiked with extras such as pulled pork, and coleslaw gets a sweet dose of pineapple.
content.property: Extensive beer selection Food served Good for groups Sports bar Outdoor seating

content.description: The standard liquor lineup and menu (eggs and pancakes in the morning, burgers and quesadillas in the evening) wont wow you. But the provisions here are just periphery to heated games of eight-ball going down on a dozen pro-quality tables (hourly rates; free on Saturday). Many of the swaggering stick slingers dont drink at all. But us amateurs, we always play better after a couple of beers.
content.public-transport: El: Blue to Grand. Bus: 8 Halsted, 65 Grand
content.property: New Outdoor seating Food served Pool table Darts Video/pinball games
Outdoor seating Food served Pool table Darts Video/pinball games

content.description: A deserted stretch of Northwest Highway isnt what you would call charming surroundings, but is exactly the kind of stretch that needs a cozy escape. Raised booths flanking a fireplace facilitate intimate conversations over pints of imported ale, while the battered old bar encourages drinking with the friendly, blue-collar crowd. That Guinness getcha hungry? Dig into menu highlights like shepherds pie.
content.property: After-work crowd Conversation friendly Good for groups Good for over-40 crowd Live bands No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Private party room(s) Wheelchair-accessible bathroom New Fireplace Food served

After-work crowd Conversation friendly Good for groups Good for over-40 crowd Live bands No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Private party room(s) Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Fireplace Food served

content.description: Its sleepers like this wood-clad corner pub that make bar-hopping worthwhile. Friendly staff and a great beer garden certainly help (well, the latter will when it warms up), but its the darn good food that seals the deal. Fish tacos and juicy burgers frame the Mexican/American menu, but take a look at what the locals order. Yep, thats cevicheperfect with whatever draft is on special that night.
content.public-transport: El: Blue to Jefferson Park. Bus: 54, 56, 78
content.property: Food served After-work crowd Conversation friendly Darts Good for groups No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Video/pinball games Outdoor seating

content.description: In its third incarnation in as many years, this narrow room (which was most recently Fixture) is now just a simple sports bar. There are no beers on tap, and only a handful of televisions. But the neighborhoods residents are apparently so happy to have a place they can pop into every night that they dont seem to mind.

As at the nearby Rainbo Club, the hipness quotient at this less-packed, stripped-down Ukie V stalwart has shot through its nicotine-stained roof, paralleling the changing demographics of the neighborhood. You can still belly up and share cheap suds with a couple of actual Ukrainian expats in the early afternoon, but eager twentysomethings with energy (and hormones) to burn rule the night.

For extreme Cubs fans who dont have Cubs tickets, this new pub offers countless flat-screen TVs and the Holy Cow! Burger Bar, which lets you pick your burger (Tallgrass beef, lamb, etc.), toppings (crispy buttermilk onion strings) and even your bun.
content.property: Outdoor seating Food served Sports bar

content.description: Weve heard that theyre aiming for a frat-boy, sports-bar crowd here during the day, but at night this place seems to be filled with the same skaterish folks who were hanging here when it was still Celebrity. In fact, though the room has been changed (its a bit brighter), the only major difference seems to be the cocktail list, which now offers gems like the PickliniKetel One and pickle juice.
content.property: No stairs to bathroom Food served

content.description: In the realm of Wrigleyville bars, this slightly edgier spot is like the one wayward bro in the group of knuckle-dragging Cubs fans who plays guitar and just happens to have decent taste in film and music. That translates to sports on TV with the sound drowned out by alternative rock, photos of rebellious cultural figures like Jack Nicholson in The Shining, and Bud and Miller suds served up alongside tasty brews by Summit.

There isnt a more accurately named bar in Chicago. The appeal is more complex, though; a jukebox is loaded with classics, the pool table lovingly worn and the room about as low-key as it is tight. Regulars might be curious about new faces, but a few rounds later youll be old hat. And those rounds will be about as cheap as they come.
content.public-transport: El: Blue to Jefferson Park. Bus: 78, 85, 91
content.property: After-work crowd Conversation friendly Darts Good for groups Good for over-40 crowd Live bands No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Pool table Video/pinball games Private party room(s)

content.description: You wont find shamrocks anywhere in this polished pub. Unfortunately you probably wont find any compelling reason why the owners didnt stay with the Irish connection its name suggests. Despite much decorative to-dobrand-new hardwood floors, granite bar top, classy stained-glass light fixturesthe menu of thaw-and-serve pub grub and the undertrained staff (Whats a white Russian?) just dont do.
content.property: Sports bar Pool table Private party room(s) Conversation friendly

content.description: Even the most crazed commuter wont find it hard to grab some subterranean suds at this Union Station bar. A quick flash of your ID and in no time youll be sipping the daily specials, a $5 martini or a $3 PBR. No food is served, but bartenders dont frown upon patrons bellying up with provisions from the adjacent food court.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Washington

content.description: Pricey drinks and strange artwork notwithstanding (we cant explain the $15 cosmo or the glass-enclosed pillars of fur), this bar has all the elements of a great, swanky cocktail lounge: well-made tipples, fantastic service and a mod interior that betrays the fact that youre in the century-old Palmer House Hilton.
content.public-transport: El: Blue, Red to Monroe; Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Adams
content.property: After-work crowd Classic Chicago spot Food served Date place Notable for cocktails Private party room(s)

content.description: No offense to the beautiful dark-wood bars here, and nothing against all those flatscreens, but while this joint looks a little more upscale than most, this is still a sports bar. The better-than-average pub grub might also take you out of sports barmode for a minute, but shuffleboard and bags bring you right back.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 8, 11, 74
content.property: Food served Sports bar Private party room(s)

content.description: Drinking on Devon usually means BYO in an Indian restaurant. This long-standing pub is the happy exception, boasting a dusty set of regulars happy to recount their versions of local lore. A pool table is a nice diversion, but settling in with cheap drafts among classic tavern decorbeer signs and stained-glass lampsis more to the point.
content.property: Conversation friendly Darts No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Pool table Video/pinball games

content.description: Darts might seem an antiquated game when compared to Golden Tee, but dont tell that to the dedicated players who gather here for a shot at the dozens of boards (newbies can buy dart supplies at the bar; pros bring their own). Nonplayers can take advantage of chatty bartenders and cheap beerbut dont pipe up while the dude behind you is taking aim, unless you want to feel just how sharp those tips are.
content.public-transport: El: Blue to Jefferson Park. Bus: 80, 86, 91
content.property: Conversation friendly Darts Good for groups No stairs to bathroom Private party room(s) Sports bar Video/pinball games

content.description: Good thing bar owner Michael Finans pa came from the Emerald Isle, because he knew just which carpentry folks to call on for a custom-built wood bar that evokes an authentic Irish pub feel. Formerly Zephyrs ice cream parlor, the space now sports a deep red exterior, exposed brick, warm lighting, an open door and a friendly staff. Take a comfy booth and some curry chips to go with your Guinness.
content.public-transport: El: Brown to Montrose. Bus: 78, 81, 145. Metra: Union Pacific N to Ravenswood
content.property: Conversation friendly Food served Fireplace Good for groups No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Outdoor seating

content.description: Maybe its because we can get plenty of wine next door at the shop of the same name, but were more into the cocktails at this comfortable, bi-level wine bar than the vino. Dont miss the Swedish Mary (a Bloody made with aquavit) or the signature G&T (Fever Tree tonic and North Shore gin).
content.property: Wine bar Notable for cocktails Conversation friendly Date place Food served Private party room(s) Outdoor seating

content.description: Normally, sports-crazed drinkers might not look twice at this unpolished Jefferson Park tavern, but once they do, two features will have them hooked on becoming regulars. One, an attached liquor store boasts killer prices and a great selectiongood for moving the party home. And two, the oval bar is rimmed with flat screens covering every sport you could want to watch, from the majors to the obscure.
content.public-transport: El: Blue to Jefferson Park. Bus: 56, 81, 85, 91
content.property: Conversation friendly Darts Good for groups No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Sports bar

content.description: Sure, its dark in Dots, but theres weight to the atmosphere that has nothing to do with light. Rather, the vibe comes from a blues- and soul-packed jukebox, clacking billiards play and cool looks from the all-day regulars, who make it one of the livelier spots around.
content.property: Conversation friendly Darts Good for over-40 crowd No stairs to bathroom Pool table Video/pinball games Wheelchair-accessible bathroom

content.description: True, there is a nice view of the Chicago River from this second-story lounge in the Trump Tower. But sometimes a view isnt enough to offset incredibly pricey drinks. Luckily, those cocktails are so delicious that they help erase the sticker shock and the crowd: Make it seasonal with the Spring Thyme (sauvignon blanc, white peaches and thyme-infused syrup) or a Strawberry Julep.
content.property: Views Notable for cocktails No stairs to bathroom After-work crowd Food served Date place Private party room(s)

content.description: If shabby-simple were a style, this Rogers Park spot would define it. No, you will not have the best panini of your life, but you will be able to grab breakfast or lunch for two, including coffee and juice, for 20 bucks. Follow this advice for a foolproof meal: Start with a double cappuccino, add a side of turkey bacon and some feta to the garlicky spinach omelette (use the English muffin for a sandwich base), and finish with Nutella crpes. Take your meal on the wrought ironclad patio and its a cant-lose scenario.
content.property: Conversation friendly Date place Food served Good for over-40 crowd No stairs to bathroom
Cheap (entrees under $10) Outdoor seating Vegetarian-friendly Kid-friendly BYOB

content.description: If you come to this Irish pub at the right time (say, Sunday at 3pm, when an Irish folk group performs), therell be plenty of room to play darts and plenty of locals to rub shoulders with over a black and tan. Otherwise, you should either be a Northwestern undergrad or be able to keep up with one to fit in with the coed crowd.

Tall, pink, Malaysian cocktails garnished with tiny umbrellas? Check. Huge platters toppling with toothsome shrimp, hefty eggrolls and creamy crab rangoon, all encased in a thick coating of golden batter? Check. Impressively cooked dumplings, sauteed until one side is browned and crispy? Of course. Sweet, tender pork ribs? Garlicky Yu Shan beef? Sweet and sour wontons? Naturally. How else do you think Chinese-American places like this have sustained such brisk business all these years?
content.property: Private party room(s) Outdoor seating Classic Chicago spot Conversation friendly Food served Good for groups Good for over-40 crowd Live bands No stairs to bathroom

content.description: The monochromatic color scheme and the Lichtenstein-ish paintings may not have legs for the long-haul, but in the meantime, this is the mod antidote to the Franco-cheesiness of stalwart La Creperie. Its thinner sweet crpes are superior to its puffy savory counterparts, so for the main event, go with the crispy Cuban panini filled with juicy hunks of shredded pork and oozy Swiss instead. Finish with the eponymous sweet, specifically the cherry mascarpone suzette smartly tempered by bitter orange marmalade.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 8, 11, 22, 36, 74
content.property: After-work crowd Good for groups Good for over-40 crowd No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Pool table Video/pinball games Wheelchair-accessible bathroom

content.description: Picture a cheesy 50s diner reimagined as a smelly dive bar with red vinyl banquettes, an uneven pool table (free on Mondays!) and walls papered with celebrity photos, and youve nailed this place. The service is slow and surly, the drinks taste funny and the music is too loud, but North Park students will escape their dry campus for this place as long as theres nowhere else to drink in the area.
content.property: Conversation friendly Good for over-40 crowd Live bands No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Video/pinball games Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Darts Pool table

content.description: In turning Hey Sushi into a sports bar, the owners did a couple of things: They decked out almost every inch in mahogany, plastered their walls with more plasmas than a Best Buy, and built uncommonly long booths that could easily fit a dozen people each. What they didnt do is install a lot of personality. Guess thats up to the white-hat-wearing, dart-throwing patrons to provide (though we wont hold our breath).
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 22, 36, 76

content.description: One of the Moonshine owners partnered with a chef from Hawaii for this all-day kebab shop that offers quick sticks of Caribbean-tinged eats. Best bets are the artichoke app, yucca fries with banana ketchup, grilled shrimp and sweet potato fritters. Late-night hours enable the surrounding bar crowds, and plans for 10 additional locations in Chicagoland are in the works.
content.property: BYOB Cheap (entrees under $10) Late-night dining Vegetarian-friendly

content.description: This Polish dive/liquor store somehow manages to look like a brightly painted burger joint decorated with fake flowers and Christmas lights. The jukebox relies heavily on Phil Collins and Eastern Bloc pop, PBR is on tap for $1.25 and theres an entire shelf devoted to $1 shots (mostly schnapps in B-list flavors like root beer). The combo is just the ticket for an end-of-the-night wake-up call that yes, you are wasted.

With a bright red awning and a pizza menu with pies called The Popeye and The Painful, Bricks feels right for grabbing dinner with your parents. But with a wine list that's longer than the drafts, its bar suggests otherwise. Just below street level, the place is built like a cave with low ceilings and exposed concrete walls that are never not cold. If it werent for the pop-art lithographs or checkerboard tablecloths, you could be drinking in a David Fincher film.
content.property: Food served Date place Conversation friendly Extensive beer selection Good for groups Good for over-40 crowd No steps at entrance Surprisingly good wine list

content.description: The cold beer in the visible cooler, the blaring TV in the corner, the wood-paneled walls with bright red and yellow accents, the postwork neighborhood guys sipping cerveza at the tiny home bar in backit all adds up to a scene thats more Latino family rec room than restaurant. Hence, the charm of San Luis, which stands out for its homey feel, fresh shrimp tostadas, whole fried snapper and hangover-helping chilaquiles. Fruity rita fans will like the pineappley house version, but beware: Its just as sweet as the Spanglish-speaking servers.
content.public-transport: El: Blue to Logan Square. Bus: 52, 56, 76

content.description: This tiny restaurant is owned by the same people who own Zam Zam, a beloved Indian sweets spot on Devon. Funny, then, that sweets play just a small role here. Instead, this huge menu focuses on savory Indian staples. You can get through the menu piece by piece if you wish (start with the spicy, fist-sized samosas). But if you want to try everything before 2020, hit the juicy tandoori chicken, tender seekh kebab (beef) and spicy Bihari kebabs all at once with the mixed grill.
content.public-transport: El: Red to Bryn Mawr. Bus: 36, 84, 136

content.property: Outdoor seating Date place Surprisingly good wine list

content.description: If your idea of winding down from the day involves 12-year single malt, a Montecristo cigar and rubbing elbows with international businessmen, youll find all three on the seventh-floor patio lounge of this Park Hyatt stunner. Its breezy, sexy and substantial (sushi and small plates abound), but it sure aint cheap, honey, so pack that Amex black.
content.property: Surprisingly good wine list Outdoor seating Notable for cocktails Private party room(s) Food served Dress code Date place Conversation friendly

content.description: Take a cue from the name and go for the nectar of the agave gods at this clubby, Mexican-themed lounge. If youve taken up residence along the sidewalk patio, opt for your tequila in rita form to maximize your tropical experience. Salsa sounds blend with bass-heavy bangers to get the crowd going on weekends, but Tuesdays are almost as busy with $5 sangria pitchers.
content.property: Outdoor seating Notable for cocktails Food served Private party room(s)

content.description: Thou shalt not aggravate thy bartender, reads a placard behind the bar at this well-tended sports dive (Old Style shares tap space with fancier stuff like 312 and Blue Moon). The cozy, wood-paneled room is filled with yellowing sports memorabilia and theres enough room to play pool without jostling the neighborhood regulars.
content.property: Good for over-40 crowd Conversation friendly No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Video/pinball games Pool table Sports bar

content.description: What can lure sports fans away from a sidewalk patio thats spitting distance from Wrigley and offers a front-row view of scantily clad passersby? A bajillion TVs playing every televised game, a batting cage, Pop-A-Shot, mini bowling and more wings than even The Fridge Perry can handle.
content.property: Sports bar Video/pinball games Food served Outdoor seating Good for groups Good for over-40 crowd Pool table Private party room(s)

content.description: If authentic Irish can be defined by the lack of outwardly Irish stuff, then this Portage Park corner pub hits the mark. During the week youll find local dudes draining pints at the bar, but the weekends see younger crowds clogging up the aisle and the adjoining room. Live entertainment amounts to covers by soloists and the occasional scuffle.
content.property: Darts Good for groups Good for over-40 crowd Live bands No stairs to bathroom No steps at entrance Pool table Private party room(s) Wheelchair-accessible bathroom

content.description: When a sign on a bars exterior reads No bra, no panties, come on in! and the interior resembles a cluttered attic (broken stove in the corner, a collection of Fred Flintstone memorabilia), were smitten. Be nice, and lovable curmudgeon Ray will flip on the lights (a miniature bar-top replica of the Budweiser horses) and the jukebox that holds both Frank Zappa and Dolly Parton. But Dont ask for nothing too fancy, Ray insists. Enjoy a $2 can of PBR or Old Style instead.
content.property: No stairs to bathroom Good for over-40 crowd

content.description: Stepping through the doors of this Portage Park disco is like being magically transported to Warszawa in the early 90sPolish girls in tight white pants gyrate to Euro dance beats, the scent of Drakkar Noir is in the air, giant disco balls spin and colored lights flash. Jedynka offers an extensive selection of fruity martinis, pricey Champagne and a bottle-keep system for regulars. Once the fog machine starts blasting, youll have more fun here than at the clubs downtown, even if you dont speak Polish.
content.property: Date place Good for groups No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Notable for cocktails Karaoke

content.description: Wicker Parks only piano bar is also one of its oldest; around since 1998, it opened while area shoppers and sippers were still in school. Karaoke is a big part of the place: the back room bursts with would-be crooners on Friday nights. And on the other nights? Professionalsreplete with boas and dirty jokesshow them how its really done.
content.openingtimes: Mon, WedFri 7pm2am; Fri, Sat 7pm3am; Sun 3pm11pm (closed Tue)

entry.name: OK Pub aka Da Udder Brudder

version.name: OK Pub aka Da Udder Brudder

content.description: This Polish tavern is full of lads drinking Okocim spiked with raspberry syrup and watching soccer on TV, but for an escape, theres a beer garden and a section of loungey leather banquettes divided by fringed curtains where ladies in slinky tops sip Cosmos and appletinis (half price for women on Wednesdays). The service is fantastic, and theres a small menu of Polish-style bar food like borscht and French bread pizza (served traditionally, with ketchup).
content.property: Food served Outdoor seating Conversation friendly Good for groups No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Sports bar Wheelchair-accessible bathroom

content.description: If spring break is a sacred ritual, this garden-level DePaul-area bar is the unofficial altar. College students arrive in flocks for potent fish-tanks, beer specials and drinking games. Hokey decor includes tiki details, AstroTurf, picnic tables and a cordoned-off sandbox where coolers of beer replace bottle service.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 8, 76, 77
content.property: Darts Good for groups Live bands Karaoke No stairs to bathroom Private party room(s) Video/pinball games

content.description: Stan Wozniak, formerly behind the Gold Coasts Jillys, tries his hand in River North, where two floors are split into four distinct rooms. One features a piano crooner; another is a disco, mirror balls and all. The suited-up crowd leans maturenorth of 40and expects to progress from Sinatra, to 80s to pop, roughly in correlation to martini consumption.
content.property: After-work crowd Dress code Food served Good for over-40 crowd Live bands Piano bar Private party room(s) Date place

content.description: The plethora of televisions tuned to ESPN herenot to mention the fratty attitude of the staffwould suggest that this is just another vanilla sports bar. And yet, with rust-colored tin and sleek blonde wood covering every surface, the place is so gorgeous it cancels out any annoying Cubs-fan behavior. (And if it doesnt, a respectable lineup of draft beer can lend a hand.)
content.property: Sports bar Food served No stairs to bathroom

content.description: Tucked away on a Pilsen side street, this kitschy sports pub has Cubs paraphernalia cheek-by-jowl with White Sox banners and an impressive array of neon signs and beer steins on display alongside photo collages of regulars and neighborhood sports teams. Perhaps as a sign of changing times, recently the game was turned off in favor of Oprah, and blue raspberry martini mix sits next to bags of pork cracklings.
content.property: Good for groups Conversation friendly No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Pool table Sports bar Wheelchair-accessible bathroom

content.description: All the sports-bar standards are here, from beer signs to dozens of flat screens, except lager leans toward Okocim Lager and Euro soccer and boxing replaces typical Sox/Cubs bouts. Come on fight night when a Polish bruiser is competing and you wont hear an English word spoken, though luckily, cheery bartenders are just bilingual enough.
content.property: Conversation friendly Darts Good for groups Pool table No steps at entrance Private party room(s) Sports bar

content.description: We could tell you about all the people dressed like faux truckers and drinking PBR here. And we could tell you about the long, narrow room, and the stage in that room that houses two leather chairs and a gothic, almost-naked (save for the thick eyeliner) go-go dancer. But instead, well just tell you that Pete Wentz owns this bar, and you can figure out the rest.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Red, Purple (rush hrs) to Chicago. Bus: 22, 66, 156
content.property: Karaoke Live bands Private party room(s)

content.description: The bordello ambience of this Polish martini bar (which has a sister location on Milwaukee Avenue) is inviting on the surface: Theres a petunia-lined patio, open-air bistro seating in front and a breezy, red-lit back room with comfortable couches and flowing white drapes. But watery martinis (candy-sweet concoctions with names like Diva and Wild Sex) and service that alternates between neglectful and borderline hostile dont beckon us to become regulars.
content.property: Food served Outdoor seating Wheelchair-accessible bathroom No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom

content.description: What sets this vaguely New Orleansthemed place apart from the cluster of cookie-cutter yuppie bars on Southport is the slightly older set; a more low-key, conversation-friendly atmosphere; and a second-floor balcony from which to watch the revelry belowand maybe even sneak a smoke. Decent draft picks, occasional live music, and plenty of outdoor seating add to the appeal.
content.property: Conversation friendly Food served Good for groups Live bands Outdoor seating

content.description: Locals who grumble about Logans gentrification need to get over itstop into this new bar and grill in early evening, and the packed rooms of young families with kids in tow, couples watching the game and eclectic groups of friends are proof that the neighborhood needed a catchall. A few warnings, though: The music often edges toward blasting, and the food pales in comparison to sibling Northside Bar and Grill.
content.property: Food served Good for groups Outdoor seating Fireplace Extensive beer selection

content.description: The namesake 29th-floor view is the thing at this tiny rooftop barat least, thats what everybody says. But though the patio section is nice, the view of the skyline is not stunning enough to fight for a seat there. Especially when you can sit at the stylish indoor bar and get just as much beauty out of one of the carefully-crafted cocktails.
content.property: Views Notable for cocktails Date place Conversation friendly Outdoor seating Food served

content.description: We had to teach our bartender how to make a White Russian (despite the fact that Cosmos were listed as a special), but the generous pours and nice beer selection (Gumballhead, Mad Hatter) made it difficult to be miffed. This friendly Pilsen sports pub also offers a selection of homey bar food, a video beer-pong machine, and Guitar Hero and Wii bowling tournaments Wednesday through Sunday.
content.property: Conversation friendly Food served Outdoor seating Good for groups Good for over-40 crowd Pool table No stairs to bathroom No steps at entrance Video/pinball games Sports bar

content.description: This Wicker Park karaoke pub has the ambiance of a yuppie dorm room: Posters of predictable rock icons such as Jimi Hendrix and Bob Dylan line the walls while drunken Chads belt ironic renditions of Who Let The Dogs Out and groups of gals get teary eyed over Pearl Jam sing-alongs. If drunken karaoke is not your thing, you can always retreat to the heavily air-conditioned pool room in back.
content.property: Darts Good for groups Karaoke No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Pool table Video/pinball games

content.description: The plush black-leather seating gives this tiny wine bar a loungey feeling, and the well-pruned wine list, full of gems from boutique wineries, is one of the best in this part of town. It all adds up to the kind of experience youd never guess was created by the same people who own the loud, fratty Duffys next door.
content.property: Surprisingly good wine list Date place Conversation friendly

content.description: Funny thing about this Navy Pierarea pit stop: Where youd expect a tourist rip-off, you instead find real value. Cold bottled beers ring in sub-fiver (a miracle in this area), and the grill itemsgyros to Chicago dogsare reasonable and rival more authentic spots around town. Forget the blaring TV and dingy decora pittance for the unexpected quality.
content.property: Outdoor seating Food served After-work crowd Good for groups No steps at entrance Sports bar Views

content.description: The bar portion of this off-the-beaten-track lounge/rock venue (featuring shows by eerily named punk and metal bands like the Gravetones, the Coffin Lids and Gorgasm) is reminiscent of a groovy 60s den with lava lamps and funky retro ceiling fans. The friendly bartender, Mike, alternates between playing pool, grabbing a smoke outside with the regulars, and serving obscenely strong Stoli cocktails in pint glasses (a steal at only $3 Mondays through Wednesday).
content.property: Conversation friendly Good for groups Good for over-40 crowd Live bands No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Pool table Private party room(s) Video/pinball games

content.description: This aging bachelors clubhouse is marked by an ancient Coors sign and frequented by a small posse of old men who dont want to be bothered while watching the game. Busts of Elvis and John Wayne share space with pennants for little-known Ohio sports teams, a jukebox full of Ted Nugent and Willie Nelson hits, and a severely limited selection of beers and liquors. This joint may have crossed the line from dive to decrepitude, but who cares when a cocktail costs only $2.50?
content.property: Good for over-40 crowd No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom

content.description: This nondescript neighborhood bar, an unpretentious dive where older guys play pool and shoot the breeze while Aerosmith blasts on the jukebox and the always-irate bartender serves cold beers, seems almost out of place in Wicker Park. Some of the regulars are real characters, such as the guy donning a hat covered in foil-wrapped cigars, and they warm up to you once everyones had a few drinks.
content.property: Good for groups Food served Conversation friendly No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Video/pinball games Sports bar Pool table

content.description: This working-class sports pub attracts its primarily male clientele with nightly drink specials, blasting rock anthems and strong pours from scantily clad female bartenders. Weekend DJ events attract flocks of coeds from Wilbur Wright College across the street, and regulars have been known to dance on the bar when theyve had one too many. Not a destination by any means, but tolerable if youre already in the neighborhood.
content.property: Food served Outdoor seating Good for groups Good for over-40 crowd Conversation friendly Darts Sports bar Pool table No steps at entrance Video/pinball games

content.description: Wisecracking bartender Colleen is the heart and soul of this otherwise unremarkable neighborhood dive, and shell mix you an extra strong Sunny D mai tai if you let her. The pub is named after owners Chuck and Sharon, who live behind the pub and have their names engraved on placards next to neon comedy and tragedy masks that hang above the bar.
content.property: Food served Conversation friendly Darts Good for over-40 crowd Video/pinball games No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom

content.description: This Logan Square lounge aspires to downtown posh but appears to be going through a transitional phase: It recently changed owners and is debuting Latincentric LGBT dance parties on Fridays as well as specials for college students on Thursdays. The rest of the week, its a bit dismala spare selection of mostly top-shelf liquor, Top 40 dance music, and a dark party room tucked in the back.
content.public-transport: El: Blue to Logan Square. Bus: 56, 76, 82
content.openingtimes: Tue, Thu 6pm2am; Wed, Fri 8pm2am; Sat 8pm3am; Sun noon2am
content.property: Gay Date place Dress code Piano bar Pool table Wheelchair-accessible bathroom

content.description: Whether the Cubs are winning or losing, both are equally good excuses for a round of bomber shots in plastic cups at this subterranean Wrigleyville bar. Many such shots went into that guy perched in the corner, getting pretzels hurled into his mouth from across the room while simultaneously screaming along to Michael Jackson. A beer-pong room in the back solidifies this spots status as post-grad frat-party basement.
content.property: Sports bar Karaoke Live bands No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Video/pinball games Wheelchair-accessible bathroom

content.description: The massive reincarnation of Lakeviews Bottom Lounge includes a live-music room that books acts ranging from Office to Witchcraft; an upstairs Volcano Room, which co-owner Mike Miller of Delilahs has turned into a rum palace, with 80 varieties on offer; and a main-floor restaurant and bar with a 100-bottle-strong beer list. See you on the killer rooftop deck in summer.
content.public-transport: El: Green, Pink to Ashland. Bus: 9, 20
content.openingtimes: Sun, Wed, Thu 5pm2am; Fri 11am2am; Sat 11am3am. Open additional hours for Blackhawks games and concerts
content.property: Live bands Food served Extensive beer selection Good for groups

content.description: A silver disco ball throws bright spots onto tomato-red walls and a mini karaoke stage at one of the longest-standing Polish joints in this area. Saturday nights bring karaoke, Mondays still offer $5 pitchers, and a penny-pincher special can be had on nearly every other night of the week (especially if youre into kamikazes). Go quick before this one goes the way of Wicker Park.
content.public-transport: El: Blue to Logan Square. Bus: 50, 53, 76
content.property: Conversation friendly Good for groups Good for over-40 crowd Karaoke No stairs to bathroom Pool table Video/pinball games

content.description: The Sports Bar label might be a bit misleading for this place: Last time we visited, the three TVs above the bar were tuned to Polish news, CNN and a Judy Dench film, respectively. So no team pennants for this cozy bar, but plenty of mirrored paneling, hanging plants, a naked cowgirl velvet painting and a jukebox featuring Sinad OConnor side by side with Metallica and bizarre East-Euro pop.
content.property: Darts No stairs to bathroom Pool table Video/pinball games

content.description: After Henry Chang got a liquor license for his formerly BYOB eatery Wakamono, he promptly built Boystowns best bar. The intimate space is, like all of Changs projects, highly stylized, employing lush, floral wallpaper and woodwork the likes of which youve only seen in an opium den. It might be a restaurant bar, but it has a style, vibeand, thanks to refreshing pear martinisa taste all its own.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 36, 77, 152

content.description: With $3 half-liter glasses of Zywiec and incredible Euro pop blasting from the jukebox, this is a much better time than anyone was having back in Warsaw. A younger-than-youd-expect crowd of regulars stops in to shoot pool and down everything from lime-topped Coronas to trays (yup, trays) of Jger shots swimming in Red Bull.
content.property: Food served Good for over-40 crowd No steps at entrance Pool table

content.description: This unpretentious, low-lit sister bar to Rocks Lincoln Park has a good lineup of microbrews (including beers from Clevelands Great Lakes Brewery) and a solid menu of pub grub to soak it all up. But the name refers to its impressive lineup of whiskeys, which is worth a try just to see the size of the ice cube they use to keep the drinks cold.
content.property: Food served Extensive beer selection Notable for cocktails Outdoor seating

content.description: Affable bartender Dr. Don is Keeper of the Flame at this homey, nautical-themed sports pub frequented by a close-knit family of neighborhood regulars. Enjoy a mai tai or a margarita under a Mylar palm tree, peruse the lending library of paperbacks, or join the gang for a tailgate potluck after a Bears game.
content.property: Good for over-40 crowd Conversation friendly No stairs to bathroom Sports bar Video/pinball games

content.description: As the Home of Glasgow Celtic Supporters Club, this Irish pub boasts a dozen beers on tap and traditional fare like shepherds pie, as well as decidedly un-Irish tacos and ribs. Weekly Wii games, beanbag tournaments, and live performances from the Polkaholics and Up Ye Boyo keep things lively in the party room behind the spacious main bar.
content.property: Food served Conversation friendly Good for groups Good for over-40 crowd Live bands No stairs to bathroom Private party room(s) Video/pinball games Sports bar Darts

content.description: The sign behind the bar says theres a two-drink minimum, but the friendly staff wont hold you to it if youre just dropping in. But as long as youre in the neighborhood, why not stay awhile? Everyone else here seems to have settled in for the long haul: Regulars set up along the spacious bar to watch TV for the afternoon, shoot a few leisurely rounds of pool, or furiously pound dominoes around a card table.
content.public-transport: El: Red, Purple (rush hrs), Yellow to Howard. Bus: 97, 201, 206
content.property: Conversation friendly Darts Good for groups Good for over-40 crowd No steps at entrance Pool table

content.description: Dont be swayed by the name: Order a lychee martini instead, grab a seat down on one of the cartoonish red and green pleather couches, and soak up the subterranean opium-den ambiance of this hidden Chinatown dive. You may need to enlist a regular to help you operate the Chinese karaoke console, or join in on the dice drinking game if youre looking to get blitzed.
content.property: Karaoke Good for groups Food served

content.description: Beware the sports bar moniker: At this new West Loop spot, its a little misleading. The place is really more of bare-bones lounge, with a few flat-screen TVs, a serviceable selection of bottled beer and nightly specials on food and martinis.
content.public-transport: El: Green, Pink to Clinton; Blue to Grand. Bus: 8, 20, 65
