content.description: Once theyd fulfilled all the requisites for a Polish neighborhood barZywiec and Okocim on tap, black-and-white checked floor, intimidatingly heavy entry doorthe owners here tacked on a few extras, such as a way-too-beautiful-to-speak-very-much-English bartender and a spacious back room that feels almost like a supper club (a dark, foodless, Polish one, anyway).
content.property: Conversation friendly Darts Good for groups Good for over-40 crowd No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Pool table

content.description: Cozy booths, banks of red velvet couches and faux marble and terra-cotta decor are the hallmarks of this low-key Balkan expat bar. Except on Saturday nights, when the place is transformed into a Euro disco replete with flashing rainbow lights, packs of drunk girls in sequined tops and lots of Serbian folk-pop.
content.property: Food served Outdoor seating Dress code Good for groups No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Video/pinball games

content.description: Red walls are said to increase aggression in bar patrons, but the vibe is amicable enough at this cozy neighborhood sports pub. (Maybe the glass case of police paraphernalia at the back of the bar serves as a cautionary measure.) Friendly bartenders serve up cheap, strong drinks and baskets of Tater Tots in two spacious rooms, while a cross-generational mix of neighborhood folks plays darts and watches the game on multiple TVs.
content.property: Food served Conversation friendly Good for groups Good for over-40 crowd No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Pool table Private party room(s) Video/pinball games

content.description: Pity the bars that share a zip code with this impressive newcomer. The friendly service, good beer list, gorgeously sleek interior, huge patio (enclosed in winter) and menu of bar eats by chef Jason Vandegraft make this place awfully hard to compete with.
content.property: Food served Fireplace Outdoor seating Extensive beer selection No steps at entrance

content.description: Not much has changed since the previous tenant, Iggys3, vacated this space: The narrow, dark red room still has a curvy bar; there are tables for indulging in bar grub; and a wall of windows opens up to the street in good weather. In fact, the only difference we can see is that now that it doesnt don the Iggys association anymore, it probably isnt nearly as cursed.
content.property: After-work crowd Food served Outdoor seating

content.description: Tucked in the shadow of the Morse Red Line tracks, this laid-back neighborhood bar shouldnt be confused with the similarly named spot farther south on Clark. Quirky art covers the red and blue walls, and bands regularly perform country, rock and bluegrass on a small stage adjacent to the main bar. If you visit on an off-night, channel the vibe via the classic country and Southern-rock-packed jukebox.
content.property: Gay Live bands No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Video/pinball games

content.description: Out went Bottle Bar, in went the Coach House, and no one inside seems to know or care why or exactly when. Nobody pays attention to the cocktail list either (with its girls'-night-out drinks priced at $8), nor the wines by the glass, nor the fairly extensive beer selection. But even with the majority of patrons clinging to their Miller Lite, theres still the sense that being herenestled into a warmly lit wooden booth with all those options on handis a step up from what came before.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 8, 11, 76

content.description: Pass through beaded curtains into a sky-blue room adorned with vintage Bacardi posters, painted palm trees and a stripper polehere youll find one of the citys best mojitos, garnished with fresh mint and sugarcane. (Its the trade-off for the annoyingly loud music and the bartenders chilly attitude.) Drink one too many? Settle the stomach with a toasted Cuban sandwich from the adjacent restaurant, Cafeteria De Pancho.
content.property: Good for groups Karaoke No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom

content.description: This Greek/Mediterranean restaurant becomes a low-key neighborhood bar late at night, but if owner Angelo is around, hell be happy to whip you up something from his menu of Greek, Italian and Spanish tapas. The soundtrack of Bob Marley and the Offspring seems to clash with the charming wooden decor and collection of Greek knickknacks, but the $15 cocktail pitchers and genuinely friendly bartender make the disconnect easy to overlook.
content.property: Fireplace Food served Conversation friendly Good for over-40 crowd No stairs to bathroom Live bands Pool table Private party room(s) Surprisingly good wine list Wheelchair-accessible bathroom

content.description: This new sports bar doesnt hold many people, and there are only a handful of flat-screens on the walls, but it turns out the intimacy has its benefits: Theres not a bad seat in the house, and the low number of patrons means you probably wont have to wait too long for your butterburger.

Once you get over the old guys stuffing bills into glistening male dancers tighty-whities, the only thing thats really surprising about this Andersonville gay bar is how low-key it is. The dancers (many of whom, it turns out, are straight) casually work the tables of twentysomethings and seventysomethings alike from Thursday through Saturday.
content.property: Darts Conversation friendly Gay Good for groups Good for over-40 crowd No steps at entrance

content.description: In case the name doesnt tip you off to what this place is all about, the owners here have painted the walls the color of green olives and put both Grey Goose and Effen vodka on tap. That attention to the martini (we wont quibble with the lack of gin on tap for an authentic version) suggests youre supposed to let them flow freely all night; the restaurant-like setup of tables and chairs, however, suggests youre supposed to savor them with something from the kitchen.
content.property: Food served Good for over-40 crowd

content.description: The most surprising aspect of the Hotel Indigos lobby bar is not the good selection of wines or the fact that despite being the hotels entry point, it remains a quiet, relaxing place. Its that its filled with tourists yet somehow feels 100% Chicago.
content.property: Conversation friendly No steps at entrance Good for over-40 crowd Food served Private party room(s) Surprisingly good wine list

content.description: Representing the first-in, last-to-leave motto of Bridgeports diehard Irish-American population, the Shinnick clan has been slinging beer in this building since the day Prohibition ended. St. Pats Day and Sox games bring the crowds, but other times youre likely to find a low-key gathering of locals or a fund-raiser for a sick kid with hefty medical bills. Well drink to that.
content.property: Classic Chicago spot Conversation friendly Sports bar Video/pinball games

content.description: Our bartender (a long-haired film student in a Primus shirt), told us he goes by PJ because there are at least three men named Patrick at this bar on any given night. Sure, its an Irish bar, but its a tongue-in-cheek one that sells T-shirts that say whos your paddy? Above-average food (oysters on the half shell, fish and chips) and excellent service keep the young clientele coming back for more.
content.property: Conversation friendly Darts Food served No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Good for groups Video/pinball games Wheelchair-accessible bathroom

content.description: This two-room darts bar seems excessively spacious relative to the sparse clientele on a Saturday night, but its rumored to draw a big crowd for the blind-draw darts tournament at 9pm on Fridays. Dont expect much excitement during the rest of the week, unless cheap PBR and a Golden Tee golf game is your idea of a good timewhich, for many regulars, is exactly that.
content.property: Good for over-40 crowd Good for groups Darts Video/pinball games Sports bar Private party room(s) No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom

content.description: At first glance, this place looks like your typical yuppie sports bar, but the vastly male clientele, plum and ochre walls adorned with abstract art, and Kylie Minogue soundtrack reveal it to be Rogers Parks straightest-acting gay bar. Its also dog-friendly and offers a nice selection of retro cocktails like sidecars and lime rickeys.
content.property: Gay Conversation friendly No stairs to bathroom

content.description: Ey Joe, how do you make a Joe Da Bone? The answer is a pint glass full of Tanqueray, with a splash of grapefruit and cranberry. This is the sort of banter youll overhear at this neighborhood pub. Funny thing, though: Joe doesnt get to make his specialty often, as the working-class clientele prefers suds to anything close to fruity.
content.property: Food served Outdoor seating Conversation friendly Darts Good for groups Good for over-40 crowd Live bands Karaoke No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Pool table Private party room(s) Video/pinball games

address.street: Dana Hotel & Spa, 660 N State St
Dana Hotel & Spa, 660 N State St

content.description: Youd think the focus of this bar, which sits on the roof of the Dana Hotel, would be the view. But theres so much to distract youthe roaring fire pit for startersthat the view pretty much takes a back seat.
content.openingtimes: MonFri 5pm2am; Sat 5pm3am; Sun 5pm10pm (sometimes closes early on slow weeknights)
content.property: Views Notable for cocktails Dress code Date place Food served

content.description: From the outside, this place looks like a gallery (which, technically, it partially is). On the inside, its open and loftlike, with a permanent stage set up for weekly live music. But behind the bar, decked out in a vest and tie, bartender Paul McGee is skillfully making expertly balanced, seasonally driven cocktails. One sip and theres no doubt that despite everything else going on here, the cocktails are the reason to stick around.
content.property: Live bands Notable for cocktails Outdoor seating

content.description: Sing-along 70s pop, ridiculously friendly regulars, free Wi-Fi, a bartender with chilled martini glasses ready for making fruity cocktails, $1.50 chili boat Mondaysthis Tri-Taylor spot goes so far with fun it might as well post a sign that says If youre looking to drink whiskey and skulk in a dark corner, look elsewhere.
content.public-transport: El: Blue to Western-Forest Park. Bus: 12, 38, 49
content.property: Food served Conversation friendly Good for groups Good for over-40 crowd No stairs to bathroom Pool table Sports bar Video/pinball games

content.description: Dueling pianos playing sing-along rock anthems (the Richard Cheesestyle rendition of Metallicas Enter Sandman was a standout) partnered with buckets of Kool-Aid-flavored booze served with multiple straws makes this national piano-bar chain a big hit for prowling cougars, office parties and easily intoxicated college girls. Cant decide what to order? The cavity-inducing Sexy Jewish Bartender tipple is the logical prequel to the X Boyfriend cocktail.
content.property: Gay Food served Good for groups Good for over-40 crowd Piano bar Private party room(s) Live bands

entry.name: Hangovers Sports Bar and Liquor Store

version.name: Hangovers Sports Bar and Liquor Store

content.description: Do you like Vegas music? Its Vegas music night, a patron informed us as we stepped into this slashie that could easily be the set of an early 80s Duran Duran video: mirrored paneling, glittering geometric dcor, checkered floors and a multicolored, light-up liquor display. Tom Jones blared out of the speakers as our fetching young bartender mixed up cheap, strong drinks. Just heed the warning on the door, and youll be fine: No children, no bikes, no dogs, no selling, no bullshit.
content.property: Outdoor seating Conversation friendly Good for over-40 crowd No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Pool table Sports bar Video/pinball games

content.description: The bare walls and smell of varnish expose the former Tavern 33 as a work-in-progress, but the potential is strong. The affable owners are quick with recommendations on the 90-strong beer list, and a brew-friendly menu is in the works. The name hints that English-style pub is the goal, but the dart boards and flat-screens make the description neighborhood favorite more likely.
content.property: Darts Extensive beer selection No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom

entry.name: Wine Bar at the Walnut Room

version.name: Wine Bar at the Walnut Room

content.description: The newest attraction at the decades-old Walnut Room is really just a corner of the dining area. But its a nice corner, full of the restaurants characteristic dark wood and formal-yet-friendly service. Nicer still is the wine list, which touts the bars pricing policy (the bottles are priced for retail, not restaurant service) and has a staggering number of bottles under $30 to back it up.
content.public-transport: El: Blue, Red to Washington; Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Randolph
content.property: After-work crowd Good for over-40 crowd Surprisingly good wine list Classic Chicago spot Good for groups Food served

content.description: Sure, its lowbrow compared to sister spots Stay and RiNo, what with the waffle fries, bowls of Laffy Taffy and antler chandeliers. But you can still expect the River North trifecta of microbrews, buxom waitresses in miniskirts and bathroom attendants who coddle you through the hand-washing process. If you find yourself craving the real dive-bar experience, you can always bounce to Snickers next door.
content.property: Food served No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Good for groups Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Pool table

content.description: True to form, Brandos Speakeasy is anything but what it seems. Its a lounge, but conversation flows more like a neighborhood haunt. Its website promises a martini bar, but the list is mysteriously MIA (most people seem to down beer anyway). The decor and vintage posters throw it back eras, but the karaoke and late-night dance music add modern flair. While its not Don Vito Corleone meets Al Capone as the name might imply, Brandos is definitely a mash-up.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Library
content.property: After-work crowd Conversation friendly Karaoke No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Video/pinball games Darts Food served Live bands

content.description: The vintage-inspired, old-world feel of the reincarnated Lakeview Broadcasting Company melds a late-night grilled-cheese haven with a back-room dance-party for gingham-clad boys.
content.openingtimes: Sun, Mon, Wed 5:30pmmidnight; Thu, Fri 5:30pm2am; Sat 5:30pm3am
content.property: Gay Lesbian Good for groups Food served Private party room(s) Outdoor seating

content.description: The novella-length menu at this low-key alcove contains loving and helpful descriptions of an impressive selection of wines and beers. And thanks to the array of small plates, executed by chef Remy Ayesh and served until 1am, this is the kind of warm, simple neighborhood place youll never wantor needto leave.
content.property: Food served Extensive beer selection Wine bar Surprisingly good wine list Conversation friendly Date place Good for groups Good for over-40 crowd No steps at entrance Outdoor seating

content.description: This loungey, two-story, two-years-in-the-making megabar shoots high with an extensive gastropub menu (that no ones ordering from) and cocktail list (that no one should be ordering from). Its beer, shots and Ed Hardybedecked scenesters as far as the eye can see, and thats how Wicker Park likes it.
content.property: Food served Good for groups No steps at entrance

content.description: TheWit Hotels swank rooftop lounge sports a specialty cocktail menu, a well-curated wine list and Mediterranean small plates by former mk chef Todd Stein. Now that the winter chills kicked in, the outdoor sections closed, but we doubt thatll keep the masses at bayespecially now that the enclosed part of the rooftop plays host to weekend brunch, with offerings like truffled egg toast, Morning Pizza and bomboloni.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to State
content.property: Notable for cocktails Outdoor seating After-work crowd Food served Date place Views Surprisingly good wine list Private party room(s)

content.description: Welcome to a Celtic version of Hooters, where the waitresses wear even less stretch fabric and TVs broadcast ESPN above every sight line. Traditionalists can scoff at Irish Nachos or Gaelic Chicken, but the burgers and wings are decent, and the bar will mix stout or cider with anything. The secret draw has little to do with Working Joes Catholic schoolgirl fantasiesits the second-floor view of the El, a nice angle on the diamond district.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Pink, Purple (rush hrs), Orange, Red, Green to Madison/Wabash
content.property: After-work crowd Video/pinball games Views Pool table Darts Food served Fireplace

content.description: Not so much Irish as Irishish, the latest bar to take advantage of Divisions double-wide sidewalks and doubly boisterous crowds has two focal points: a Tiffany-like stained-glass chandelier and 80-ounce, blender-shaped table taps with a block of ice in the middle that keeps booze chilled. The latter of which makes it easy to get doubly wasted.
content.public-transport: El: Blue to Division or Damen. Bus: 50, 70
content.property: Food served Good for groups No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Outdoor seating Fireplace

content.description: Follow the tamale guys trail, and you might end up at this low-key, dive-bar-ish hang. The no-frills space is a natural plaidstravaganza thanks to Two Brothers on tap; a back room that plays host to not-bad, no-cover live music; and plenty of space to settle in for the night (and not have to worry about waiting at the door, as at that other hipster-hang up the block).
content.property: Live bands Good for groups No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Pool table

content.description: Few neighborhoods show the signs of recession quite as viscerally as the South Loop, and this sleek cafin the lobby of a glitzy condo building, of coursesits at the nexus of the stalled mega-projects and half-inhabited high-rises that loom like ghosts from the real-estate-boom-that-wasnt. But inside Little Branch, the scene is much less bleak: An elegant bar lined with tree-trump stools offers a short but well-curated wine and beer list served by some of the friendliest staff aroundservers who could use some real-life company.
content.public-transport: El: Green, Orange, Red to Roosevelt. Bus: 3, 12, 29, 62, 146
content.property: Conversation friendly Food served Good for over-40 crowd No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Outdoor seating Surprisingly good wine list Wine bar

content.description: We could try to scare you away from the Cedar Hotel. We could tell you the host has arms bigger than our legs. Or that we threw down $14 for a 24-ounce keepsake cocktail that came in a plastic cup we most certainly did not want to keep. Or that the Fifty/50 signatureslike sliders and burgerswere nothing wed ever sign our name to. But the people-watching is so damn mesmerizing we might just be back ourselves.
content.property: Classic Chicago spot Conversation friendly Food served Good for groups Good for over-40 crowd No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Outdoor seating

content.description: Nothing brings together the hip kids and blue-collar Chicagoans better than cheap alcoholand this no-frills Logan Square dive across from Fireside Bowl is living proof. Watch as the earnest mustaches of Blackhawks and Sox fans mingle amiably with ironically bearded Black Keys and White Stripes fans. And if that gets dull, just head to the back for a 75-cent game of pool.
content.property: Darts Pool table No stairs to bathroom Video/pinball games

content.description: When we strolled into this endearingly tacky Latino holdout tucked into a gentrifying residential block, a tipsy twentysomething swiveled his stool our way, raised his hands to the sky and gleefully announced to the four other people in the place, Finally! Youre here. It was drunk talk all right, but this stranger summed up exactly how this bewitching bar makes you feel: like its been waiting all these years for you to become a regular.

To go to this glamorously vintage bar and not order chef Jared Van Camps charcuterie is to miss the point: Finocchiona emanates a deep fennel flavor, the hearty sausage with cornmeal waffles is as gluttonous a brunch plate as we could ever wish for, and the pastrami is a subtle, smoky revelation. So it comes as a bit of a surprise that most of the crowd here is, indeed, missing the point: Theyre here for that other kind of meat market. Some yuppies just dont know how good they have it.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Sedgwick. Bus: 9, 11, 72
content.property: Extensive beer selection Fireplace Food served Good for groups No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Notable for cocktails Sports bar

content.description: Chef Rick Spiros took a short hiatus after the last restaurant he cooked at, Mantou Noodle, abruptly closed after no more than a month. Now hes at this West Town lounge, where his food takes a back seat to the two-level, exposed-brick, warehouse-like space and the partyers filling it. So go for the scene, and while youre there, try the fried quail.
content.property: Food served Good for groups No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Outdoor seating

content.description: Are you prepared to jostle? This is the downtown happy hour to end all downtown happy hours, and youre going to need your elbows to get anywhere near the dozens of craft beers behind the bar. Bar waitresses attempt to holler over the crowd, but the goal of after-work drinking has never been to listen.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Green, Pink, Purple (rush hrs), Orange to Randolph/Wabash; Red to Lake; Blue to Clark/Lake
content.property: After-work crowd Food served Good for groups Good for over-40 crowd No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Sports bar

content.description: In practically any other neighborhood in the city, a nice-looking neighborhood bar (even with slightly above-average food and way-more-attentive-than-average service) wont stand out. But in the chichi West Loop, a welcoming watering hole is actually exactly what the neighborhood needed.
content.public-transport: El: Green, Pink to Clinton. Bus: 56, 124, 125
content.property: After-work crowd Food served No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Sports bar

content.description: Although it was formerly known as the Rockhouse, nothing at this Lincoln Park rock bar has changed but the name. Neon lights, a backlit bar and long black booths lend a sheen of edginess, but the sea of backward baseball caps holding plastic tumblers bobbing along to Oasis covers makes it all feel a bit inauthentic. Go for the decent beer selection on tap, not for a real rock & roll atmosphere.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey; Red to Fullerton. Bus: 11, 74, 76
content.property: Late Night Live bands Video/pinball games

content.description: Although the Globe Pub next door quickly established its personalityBritish, soccer, triviaRed Brick (which opened earlier this fall as a BYOB and recently received its liquor license) is a bit more schizophrenic. The exposed brick walls are fairly bare except for a bunch of flat-screens, and its as much a restaurant as a bar. The menus split between traditional Middle Eastern fare (hummus, falafel) and bar food (fried calamari, pizzas), none of which stands out enough to help determine what exactly the place is going for.
content.public-transport: El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 11, 50, 80
content.property: Conversation friendly Food served Good for groups Good for over-40 crowd No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Sports bar Fireplace

content.description: If youve ever forgotten to go into a show at Schubas because of how immensely comfortable the front bar is, you might want to consider tying a string around your finger at the Schuba brothers new restaurant-bar-venue. The design is sleeker and more modern than its Lakeview siblings, but the fresh-ground burger and the big booths are just as inviting.
content.public-transport: El: Red, Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Fullerton. Bus: 8, 11, 74
content.openingtimes: SunFri 11am2am; Sat 11am3am. During shows, the bar may be available only to ticket holders
content.property: Food served Good for groups Live bands No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom
Outdoor seating Food served No steps at entrance

content.description: Faced with increasingly fierce pizza competition, owner Chris Peckat (who also runs Risque Caf next door) shuttered Purgatory Pizza and opened this burger bar in its place. (It was first called Park Ave; now its Purple Haze.) So while Peckat has the burgers figured out (with topping like fried pickles and smoked ham), the question remains how quickly the neighborhood will catch on.
content.property: Extensive beer selection Food served No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom

content.description: Can a neighborhood bar still attract the neighborhood even if it seems to lack soul? Yes, if youre okay settling for bottom-of-the-barrel bar food. Yes, if you just want to watch sports. Yes, if its late and theres nothing else around thats opena likely scenario around these parts. Sound like a place thats not quite worth a trek? Yes, thats why its for the neighborhood.
content.property: Food served Good for groups Good for over-40 crowd No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Sports bar

content.description: New owners closed the spacious, low-key Black Beetle for two weeks of renovations, reopening assimplythe Beetle. The space itself came out relatively unscathed: Its wood-paneled bar and antique taps retain a sense of authenticity. Its the menu that has moved into new territory, particular this beast called the Elvis burger. The patty itself is underseasoned and a tad mushy, but you wont notice: The thing is topped with sweet plantains, awesomely crisp bacon and a dangerously delicious layer of peanut butter. Believe it.
content.property: Pool table Video/pinball games No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Outdoor seating Fireplace Food served Extensive beer selection Good for groups

content.description: An all-reggae juke, jerk chicken so smoky itll probably kill you, no-cover DJ nights and bartenders dolled up to the nines make this Marley den a natty addition to town.
content.openingtimes: Sun, TueFri noon2am; Sat noon3am (closed Mon)
content.property: Food served Live bands No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom

content.description: Its probably only going to be you, whomever you bring and the owner, Celina, in this place. Sweet gal, but she doesnt speak much English, so shell hand over your $2 beer and leave you to soak up the wood paneling, year-round Christmas lights, video-game slots and pool table in solitude.
content.property: Pool table No stairs to bathroom

content.description: After opening earlier this year with a country twang, the Cattle Call ditched the hoedowns and is now just the Call. Weekends offer high-energy sounds for the sweaty masses, but theres room to kick it in the corner with a beer if thats more your style. Different nights (like Monday industry nights and Curtains Up show-tunes nights on Wednesdays) generate different herds.
content.public-transport: El: Red to Bryn Mawr. Bus: 22, 50, 84
content.property: Conversation friendly Gay Good for groups Good for over-40 crowd Wheelchair-accessible bathroom

content.description: The bar that took over the Pontiac space is just that: a bar. With whiskey shots, cheap beer and quick cocktails. Of course, if you can just drink and not partake in Paul Kahans tacos, you have more restraint than us. Braised lamb and pork belly have our names on thembut since each is about $3, you can afford to try them all. Which just about makes this the best thing to happen to Six Corners in some time.
content.property: Classic Chicago spot Conversation friendly Extensive beer selection Food served Good for over-40 crowd No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom
Classic Chicago spot Conversation friendly Extensive beer selection Food served Good for over-40 crowd No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Outdoor seating

content.description: If youre going to pay $14 for a sidecar, this is the place to do it. In this classy, dim room, Bon Iver is piped through the speakers, linen napkins grace the tables, and the bar snacks (marcona almonds, marinated olives, fresh potato chips) are bottomless. And that sidecar? Lets just say theyre not skimping on the cognac. So when all is said and done, yes, youve dropped $14 on a drink. Yet somehow, you feel as if youve just scored a deal.
content.property: Dress code Conversation friendly Surprisingly good wine list Extensive beer selection Date place

address.street: ShowPlace Icon Theatre, 150 W Roosevelt Rd
ShowPlace Icon Theatre, 150 W Roosevelt Rd

content.description: Jerry Kleiners wildly tacky aesthetic feels so at home among the low-culture grandeur of a movie theater that a multicolored Fiat 500 in the middle of a bar practically goes unnoticed. Add 20 minutes to your movie date, and you can score housemade chips with onion dip and a martini for about the same price as theyll gouge you for a Diet Coke and Twizzlers at the concession stand below.
content.public-transport: El: Red, Orange, Green to Roosevelt. Bus: 12, 18, 24, 62, 146, 192
content.property: Conversation friendly Food served Good for groups Good for over-40 crowd Views

content.description: Lockdown attempts to set itself apart from the citys other metal bars with a vague prison theme, burgers with names like Arson and Ponzi Scheme, and a virtual venue concept, meaning live concert DVDs are played on plasma screens. This latter idea sounds silly on paper, but given that Lockdown offers its nightly musical lineup in advance like any music venue, its actually kind of brilliant. Big Slayer fan but hate Mtley Cre? Check the schedule, and youll know what night to come for beers. (Skip those burgers, thoughtheyre the real crime.)

Chef Kendal Duque (formerly of Sepia) returns to the scene with this slightly clubby Lakeview spot, where his food has taken a casual turn: Flatbreads get topped with bright grapes and sausage, a skate wing is served on porky collard greens. The setting (uncomfortable stools, tacky art), the service (poorly trained, unprofessional) and the cocktails (almost toxically strong) seem at odds with Duques food, but even some of that feels phoned in. Solutions: Stick with beer, sit at the bar and consider the lack of neighborhood alternatives.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 22, 77
content.property: Conversation friendly Food served No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Sports bar

content.description: Compared to its brethren (in Wicker Park and Logan Square), this Lincoln Park addition to the growing Small Bar empire feels like a giant. Famous for its past life as a pool hall once given screen time in The Color of Money, the space, which has a lofted mezzanine level, is now outfitted with a gorgeous bar and a couple of flat-screens devoted to soccer. And at least as far as the extensive and well-curated selection of 22 drafts and 180 bottles of beer is concerned, the Small Bar guys have always been known to go big.
content.public-transport: El: Red, Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Fullerton. Bus: 9, 74
content.property: Classic Chicago spot Conversation friendly Extensive beer selection Food served Good for groups No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Outdoor seating Private party room(s) Sports bar

content.description: This vaguely porn-themed, vaguely-Italian bar/restaurant, constructed to vaguely resemble a River North nightclub (bouncers, big booths and all) seems like something out of a raunchy SNL sketch. But it exists, its on the outer reaches of the North Side, and the way the party-ready patrons are pounding electric-blue Vodka cocktails and Irish car bombs, its almost too real.
content.property: Conversation friendly Date place Food served Good for groups Good for over-40 crowd New No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Sports bar
Conversation friendly Date place Food served Good for groups Good for over-40 crowd No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Sports bar

content.description: Small Bars Phil McFarland and Ty Fujimura have grown up, and apparently that means scrapping the club of their youth, Lava Lounge, and transforming it into a cocktail bar with drinks designed (and sometimes executed) by Sepia vet Peter Vestinos. The list is clever: It features punch bowls (for groups of four), as well as a section called In The Ring, whereby a classic cocktailsay, a Negronigets pitted against a retooled version. Though theres no doubt theyre taking cocktails seriously here, theres none of that Violet Hour pretentiousness. So expect grown-upsbut not those who are too grown up.
content.property: Conversation friendly Date place Extensive beer selection Good for over-40 crowd New No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Notable for cocktails
Conversation friendly Date place Extensive beer selection Good for over-40 crowd No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Notable for cocktails

content.description: If ever there was a cursed space, its the former Darwins/Whiskey Road/Chinaskis. The latest inhabitant has done away with the gimmicks and opened the doors onto the sidewalk with a list of decent beers and margaritas. If friendly servers, exposed brick and a diverse jukebox dont cut it, the new owners offer one appeal to gluttonous patrons: the Horseshoe, an open-face sandwich laden with cheese fries.
content.property: Food served No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom

content.description: The mall location and the LEYE association might bring out the skeptic in hard-core foodies, but we have to admit the food at this affordable Italian spot is good enough to justify a casual dinner after holiday shopping on the Mag Mile. Top-notch, characteristically creamy burrata cheese and simple fennel-topped Sardinian-style pizza get things off to a good start. Pastas are standard and typically substantial, but youd do better to save room for the pepper-smothered, crispy-skinned brick chicken or the tender veal limone. Servers have the robotic spiel down, but if chef Frankie is working the room, youll glean some genuine hospitality.
content.property: Good for dining at bar Vegetarian-friendly

content.description: Joe Farina added this counter-service lunch spot to his expanding network of Italian eateries, and for our money, its the star of the family. Pastas and salads join signatures like Joe Mamas Meatball Bomber sandwich, which is our pick for best of the lot thanks to bright, zesty tomato sauce and the massive meat-to-bread ratio of the meatballs. Eggplant parm is nearly as good an option for those looking to eat relatively healthy, and the Italian beef with both sweet and mild giardiniera is the best within a Turano-roll toss of the tiny carryout space.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to LaSalle/Van Buren

content.description: You can be forgiven for assuming that the bourani badenjan at this Afghan restaurant will be like baba ghanoush, but youll be pleasantly proven wrong: Its smoother, more complex, a little sweet (thanks to caramelized onions) and a little tangy (thanks to yogurt). Thats the theme with most of the food here, which always tastes markedly better than youd expect. After gorging on the aushak, a delicate, beef-stuffed raviolilike pasta, and the kabuli palaw, a tender lamb shank cooked with sweet carrots and raisins, youll get a handle on Afghan cuisine. And youll wonder why there isnt more of it locally.

Just off of one of the busiest intersections in hipland, this multilevel venue has survived a few noise violations to become more relevant than ever. The upstairs is devoted to a live stage (viewable from a third-floor balcony), which features indie, garage, hip-hop and jammy acts nightly (see Music venues, Rock, pop & hip-hop). The downstairs bar serves as a cozy dance den for locals to let loose. The weekly lineup includes hip-hop, reggae and some very fine mod and soul nights.

If we ever create our own spa, we want it to look exactly like Mojo's—pink everywhere, princess-worthy manicure chairs and natural products galore. The owner, Amanda, used to be a professional chef, but she turned her creative juices to skincare, and we are thrilled with the result. She makes all the products in her studio, which is six blocks away, and they smell and feel scrumptious. If you could tear yourself away from the retail at the front of the spa, head back for a super-pampered mani and pedi, where nail techs will use all of Amanda's lotions and scrubs on your hands and feet. Our hands smelled so good afterwards, that the person sitting next to us at a concert later in the evening commented on our scent. Come on Sundays for Amanda's homemade brunch, which is complimentary with any service.

Among the framed drawings of regulars cluttering the wooden walls of this saloon-style staple are posters boasting that youre in le premiere dive bar of Chicago. We dont know where this place gets off speaking French, but its been around since 1958, so well grant it bragging rights.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Sedgwick. Bus: 11, 72, 156
content.property: Video/pinball games No steps at entrance Late Night Good for groups

content.description: The big white Ss that are emblazoned on the forest-green backgrounds of signs, flags, pennants and posters hung all over this Lincoln Park bar stand for the Spartans of Michigan State. But when youre watching the MSU alums and barely-of-age DePaul students dance on tables and suck face under green neon lights, other s-wordssloshed, skimpy, sleazycome to mind.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 8, 11, 74
content.property: Darts Pool table Live bands Wheelchair-accessible bathroom No stairs to bathroom No steps at entrance Sports bar

content.description: Its nestled on a corner in the heart of Lincoln Park, but this isnt your typical trixie spot. Its a casual, sophisticated space thats low-key and laid back, and filled with folks who are a couple years past frequenting spots where a 22-year-old vomiting Jager on their shoes is commonplace.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Armitage. Bus: 8, 11, 73
content.property: Pool table Video/pinball games No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Sports bar Darts

content.description: Six nights a week, the citys jazz enthusiasts gather at this bar-cum-jazz-club to drink and listen to local and traveling talent; on Sundays, they listen to the blues. Although the digs might be new, most of this crowd seems already well-acquainted with one another; newcomers intrigued by the music roster (curated by the husband-and-wife jazz musicians who own the joint) might find themselves just as fascinated by the eclectic cast of characters.
content.property: Conversation friendly Date place Food served Good for groups Good for over-40 crowd Live bands New No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Piano bar

content.description: Steven Songthe man who was behind Tsunami restaurantis now doing the izakaya thing, offering Japanese shared plates such as tempura shrimp and grilled meats alongside a full selection of sushi.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Armitage. Bus: 8, 73

content.description: This popular Avondale Thai spot (best known for its private-party room that held many a karaoke birthday party) may still be quite a way off from rebuilding its original location after a fire destroyed it, but in the meantime this West Town shop serves as the stand-in. The menu is identical, with the standard noodles, rice dishes and curries front and center. Best bets include the sweet and spicy 7 Buddies, a fresh and crunchy green papaya salad; and the catfish pad ped, hunks of crispy fish smothered in red-curry paste with globe-shaped Thai eggplants and al dente bamboo shoots. No karaoke, but feel free to sing along with the random tunes piped out of the overhead speakers.

Simple is not a word thats used casually at Antica: The dining room is so nondescript youll hardly remember being in it, and the only thing thats rare about the food is how nakedly honest it is. The Margherita may not pass muster with Neapolitan snobsthe crust is just millimeters too thick and a little too dry. But anybody who can get past those details will be rewarded with a crisp crust and a piquant sauce. The nuances of the sauce can get lost amid the ham, eggs, peas and mushrooms (as on the fattoressa pizza). But it is a praiseworthy pie nonethelessnot because its complicated, but specifically because it isnt.
content.public-transport: El: Red to Bryn Mawr. Bus: 22, 50

content.description: Seemingly untouched by neighborhood change, this cozy, attitude-free diner is all about breakfast. Ukrainian Village locals stumble in for fluffy omelettes with golden hash browns or the house special, Smokey Mountain eggs: an artery-busting plate of biscuits topped with sausage gravy, eggs and bacon. But its not all hearty, starchy fare. The neighborhoods Mexican influences are reflected in plates of chorizo and eggs with a zippy green tomatillo salsa, as well as savory chilaquiles.

At this cheerful mom and pop decorated with photos of the nearby Uptown Theater, there's a little cognitive dissonance in seeing standard Lebanese items offered side by side with Indian curry specials. But go with the flow and you'll see the charms of washing your falafel down with a housemade blueberry lassi. Vegetarians fare especially well here, as the falafel are fresh and brightly spiced, the dolmas are tart, and there's a meatless special each day (usually a simple stew or curry). Carnivores with light wallets will appreciate chicken shawarma sandwiches, and kifta are easy to like at such modest prices, too.

If hoity-toity spas rub you the wrong way, this low-key alternative may be for you. Housed in a remodeled vintage apartment, the space is more akin to a relaxing holistic home than a clinic. Choose from basic services such as manicures and facials, or go for a reiki treatment or seaweed body facial. Our pick: the Siddha Body Detoxification massage ($150), which starts with a brisk dry brushing of skin, progresses to a full-body wrap and head-to-toe massage, and concludes with you practically melting on the table.

content.public-transport: El: Red, Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Belmont. Bus: 77

content.vendor-category: Sports | What to do | Bar games

content.description: This bar looks like a familiar North Side baseball-crazed, watered-down pub (and if transplanted above Division Street, were sure the endless flat screens would serve it well) but feels a whole lot friendlier. The vibes got less to do with sports and more to do with West Loop urbanites chasing their work blues with pint upon pint, hella-delicious bar fare and downloaded jukebox tunes.
content.public-transport: El: Green, Blue, Pink to Clinton. Bus: 8, 20, 56
content.property: Darts Pool table Video/pinball games Sports bar No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Outdoor seating Late Night Food served

content.description: When Wrigleyville singles hear the phrase last call at their neighborhood bar, their next concern is getting to this late-night drunken den. The buildings Art Deco details (including a vaulted ceiling) are impressive (albeit a little difficult to appreciate with glazed, half-closed eyes), and the setup of four pool tables and two bars seems a sympathetic nod to the fact that intoxicated and impatient go hand in hand.
content.property: Pool table Date place Good for groups No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Late Night Video/pinball games

content.public-transport: El: Brown, Red, Purple (rush hrs) to Fullerton. Bus: 8, 74

address.street: Chicago Artists Coalition, 2010 W Pierce Ave, unit 101
Chicago Artists Coalition, 2010 W Pierce Ave, unit 101

entry.name: Old Town School of Folk Music

version.name: Old Town School of Folk Music

content.property: $18 Old Town School members, $16 seniors and kids USD 20.00

content.public-transport: El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 11, 50, 80, 78

content.description: This raucous new rocker bar has loads going for it: It’s in a space with its own working-class history (as a hangout for railway workers), stays open very late, and the DJs play almost exclusively rock, usually of the psych, indie and garage varieties.

Upon stepping into the adorably red, black and grey-outfitted Trim, it's clear from the numerous hair-removal tools, waxing stations and eager aestheticians that the waxing salon takes an obsessive approach to hair removal—in a good way. Trim carries vitamin-enriched waxes for different skin types and sensitivity levels, and sells products to help keep skin soft and smooth afterward (like bikini brushes and exfoliants). The therapists are quick, friendly and adept with wax. It'll only take a few minutes to transform unkempt brows into pretty curves. Brazalians are a treatment option, but daring types may opt for something bolder—anal brightening comes to mind (yes, you read that right)? The menu has dozens of waxing, threading, tweezing and tinting options, so you can groom yourself from head to, er, bum.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Red to Fullerton. Bus: 11

content.description: Japanese pictures, prints and decorations are plastered on the walls, stemming from the owner's Japanese heritage (he moved to Chicago 20 years ago from Tokyo), making the otherwise barebone salon and spa a little more zen. We wish, however, that the owner would add some Japanese treatments instead of sticking to the basics—massage, manicure, pedicure and facial (although he promises to start using some Japanese products in the future). The massage we received was decent, although we hope the squeaky wood floors will be oiled soon, to up the relaxation factor.

If there were such a thing as a pain-free Brazilian wax, you'd find it here ($50). Alas, no such thing exists, but Trim comes pretty damn close. Before mercilessly ripping out your hair, the aestheticians rub oil on your skin, softening it prior to waxing. We tried it once, and now we'll never let anyone wax us before applying the much-needed oil beforehand. It makes the difference between a hair-raising nightmare and a painful but manageable treatment. The spa offers a multitude of hair-removal services, from full face threading to back waxing. Brides-to-be can even ask for “I Do” to get their hoo-has bedazzled. Sparkle isn't reserved just for the ring finger anymore.

content.vendor-category: Sports | What to do | Bar games

content.public-transport: El: Red, Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Belmont. Bus: 8, 77, 152

content.description: Brooke Dailey and Gina Howie, two friends who met at the French Pastry School, opened this homey bakery in June 2007. And though we hate to state the expected, we have to admit it: This place is pretty damn lovely. From cakey, star-shaped muffins to flaky pain au chocolat, the pastries are just as sweet and delicious as they should be. And their brownies? Tinged with crme frache and dark chocolate, they are some of the most serious and decadent weve ever had the pleasure of savoring. The homey shop also sports a small selection of baking-inspired gifts. Cute stuff, but wed rather receive one of their mini pies any day.

There are a couple of things you can count on at this Puerto Rican caf: hefty pressed sandwiches, the crusty bread stuffed with copious amounts of fillings like sweet roast pork and grilled onions; strong espresso and caf con leche; delicious pastries, such as a tangy-sweet Danish stuffed with cream cheese and guava; and a multigenerational clientele that comes in to discuss the merits of the aforementioned offerings (and everything and anything else).

This restaurant, which took over the space formerly occupied by Thai Nippon, serves food from every region in Thailand, and even ventures into more contemporary stuff (such as a Thai take on mango salsa shrimp).

entry.name: Take Me Out, Lets Eat Chinese

version.name: Take Me Out, Lets Eat Chinese

content.description: More than 20 years ago, Chinese immigrant Nai Tiao opened Great Seas on the Korean stretch of Lawrence Avenue and unveiled a now legendary lollipop-style soy-and-chileglazed chicken wing. Now his daughter, Karen Lim, has taken the wings to Pilsen. The decor screams franchise, but the food is the real deal. Freshly fried egg rolls are stuffed with peppery vinegar-laced cabbage and pork; soy-splashed fried rice is topped with fluffy butterflied caramelized shrimp; and the sweet-and-spicy wings, a.k.a. Little Hotties, are as good as old man Tiaos.

Lifeway Foods, the local company known for its kefir products, is behind this new Ukrainian Village shop. Kefir is a fermented milk drink popular in Eastern Europe, and it contains strains of bacteria and yeasts that yogurt doesnt. The health effects are hotly debated and havent been scientifically proven, but Lifeway claims the probiotic live cultures aid in digestion, among other things. Like the drink, the plain flavor is sour. Problem is, the flavor of the day we sampled had a strangely fakey peach flavor and overly grainy texture.

For the last year and a half, Paul Fehribach has brought a taste of New Orleans to Andersonville with tasso-ham-and-pimento-cheese sandwiches, spicy gator sausages with crunchy fried pickles and barbecued shrimp. Now, along with sous chef Corey Fuller, an Alinea alum, hes expanding on that Southern theme, beginning with curing andouille in house.

The dining room of the short-lived Shochu is pretty much unchanged, but the owners have shifted the format from a Japanese-style izakaya highlighting the namesake distilled liquor to an American platform that matches that of their original restaurant, Deleece. Steak is the major focus (take heed: What is medium-rare here is probably just rare, or even raw, to you), and the rest of the meat-and-potatoes menu includes a nuanced porcini-garlic soup and gluttonous beer-battered cheese curds. It might no longer be a forward-thinking restaurant, but if it can survive where Shochu couldnt, then its probably what the neighborhood wants.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 22, 77, 152
content.property: Late-night dining Good for dining at bar Good for groups Outdoor seating

content.description: Chef Ryan Poli is squarely at the helm of the latest venture from BOKAs Kevin Boehm and Rob Katzand the results are impressive. Its tough to decide which is better, the black truffle gnocchi with tender squash and deliciously bitter chard or the rectangle of vanilla-scented crispy-skinned veal breastget em both. The surest sign of summers approach (besides Green City Market returning across the street) is the rollout of the Cabana menu, with offerings like mini grilled pork belly sliders and shrimp croquettes for relaxed dining on the spacious patio.

Though its 60 years old and inhabits the original location of the legendary Gene & Judes, this spot doesnt seem much different than any other old grease shack. RC Cola on draft; lots of stainless steel; sullen, wary-eyed counter helpcheck. But, ford your way past the dogs and beefs, and youll find the french-fry sandwich, a gluttonous beef jusdipped bun piled high with skin-on shoestring fries, chunky giardiniera, and your choice of mozz or oozy nacho cheese.

No cupcake has ever tasted quite like the BLT concoction at this sleek (and tiny) Gold Coast cupcakery: Sweet cake is filled with salty pieces of bacon, smeared with a completely savory ranch icing and topped with fresh slices of tomato. Its jarring at first, but it works so well that its perhaps the most convincing proof that cupcakes can swing both ways. Showcased in a glass display, the rotating selection of cupcakes (including classics like Red Velvet and Chocolate for the more conservative cupcake connossieur), look like works of artbecause they are.

Youd be right to be dubious of the theme-park look of this place. But think about it: If this restaurant is able to consistently fill its enormous dining roomsnot to mention not one but two parking lotsit must be doing something right. What that thing is is its well-seasoned steaks; plump, garlicky shrimp; crispy-skinned tilapia topped with a sprightly veracruzana sauce; and crpes smothered in cajeta and doused with a generous dose of tequila.

This East Coast import feels like a cross between In-N-Out and Potbelly: Burgers, made to order, make up 90% of the small menu, and theres a list of toppingsgrilled onions, relish, pickles, barbecue sauceto pile on. By littering their walls with media praise for their food, this place sets expectations incredibly high. Unfortunately, it doesnt quite live up to the hype: The fries are thick and freshly cut, but the Cajun seasoning theyre dusted with needs a lot more salt, and even with toppings, the burgers can be kind of blah. Still, this stuff is much fresher than McDonalds, so if you can keep your hopes in check you might be pleasantly surprised.
content.public-transport: El: Green to Oak Park. Pace bus: 309, 311, 313

content.description: As close as you're going to get to a Puerto Rican beachfront shack in Chicago, Papa's is famous on the Paseo Boricua for juicy rotisserie chicken, lightly seasoned with tropical spices and roasted until it's moist and tender. But it also has a contender for Chicago's best jibarito, that "Puerto Rican" delicacy (actually invented here) in which steak (or chicken) is served up between two slices of "bread" made of fried plantains. On Saturdays, Papa has a special of lechon, succulent roasted pork. And on Sundays, Papa rests.
content.property: Kid-friendly Outdoor seating BYOB Late-night dining

content.description: Typically, pan-Asian spots suffer from casting the net too wide, but this little BYOB does a nice job of executing most standard Anglo cravings, from crunchy egg rolls and gooey crab rangoon to jam-packed maki. Thai classics are standard in depth and execution; try the Hot Woks Noodles, stir-fried spinach noodles that resemble fettucine (stay with us now) wok-tossed with good-size shrimp, chicken chunks and jalapeo peppers for heat. Like the Akira roll (tuna, salmon, spicy mayo, ginger and avocado rolled in crunchy tempura flakes), it might not open any rabbit holes for the authenticity police, but its tasty nonetheless.
content.public-transport: El: Blue to Irving Park. Bus: 53, 80
content.property: BYOB Cheap (entrees under $10) Private party room(s) Vegetarian-friendly Outdoor seating

content.description: This Evanston stalwart has been going strong for more than 30 years on the reputation of its hot dogs. But ever since a new owner took over in 2005, the dipping dogotherwise known as a corn doghas been a main attraction as well. Unlike other corn dogs, this dipped-and-fried-to-order specimen is only lightly sweet, and it actually tastes like corn. But then, everything here is done the way it should be: Chicago dogs exhibit their proper snap, thin burgers are served on fresh, fluffy rolls; and the frieswell, we know this is a hot-dog joint, but the fries are so perfectly crisp that they steal the show.
content.public-transport: El: Purple to Dempster. Bus: 201 Central/Sherman, 205

content.description: If the quintessential Chicago food is Italian beef, the quintessential foodie tip would be a great unknown beef stand. Chickie's has a fervent following in its slice of Little Village, but deserves to be talked up citywide. It has it all: loads of divey stand-and-eat-it-with-guys-in-hardhats atmosphere; a beefy, herb-rich gravy; a unique housemade giardinera that mixes paper-thin celery slices with jalapeos; and a fistful of excellent fresh-cut fries with every sandwich. Try it, then let people think you've known about it all along.

This fish is so nice that they named it twice. Well, okay, its certainly not the best sushi restaurant in town, but for a no-frills, easy-on-the-wallet option for fresh fish, this simple spot hits the mark. Counter service might scare purists off, but youll be pleasantly surprised when you pick up your tray of artfully presented maki (go for the spicy Mexican roll of hamachi, cilantro and jalapeos, and the tropical roll filled with shrimp tempura, eel, cucumber, avocado and mango puree). Lunchtime maki meal deals (two rolls, miso soup and salad for about $9) are a big hit with Northwestern students, as are the sweet and colorful bubble teas.
content.property: BYOB Vegetarian-friendly Outdoor seating Good for dining at bar

content.description: This sibling of Highwoods Curry Hut has a leg up on typical tikka masala spots with a few lesser-known Nepalese specialties, so go for the dishes that truly stand out. The Bhojan (a thali-style sampler platter) is a nice assortment of flavors, and the momo dumplings are tasty, but save room for the chhoela, slices of chilled, tandoor-cooked goat tossed in a bracing salad of raw onion, garlic and ginger slivers, and the kukhura ko pakheta, chicken wings marinated overnight in the Nepalese holy trinity (ginger, garlic and cumin) then cooked in the tandoor for crispy skin and juicy meat.

Of all the tacos this new Rogers Park Mexican spot offers, the slightly sweet, slightly peppery pastor version is the best. The creamy refried beans make a good taco, and the steak taco isnt bad either. Chicken needs some help, though: When its piled onto a torta, youll need a big douse of salsa before things get interesting, and the chicken-stuffed tamales are crumbly and dry. But where this place really excels is not the food but the hospitality: The service is attentive, kind and gracious. And that, more than anything, is what sets this taqueria apart from the rest.

Quick thinking is the key to success at this classic cafeteria: Once the line reaches the counter, you have only a few seconds to place your order, pick a side, order a drink and pay. For breakfast, we like the generous stack of French toast with a side of poached eggs (which, unlike other, more popular items here, are usually cooked to order). For lunch, its the baked chicken, which comes with forgettable stuffing but is so sumptuous that the meat falls off the bone. At either meal theres the question of whether to eat the sweet, cakey biscuits with your meal or save them for dessert; either way, make your choice the first time around. Otherwise, its back to the line.
content.property: Cheap (entrees under $10) Good for groups Kid-friendly

content.description: The problem: A caf as lovely and sunny as thisand with coffee this goodinspires lingering. But lingering requires cup upon cup of caffeine, and that could become hazardous. This European export has a solution for all that, though: a full menu of food, most of it the unlikeliest coffeehouse food youve come across. Braised lamb is served with golden, toothsome spaetzle; hearty sausages arrive with soft dumplings; and smooth, savory pork rillettes come with crusty bread for spreading. At the end of the meal, a slice of impeccable opera cake is a necessity. And with it, yet another cup of coffee.

It takes some time to fall for this French-African spotluckily, youll have plenty of time while you wait for your meal. A platter of delicate meat patties and sweet, ripe plantains can take so long to arrive that youll be ready to eat your place mat. But it doesnt matter how long it takes for the earthy, spinachish cassava-leaf stew or the sweet-and-just-barely-spicy fish with onion sauce to arrive. Because when they do, youll find flavors so complex that they demanded savoringand soon youll be the one whos taking it slow.

Though it was franchised at the turn of the millennium, this location of Als is the oldest (having opened in 1938), and the only direct descendant of the original (a wooden stand at Laflin and Harrison). These days, youll find Italian beefs all over town, but theres something about eating one at this surviving piece of Little Italy. A six-inch bun piled with tender, thinly sliced beef is only better as a combo (topped with char-grilled sausage), dipped in beef jus and finished with hot giardiniera. Skin-on fries smothered with cheese are required eating for a meal lingering locals would be proud of.

For anybody within a ten-block radius, Palette is perhaps the perfect spot. The charming room has huge windows and lots of local art, the cured salmon is right on point, and the service is usually chipper and relaxedjust as a neighborhood joint should be. But if the food alone is what youre coming here for, take care: Much of it (an overly sweet lasagna; slightly sandy scallops) is too boring to keep your interest. The good news: Whether you live in the neighborhood or not, the sumptuous short ribs will never let you down.

The Pastoral vets behind this cozy BYOB know the secret to making a sandwich more than just a sandwich: sourcing. Thats why they let a brunch plate of smoked salmon take its cues from creamy Zingermans goat cheese, and why Mint Creek Farms lamb gets sliced onto a baguette, then dipped in a sweet jus. And now that burgers have been added to the menu on weekdaysincluding a turkey-burger with chipotle-sage aioli and a salmon burger with pickled gingerwere beginning to consider the shaded back patio more as our personal backyard.

The cozy, cushy, Byzantine-style dining room, the simple (and often simply delicious) seasonal Mediterranean foodthats all thanks to David Schneider, the chef-owner of this dim Greek den. Minimal ingredients are needed for a pouf of housemade phyllo filled with leeks and flanked by goat feta or a whole loup de mar with crackly-crisp skin alongside dandelion salad, but solid execution yields maximum flavors. Nice prices and a share-everything platform means more dough for sampling through the superb Greek wine list.
content.property: Late-night dining Outdoor seating Vegetarian-friendly Notable wine list

content.description: The second Lincoln Park outpost of this popular brunch spot lacks the sheer scale of the now-closed West Loop location, but the menu survived the move unscathed. In addition to the fruishi, pancake flights and customizable juices by which Orange earned its cred, the kitchen turns out eggs cooked right on the mark in huevos rancheros with tortilla chips and does a genius variation on French toast: thick-cut brioche dipped in what is effectively a chai latte.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 22, 36

content.description: Although Julie Palmer (Red Kiva Lounge) named her coffeehouse after the 1950s beat hang Cafe Wha? in Greenwich Village, the River North space is more about comfort than counterculture. Free Wi-Fi, magazines youll actually want to read and board games make this an appealing (if somewhat generically offbeat) place to stop in for a cappuccino or a glass of wine or to settle into for an afternoon. The simple workings of a sandwich press elevate the limited snack menu by adding warm pita to hummus and grilled bread to a cheese plate of Manchego and Brie.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Chicago. Bus: 11, 66, 156
content.property: Late-night dining Outdoor seating Good for groups

content.description: Dont let the massive stature and the slick, chain look of Logans newest Mexican spot scare you awaythere are actually some mighty tasty dishes lurking about, and downright delicious margaritas to wash them down with. Start with the app of crispy corn tortillas filled with braised lamb meat and topped with a mound of fuschia pickled onions, then move on to anything smothered in one of the mole sauces (the pillow-soft tamales or the roasted chicken are our favorites. Indulge the kids (or the kid in you) with fried ice cream for a finale, or cheesecake flan if you just cant bring yourself to go Chi-Chis.
content.property: Good for dining at bar Late-night dining

content.description: By now, almost every Mexican-food enthusiast knows how chef Geno Bahena cooks. In fact, Bahena has opened (and closed) so many restaurants in the past four years that many people can probably recite the menu at this new joint sight unseen. But if this is an unsurprising experience, it is at least unsurprisingly good: The ceviche is sharp with lime juice and olives, the steaks are cooked perfectly medium-rare and, of course, there are the moles. Each one is distinctive in its layers of sweetness and spice, proving that there are no bad Geno Bahena restaurants. Just predictable ones.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 9, 11, 77
content.property: BYOB Outdoor seating Private party room(s)

content.description: East doesnt so much meet West as sit quietly alongside it at this Italian-Asian fusion restaurant on the 15th floor of the Holiday Inn Chicago Mart Plaza. Unfortunately, this is the kind of food that gives fusion and hotel restaurant a bad rap: Rubbery chopped octopus joins fresh arugula in a fine salad, a trio of mini sliders are more like marinara-drenched sandwiches, and veal meatballs have an off-putting mouthfeel and are just as bland as the spaghetti noodles theyre perched atop. Wonton cannoli (exactly as it sounds) are actually more successful than a dry cake mysteriously labeled a Milk Chocolate Cappuccino. Still, this is a place best left to out-of-towners afraid to stray too far from their conference rooms.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Merchandise Mart. Bus: 11, 123, 125
content.property: Private party room(s) Good for groups

content.description: The long-established (and rather static) Middle Eastern strip in Albany Park has recently seen a couple of new entrants, and the most ambitious might be this Iraqi restaurant, both for its relatively snazzy interior and for the fact that its open 24/7. So far, the menu seems to follow the standard offerings of its neighbors, but everything is prepared as well as anywhere: Falafel were freshly fried and served with garlicky toum, and shawarma tasted of good-quality meat and was thankfully moist and tender. Service couldnt have been more welcoming at noon, and by reports its the same at midnight, making it a civilized alternative to late-night greasy spoons.
content.property: Kid-friendly Late-night dining Vegetarian-friendly Cheap (entrees under $10)

content.description: A space this cavernous can house only one thing: pizza. Which explains why John Figlioli (of Estelles and Bucktown Pub) opened his family-friendly pie palace in the former Ranallis location. Figlioli outfitted the room with 20 flat-screens, but its the shaded outdoor patio that calls for attentionnot the double-crust pizza (slightly thicker than thin-crust). There are other crowd pleaserssimple but nicely dressed salads, bowls of garlicky spaghetti tossed with a couple of clams, molten chocolate cakebut it doesnt take more than decent pizza to fill the place.
content.property: Outdoor seating Late-night dining Kid-friendly Good for groups Vegetarian-friendly Private party room(s)

content.description: The call-and-response routine behind the counter at this West Coastbased chainin which the person working the register repeats your order, then the crew of line cooks shouts it backis more exciting than the meals themselves. There are countless ways to customize your burger (in S, M, L, XL and XXL; topped with a fried egg, chili or bacon) and fries (skinny ones, fat steak fries or disappointing onion rings). And the beef is of higher-than-average quality, even if it wont exactly make you rethink fast food.
content.property: Cheap (entrees under $10) Good for groups Kid-friendly

content.description: We werent huge fans of chef Dudley Nietos foray into Spanish food when Eivissa first opened, and were guessing we werent the only ones who said so. Nieto recently left the restaurant and returned to San Gabriel Mexican Cafe in Bannockburn, and Jorge Miranda (an Adobo Grill alum) has taken the reins. The new chef is focusing on dishes from the Ibiza region of Spain: charcuterie, such as chorizo and serrano ham; flatbreads topped with manchego or goat cheese; and grilled ribeye and braised lamb pintxos.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Sedgwick. Bus: 9, 72, 156
content.property: Late-night dining Outdoor seating Private party room(s) Good for dining at bar Vegetarian-friendly

content.description: Kettle-boiled, New Yorkstyle bagels are now available in the Loop thanks to the opening of a second location of this Lincoln Parkbased deli and sandwich shop.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Quincy/Wells

content.description: Sweet Occasions fans can stop their mourning: The new ice-cream slinger in this space is practically identicalonly upgraded. The walls are now decked out in cool grays and dark blues, and the savory menu has been expanded to include hot panini such as a roast beef with soft onions and horseradish mayo. Most important, the ice cream is the same (Chocolate Shoppe from Madison, Wisconsin). The scoops are now offered in over-the-top sundaes, but save the cash and the sugar overloadthis ice cream holds up well enough on its own.

Sean Sanderss homey, green-minded North Center restaurant may not look like much of a destination, nor does his menu read like a list of must-haves. But dont be fooled: The food, while on the simpler side, is rife with flavors both big and nuanced. Juicy chicken thighs get paired with rich polenta, beautifully seared walleye gets a lively dressing of salsa verde, and the Browntrout fish trio is made of some of the silkiest cured fish in the city. Some dishes fall flat (the chocolate-chip cookies from his grandmothers recipe are heartbreakingly not up to par). But for the most part, eating simply just got a lot more exciting.
content.public-transport: El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 11, 50, 80
El: Brown, Purple to Sedgwick. Bus: 9, 11, 72

content.description: Fro-yo never dies; it just reincarnatesthis time in Lincoln Park environs. Top Starfruits frozen kefir with anything from Brazilian gogi berries to Milk & Honey granola at this second Chicago location of the probiotic yogurt house.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Armitage. Bus: 8, 11, 74

content.description: This sibling location of Clybourn Avenues popular Cuban carry-out joint is nearly a spitting image of the originalsame toasted Cuban sandwiches, same flaky empanadas, same garlicky fried yucca chips, same potent cafe con leche. But even if the tiny interior, with its newspaper-covered walls, elicits the same claustrophobia, the big draw here is the spacious side patio, complete with a provocative mural, colorful planters and a table for playing dominoes.
content.property: BYOB Outdoor seating Cheap (entrees under $10) Vegetarian-friendly

content.description: Popping up in Bridgeport as some sort of budget-conscious beacon of pan-Asian flavors, Han 202 might just be the best value in town. Twenty bucks brings your picks of five different courses, with fun and flavorful options like lemongrass beef on matchsticks of Granny Smith apples, delicate salt-and-pepper baby octopus, moist grouper peeking out from a blanket of scallions and fresh ginger, and an ending of simple vanilla ice cream with a peel-it-yourself lychee. Figure in a tasteful dining room and a BYOB policy and this place has date night written all over it.

Longtime friends and first-time restaurateurs Julio Perez and Jose Luis Hernandez tapped Cuban-born chef Guillermo Numa to turn out traditional fare on the edge of Bucktown. Neither the food nor the decor is particularly remarkable, and the service (although helpful) can be awkward. Appetizers like tostones (fried pounded green plantains) and bolitas de yuca, fried balls of cheese-filled mashed yuca, are as good as fried street food always is, and mains like pounded flank steak with chimichurri sauce and garlic-rubbed shrimp are simple successes, but swordfish and pork tenderloin are both tough and dry. Desserts, too, feel like a crapshoot: play it safe with a caf con leche.
content.property: BYOB Good for groups Good for dining at bar

content.description: This Scandinavian gourmet store is a fixture not just in Andersonville, but in the Midwest as well. Open since 1925, the delicatessen is one of only a few that imports goods from the Scandinavian countries. Shoppers flock from the suburbs and the rest of the country to browse the selection of pickled herring, Swedish candies, lingonberries, cheeses like bond ost and vsterbottensost and the always-popular Swedish meatballs.

Chef Rick Spiros took a short hiatus after the last restaurant he cooked at, Mantou Noodle, abruptly closed after no more than a month. Now hes at this West Town gastro-lounge. But if it wouldnt make that moniker sound (even more) ridiculous, the owners probably should have flipped those words: Its the hard-partying crowd that are getting the attention herenot the mid-sized plates coming out of the kitchen. Too-cold lobster rolls, soggy french fries, chewy octopus are all passable. So go for the scene, and while youre there, try the fried quail.
content.property: Late-night dining Notable wine list Good for groups

content.description: Its tough to critique an Italian newcomer in a neighborhood with only one other similar option (Pilsen might have a plethora of taquerias, but Little Italy it aint). Still, while former Caro Mio chef Cesar Pineda might have honorable ambitions, theyre tough to appreciate when the food is mediocre and the room already seems dated. Standards like calamari and arancini are fine but not memorable, lobster gets lost amid filler in its ravioli pocket, and braciole is both tough and underseasoned. Barring a drastic turnaround, the surrounding taquerias should remain unscathed by this competition.

With a counter made from recycled corrugated steel and walls neatly decorated with National Geographic covers, this is one of the few cheap-eats destinations that can honestly be described as cute. The piled-high sopes and tortas heading out of the kitchen are pretty good looking, too, layered with enough avocado and hot sauce to hide pasty masa and dryish chicken. And the pastry case showcases rice pudding and tequila-mousse that are almost too pretty to eat. But its the fish and shrimp tacos (lightly battered, juicy) that really got us taking this place seriously.
content.property: BYOB Cheap (entrees under $10) Vegetarian-friendly Good for groups

content.description: Breakfast at Rick Baylesss new baby is quiet perfection: a cup of masterfully concocted hot chocolate, a flaky egg empanada, one hell of a sugar-and-cocoa-coated churro. Lunch here is no less delicious, but its a frenzy: Lines extend out the door for tortas filled with fatty, crispy pork carnitas and La Quercia prosciutto. The crowds keep up at dinner, when caldos like braised-short-rib soup and chicken stew with toothsome posole are the ideal prelude toanother cup of rich hot chocolate and a churro. Its nice when things come full circle.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Merchandise Mart; Red to Grand. Bus: 22, 29, 36, 65

content.description: If youre going to get a pannenkoeken (crpe-like pancake) hereand thats what you came for, right?it may as well be the one topped with salami and cheese. Like the rest of the pannenkoeken, its pretty unattractive, but because the salami has a greasy, meaty punch to it, its likely to be the most successful dish you order. The rest of the menupedestrian eggs, soft wafflesisnt worth your time. For that matter, some of the other Dutch dishes may disappoint as well. Because while food of this nationality may be a novelty, at the end of the day its simple, unremarkable diner food just the same.

Until judges resolve Lettuce Entertain Yous trademark-infringement lawsuit against Sean Tehrani, the owner of this salad-and-sandwich spot, the banner outside this place will read let us be: name pending. And that legal battle will likely be the most interesting thing about this place. Because, unfortunately, the 14 varieties of mostly organic salads (available in one giant size only, packed with enough butter lettuce or mixed greens to almost merit the high price tag), the handful of sandwiches (smoky bacon on dry foccacia) and the healthy-tasting soups here arent sustaining our interest.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 8, 22, 36

content.description: After opening three New York City locations, this late-night taco-and-tequila parlor has entered the Chicago market, ostensibly bringing something to the scene that we dont already have. The tacos are indeed originalcarnitas tacos come with cool coleslaw and rich peanuts; crispy estilo Baja tacos come with an aioli spicy enough to make you sweatbut the rest of the wares (including the much-hyped cocktails) are inconsistent. But when you taste chef Patricio Sandovals flans, youll be convinced that despite the growing pains, this place has something going for it. Who knows? Maybe New York has something to teach Chicago about Mexican food after all.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Merchandise Mart; Red to Grand; Blue, Green, Pink, Orange to Clark/Lake. Bus: 11, 22, 156

entry.name: The Original Alps Restaurant & Pancake House

version.name: The Original Alps Restaurant & Pancake House

content.description: Is it us, or does every place that calls itself a pancake house put out flapjacks as dense and heavy as manhole covers? Wed just as soon make our own pancakes as eat them here, but the thin, overstuffed housemade blintzes and juicy, house-roasted ham are a different story. So is the perfectly sassy service, whichunless youre living with a particularly trying girlfriend/mother/sisteris pretty much irreplicable.
content.public-transport: El: Blue to Irving Park. Bus: 53, 80, 82

content.description: At this Wicker Park sibling to Tango Sur, the lights are dim, the mojitos are strong, the wine list has tons of inexpensive by-the-glass optionsjust the right setup for a romantic dinner. But plan to pay more attention to your date than to the food, which has many more misses (flavorless, underseasoned steaks; lackluster seafood and chicken) than hits. For best results, go with the flaky empanadas filled with juicy beef and the parillada para uno, a skillet teeming with on-the-bone short ribs and charred sweetbreads, which will serve you, your date and then some.
content.public-transport: El: Blue to Damen or Division. Bus: 49, 50, 70

content.description: Rida Shahins soft and chewy salted ciabatta is good enough that you could eat it all by itself and have a perfectly satisfying lunch. And in fact, until this bread baker opened his storefront bakery, his bread (sold wholesale) was the only thing he had to offer.
