But now he serves sandwiches and a full line of pastries, from crispy-and-chewy chocolate chip cookies to nuanced apricot-cardamom tarts. So you can go and have a nice lunch in the caf if you want to. But a word to the wise: Buying a couple of loaves and taking them home makes the moment last longer.

Cheddar fries didnt sound like something we would want with shawarma. Until we learned that this was Merkts cheddar, served with burning hot, crispy fries. As it turns out, it was the dryish chicken shawarmabeefed up with hummus, carrot salad and a burritos worth of other condiments and served in a pita or soft, doughy laffa flatbreadwe didnt necessarily need with our cheddar fries.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Quincy/Wells; Blue to LaSalle; Red to Jackson.

content.description: Stephan Outrequin Quaisser says he doesnt want Lincoln Square locals to have to trek downtown to celebrate a special occasion. So hes taken over Tallulah and brought in chef Brad Phillips to execute a laundry list of French classics. Plump sweetbreads arrive with caramelized onion ravioli; pan-roasted poussin arrives with plenty of buttery pan sauce and a handful of chanterelles; and the veal cheeks are rich enough to get elected mayor of New York. A textbook crme brle and a perfect apple tarte Tatin with freshly whipped cream end things on a high note. The only thing the place needs now is some people to do some celebrating.

This collaboration between Michael Kornick (mk) and David Morton (of the steakhouse clan) is an attempt to be Chicagos answer to In-N-Out and Shake Shack. If it were left up to its fries (fried in beef fat), shakes (made with Petersens ice cream) or sides (anchovy-draped Caesar salad), itd come close to achieving that iconic status. But the star of the showthe burgeris where things get all tripped up. Patties are cooked only medium plus, which renders the things juiceless and disappointing. Even more disappointing: DMK seems completely uninterested in ever cooking its burgers any other way. And to think it had such promise.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Wellington; Red to Belmont. Bus: 8, 76, 77

content.description: A sprawling menu of sushi, noodles, and entrees like lamb chops with shiitake mushrooms takes off in Logan Square.

Expansive, kid-friendly and straightforward more aptly describe this breakfast-and-lunch emporium than its given surname, a Lovely idea. (Its owned by the same folks as Lovely: A Bake Shop.) Though the preparations may not be delicate or especially sophisticated, its hard to go wrong with bacon, either in a flight (five strips, each coated with a different glaze) or floating in a creamy potato soup. Other dishes (a spongy meatloaf sandwich, unremarkable pumpkin pancakes) unfortunately read better than they tastewhich makes them most well-suited for those who are too young to read anyway.
content.property: BYOB Cheap (entrees under $10) Good for groups Kid-friendly Vegetarian-friendly

content.description: This quick-service fish shack shows some gourmet leanings: Its run by former Hells Kitchen contestant Tony DAlessandro, the fish is breaded-and-fried to order, and burgers are made from Angus beef. But dont get it in your head that this is anything other than a dive. Youre best off keeping it simple with that fried fish and tartar sauce. Other dishescrab tostadas, shrimp tacos smothered in mayo and cocktail sauce on a tough grilled tortilla, beet salad in a pool of liquiddont live up to their aspirations.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Chicago. Bus: 11, 66, 156

content.description: Cream-puff aficionados have been making due with paltry eclairs for a long time in this city. But no longer. Beard Papas, the Japanese cream-puff chain, now holds court in the Block 37 pedway. The brilliantly airy cocoons of choux pastry hide a copious amount of vanilla custard cream, enough that once the shell is broken, walking and eating is out of the question. A bag of travel-friendly mini puffs could suffice, but youll lose the proper pastry-to-cream ratio. When youve waited this long, its the classic or nothingunless, that is, theyre selling the green-tea filling. In which case get out of our way.
content.public-transport: El: Blue to Washington; Red to Lake; Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Randolph/Wabash

content.description: Years ago, Ramon Delgado was famous for his Cuban sandwiches at La Bombonera, which was then located in the current New Wave Coffee. He recently reopened in the less-gentrified part of Logan Square, where his son Carlos has joined him. At $3.95, the Cubanos perfectly fine for breakfast or lunch, but at dinner, its the chicharrones de pollolightly fried chunks of bone-in chickenand smashed plantains that stand out. Then again, we poured so much of the green salsa (a simple but knockout jalapeo-and-garlic puree) over everything, at some point we stopped tasting anything but delicious, sweat-breaking heat.
content.public-transport: El: Blue to Logan Square. Bus: 53, 56, 76, 82
content.property: Cheap (entrees under $10) Good for groups BYOB Private party room(s)

content.public-transport: Metra: Union Pacific NW to Arlington Heights
El: Red, Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Belmont. Bus: 36, 77
El: Brown to Chicago; Bus: 66 Chicago (24 hrs), 156 LaSalle

content.description: Testing this venue blurb out.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Wellington. Bus: 11, 77

content.description: By day it’s home to dedicated regulars, by night it’s packed with rock & rollers drinking $5 half pitchers and nodding to free live bands. Pool, darts and Golden Tee are all free, and so is the chance to mark your territory by painting a ceiling tile. If you’re in search of (semitarnished) gold, this is your treasure. this is extra text.

Bring your aches, pains and chronic conditions to the Healing Room, where clinically trained therapist Ellen Letten oversees a team of clinical massage therapists who help relieve pain and provide relaxation. Specialties include trigger point treatment (said to reduce pain), Bach Flower Therapy (homeopathic stress management), cranial sacral therapy, and pregnancy and hot stone massage.

content.property: members and kids under 5 free USD

content.public-transport: El: Red to Harrison; Brown, Pink, Purple (rush hrs), Orange to Library. Bus: 1, 3, 4, 6, 7, 10, 14, 26, 28, 126, 145, 146, 147
El: Red, Green to Garfield, then bus: 55. Metra: Elec Main to 55th St

address.street: James R. Thompson Center, 100 W Randolph St, second floor
James R. Thompson Center, 100 W Randolph St, second floor

content.public-transport: El: Blue, Orange, Green, Brown, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Clark/Lake

content.vendor-category: Get | Spas & gyms | Classes and workshops

content.description: Break out the ten-hole Doc Martens and the hair products for this goth-punk outpost that hasn’t changed much since, well, before you were born. Neo has a small dance floor and a calendar crammed with DJs specializing in everything from metal and industrial to new wave and electro.
content.public-transport: El: Red, Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Fullerton. Bus: 22, 36, 74

entry.name: Old Town School of Folk Music

version.name: Old Town School of Folk Music

content.public-transport: El: Red, Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Belmont. Bus: 8, 77

Bus: 55. Metra: Elec Main to 55th-56th-57th St
El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Chicago. Bus: 11, 66, 156.
El: Red, Blue to Jackson; Orange, Green, Brown, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Adams. Bus: 3, 4, 14, 26, 143, 144, 145, 146, 147, 151, 157

content.description: Relaxation is dished out Big Easy-style at this Edgewater day spa. With exposed brick, wrought-iron balconies and a waiting area reminiscent of a New Orleans courtyard garden, this retreat oozes Southern hospitality. Keep the mood going with specialty services like the Mint Julep Manicure ($40) or Pedicure ($60) or immerse yourself in a fresh flower–enhanced milk bath ($45) in a stunning, sunken hydrotherapy tub. A full menu of services for men and women is available, with discounts for those who prepay or sign up for the Spa Select Membership.

content.public-transport: El: Red, Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Belmont. Bus: 9, 77
El: Red, Blue to Jackson; Orange, Green, Brown, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Adams. Bus: 3, 4, 14, 26, 143, 144, 145, 146, 147, 151, 157

content.description: This is Wicker Park’s latest starter club—basically the bridge between college bars and real nightclubs. The engaging design—think a sexed-up, futuristic hunting lodge—sets high expectations, which the clumsy service and inconsistent deejaying don’t meet. It’ll be a while before this one can run with the big dogs.

content.public-transport: El: Blue to Jefferson Park. Bus: 56, 81

entry.name: Center for Performing Arts at Governors State University

version.name: Center for Performing Arts at Governors State University

content.public-transport: Metra: Elec Main to University Park

content.description: As its name suggests, this salon/spa is strictly for the guys, but it's located right in the heart of Boystown—so it's a touch more fabulous than other men-only spas. The small space, where stylists cut hair ($15 and up) may be full of soothing brown leather tones, but the real soothing area is the facial room off to the side. The Anti-Aging Treatment ($80) uses a papaya mask that rejuvenates skin while you listen to soft music. We suspect this room isn't comfortable all the time, though, since it's also the same space where the “manscaping” takes place. Who knows, though, in such a calming environment, even a thong wax ($70) might be bearable.

With Beatles in the bathrooms and Madonna in the corridors, there’s little doubt about this hotel’s theme. The rock ’n’ roll aspect is toned down in the guestrooms, where amenities include flat-screen TVs and a selection of Aveda toiletries. The hotel occupies the beautiful 40-story Carbide & Carbon Building, an art deco superstar built in 1929 by sons of famed architect Daniel Burnham.
*High-speed internet (free wireless in public spaces & in rooms).
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs); Red to State/Lake. Bus: 3, 4, 10, 14, 26, 143, 144, 145, 146, 147, 151, 157
El: Green, Pink to Ashland. Bus: 9, 65

entry.name: Chicago Center for the Performing Arts

version.name: Chicago Center for the Performing Arts

content.description: Nourhy’s cottage-esque studio in Bucktown (plus the presence of her pooch) disarms clients even before she employs her light, practiced touch to her reflexology, massage, and craniosacral treatments. Nourhy uses organic sheets, towels and oils and has an intuitive knowledge of what the client needs: She blended several treatments for us, and our stress levels—not to mention our shoulders—dropped immediately and stayed that way for days.

Complimentary snacks and cocoa, a foot soak with every treatment, and a personal welcome from owner and nine-year industry veteran Audrie Mumphery are a few of the little details that make this second-floor, 4,000-square-foot spa feel more like a friend’s apartment than a busy Loop business. Choose from a traditional assortment of facials, body wraps, massages, manicures and pedicures. Signature treatments include the detoxifying and moisturizing Green Tea Facial ($95) and the hydrating Lemon Cream Pedicure ($55).
content.public-transport: Metra: Elec to Millennium Station. El: Green, Brown, Orange, Purple (rush hrs) to Madison. Bus: 3, 4, 6, 14, 147, 151

content.description: This Korean-run and -patronized spa harks back to the days when spa-ing meant sweating en masse, and no one much fussed about ambience. The entryway is quiet and low-lit?ladies go right and men go left, please?but in the back things cut loose. The sauna and steam rooms are fairly tame, but if the formidable six-jet whirlpool doesn't stun your body into submission, the hot and cold dipping pools will. If you want to fork out for a massage or body scrub (average price $60), there are no-nonsense experts to accommodate you. The locker rooms can be loud. There is refuge, however, for those who prefer to wind down a little more quietly. Beat a hasty retreat to the post-spa area, a darkened room where Barcoloungers abound, and hope that no one's turned on the television?unless you're into Korean soap operas. There's also a sushi bar, where you can score a decent roll, but the hours can be willy-nilly.

entry.name: Mitchell Museum of the American Indian

version.name: Mitchell Museum of the American Indian

content.description: The museum’s artifact-packed permanent displays include items from Native American tribes from across the country, as well as Canada. See baskets, masks, ceremonial dolls, wooden carvings and other historic items that span the centuries; most have been culled from local collector John Mitchell’s personal collection.

It's easy to get lost in this multi-level spa, but we always head right downstairs to sign in for a super relaxing manicure with paraffin and a scalp and neck massage. (The gift shop is also down there, and we always manage to pick up a scented candle or two.) Upstairs, you'll find services from a nutritionist, plastic surgeon and even a sleep specialist—convenient for those looking for a one-stop spa. Our only complaint? The table was a little wobbly during our massage, but we were so stress-free by that point, that we didn't even mind.

content.description: Under a glass dome and in greenhouse rooms on just over a half acre of land thrive more than 40,000 plants representing around 200 species. Attractions include an extensive fern collection, a room full of dozens of orchid varieties and a 100-year-old, 50-foot rubber tree. Flower shows change with the seasons.

content.description: Tucked into the heart of downtown Evanston, Egea Spa is a full-service city spa with all the perks of suburbia. Parking is no problem, appointments are generally easily available (even day of) and friendliness abounds. Nail, facial, massage and body treatments are performed with care and expertise.

content.description: This freak-friendly dance destination in Lakeview built its reputation back in the mid-’80s with a mix of German new-wave music, art installations and even transvestite shows. These days, it’s still quirky but more retro, with Prince-tribute, disco and ’80s nostalgia nights. Goths and gays are extra welcome, but the scene here is made up of almost everyone.

content.description: The vivid colors and exotic look of this cozy establishment have weathered to ridiculous kitsch, but the spirit at the venerable venue is strong. Weekends are jammed with crunkers, sitters and sippers. Tuesdays host the musically adventurous gay-friendly party OUTdanced!; and mid-week, Top 40 hip-hoppers and underground R&B divas sometimes drop in for live sets.

content.description: The outlandishly bright, hyper girly spring/summer collection—cotton day dresses, organza evening frocks and playful bloomers—featured in this Wicker Park shop bears shades of Anna Sui and Betsey Johnson. And they ought to—local designer Chatzka assisted both as an intern in New York. Accessories such as headbands, cuffs and change purses go for less than $50 a pop.

content.description: This studio has been around since 1984, and we can easily see why—the teachers totally know their stuff. Suddha Weixler, the director, lived in a monastic setting for eight years to learn the classical system. That's hard core. Chicago Yoga Center is on the third floor of a building filled with other artsy studios, and the center consists of one room. That means no one else is practicing at the same time as you, so you can be assured a really peaceful, quiet experience. They offer Astanga, Vinyasa, Yin, open and beginning classes, in addition to a host of ever changing workshops and teacher training sessions.

content.description: Amid the barrage of yoga studios, Yoga Now distinguishes itself as the only one authorized to teach the Mysore technique, the traditional method of learning ashtanga that allows students to work at their own pace. Instructor Amy Beth Treciokas studied with guru Sri K. Pattabhi Jois in India for two years and teaches here (Sun?Fri 8?10am). The studio is closed on “moon days”?as in new and full?so check the calendar before popping in. Prenatal, Forrest and free community class on Sundays 6?7:30pm.

Metro is one of the city’s older and more famous clubs. Formerly known as the Cabaret Metro, it hosts a variety of midsize national touring acts of all genres, from rock to hip-hop to electronica. It’s also known for larger showcases of local bands, such as the annual Chicago Rocks fest, where you can catch a slew of the city’s top hip-hop artists all in one night. A number of its shows are all-ages or 18-and-older, so you’ll likely be frequenting it. Downstairs you’ll often find excellent DJs at the adjacent Smart Bar—see Clubs listings for more.

entry.name: Piven Theatre Workshop at Noyes Cultural Arts Center

version.name: Piven Theatre Workshop at Noyes Cultural Arts Center

content.description: The tallest building in the country, this 1973 landmark occupies two city blocks and stretches 1,454 feet high. Skydeck views from the 103rd floor allow you to see as far as 50 miles out. While you’re up there, learn about the city’s landmarks from a multilingual computer program and about its history from wall exhibits. The Skydeck’s newest feature, The Ledge sounds like a horror movie, but there’s a reason for that: Crawl into the Sears Tower’s new glass cube structure, and you’ll be defenselessly suspended 1,353 feet off the ground. If that doesn’t make you want to scream like Sarah Michelle Gellar, nothing will.

Returns are surprisingly hassle-free, there’s a shoe department the size of Montana, and the varied selection storewide is sure to please everyone from high-maintenance designer divas to no-fuss grumpy gramps.

content.description: Tucked into the second floor of an Old Town office building, the small muted green space is low on frills (pedicure stations are office chairs with metal bowls), but high on service. Owner and former flight attendant Megan Parr ensures tools are cleaned religiously, industry trends are followed closely and training is rigorous. Personal attention (color preferences are recorded), details like crystal nail files (said to be less abrasive) and long-lasting polish compensate for subpar décor. Basic, spa and sanctuary manicures and pedicures are available, as are gel and acrylic services.

content.description: This slick, modern, multilevel Euro-style club in River North opened to much fanfare in 2004 and has kept clubbers busy ever since. On weekends, resident DJs, costumed dancers and powerful sound create a spectacular scene in the multiroom venue. Touring big-name DJs in techno and progressive house usually play Friday nights with residents spinning house and electro on Saturdays. On long holiday weekends, the club squeezes in popular internationally oriented nights.

content.description: Be prepared for fog machines, flashing lights and loud rock & roll when you enter this hidden gem.

Housed in a former synagogue and theater and set on a quiet residential street, this museum is purportedly the only one in the country devoted to the leather lifestyle. Paintings of men with bulging biceps and perfect “packages” adorn the walls of the worship hall. Downstairs, visitors can thumb through around 10,000 underground sex magazines and peruse exhibits featuring leather whips, a 19th century chastity belt for men and common kitchen tools used for sex play.

The late-night hanging at this River North spot (RiNo, get it?) feels like a wealthy socialite’s loft party for pretty people with fairly pedestrian taste in music. The casually trendy ladies seem to love dancing on the furniture—which makes sense when you consider they’re usually already drunk when they arrive at 1:30am.

content.description: This Lincoln Park studio is named for its sweeping fourth-floor vista of the city. Co-owner Quinn Kearney regularly works with the tantric-happy Sting whenever he comes to town, and word has it he's even known to pop in for class. The studio does the occasional workshop, with emphasis on ongoing classes and a focus on vinyasa-flow breathing and alignment.

content.description:
A feeling of refined romance pervades in these cushy digs: oversized bathrooms, separate dressing rooms, fluffy robes and in-room spa services complete with chocolate-covered strawberries and champagne. Tea and frothy coffees are served in the art-filled sunken lobby, while the classy, revamped Aria bar serves sushi with glasses of Evolution, its signature champagne and sake cocktail.
*High-speed internet (free wireless in public spaces; $14.95 via cable in rooms).
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Randolph. Bus: 4, 60

content.description: Originally on the fourth floor of the magnificent Wrigleyville building (also home to Metro; see Music venues, Rock, pop & hip-hop), this venerated dance club is now in the basement. A makeover in 2006 slicked up the looks a notch and brought back a vibrant young crowd. But more important, the club boasts a world-class Funktion One sound system, which sounds tremendous on the central dance floor. Cutting-edge DJs from Europe, Detroit and Chicago form the bulk of the weekend bookings with house, techno and electro styles; but local mash-up and indie jocks rule on bargain weekday nights.

Local eccentric fund-manager and philanthropist Driehaus has opened this museum to publicly display his expansive collection of Louis Comfort Tiffany lamps and accessories, and other late 19th century furnishings. Housed inside the mansion built by 19th-century liquor-magnate Samuel M Nickerson, the immaculately rehabbed “marble palace” is also a shining example of building preservation.

content.public-transport: El: Brown to Chicago; Bus: 66 Chicago (24 hrs), 156 LaSalle

content.description: This 11,000-square-foot retreat has “spa day” written all over it. Drop in for a yoga class and you’ll want to linger in the eco-friendly retail area, dine at the café and treat yourself to Vosges elixirs and truffles. Better yet, lose yourself in organic-focused treatments like the Singing Bowl ($140) or Organic Stone and Crystal ($160) facials. We hauled our stressed-out selves to Glenview and said we wanted to leave “utterly relaxed.” Our facial technician took the challenge so seriously, we literally had to check to be sure she hadn’t used extra fingers to achieve the desire effect. Ladies can finish with a complementary water ritual, featuring a monsoon shower and signature scrub, aromatherapy steam and sauna and a few moments of quiet in a private room with just you, a cozy chair and a bubbling fountain. Mission accomplished.

address.street: 835 N Michigan, 3rd floor of the Water Tower
835 N Michigan, 3rd floor of the Water Tower

content.description: Everything reminds us of a doctor's office at Georgette Klinger, from the tubes of products in the waiting room down to the white uniforms the aestheticians wear while they're performing the services in the silent, bare treatment areas. But this was one “doctor's office” we wouldn't mind returning to again and again. While they offer a range of services, they're best known for their facials, which are extraordinary. They start with an in-depth conversation about your skin before the customized facial tackles every area on your face, neck, upper back, hands and feet using luxury SkinCeutical lotions, toners and masks. We walked in with a face filled with blemishes, and we left with soft, clear skin. We just wish they wouldn't have pressured us to buy their (excellent) products.

content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Merchandise Mart; Red to Grand. Bus: 11, 22, 29, 62,156.

content.description: This spacious, unpretentious Ukrainian Village nightspot has gradually upgraded sound and stage features, enabling it to turn from rock bar to DJ den in a flash. The photography-themed decor extends to displays of local photographers’ prints. DJ nights for reggae, hip-hop and house predominate, but rock, indie and electro nights are frequent. Somehow, it’s never gotten overly hip, which might be because it needs a headcount of 100 before it starts to get cozy.

Our favorite part of spa-ing at the Peninsula Hotel Spa is the time we spend chilling in the newly remodeled lounge area. Single-person beds with fluffy comforters nestle in private, draped enclaves. You can spend hours reading or napping, completely undisturbed—except for someone refilling your tall glass of fruit-infused water or mug of tea. Nearby ther's a flickering fireplace. The spa menu is pricey (manicures start at $35), but the top-notch products (like June Jacobs) make a body treatment worth the splurge.

content.description: Before the likes of Ludwig Mies van der Rohe or even Louis Sullivan started putting Chicago on the architectural map, this 1836 Greek Revival–style home, graced with a four-column portico, symbolized the first national architectural style. It also lays claim to being the city’s oldest house.

content.description: In 2008, taking over the former Rive Gauche space, another nightlife contender entered the fray. The usual combination of go-go dancers, bottle service booths and energetic house and electro remixes might not set this place apart. the faux display windows are occupied by sloppily posed mannequins which don't do much for the glamour vibe. On the other hand, the open floor plan is ace for people watching and seeing and being seen. The young folks, particularly suburban based adventurers, love it.

version.name: The Spa by Asha at The James

content.description: The folks at the newly remodeled downstairs spa encourage guests to come early so they can enjoy a relaxing aromatherapyfoot bath in the dimly lit lounge. While you soak your peds in a warm, soothing blen of rose, vanilla and lavender oils, a therapist will wrap a heated, herb-scented pillow around your neck and massage your feet and calves with finely ground walnut shells, kelp, aloe, lavender and herbal extracts. The pretreatment ritual is so relaxing, it's almost a buzzkill to have to get up for your scheduled service. Almost.

content.description: To get to the spa here, you have to walk past the busy salon area downstairs, to the serene floor they reserved for spa pampering. While not too plush, the brown tones throughout the spa give it a relaxed, calming feel – even though the spa space isn't huge. They use all Aveda products, and we sampled their offerings though a 1 ½ hour Ultimate Rejuvenating Body Treatment ($120), which includes a body wrap, a scalp massage and a facial. Heavenly—although we wouldn't recommend the manicures and pedicures, which take place in the hallway between the stairs and the spa waiting room.

entry.name: DuSable Museum of African American History

version.name: DuSable Museum of African American History

content.description: When this institution opened in 1961, African-American history was suffering serious neglect at the hands of the city’s—and for that matter the nation’s—cultural institutions. The Hyde Park cultural hub is now one of the oldest and most respected African-American–focused museums in the country. On display are documents and artifacts from the lives of overlooked or unjustly marginalized movers and shakers, plus a collection of vibrant African-American art.
content.property: kids under 6 and Sundays free USD

content.description: It's a one–woman, one–room show at this skincare spot. Owner and aesthetician Liz Quesnelle opened up shop in 2003 after learning the ropes at the Aveda Institute and assisting an M.D. at Northwestern Memorial Hospital, where she specialized in skin disorders and corrective cosmetics. Thanks to her rigorous training and hospital experience, Quesnelle has an honest, optimistic, yet scientific approach to skincare (she does makeup application and lessons, too). And as a rule, she doesn't sell products (“you can get great stuff for a lot less at any drugstore”) and she follows up after sessions with each client via email. It's a small operation but the facials are fantastic–and we felt like we were in the hands of a pro with the bubbly, but not overly chatty, Quenelle.

content.description: Waxing specialist Sisters is known for being one of the first spas in the country to take it all off down there. Founders Jeannette Abou-Mourad and Elaine Youhanna have been giving the “honeymoon” wax since they were teenagers in Lebanon (Jeannette was quick to remind us that the “Brazilian” is named after the bikini-style, not to be confused with waxings' origins, which are Middle Eastern). All those years have paid off: The ladies have honed frill-free waxing down to an art form and Chicago's who's-who make monthly pilgrimages to the Water Tower Place location for speedy, clean, impeccable and less painful waxing experience.

A downtown destination for the past 15 years, this superclub is housed in a historic church and seemingly has a room for everything: There’s a weekly cabaret show, live flamenco music, Latin dance lessons and even a paranormal interactive-theater event. With all the cross-promotion going on, it draws a crowd of enthusiastic out-of-towners and club novices who would settle for a mediocre experience.

The organic sister club to Funky Buddha (see below) is a newcomer with a healthy, earth-friendly agenda and an interior molded from Central American mud. The hippy-green aspect extends to alcohol-free stimulant drinks, partially off-the-grid power, organic spirits and ice cubes made from spring water. Luckily, the DJs are up to par, delivering hip-hop and soulful dance with an international bent.

Brow shaping, the spa?s signature service, runs $100 for the first visit and $55 thereafter. Other services include Swedish and hot rock massage, aromatherapy and clarifying facials, a variety of body wraps, manicures and pedicures.

content.description: Massages are the specialty here, and the spa offers every type—from the classic Swedish to the ashiatsu (therapist uses feet to massage you) and the oncology (a blend of Eastern and Western treatments to get you rested). While the massages are excellent, the best part of the spa is outside the treatment rooms, where you can choose between three complimentary showers: steam, rain (heavy overhead water flow) and European style (multiple jets). Before your appointment, the receptionist will ask if you’d like a shower. Your answer should be yes. And if you have the foresight to do it, we recommend you call ahead to schedule the shower because our favorite—the rainshower—is sometimes overbooked.

content.public-transport: Metra: Milwaukee District North to North Glenview.

content.description: Described as “landscape art under glass” when it opened in 1908, the conservatory, while being one of the largest in the world, also boasts revolutionary architecture. Between the building’s haystack shape and walls of stratified stonework, landscape architect Jens Jensen considered the Fern Room in particular, with its “prairie waterfall”—a stone and water element within a glass structure—to be one of his greatest achievements. About 120,000 plants representing some 600 species occupy the conservatory’s 1.6 acres, and four times a year flower shows premiere to herald the change in seasons. In 2008, the conservatory opened Sugar from the Sun, an exhibit on photosynthesis, which is explored in living displays, that is to say, plants alongside scant few text panels.
content.public-transport: El: Green to Conservatory/Central Park. Bus: 20, 52, 82
El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 11, 50, 78, 80, 152

content.description: A standing testament to the work of humanitarian Jane Addams, this museum is housed in the home she opened in 1889 to serve people in need, including a young Benny Goodman who learned to play clarinet there. The text-intensive displays supplement paintings that hung at the settlement, pottery and tableware created through her community art program, her desk and, next door, the dining hall where she and residents shared meals.

Working with just 900 square feet, the two women behind this Rogers Park spa have managed to create a warm, relaxing space that doesn?t skimp on luxurious touches. Slip off your shoes in the plant-filled, sun-splashed waiting area, head to one of three dimly lit treatment rooms, climb onto the heated massage table and snuggle up against butter-soft flannel sheets. Both Liz Ellis and Suzen Cook are trained doulas (midwives), and offer massage from pregnancy to deep tissue. Cook, who worked at Santa Fe?s Ten Thousand Waves, also specializes in body treatments such as herbal wraps, salt or sugar glows, and a fantastic head and neck treatment: Warm oil is massaged into your hair and scalp, and refreshingly cool marble stones are used to work the oil into your face. Also soothing is the hot stone massage, in which Cook kneads heated basalt stones into tight muscles, then places them on your chakras.

content.public-transport: El: Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs), Brown to Washington; Blue to Monroe. Bus: 20, 60, 157

content.description: This Edgewater spa is mostly dedicated to spot- and hard-to-find massages focusing on the head, face and neck. The resident therapist practices a West Coast technique, beginning on your belly and massaging neck and appendages before turning you over to focus on face, feet, torso and, finally, back. It’s a nice change of pace. Nicer still is the bowl of eucalyptus water strategically placed on the floor so you can inhale the sinus-opening vapors. During the evening, the place is transformed into a studio for belly dancing, group meditations and yoga classes. Don’t leave without buying Cherie Bianco’s homemade all-natural soaps, scrubs and creams.
content.public-transport: El: Red to Bryn Mawr. Bus: 36, 84, 151
El: Red to Harrison; Blue to LaSalle. Bus: 29, 36, 62

content.description: Though it’s staffed by world-class researchers at the forefront of their field, the museum’s real draw will always be the virtual-reality trips through time and space in the StarRider and Sky Theaters. Themes usually center around the known and unknown universe and how humans have engaged with it throughout history.
content.property: Galaxy Package (includes one Sky Show) USD 19.00

content.description: Mind, body, spirit takes on new meaning at Tsubo, where you can sweat off lunch in a personal training session, optimize skin in a custom-blended facial and minimize any remaining stress in a balancing Reiki massage—all without leaving the building. Housed in a 4,000-square-foot converted loft in a dusty industrial corridor, Tsubo blends the skills of co-owners Trisha Kaufman, a personal trainer and hairstylist, and Jay Holtman, a massage therapist, to give customers a complete wellness experience. Free weights, salon chairs and massage tables co-mingle amongst hardwood floors, sweeping loft windows and Asian-inspired décor. Don’t be intimidated by the building’s near-deserted appearance—parking is free and plentiful and the walk up the creaky flight of stairs is worth it.

content.description: At the Detox Flow: Purification of Body, Mind & Spirit workshops at Moksha Riverwest, you’ll examine everything you take into your body. The four days of classes will include sun salutations, detox standing sequences, breathing exercises, meditation, dietary counseling and more. Don’t you feel healthier just thinking about it?

content.description: The emphasis is on wide-open space at this after-work lounge that turns clubby later. An interesting LED lighting fixture captures the theme, while some of Chicago’s harder-hustling disco and electro DJs man the booth.

content.description: You can get everything from holistic body wraps to haircuts to eyelash extensions here, but our favorite is the incredibly detail-oriented spa pedicure ($46). It’s done in a semiprivate room, which would be perfect for spa days, as it holds three people. The nail technician buffs, massages and polishes your feet and toes for an hour before declaring them stiletto-ready. Just as much attention is paid to the facials, which are usually done by Daniela herself. The one thing the spa doesn’t do is massage, but its menu appears to expand every time we walk in, so maybe we’ll see it soon.

entry.name: Meet at the CARA bulletin board

version.name: Meet at the CARA bulletin board

content.description: If you’re not relaxed by the muted orange and brown wall tones, by the candles or by the dim lighting throughout the spa, you must be seriously stressed out. But worry not—the minute you step into Mi Spa Chicago, which is perched on the second floor of a lofted South Loop building—your body will start to calm down. Flower petals cover every massage and facial bed, and the pedicures are done in a secluded but beautiful peaceful room. Our hot stone massage ($100) whisked away every ounce of soreness in our tired body, and their make-up applications are so fabulous that even Gov. Rod Blagojevich has gotten his face beautified there (and they’ve got the pics to prove it).
content.public-transport: El: Red, orange to Roosevelt. Bus: 1, 4

content.description: This 24.5-acre park features Frank Gehry's Pritzker Pavilion and serpentine bridge; sculptor Anish Kapoor's 110-ton Cloud Gate (a.k.a. “The Bean”); and Jaume Plensa's Crown Fountain, with its ever-changing array of locals' faces spewing water very five minutes in the summer months.

content.description: See some 1,200 animals, from apes to zebras, at the oldest and one of only a few free zoos left in the country. It is small, only 35 acres, but big attractions like the Kovler Lion House and the Regenstein Center for African Apes pack a big punch.

Charles Gates Dawes House, 225 Greenwood St

content.description: This tiny storefront Pilates studio specializes in private group reformer classes, which are taught by dedicated and informed instructors. They quickly assess your body, determining the pilates routine that works best before getting started with your workout. Our teacher told us that the arch of our feet was formed by our running habit, and our hunched back resulted from staring at a computer all day. Then, she got to work fixing our disheveled body. They offer discounts for private group reformer session with a few friends, and they also have mat classes.

content.description: This Gold Coast mind-body spa breaks new ground in luxury. The spin is spa treatments and fitness classes that focus on healing. The atmosphere is part ultramodern and part exotic and the treatments are also a delightful melding of disciplines. You'll find a range of massages (including Thai, four-handed, acupuncture and energetic therapy, which incorporates guided meditation). By far the most wondrous is body enlightening, which is full-body contact with your therapist, who gently and expertly stretches, balances and aligns you from the outside in. The menu extends to nails, facials and waxing, but the spa's crowning glory is the Core Fusion class. It's the signature workout and combines a slew of disciplines that promise to rejuvenate and transform.

Owned and operated by world-champion ballroom dancers Tommye Giacchino and Gregory Day, these studios offer a ton of classes for kids and adults in a wide variety of ballroom styles. They also organize parties, workshops and offer private lessons.
content.public-transport: El: Blue to Irving Park. Bus: 53, 80

content.description: While the Michigan Avenue address suggests sky-high prices, the small, beige changing areas are no-nonsense and not especially ritzy, highlighting that service is top priority. Unfortunately, we've experienced a few snafus with the spa's black hole of an appointment database. However, once you get into your treatment room, the results are impressive: Try the transformative Classic Facial ($90), which was truly transformative—our face went from blotchy and flakey to smooth and glowy. Plus, if your aesthetician isn't too busy, she might throw in gratis brow shaping. The salon is equipped with plenty of hair trimming and color stations, while manicure and pedicure chairs are tucked in a separate area.

content.description: Honey Child has a primo reputation for sweetening your experience by taking its full-service spa services up a pampering notch or two. The menu includes traditional nail, massage and facial services—all sure to please. Daredevils can roll the die with one of several exotic waxes, including honeymooner favorite “Hidden Treasures.” It's a full pubic wax artfully adorned with rhinestones or crystals in the shape of your choosing. How do the crystals stick? Trade secret—you'll have to ask.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Chicago. Bus: 22, 29, 36, 66

content.description: The studio gets its name from its sunny loft space in the heart of Rogers Park and its emphasis on personalized care. Bodywork like therapeutic massage forms the basis of services, with a particular focus on catering to the needs of dancers, actors, athletes and musicians—those whose livelihoods depend on achieving and maintaining peak performance. The occasional nutrition-based workshop is offered, as are family-centric music and arts soirees.

content.description: The iconic clock at State and Washington, the Frango mints­—yes, we know they’re not made here anymoreand the magnificent Tiffany dome you can see up close from the 5th floor are just a few of the attractions that make this department store, one of the largest in the world, a must-see. The shopping here is divine, offering everything from modestly priced pots and pans to the latest in high-end fashion.Holiday-themed window displays go up every November, and you can take self-guided audio tours of the store year round.

entry.name: The Spa at the Carlton Club

version.name: The Spa at the Carlton Club

content.description: Elegance and sophistication abound at this spa, which is housed inside the Ritz-Carlton. It (annoyingly) decided that you can't get a treatment here unless you are a guest at the hotel, but the services on offer are so good, they're worth the night at the (not-too-shabby) Ritz. Try the Punta Mita massage (85 minutes for $185), which uses tequila and sage to cleanse and detoxify the body, leaving you tipsy with health. While the treatments are expensive, the added perks at every turn make you feel like you're getting your money's worth. Everyone who uses the spa gets to spend the rest of the day in the gorgeous pool, Jacuzzi, steam room and sauna. If you're motivated, you could also use the fitness center. You'll also be treated to complimentary coffee, tea and juice.

Connected to the populist Excalibur in a castlelike former church—but marketed separately—the expansive Vision has multiple rooms of varying size (the dome, sky and the penthouse) where DJs pump out different styles, from trance to techno to hip-hop. There’s a house event Fridays except the first of the month. Celeb-connected promotions alternate with visits from big-name electronic stars

Guilt trip warning: In order to get to your massage here, you must first walk through the Holmes Place Health Club (and all the people working out in it), an experience that can easily make you feel like a slacker. Luckily, all anxieties evaporate once you enter this friendly spa, where massages are considered both therapy and relaxation. Atheletes with sore muscles will appreciate the knowledge of masseurs, who may take a whole hour to work on your calves (with your permission, of course). And for those who aren't sore at all, the massages will rid you of all anxieties, and nothing—not even the sight of thirty people working out harder than you—will bother you for the rest of the day.

Intimacy and coziness reign at Purity, where owner Michelle Woodard has converted two two-bedroom apartments into one giant living room. The space is obviously designed as an apartment rather than a spa, but facial, massage, nail, changing and relaxation rooms are all outfitted with soothing music, soft sheets, plush robes and homey touches like a snack basket. The menu is thorough and the prices are reasonable, but the spa parties are easily the best deal: For $75 a head, each guest enjoys a 45-minute pedicure and the choice between a 30-minute massage or a 30-minute facial.

Expect a full-sensory retreat from stress during your visit. All massages and face or body treatments begin the same way: After changing into a cushy robe and slippers, you’re directed to the relaxation area, a dimly lit room with scented candles that get you in the mood for an herbal foot soak as you sip tea. Seven treatment rooms are on standby for luxurious services that range in style from East to West. Top that off with a tall glass of one of six elixir tonics.

Chicago nightlife impresario Billy Dec unveiled this bomb shelter–themed spot to no shortage of hype in 2007. For the most part, it lives up to expectations. With populist hip-hop and house remixes from DJ White Shadow, the sleek, dark, militaristic space comes alive. Celebrity command performances might not always be A-list, but the service here impresses.

content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Sedgwick. Bus: 72, 156
El: Red to Lake; Orange, Pink, Green, Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Randolph. Bus: 3, 4, 6, 10, 14, 26, 143, 144, 145, 146, 147, 151, 157. Metra: Elec Main to Millennium Station

entry.name: Spa at the Four Seasons Hotel

version.name: Spa at the Four Seasons Hotel

content.description: The services are divine here: We melted into a puddle of relaxation after the hour-long massage ($150). But it's the environment that feels extra luxurious. The changing areas have fancy amenities like plush robes, a eucalyptus steam room and oodles of beauty products for postservice primping. Plus, you can upgrade your experience for an extra $30, which allows you to crash the pool and lounge center. (The fee includes access to the fitness center, if you're feeling ambitious.) Swim some laps, laze around on the lounge chairs, or sample the full spread of coffees, teas, and fruit and cookies. It's as close as you'll come to feeling like a trust fund kid.

content.public-transport: El: Red, Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Chicago. Bus: 11, 22, 36, 66, 145, 147, 173
Bus: 55, 59, 170. Metra: Elec Main to 59th St

content.description: While nudity-shy spagoers will appreciate the ankle-length kimono provided by Japanese Spa Zen, anyone with a knotted back or an empty wallet will love the moderately priced relief provided by the Amma Massage ($65 for 60 minutes). The traditional Asian style of massage uses kneading, pressing and pulling (rather than surface strokes) to remove energy blockages. Naoko Luppescu, who co-owns the spa with her husband, Stuart, learned the technique in her native Japan. She begins the treatment at the feet and ends at the base of the skull, skimming the body with a soothing combination of firm pressing and gentle squeezing. The environs aren't cushy and we recommend skipping the nail services (our pedi was done in lukewarm water and the aesthetician couldn't be bothered with smudges), but for a massage, it's worth a try.

There are many reasons to live in Evanston, but unless youre in a Northwestern fraternity, nightlife likely isnt among them. The Cellar, with its slightly staid aesthetic, isnt going to change that, but it does fill a niche: It serves good food (such as salumi sandwiches and sake-steamed mussels, which come from the adjacent Stained Glass kitchen) at a reasonable price after 9pm.
content.public-transport: El: Purple to Davis. Metra: Union Pacific N to Evanston (Davis St). Bus: 93, 201, 205
content.property: Conversation friendly Food served No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom

content.description: The menu at this Oak Park newbie is the opposite of ambitiousits full of clichs like mango shrimp, fried artichokes and goat cheesemarinara dips. But chef Jody Andre seems to know what kind of food people want. Not what they may think they want, but what they crave deep down when the trend police have their heads turned. Those fried artichokes turn out to have an ethereal quality, mussels arrive in an addictive, garlicky sauce, and crab cakes sport a crisp exterior and a warm, creamy middle. Its not all perfect, of course. But if you end with the impeccable goat cheese cheesecake, any mishaps will be quickly forgotten.
content.public-transport: El: Blue to Austin. Pace bus: 311, 315, 320

content.description: Everything about this place seems like a good idea: The riverside location (admittedly more attractive in the summer than the winter), the five choices of burgers (salmon, tuna, turkey, beef or veggie), the long list of toppings for those burgers (guacamole, cheddar-bacon sauce), even the drinks program, which boasts some decent beers and artisanal sodas. Where the place falters is in some of its execution. While the turkey burger is moist and the onion rings perfect, the beef can be gristly and tough and the veggie burger mushy. Whether the milk shakes and malts can help you forget these missteps depends on if you like Wendys Frostyif you do, youll leave happy.

If Colombian restaurants are only as good as the music they play (and if you ask the owner of one, thats what he or she will tell you), this corner spot has a chance at greatness: Expert guitar stylings come from either the flat-screen in the front dining room or, on Fridays and Saturdays, from a live band in the back. Empanadas filled with tender steak make a good nosh for watching the band (especially if you put some chimichurri on them), and so does the sobrebarriga a la criolla, which is more of that grilled steak flanked by sweet plantains. But the picada grande, a platter of deep-fried ribs, fried sausage, fried beef and fried yucca? Lets just say its a little discordant.

Clean yet complex sums up this Argyle spots namesake soup, which bears a hint of the sweet star-anise flavor others tend to overload on but relies mainly on subtle beefiness and silky fresh noodles. Those same noodles serve dozens of other dishes almost as well, but our two favorites dont include them. The banh mi thit nguoi nails perfectly crusty bread, salty ham, a slather of earthy pt, plus crunchy daikon, carrots and sliced chiles. And the massive lotus root salad is the best around, with plump, fresh shrimp, plenty of crunchy peanuts and enough tangy, herb-flecked dressing to spoon some onto your banh mi for extra flavor.

Since youll barely be able to see the menu in the pitch-black of theWit Hotels first-floor, all-day restaurant, let us make some recommendations. Small plates are the best betand, thanks to their uncharacteristically generous size, the best deal. Juicy, marinated tomatoes (sliced in a thin carpaccio style) delicately offset breaded-and-fried slices of mozzarella; a trio of roasted bonesnot your average hotel foodyields luscious marrow; and juicy shrimp glazed in Louisiana-style BBQ sauce deftly balance heat and sweet. Bigger plates and desserts can feel like placeholders, so those youll have to order blindly.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to State

content.description: Theres a science to getting the most out of all-you-can-eat sushi ($18.99 dinner, $15.99 lunch), especially when youre charged for uneaten pieces or rolls as you are here. Weve cracked the code. First, eat a light lunch. Then, rather than estimating how much sushi you can take down and ordering all at once, ask for a couple of rolls and pieces at a time, allowing for the rice to expand in your gut and signal youve had enough. What to order? Not surprisingly, the fish is cut pretty thinly, but even so, we liked the Rainbow roll (essentially a California roll topped with tuna, salmon, yellowtail and shrimp) and the Michigan roll, which adds tempura bits to its spicy tuna.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 36, 76, 77, 134

content.description: Shawn McClain is out of the picture at this South Loop spot, which has ditched its steakhouse identity and added Tavern to its moniker. Chef Aaron Deal comes to Chicago via Charleston, South Carolina, and hes brought with him dishes like duck rice topped with toasted hazelnuts and foie-gras mousse, crispy pigs-head terrine served with a deviled quail egg and pork cheeks accompanied by winter ramps.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Library; Red to Harrison. Bus: 6, 29, 36
content.property: Notable wine list Private party room(s) Good for dining at bar Kid-friendly

content.description: The room is big and wide-open, and yet thanks to the homey design (the mismatched chairs; the collection of plates on the wall), this diner feels more like a small, charming cafe. But dont let that fool you: The menu has all the diner staples it should have, from plate-sized omelettes to hearty Monte Cristo sandwiches to their signature: Oven-baked pancakes almost the size of the room.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Sedgwick. Bus: 72

content.description: Scott Harris (Mia Francesca, Purple Pig) and Dean Zanella (formerly of 312 Chicago) have teamed up on this restaurant, where Zanella offers dishes such as classic ribollita and house-cured baccal. An adjacent market offers hard-to-find items, such as fregola and preserved lemons.
Cans patrons, rejoice! The throwback diner has opened a fourth location, with a similar menu served 24/7.
content.property: Good for groups Kid-friendly Late-night dining

content.description: Its purposefully unclear whether the name of this California-based chain refers to the long, bright-white counter that runs along one side of the room or the tally of possible burger combinations youll start keeping the minute you look at the menu. There are about 50 choices of ingredients to dress the burgers with, and all of them work, mainly because the patties themselves are well-cooked and juicy (even the turkey burger, amazingly). When it comes to sides and drinks, decision making becomes much easier: Sweet-potato fries, onion strings and milk shakes are a no-brainer.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 22, 36, 76

content.description: You can forget about the falafel at Jerry Suqis new Middle Eastern joint. You can forget about the hummus and the baba, too, which is all merely fine. Whats special is the kibbeh, with its delicate, thin layer of bulgur encasing cinnamon-dusted ground beef and pine nuts. And the lamb pie, packed with sweet onions. And the lamb kebabs, rubbed with salt and ridiculously tender. This is food that has clearly been cared for by chef Amni Suqi (Jerrys mother). In fact, if you find the matriarch on the right night, shell pull up a chair and explain how much she cares for it herself.

A couple of Hyde Park veterans (the former owners of Istria Caf) and a sandwich maker from the suburbs (the owner of the now-defunct Shanes Deli in Wheaton) have joined forces to open a casual but high-quality grocery store and sandwich shop. The shelves are stocked with gourmet groceries, but the crowds tend to gather at the deli counter for quince paste and Spanish jamon sandwiches and panini with farmstead cheese and ham pressed between pretzel bread. Oatmeal-chocolate-chip cookies are a hot item, too; still, with only four tables, the most coveted thing in the place is a seat.

After almost a decade of making Oakley Avenue a destination for Devon diners, Hema Potla has moved her original restaurant onto the main drag. The new space is about twice as roomy, with amber-tinted chandeliers, tiny bouquets on each table and the always-smiling namesake floating around the room. The menu remains largely the same, but the new kitchen is outfitted with a tandoor that turns out additions like nan and kebabs. Old favorites remain flavorful, including fiery lentils with spinach, excellent eggplant with hunks of lamb, and tender chicken in Hariyali, a grass-green gravy of cilantro, curry leaves, peppers, yogurt, ginger and garlic.

With the sale of Lincoln Squares Tallulah (Its still open but will be reconcepted by a new owner later this month), owner Matt Fisher and chef Troy Graves are focusing their energy on their newer restaurant, Eve. The bar continues to go the extra mile on cocktails, infusing liquors, muddling herbs and coming up with clever concoctions. And this weekend, Saturday and Sunday brunch launches with indulgent dishes like a lobster Benedict, baked eggs with chorizo and the dukkah-crusted lamb burger.

If you want to call this a diner, fine. But the place is so clean and friendly that its chosen moniker of Restaurant sits just as well with us. (Also going against the diner mold: the hours, which stray from the late-night norm with a closing time of 9pm.) But the menu here looks like your typical diner lineup (that is: Everything that can possibly be served will be served). We say stick to the Greek stuff: the lemony char-grilled chicken, the crisp Greek salad and, believe it or not, a fluffy omelette stuffed with gyro meat.

content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Sedgwick. Bus: 72, 156

content.description: Join the degree-seeking undergrads and some of the city's most dedicated professionals as a “community student” in advanced morning modern dance class, or sign up for a beginning course in the dance style of your choice.
content.public-transport: El: Red, Orange, Green to Roosevelt. Bus: 1, 3, 4, 129. Metra Elec Main: Roosevelt Road Station

at Division St, Milwaukee Ave and Ashland Ave

content.public-transport: Bus: 80 to Irving Park; El: Blue to Irving Park

content.description: It’s a healing sanctuary, a spa, an elixir bar, a yoga studio, a crystal bar, a hair salon, a meditation studio, an educational laboratory, an apothecary and a makeup-to-lifestyle-products retail space all rolled into one 10,000-square-foot space. Ruby Room, located in Wicker Park and easily recognizable by its red double doors, recently reopened in the newly minted category of outside-in rejuvenating venues known as the “spa of the spirit.” Besides its size, the biggest difference between Ruby Room and most other spas is that its treatments skew more to your energetic system with such offerings as intuitive-energy healing, chakra cleansing, crystal-energy healing and astrology. Owner Kate Leydon may have created a spa dynasty, and from the briskness of business here, it looks like she has plenty of followers.

The longstanding modern dance group Chicago Moving Company runs the dance programming in this spacious second-floor studio that overlooks a swimming pool and a playing field. Mornings cater to intermediate and advanced dancers, while after-work and weekend classes offer respite from cubicle confinement.

entry.name: House of Blues Back Porch Stage

version.name: House of Blues Back Porch Stage

address.street: main entrance on Northgate Rd west of Cass Ave
main entrance on Northgate Rd west of Cass Ave

content.description: Compact but handsomely designed in modern blues and wood, rodan fulfills the fantasy of the hipster who’s moved on from squalid nights sucking PBRs in no-name dives. The menu includes reliably filling Asian and South American dishes and Japanese white ales. DJs spin wildly eclectic sets to their own tastes—anything from Afrobeat and soul to space rock and psych—and the big video screen and weekly live avant-jazz make it a multimedia mecca.

El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Sedgwick. Bus: 11, 22, 36, 72, 156

content.vendor-category: Get | Spas & gyms | Classes and workshops
content.description: Bloom's husband-and-wife team intends to use its studio to create a community in which “the pursuit of health and happiness is a normal part of daily life.” Sounds like a good plan. To fulfill that mission, the couple offers an array of classes, many of which are geared to prenatal and new moms without excluding the nonparents among us. Classes are taught in the hatha-yoga tradition with an emphasis on proper alignment. Bloom also features regular innovative and ongoing workshops and yoga-inspired social events, and they all take place in its sunny, new environs.

Everything is pink at the Garden Salon—the walls, the candles, much of the nail polish—even the toilets. Stepping out of the elevator into this second-floor spa is a bit like stepping back in time when salons were called beauty parlors and women chatted for hours under dome-shaped dryers and bad fluorescent lighting. But don’t let appearances fool you—facilities may be a bit dated and personnel may be on the older side, but massage, nail and body treatment services are top notch. Long-term employees knead, file, polish and wax with the confidence earned from years of practice.

content.public-transport: El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 9, 11, 50, 80

content.description: This Wicker Park spot, which once housed BigWig, may have changed names more than any other venue in town, but it’s become an unlikely hipster hangout in 2008 with its Monday night Rehab party. It sports two levels, a back room, booths in front and a dancefloor that gets cozy real quick, plus a late-night license.

content.vendor-category: Get | Spas & gyms | Classes and workshops
content.description: Soar to this eighth floor spa in a cloud-lined elevator and melt into 9,000 square feet of premium pampering space. This New York import features 16 treatment rooms, four movie-while-you-manicure stations with personal DVD players and a full slate of massage, nail and body treatments. Try the signature triple layer oxygen facial ($150), said to clean, calm, hydrate and illuminate. Warning: Prices are as lofty as the lake views.

content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Sedgwick. Bus: 11, 22, 36, 72, 156.

content.description: First the (very) good news. The treatments here rank with the best in the city. Aestheticians have medical training so you're in able, confident hands whether you're getting a classic facial, microderm abrasion or a chemical peel. Our aesthetician listened closely to our skin concerns, then fixed up with yummy-smelling, 100% organic Ilika products (bonus points: she didn't pressure us to purchase anything). Massage and acupuncture are also on the menu, and are often part of the medical treatment plan given by one of the center's doctors. Which leads us to the (slightly) bad news. The spa is in a medical building, so you don't exactly get the cushy, lounge-in-slippers preface to your service like you would at a traditional spa. No matter, when you walk out the door totally thrilled with your glowing complexion, you couldn't care less what that door actually looked like.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Wellington or Belmont; Red to Belmont. Bus: 8
content.property: $60 for laser hair removal, $145 for microdermabrasion facial. USD

content.description: Climb the wooden stairs to this sprawling West Loop spa and enter a serene loft space boasting high ceilings, exposed brick and a gurgling waterfall. Turn to your left and there's a nail salon; go right, past the “quiet room,” and you're on your way to the cushy changing room, where you're outfitted with a luscious robe (on sale in the front) and therapeutic sandals. Pampering options range from green tea facials to an “East Meets West” body wrap designed to make skin younger, tighter and fresher. Hydrotherapy and massage offerings are also on the menu, but the best part may be the first-floor parking lots sure to guarantee door-to-door serenity.

content.public-transport: Metra: Union Pacific W to Elmhurst.
El: Red to Bryn Mawr. Bus: 22, 92

content.description: Green is the color of choice at Salon Echo, where the emphasis is on environmentally-friendly indulgence. Eighty percent of the pastel-colored salon is made of recyclable materials and all services excluding hair coloring exclusively use botanical products. Fresh flowers, a welcoming staff and a tempting menu of nail, massage and facial services make guilt-free indulgence as easy as dropping a can in the recycling bin.
content.public-transport: El: Red to Bryn Mawr. Bus: 36, 84, 136, 147, 151

content.description: The movie Gone in 60 Seconds blaring on a big screen TV isn't exactly the most soothing thing to encounter on a Saturday morning before a spa service, but hey, this place is strictly for the guys and loud action movies seem to be part of the deal. Thankfully, once you escape Nic Cage stealing someone's car, you have nothing else to worry about here. From the tranquil changing room to the waiting area with a relaxing koi tank, the actual spa area is very soothing. Standout services include The Rubb, a 60-minute massage with your choice of deep tissue or Swedish versions ($90), and even one-on-one private yoga classes ($80 per session). While you're there, don't forget to visit the salon side for the “The Man, which includes a shampoo, cut, paraffin hand wax, hand massage and facial toner ($44).

content.public-transport: El: Orange, Green, Red to Roosevelt. Bus: 1, 3, 4, 6, 7, 10, 14, 26, 28, 126, 145, 146, 147

address.street: Birthplace 339 N Oak Park Ave and museum 200 N Oak Park Ave
Birthplace 339 N Oak Park Ave and museum 200 N Oak Park Ave

content.description: See where the international adventures of this lit-class favorite originated. The irascible master came into the world in a Victorian Queen Anne–style home in 1899. Though the author was oft quoted referring to the near west suburb as “a place of wide lawns and narrow minds,” proud local devotees celebrated the centennial of his birth by completely restoring the space to better reflect Hemingway’s formative years. Look at original furnishings and photos, then, at the museum, about two blocks away at 200 N Oak Park Ave, find out more and pick up Hemingway books, tote bags and postcards.

content.public-transport: El: Red to Bryn Mawr. Bus: 147, 151

content.description:
A traditional ‘old money’ stomping ground favored by Chicago socialites and celebrities, this stately icon exudes old-school style, with velvet seats in elevators, bowls of fresh fruit lining check-in desk and enormous chandeliers. Feels a bit like crashing a rich aunt’s downtown condo, yet some parts of hotel are a bit tired.
*High-speed internet (free wireless in public spaces for guests using internet in rooms & $6.95/hr for nonusers; $12.95-16.95 via cable in rooms).

content.public-transport: El: Red to Monroe; Orange, Green, Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Madison or Adams. Bus: 3, 4, 6, 14, 26, 143, 144, 145, 146, 147, 151, 157. Metra: Elec Main to Millennium Station

content.description: Located in the heart of the city's Ukrainian Village, this museum houses traditional clothing, musical instruments, agricultural tools and folk art from the Eastern European nation. Also on site are a library with more than 16,000 books and periodicals, and a set of archives that document the cultural happenings of Chicago's Ukrainian community.

The menu tantilizes the over-40 crowd with treatments like Botox, Restylane and Mesotherapy Cellulite and Fat Reduction (microinjections said to break up fat and increaase tissue metabolism). But even if you're not looking to de-vein your legs or plump your lips, Pure has plenty of services that will be right up your alley, such as massage, an array of facials and acupuncture. We tried their microderm abrasion treatment and felt perfectly relaxed and pampered. And the words that come to mind to describe how our skin looked afterwards—glowing, tight and fresh-faced—doesn't do justice to the rejunevated reflection we saw in the mirror. The talented, friendly staff wants you to feel utterly beautiful and completely cared for—and they deliver on both counts.
content.public-transport: El: Red to Chicago. Bus: 151, 156, 146 Walton

entry.name: Institute of Puerto Rican Arts and Culture

version.name: Institute of Puerto Rican Arts and Culture

content.public-transport: Bus: Pace 213 Northbrook Court. Metra: Union Pacific N to Glencoe

content.description: Under new management, the Rush Street perennial came back strong in 2007 with a shiny new interior and amped-up dining, but it also injected some much-needed youthful energy into the music program down. A pair of seasoned, open-minded party rockers, E6 and Matt Roan, run the decks on weekends with R&B, hip-hop and electro-house. On Sunday nights, the pair curates an industry party—read: riskier music night—that features on-the-way-up chums like San Francisco’s DJ Sol and Michigan’s Benzi in the booth. And note the sound system was refocused on the dance floor—it’s about time.

Tucked away on the second floor of a quaint West Town building, this full-service spa is instantly inviting with cool aqua-blue walls, deep chocolate brown chairs and a precocious pup named Maxwell who greets each guest with a wagging tail. The extensive menu includes quick beauty fixes like eyelash tinting ($25), lip plumping ($20) and face bronzing ($25) as well as more time (and wallet)-intensive custom massage and facial treatments. The signature 90-minute Top Shelf Facial ($120) features a customized enzyme cocktail and hand, arm, neck, shoulder and back massages.

content.public-transport: El: Red, Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Fullerton. Bus: 8, 11, 74

content.vendor-category: Get | Spas & gyms | Classes and workshops
content.description: Like Dorothy’s ruby slippers, Equilibrium, a wellness center on Printers Row dedicated to energy healing, wants to bring you back to a safe, comfy and happy emotional place. Longtime healer Bernadette Doran has created a sanctuary where she leads clients through an impressive array of traditional energy-healing techniques, such as reiki, and color therapy. And she’s brought in healers to provide unique experiences like colorpuncture (acupuncture with focused colored light instead of needles), aura-soma (color and light therapy) and holographic memory resolution (a combination of guided visualization and energy work used to heal emotional trauma). Doran also holds workshops and lectures at least once a week. Whether you’re a believer, a skeptic or just curious about this sort of stuff, Doran’s warm personality will make you feel right at home.

entry.name: Michael Anthony Salon Spa Wicker Park

version.name: Michael Anthony Salon Spa Wicker Park

content.description: The newest Michael Anthony outpost is luxuriously calm despite its strip-mall location. Downstairs from the hair salon is the tranquil spa (offering massages, facials, hand/foot care), where our bod was was treated to a Body Polish, leaving us buffed and baby-smooth, before the Hot Stone Massage got us dozing. (True, our room was somewhat frigid and the masseuse pulled our hair but we’ll chalk that up to newness.) Best of all was the shower-room, complete with jetstreams and fragrant Aveda products galore.
content.public-transport: El: Blue to Division, Red to Division. Bus: 70, 50

content.description: This museum’s interactive displays keep kids occupied with dinosaurs, a hands-on laboratory, nature exhibits and more. Other exhibits teach lessons on the water cycle, life under the sea and the great outdoors.
