content.description: Get ready for a dose of decorating delight. Inside this vintage building are unique furniture and accessories worthy of inspiring an entire room: Driftwood sculptures ($135-$1,500), silver plated pitchers and trays with horn handles ($100-$750), zebra rugs ($800) and even cocktail tables mounted on tree trunks ($750-$1200). The garden section carries fresh plants and flowers year-round, plus beautiful pots and planters.

content.public-transport: El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 11, 50, 78, 80, 152

content.description: “Inhale world, exhale peace.” This has been the school's mantra since 1972, when Korean founder Grand Master MyungSu Y.S. Kim first came up with his plan to promote world peace through meditation. The school remains active in advancing worldwide peace through large-scale initiatives, and the Lincoln Avenue location, a rambling space that has windows, remains a guiding force for an expanding community of peaceniks. Classes range from yoga to martial arts for women, peace breathing to meditation.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Red, Purple (rush hrs) to Belmont. Bus: 9, 11, 77
El: Red, Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Belmont. Bus: 8, 77
Metra: Union Pacific to College Ave, then Pace Bus 715

content.description: If the name sounds familiar, you may have seen the Honky Tonk portable smoker kicking out cue at a neighborhood fest; owner Willie Wagner has been known to show up at the Hideout Block Party and Northalsted Market Days, among others. At his shop in Pilsen, Wagner serves Memphis-style, dry-rubbed barbecue in a small country-casual dining room. The ribs are on the dry side and dont pack much juice, but the smoky pulled pork makes up for it, clocking in at one of the best around. Tender and juicy chicken comes in second for best bets, with puckery slaw and meaty beans solid runners-up.

From the name to the graffiti-inspired splashes of color to the hip-hop videos playing during our visit, this buzzing River North shop is the first of what could become a homegrown mini-empire for Yogurteur Michael Farah. This fro-yo contains healthful live and active cultures, and the texture is about as good as can be, balancing between light and creamy. But the flavor suggests there might be some added citric acid, bumping up the yogurts natural tartness to an almost tongue-tingling, lemonlike taste that would clash with any chocolate-based toppings.

Chocolate and wine may be the focus of this cheerful (if somewhat generically decorated) spot, but a proper dinner can be cobbled together with the savory small plates. Juicy slices of tenderloin on a sourdough baguette make for a hearty start, and the veggie sandwich (sporting a tall pile of sweet, balsamic-kissed slices of roasted eggplant and zucchini) is surprisingly satisfying. Of course, the goal here is to get to dessert, and for that we suggest you go as literal as possible and order the creamy PB&J trufflesolid proof that chocolate and grapes are an inspired pair.

Faced with convincing blue-collar neighbors to eat ethnic food when they opened in 61, the Cornejo family behind this joint offered up gooey enchiladas and deep-fried goodies while keeping corn tortillas and spicy chiles on hand for expats. The resulting regional Mexican and Tex-Mex hybrid experience includes crispy fried hard tacos filled with green-chile-marinated pork nuggets and the soft cheese, corn tortillas topped with an oozy bchamel. The house hot sauce, which is sold by the pint, is as thick as ketchup and packs a satisfying tang that trumps the vinegary firewater found elsewhere.

A sibling of Outback Steakhouse, Flemings has a clear agenda: They want to be an upscale, wine-focused steakhouse that doesnt feel like a chain. But despite an impressive wine list (100 wines by the glass), this place is still seriously corporate. The extra-smiley service becomes intrusive around the 20th time somebody asks you how your night is going, and the menu reads like a Best Of compilation of food from the 90s. Worst of all, the steaks are mushy, and the deep-fried mushrooms and chocolate lava cake arent much better. And thats something even the nicest service cant fix.

Opening a Vietnamese restaurant on Argyle is like tossing a coin into the U.S. Mint. Though, with most of its neighbors sporting utilitarian storefronts, Pho Xua, with its golden microsuede chairs and sleek wooden tables, is the shiniest coin in the till. The restaurant is named for the traditional beefy broth, but the best bowl in the house is the fried duck noodle filled with ribbons of delicious ramen, a juicy caramelized duck leg and a confetti of scallions. Segue into the noodles with a starter of betel leaf beef mini kebabs wrapped in wilted greens with a smoky honey flavor.
content.property: Vegetarian-friendly Good for groups BYOB Cheap (entrees under $10)

content.description: The combination of exemplary ingredients and minimalist preparation is at the heart of every dish at this simple BYOB, and this turns out to be an excellent way to cook. It allows sunchokes, dressed with lemon and parsley, to show off their crunchy earthiness, housemade charcuterie to exhibit its lingering richness, and flaky shortbreads to simply melt in your mouth with no distractions. The food is so naked that it cant hide even the smallest flaws. Luckily, those flaws are few and far between.

Outside of the Maxwell Market, many taquerias have banished fresh masa in favor of machine-made stuff from local tortillerias. Here, theres a little old lady patting and shaping balls of the cornmeal dough and griddling them until they puff up like corn-perfumed balloons. And while the tacos and gorditas (including a rich picadillo) are good, the star of the show is the braised chicken tinga flecked with smoky bits of chipotle, served on a flat oval-shaped huarache and topped with crumbly queso fresco.

So maybe the carrots in the chicken soup here are undercooked, and maybe the broth itself is weak. Doesnt matter. People will order the soup for the good matzo balls, because a good matzo ball in Chicago is hard to find. And good sablefish? Good lox? Happily, these elusive goods are also found at Steves. No, the bagel you put the fish on isnt great. And this isnt a corned-beef place, eitherthe beef is leaner than the economy. But all of this can be forgiven. Because what would a Jewish deli be without something to kvetch about?
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Merchandise Mart. Bus: 11, 65, 125

content.description: Greek-style greasy-spoon diners don't dot Chicago neighborhoods as much as they used to, which is why we go out of our way for this classic. All the standards are in place: brown plastic water glasses, slightly-worn leather booths, bottomless cups of drip coffee, dependable pancakes and omelettes for breakfast, and a basket of rolls to eat while we decide between the French dip or the Greek chicken at dinner. In a final nod to dying traditions, kids can either get Jell-O with whipped cream for dessert or just save room for a free lollipop on the way out.
content.property: Late-night dining Good for dining at bar Outdoor seating Cheap (entrees under $10)

content.description: Diners come to this megaproject from Paul Kahan and crew for three things: to sample the massive list of brews while basking in the golden-hued, beer halllike space; to sample impeccable charcuterie and amazing oysters from chef Brian Hustons dinner menu; or to begin their Sundays with arguably the best brunch in town. We oscillate, but currently were in the latter camp, and once you taste the housemade ricotta, the fig-pistachio scone, the wood-fired eggs with harissa and the thick slabs of Publican bacon (not the strips that come with the omelette but the top-shelf stuff), you will be too.
content.public-transport: El: Green, Pink to Clinton. Bus: 8, 65
content.property: Good for dining at bar Notable wine list Outdoor seating

content.description: Thin-crust pizzas and panzerottimassive, mutant calzones available baked or friedare hustled out the door with regularity at this casual corner caf, which does a brisk takeout business. However, the rest of the menu is a bit hit-or- miss. Fussy basics like veal parmigiana are underwhelming and overpriced, but the simple rotolo primaveratricolor pasta stuffed with spinach and ricotta and smothered in mozzarellacan be surprisingly addictive. Prices are higher than youd guess given the excess of plastic ivy choking the ceiling, but the linguine al pescatore ($26.50), while still a relative splurge, delivers a tide pool of shrimp, calamari and clams. When you consider its enough for three meals, it seems like a downright bargain.

This Hyde Park newbie casts the net wide with a catchall menu of wallet-wise, student-friendly dishes: sushi, pizza, sandwiches, soup, salad, hummus. Most of it comes out of the bright, open kitchen decently preparedthe chicken pesto sandwich featured thinly sliced bird and plenty of pesto; the firm, if unremarkable, fish in the Chicago Fire roll was spiced up with cilantro, chili oil and jalapeo. Even the overly gummy pasta fagiole at least packed a lot of flavor. But when youre offering something for everyone, theres bound to be some bombs, and the caprese salad was a miss: wan, watery tomatoes and scoops of dried basil drowning in balsamic vinegar. Thatll teach us to order caprese in winter.

A fast-food joint that claims its dedicated to freshness is one thing. A fast-food joint that proves it is another. Nesh bakes its own pita, and the soft, warm bread heightens everything put into it: smoky baba ghanoush, fried-to-order falafeleven the somewhat dry chicken shawarma benefits. Another housebaked bread the kitchen calls shrock (a flatbread used for wraps) is slightly less delicious than the pita. But for such fresh food at such cheap prices, its hard to complain.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 8, 11, 74

content.description: With a new out-of-town hamburger chain popping up in Chicago seemingly every week, it's worth saluting this homegrown Lakeview stand. Its been serving rock-solid char-grilled burgers and dogs, along with fresh-cut fries and thick chocolate shakes, to everyone from city workers to stroller moms for two decades. When we're in the mood for a burger that's not so huge it will kill us, this is where we go (but don't forget the gooey Wisconsin cheddar). And when we're not in that mood we get the Rooster (grilled chicken sandwich), which is about as good an argument for white meat as any we know.

A torrential downpour couldnt take the sunniness out of this Pilsen caf, which is painted in bright colors inside and out. What does it have to be so cheery about? Well, first of all, its one of the citys most successful purveyors of corn and flour tortillas. And, as they show at this caf, employees clearly know how to put those tortillas to good use: piling them with tender chicken legs submerged in mole rojo, or sumptuous, slow-cooked beef in a rich tomato sauce. Satisfying tamales are available for a more portable mealbut keep in mind that you cant take the sunniness with you.

Not feeling Subterraneans music for the night? Cant take the hipper-than-thou crowd at Rainbo? Prefer a place less clubbier than Debonair? Well, then head to this low-key sanctuary in the Milwaukee-North-Damen intersection. No ones trying to out-cool anyone here (though late at night, theyre definitely trying to pick each other up), so feel free to strike up a conversation with a stranger over some tasty late-night bar eats, served till 3am.
content.property: Wheelchair-accessible bathroom No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Conversation friendly Late Night Food served

content.description: Dont be misled by the location: Finkels has nothing to do with Kendall College (even though its on the first floor of the cooking schools building). And dont be fooled by the name, eitherthis Finkels has nothing to do with the legendary Finkls that used to be in the Loop. Nevertheless, its doing its best to hold up the classic deli traditions. The food is hit and miss: The pastrami is warm and nicely fatty, but the egg salad needs salt. On the other hand, the authentic, sweet-and-salty deli service is something its gotten just right.

Though old George has been bellying up to the big bar in the sky for decades, his small tavern survives untouched, save the digital juke. Within this true dives smoke-stained, wood-paneled walls, the beers mostly canned, and on-tap suds are limited to Bud and Bud Light. Not exactly what we would call selection, but the construction crews seem to like it just fine.

This loud, sports-crazed triangular pub fills up fast, mainly because it plays host to boisterous beer-swilling alums, with alliances leaning toward University of Arkansas, UNC, Penn State, Syracuse and University of Kentucky. On Thursdays, its asses-to-elbows when 10-cent wings and $7 pitchers of Bud Light draw even nonsports fans out of the woodwork.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Armitage. Bus: 11, 22, 36, 73
content.property: Sports bar Late Night Food served

content.description: This new Logan caf got a lot of preopening hype because its chef cooked at Ambria, but that should be banished from memory, if for nothing else but to keep potential diners from making comparisons. There are none. But for what Bella isa little neighborhood spot with simple sandwiches and a couple of slightly more ambitious optionsit succeeds. The incredibly affordable menu is as eclectic as the art collection, ranging from hummus (fine) to fruit-spiked guac (tasty) to hand-formed burgers (surprisingly well-seasoned and well-executed at a juicy medium-rare). One hope is that the owner ditches the weekday counter-service/weekend table-service switcheroo; its not only confusing for diners, it sucks for servers wallets.
content.public-transport: El: Blue to Logan Square. Bus: 56, 74, 82

content.description: Spending your night comparing the pan-Asian eats at this new hot-stuff megarestaurant from the Rockit Ranch crew to your favorite dumplings in Chinatown will leave you feeling salty and ripped off. So dont. Instead, go with an open mind, enjoy the people-watching, and opt for the creative signatures of the house: crispy rice nigiri topped with spicy tuna, strip steak formed into lollipops around lemongrass skewers, and a salad of salty, crispy-skinned duck meat. Stop by for the recently launched Sunda Social, an after-work cocktail hour (MonFri 57pm) where flights of sake are paired with sushi, and appetizers (like the shrimp toasts with spicy tuna jam) are half-price.
content.public-transport: El: Red to Grand; Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Merchandise Mart. Bus: 22, 65, 156
content.property: Late-night dining Private party room(s) Fireplace Outdoor seating Good for dining at bar

content.description: Not to be confused with ESPN Zone, this cozy South Side spot banks on real sports fans and loyal locals rather than tourists and buffalo wings. You can still catch just about any major pro or college game on one of the tubes, and if you get bored with the game, you can roam the room, checking out the vintage photos and clippings of sports legends from an era that predates bling teeth.

In almost every way imaginablethe laminated picture menus, for instancePintxos feels not so much like an authentic Basque restaurant as it does a restaurant in Basque country geared toward tourists. The one exception to this? The prices. Individual pintxos (the Basque version of small plates, usually made up of roasted meats on skewers) never surpass the two-dollar mark; puffy, open-faced Spanish tortillas (egg-and-potato cakes) overflow with generous handfuls of fillings for $8; so do big plates of garlic-roasted drumsticks. But much of this food lacks flavor, so ultimately it doesnt matter how much the food costs; if its bland, its still a waste of money.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Chicago. Bus: 22, 66, 156

content.description: This bar sits high above Michigan Ave, just north of the fountain and atrium in the 12th-floor lobby of the Ritz-Carlton Hotel. And as could be expected from a bar inside one of the citys most luxurious hotels, this place is old-school swanksville. Chairs upholstered in soft leather, ribbed corduroy and plush velvet surround ornate tables in a copper-tinted room that, after a couple martinis, youll never want to leave.
content.property: Food served Live bands Notable for cocktails

content.description: Reflections is no more, and its Lakeview storefront space has undergone a minor face-lift. Fish tanks and romance novels have been replaced with exposed brick, new ceilings and a fresh paint job, though the loyal clientele stuck around just the same. The bar has also added two more flat-screen TVs, but itll show The Simpsons or PBS over sports any day of the week.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 22, 36, 77
content.property: No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom After-work crowd Conversation friendly

content.description: John Manion, who recently joined Branch 27 after a yearlong stint at Goose Island Brewpub, has taken what used to be a broad and inconsistent menu and chucked it for something thats much more specific, personal and interesting. Yes, theres still a burger, but its merely a good-enough burger. Because while there are plenty of places in this city to get a truly great burger, there are far fewer serving rad renditions of cassoulet, deep-fried chicken livers and braised rabbit legs countered with spright pickled carrots. And fewer still where an aggressively acidic grilled-radicchio salad gets topped off with a truly wild amount of dill. This is pretense-free food that the Mado set can appreciate. But while the target audience may have narrowed, one thing hasnt significantly changed: The space is as nice as always. Although something about it feels even nicer, now that its got the food it deserves.

Despite the name, the after-work crowd that loosens their ties and slides up to the bar here sport very little bling. Instead, its the slew of eccentric characters this place (attached to Adas Deli) attractsboth bartenders and barflies alikethat makes this place a diamond in the rough.
content.public-transport: El: Blue, Red to Monroe; Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Madison
content.property: No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Sports bar Food served Outdoor seating Piano bar Private party room(s)

content.description: Stumble into this Edgewater dive most nights and the drinkers bellied up to the bar look as if theyve been sucking suds since the place opened at 7am. This is your typical shot-and-beer bar, but if simply chugging bores you, theres a pool table, some TVs and a jukebox featuring choices from Hank Williams to the Clash. Oh, and now that a regular sold the bar owner a piano he garbage-picked from a nearby church, you also can tickle the ivories.

This long wooden bar is helmed by a few middle-aged women who, on Sundays, mix huge batches of kamikazes and sell them for $2 a popbut the real draw here is karaoke. If you get there and the doors locked, dont get discouraged. Just ring the bell over and over again (sometimes the bartenders cant hear it over yet another version of Dont Stop Believin).

When we asked our waitress at this dimly lit basement bar if there were any specialty beers on tap, she looked awfully confused. Despite its wide selection, thats a question that doesnt get asked a lot. Instead, regulars (a youngish, button-down crowd) suck down $3 Coors bottles, listen to the classic-rock-fueled jukebox and play table tennis, pool and foosball. Stop by during the week when frat boys are nowhere to be found
content.property: Pool table Video/pinball games No stairs to bathroom Sports bar

content.description: At first glance, theres much to like about this Lakeview newcomer: an understated decor straight out of the Ralph Lauren catalog, loftlike high ceilings and spacious booths that can fit you and seven of your mates. But if the dance floor in the back beckons, beware of that guythe one whos going to drop his pants and blind you with his sparkling white ass.
content.property: Karaoke No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Wheelchair-accessible bathroom Sports bar Food served

content.description: Adult foodies may have buzzed about avant-garde baked goods in the previous months, but as the cupcake craze simmers, pastry chefs Phoebe Walters and Kate McNamara keep things simple (if rather uninspired) at their cupcake-only bakeshop. A handful of flavorsfrom kid-friendly Funfetti to adult-oriented salted caramel to classic red velvetrotate weekly, and tables and free Wi-Fi invite you to stay and taste at least a few. The muted flavors may not appease highbrow aficionados, but sometimes, a cupcake is just a cupcake.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Red, Purple (rush hrs) to Belmont. Bus: 36, 77, 151

content.description: Lisa Lee and Jose Palomino took over this restaurant from Lees aunt, who operated Taqueria y Restaurant el Gusto in the same space. Now the place looks like a proper neuvo-Mexicano jointbut for the most part, the food remains in that common, corner-taqueria category. Thats not a bad thing: The queso fundido sprinkled with chorizo is decadent and satisfying, and the snapper Veracruzana-style is a well-executed, piquant dish. Anybody coming here for something completely different from what it used to be, however, should consider themselves warned that the upgrade was mostly aesthetic.

You know youre in a neighborhood favorite when a cop stopping in for his usual knows the name of the stroller-pushing mom whos come to pick up her sisters birthday cake. The couple running this sparse but cheerful daytime-only spot take it all in stridethey may have only opened in 2004 but their Beverly roots go back plenty. That would explain the careful local sourcing: Sage-rich breakfast sausage, thick applewood-smoked bacon and Fratelli coffee are all produced in the Chicago area. Fill up on a solid breakfast (have it on the simple little back patio if the weathers nice) and take the cops cue for a doughnut for the road.
content.property: Vegetarian-friendly Outdoor seating Kid-friendly Cheap (entrees under $10)

address.street: 159 E Monroe, Art Institute of Chicago
159 E Monroe, Art Institute of Chicago

content.description: Like the rest of the Renzo Pianodesigned Modern Wing, the restaurant at the Art Institute is a beautiful space: sleek, pristine and awash with light. The highlights of the menu, which is overseen by Spiaggias Tony Mantuano, exhibit similar simplicity and elegance. Eschew lackluster mains in favor of flatbreads (topped with creamy burrata cheese and seasonal ingredients like scapes) and heaping salads (like pea shoots and crisped prosciutto), then end with a rich, indulgent chocolate-hazelnut semifreddo. We said the place was aesthetically pleasing, not ascetic.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Madison
content.property: Outdoor seating Vegetarian-friendly Notable wine list

content.description: After opening Paulas and Monicas Pizzeria in West Town, owners John Fornari and George Dragne (of Schaumburg-based Johnny Ds) are serving pizza as well as entres like fettucine Alfredo and veal marsala in their new outpost a stones throw from the heart of Little Italy.

Some outposts of Ranallis serve breakfast. Some serve Mexican food. But this location, a sunny room on a side street in Andersonville, sticks to what all Ranallis ostensibly do best: thin, pan, double-crust and deep-dish pizzas. Actually, its the thin crust that keeps its rep intact, and when topped with, say, mushrooms and Italian sausage, the square-cut pies do an apt job at quelling cravings for cheesy carbs. But take note: On Mondays, when a large thin crust is just $10, the pizza tastes much, much better.

After losing 60 pounds on a high-protein diet, owner Matt Matros decided to spread the healthy-lifestyle love to Loop workers with this acai-and-agave-nectar haven serving fruit-blended protein shakes and bowls of steel-cut oats (also, of course, mixed with protein powder in a variety of flavors). The peculiar mouthfeel of protein powder disappears much more smoothly into a hot bowl of McCanns oatmealespecially the Pancake in a Bowl version, hit with maple syrup and cinnamonthan into a shake, especially when you try and fail to customize your own.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Quincy/Wells

content.description: Former Blue Water Grill pastry chef Nathaniel Meads is behind this Lakeview pastry shop, and so far, hes managed to convince hungry wanderers that there is indeed a reason to navigate the odd side entrance and look beyond the shops dreary tinted windows. Incredibly friendly counter help makes up for the rather dark atmosphere, and solid coffee cakes, streusel-topped fruit tarts and chocolate macarons make nice latte companions. Stop by in the afternoon for a selection of light, simple savory fare that changes every few days or so. Recently offerings include a chilled fennel soup and a salad of Bibb lettuce and hard-cooked eggs in a cider vinaigrette, with sandwiches still to come.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 9, 11, 76

content.description: Small-batch artisan cheeses are cut to order at this friendly, well-stocked wine-and-cheese shop. The place is attitude-free, and if youre new to the game, wine director Jan Henrichsen will help you pair your Neufchtel with your sauvignon blanc. Recent additions to the menu, like the Nut N Chutney sandwich of spiced almond butter and cranberry chutney on cracked wheat bread, are perfect for a quick lunch in one of the handful of seats on the outdoor patio, or grab a Spanish cheese plate (with Mahn, rosemary Manchego and pata cabra) to go and make it a picnic.

The most consistently successful dishes at this modern, understated restaurant from the Lula Cafe crew exhibit one of two traits: first, that fresh-from-the-garden liveliness thats garnered Lula its cultish status. (See, e.g., a stone soup filled with bright lima beans or a squash salad accented with crunchy purslane.) Second, a distinctive wood-grilled flavor that gives an intoxicating aroma to a juicy half-chicken and earthy cheeseburger. The sweet side of the menu hits all the right notes, and Sunday brunchfeaturing fried-chicken-and-waffles and ricotta griddlecakesjust might give it the cultish status accorded its Logan Square sibling.
content.property: Vegetarian-friendly Outdoor seating Private party room(s) Good for groups

content.description: Add this dimly lit date-spot to the citys quirky cadre of Thai/sushi joints, but be forewarned: The wide selection of raw fish is uniformly mushy, a problem that pervades everything from a salad of tuna sashimi and avocado to cucumber-wrapped rolls of salmon and shiitakes. However unadventurous, Thai mainstays like anise-perfumed ground chicken stir-fried with basil or a bowl of green curry brimming with Japanese eggplant are better bets. Or make like fellow patrons and get so crunked on (BYO) Jack Daniels and cases of Sapporo that you wont care what youre eating.

If imitation is the highest form of flattery, Hot Dougs Doug Sohn must be blushing. The friendly recent grads running the show at this hot-dog shop in the heart of Lincoln Park serve picture-perfect Chicago-style dogs and hand-dipped corn dogs along with a rotating menu of franks with cheeky names like the Blago (Opening bid: $1,000) and the Snoop Dogg. Specialty sausages are hit-or-miss (the rib-eye steak dog was nearly swallowed inside a dry-and-bready French roll), and curly wisps of potatoes are not quite crispy enough to be chips nor substantial enough to be fries. Still, if its timenot duck fatyou value, consider this a viable wait-free alternative to Dougs.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Fullerton. Bus: 8, 11, 74

content.description: Theres nothing that weird about a soup-only restaurant. (The Soup Box, anyone?) But its hard to describe this 16-seat caf as anything butodd. Theres no tap water (a request was met with rumblings from first-time owner Dino Agudo about health-department restrictions), theres no for-here bowls, theres nothing here really besides a rotating selection of nine vats of soup. Crab-corn and beef-barley were well-balanced, brought subtle heat and felt hearty without being overly rich (even if both were a little stingy on the proteins). For upwards of $7 for a 12-ounce takeaway container, though, the soup here doesnt leave you full so much as it does depleted.

Fortunately, this new Loop lunch spot takes its Middle Eastern options more seriously than its name. Choose between the namesake chickpea fritters, grilled lamb, chicken or beef shawarma, then have your filling rolled into pita, tossed with mixed greens or plated on rice or creamy hummus. Kefta and falafel can be a bit tough from resting under the heat lamps, but the generous use of parsley lends them an herbaceous flavor. Besides, top them with the sprightly baba ghanoush and place them in a whole-wheat grilled pita and the proteins flaws will be unnoticeable. So is this the falafel of our dreams? Not exactly. But it just may become the falafel of our lunch.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Quincy/Wells
content.property: Vegetarian-friendly Cheap (entrees under $10) Good for groups

content.description: The name implies otherwise, but there are a couple of tables for dining in at this Brazilian pizzeria, where the menu includes whole pies and slices, and grilled chicken served with sides of porky black beans, rice and pita. You read that right: Brazilian pizza. It has a soft, doughy crust and comes in 50 combinations of ingredients such as codfish, pulled chicken and ranch dressing. Sounds like too much fusion? Then start with a coxinhaa shredded chickenstuffed potato cakein one hand and a Guarana soda in the other. Youll soon be convinced this place has Brazilian cred.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 8, 11, 76

content.description: Chef Todd Stein has a lot of good ideas for theWits high-end dining spot, some of which result in really great dishes. His rich roasted chicken livers, for instance, are paired with polenta and mushrooms to a deliciously earthy effect. But hes often heavy handed with ingredients, overshadowing what could be complex flavor combinations (chicken with pancetta) with one big, clunky taste (a big slathering of honey). Luckily hes a master of pasta, and his corzetti topped with sweet corn and thick bucatini with bacon is enough to make this place a destination. For at least one course, anyway.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to State/Lake; Red to Lake

content.description: With the opening of this, the first city location of the yogurt chain, fro-yo fiends no longer have to trek to Evanston to get a fix. And its just in time: The chain recently unveiled its new flavor, Tangomonium, which smacks of orange, mango, lime, banana and, well, mystery: Its a secret recipe that even the chains employees arent privy to. But is it any good? Its mellower and more accessible than the sometimes-overpowering pomegranate and green-tea flavors, but for our money, its just not as creamy as the refreshingly sweet and tangy original.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 8, 22, 76

content.description: The second city location of the Virginia-based chain hawks the same namesake burgers (aggressively advertised as never-frozen and freshly ground) and fries (made from Idaho potatoes cooked in trans-fat free oil) from beneath the Loyola Red Line stop.

With only one other location (in Jackson Hole, Wyoming), this bakery/caf can just barely be considered part of a corporate chain. And yet this food tastes as if it has been focus-grouped (read: dumbed down) to death nonetheless. The cinnamon rolls are huge but contain hardly any cinnamon; the barbecue brisket couldnt be sweeter if it were candied; and the white sandwich bread on the Thanksgiving turkey sandwich is dense and gummy. So unless youre going to go for the fresh avocado salad, this chain is probably better off growing without you.

How good you think the food is at this Lincoln Park outpost of the Evanston institution/diner Sarkis is directly proportional to how wasted you are. Only kinda drunk? The Special Grilled Cheesea fried egg, crispy bacon, guiltily pleasurable American cheeseis a pretty good bet. Totally blazed? Thats what the grease-dripping omelettes and hash browns are for. But no matter how wasted you are, stay away from the Disaster Sausagethey call it that for a reason.
content.public-transport: El: Red, Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Fullerton. Bus: 22, 36
content.openingtimes: Breakfast and lunch daily, dinner (closed Sun)
content.property: Cheap (entrees under $10) Late-night dining BYOB Good for groups Kid-friendly Outdoor seating Vegetarian-friendly

content.description: On the heels of the success of Chickpea, Jerry Suqi has opened this charming breakfast-and-lunch-only spot. This time, however, its not his mom in the kitchen but chef (and co-owner) Jeffrey Mauro, a Charlie Trotters alum, who is putting out twisted classics such as egg sandwiches with pork cheeks and lamb crpes with Asian pear. Even breakfast tropes here (like omelettes or steak-and-eggs) exhibit a degree of care that usually gets lost in mounds of poached eggs. Jam takes a lot of risks, some of which pay off better than others, but the breakfast amuse-bouches (such as a mini raspberry muffin drizzled with honey) always get things off to the right start.

The Eat Well Drink Better group closed the Central and opened this supposedly Southern-inspired bar in its place. Its like every other Wrigleyville sports bar (good flat-screens, bad food), except newer and cleaner and generally more pleasant. Perhaps because of those things, its also less crowded. Whether thats a good thing or a bad thing is up to you.
content.property: Food served Good for groups No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Sports bar

content.description: After 22 years as Cafe Shino, this Gold Coast stalwart got a makeover and has emerged as a sake lounge, complete with two dozen varieties of rice wine, a private karaoke room, and a menu of otsumami, traditional Japanese small plates (were fans of the crispy-edged hot-dog bites, plummy baby octopus, spicy salmon hand rolls and tofu-topped udon noodles). For a primer on sake, ask manager Kerry Tamura, whos happy to steer you in the right direction.
content.property: Conversation friendly Date place Food served Notable for cocktails Karaoke

content.description: Think Wicker Park aint what it used to be? Yeah, no kidding. Take this bar: Its clean and not the least bit edgy, and everyone is just soniceand friendlyand chatty. And the foodmost of it fried and goofily organized around saucesisnt bad at all. So, yes, you might as well be on Weed Street. But tell us why thats a bad thing again?
content.property: Food served Good for groups No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Sports bar

content.description: Nothings sure to sober up the postFunky Buddha Lounge crowd quite like the ugly lighting and uglier food coming out of the kitchen at this fifth (and first late-night) location of the local chain. Just imagine gnawing on a thin, dry chicken breastor inhaling the rosemary aroma emitted by a plate of infused French toast till the point of chokingor taking a bite of the cloying, slimy frushi (fruit sushi)your buzz worn off yet?
content.property: Late-night dining Vegetarian-friendly Good for groups Cheap (entrees under $10) BYOB

content.description: Dont waste time mulling over the scant appetizer and dessert offerings hereyoure going to need all the extra minutes (and brain powerand stomach space) to make one big decision: Neapolitan-style brick ovenfired pizza thats charred on the bottom and crackly at the edges, or a standout calzone, even more beautifully charred than the pizza, filled with creamy ricotta? Of course, smart eaters know the answer to this conundrum already: Rally the troops and order both.
content.public-transport: El: Red, Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Chicago. Bus: 22, 66, 156

content.description: Dont discount that falafel sitting under the heat lampstuffed into a pita and topped with some tahini, it is, surprisingly, the best thing this stark takeout shop has to offer. Of course, thats unfortunately not saying very much. The baba is oddly chunky, the shawarma is dry, and the kebabs are tough (perhaps having spent some time under heat lamps as well). Still, with the closest restaurants around here being a McDonalds and a Go Roma, without that falafel sandwich youd be doing much worse.

Celebrities grab plenty of press for Chef Randal Jacobss rustic-chic space but dont hold that against him. The food is still the main attraction. Fried dough, dipped into a thick pesto, is addictive as are the truffle ruffles. And his smoked chicken with a corn fritter and pea tendrils feels like spring. And yet his best dish is a spinach salad with molten egg and chicharrones. Thats right: a salad. It takes a pretty special chef to make salad so appealing, and Jacobs is just that kind of guy. Think about it: If he can convince you that salad can be decadent, what cant he do?
content.public-transport: El: Red, Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Chicago. Bus: 22, 36, 156

content.vendor-category: Cocktail bars Swank spots Pick-up joints
Cocktail bars Swank spots Pick-up joints
Cocktail bars Swank spots Pick-up joints
Cocktail bars Swank spots Pick-up joints
Cocktail bars Swank spots Pick-up joints
content.description: There are a handful of hoops to jump through to get into this subterranean, suana-like bar. (Start by e-mailing rsvp@doubleachicago.com for a reservation.) But once youre settled into a cushy black-leather boothwatching bartenders alternate between vigorously shaking cocktails (spicy, strong concoctions designed by NYCs Tippling Bros) and passing off oversize bottles of Belvedereyoull find getting yourself out of this lounge a lot harder than it was to get in.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Merchandise Mart; Red to Grand; Blue, Green, Pink, Orange to Clark/Lake. Bus: 11, 22, 156
content.property: Good for groups Notable for cocktails

content.description: The Bad Apple advertises that it proudly serves burgers made with beef from Pat La Frieda, a wholesale butcher whos been operating out of Manhattan for nearly a century. Thats supposed to be a mark of excellence for the burgers, but without the bells and whistles of the various toppings, the burgers actually arent all that impressive. Likewise, a beer-can chicken sandwich, a chickpea salad and a starter of house-cured salmon are serviceable but not memorable. (The skin-on fries, crisped to a deep brown and liberally salted, were the sole standout.) Couple this with a far from cozy room, and its tough figuring out why the place is packed.
content.property: Cheap (entrees under $10) Good for dining at bar Late-night dining Fireplace

content.description: Wrigleyvilles mecca for Alabama pride has reopened a half-block south, but dont bother jotting down the address. Just look for the wobbly, wasted frat boys keeled over outside, or gape through the windows at the five-deep bar crowd gripping 40s and hollering as if its the last school party before graduation.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 8, 22, 77
content.property: Food served Good for groups New No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Sports bar
Food served Good for groups No steps at entrance No stairs to bathroom Sports bar

content.description: This Lakeview location of the Texas-based franchise is basically Baskin-Robbins: Italian Edition, but aside from the color palettefaded pastels and the incumbent sterilitythats not necessarily a bad thing. Yes, the gelato lacks the thick consistency of the authentic stuff, but its creamy, melty and comes in some deeply delicious flavors (pistachio and sea-salt caramel are both worth trying). The frequently rotating selection means more adventurous flavors like black-pepper olive oil make an appearance just often enough to keep things from going full-on 31 Flavors.
content.public-transport: El: Red, Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Belmont. Bus: 36, 77, 151, 156

content.description: When yet another cupcake shop opens, the correct approach is not to complain: Its to compare. This new Loop shop is a tiny sliver of a storefront, similar to the Gold Coasts More. And the frosting shots on the counter cant help but bring to mind that other downtown cupcakery, Sugar Bliss. But the mom-and-daughter owners and the familiar flavorsairy vanilla cake with sugary frosting; moist, deeply-red red velvet; old-fashioned, not-too-chocolately chocolateremind us most of Mollys, with a touch of Mores sophistication.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Washington/Wells

content.description: For anyone oblivious to the charms of Mongolian barbecueor afraid of ending up with a bowl of oddly flavored mushhere are some suggestions for a fail-safe FTG experience: (1) Brown rice, not white. (2) Forget the meatsthe tempeh, Quorn (mushroom meat), tofu, seitan and egg are all much tastier. (3) Sauce with one ladle of yellow curry, one ladle of vindaloo, a half ladle of chile paste, a half ladle of sesame soy and a spoonful of fresh jalapeo. (4) Just before handing over your masterpiece to be cooked, add a heaping spoonful of chopped peanuts and a stick signaling for roti bread. Then all thats left to do is to head back to your seat and start sucking down that tasty mojito.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Green, Pink, Orange, Purple (rush hrs) to Madison/Wabash; Red, Blue to Monroe

content.description: Roti sandwiches seem like the thing to get at a place called Roti. But trust us and ignore them. The grilled meat (chicken or steak) is perfectly fine, and with all the sauces you can put on it (cucumber-yogurt; red-pepper-aioli), you can definitely make it taste good. But the specialty here is the falafel. It is perhaps the least-authentic falafel in the cityits got a fluffy, eggy, fritterlike consistencybut it is also one of the most ethereal.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Quincy/Wells

content.description: Like french fries, probiotic frozen yogurt is one food group on which everyone is a self-proclaimed expert. So while we could tell you the tart stuff at Yogen Frz, an international chain that has opened its third Chicago location in the South Loop, is a bit icy, and the chocolate flavor is unevenly churned, and the smoothies are kind of watery, wed honestly prefer to let the Red Mango and Berry Chill aficionados duke it out among themselves.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Library; Red, Blue to Jackson

content.description: Reinvention is usually a restaurants last gasp, but in Green Dolphins case the conversion from white tablecloth to pizza joint has probably saved it. Pizza never gets old, especially the white pizza topped with thin slices of potato, which is crisp and made aromatic with healthy doses of rosemary. The red-sauce pies arent bad either, but the main difference between the two campsthat is, the mild tomato saucemakes the whole thing a little soggy. As it turns out, sticking with the white food and avoiding the red is a good way to navigate the rest of the menu, too: The housemade gnochhetti in lamb rag is rubbery and boring, but the all-white plate of tilapia topped with artichokes has flavors that are simultaneously bright and salty and creamy and rich.

Fusion gets a bad rap, and Havana, which carried over the happening bar scene from its former tenant, Mambo Grill, isnt doing much for the cause. The problem isnt so much the fusion of ingredients as the ingredients themselves: a dry block of lechon in the torta cubano; fishy shrimp in the seafood curry; icy tequila sorbet. Stick with a traditional dish, such as the tender sirloin steak (lomo salteado), and a mojito: The cocktails are the only things in the place that are muddled in a good way.
content.public-transport: El: Red to Grand; Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Merchandise Mart

content.description: Few pastry chefs with the fine-dining pedigrees of husband-and-wife Jennifer and Eric Estrella would be caught turning out homestyle cookies, cupcakes and pies. But who else could execute the classics so perfectly? In a storefront thats both kid-friendly and appropriate for adult-age lingerers, those pies are actually stunning galettes made with butter-rich pastry, that cookie is crisp on the outside and soft on the inside, and the chocolate-chip scone, with a welcome backnote of orange, goes perfectly with a cup of Metropolis coffee.

Its been Middle Eastern joint after Middle Eastern joint in this space, and at the rate theyve all closed, youd think restaurateurs would take the hint and try something else. But if ever a place has had a chance of survival, this is it. The service is friendly, the room is warm, and the food has all the simultaneously bright and savory flavors that good Middle Eastern food should have. Of particular note is the lahmacun, the sprightly fattoush salad and the tender chicken shawarmabut if you want it, hurry. In this space, these things dont last long.

address.street: Dana Hotel & Spa, 660 N State St
Dana Hotel & Spa, 660 N State St

content.description: The folks at the Dana Hotel are calling the changes they made to their restaurant, Ajasteak, a reconcepting, but downsizing is more like it. Gone are the steaks, and in their place is more sushi (tuna rolls with crme frache come off as sophisticated, believe it or not) and an Asian-influenced menu that goes beyond Japan. Korea is represented (by way of Mexico) in tiny, tasty but oddly lukewarm Korean barbecue tacos, and Vietnam gets a shout-out in a pork bahn mi, which is saucy and sweet but ultimately balanced by heat and fresh basil. The only problem with the sandwich? It doesnt taste much like bahn mi. Then again, this shouldnt be much of a surprise. If Aja was going for authenticity, it wouldnt have a J in its name.

Someone chopped Kitschn River North in half and opened this place in the other part of it. It wasnt a bad ideathis is a huge building in a weird area that doesnt seem fit for much besides after-work eating and drinking. The execution leaves much to be desired, though, starting with the imbalanced cocktails, continuing with unappealing mains (mushy, underseasoned Kobe burger and steak; carb-on-carb potato ravioli) and ending with an icy trio of ice creams. The short wine list (all sustainable, biodynamic or organic) and chipper servers are just about the only reliable factors.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Chicago. Bus: 8, 11, 66, 132
content.property: Late-night dining Notable wine list Good for dining at bar Vegetarian-friendly

content.description: Name a region of the globe, and its likely to be represented somewhere on the sprawling small-plates menu at this equally sprawling West Loop lounge. With a menu this varied, its no wonder some dishes fell by the wayside: The promised tart beneath a goat cheese spread turned out, oddly, to be a dinner roll; vegetarian spring rolls were slimy and basic; grilled lamb chops and burning hot papas bravas were middling successes. The single dessert on the menua flaky pastry tart beautifully layered with applessuggests that if Mez pared things down a little, dining here might not feel like such a guessing game.
content.public-transport: El: Green, Pink to Clinton. Bus: 8, 65
content.property: Late-night dining Good for groups Good for dining at bar Vegetarian-friendly

content.description: While the aesthetics might recall a slick sushi restaurant, this newcomer trades almost exclusively in crpes. Sweet ones are thinner and crisp at the edges, filled with straightforward Nutella or berries. Thicker, doughier savory ones span the globe ingredients-wise, but we liked the Thai-ish Spice Up (fried fish, almost overwhelmed by the sheer volume of sweet curry sauce) and Boom Boom Egg (eggs over gently spiced ground chicken).
content.property: BYOB Cheap (entrees under $10) Good for groups Kid-friendly

content.description: The most recent discovery of LTHForum.com is this family-run Krgyzstani restaurant (the citys first). While the menu tempers expectations with the warning, Dont expect the food in Kyrgyzstan to be the highlight of your trip, a visit to Jibek Jolu, whose name translates to Silk Road, is certainly worthwhileif not simply to satisfy curiosity about the distinctly Central Asian dishes. Try the slick, eggy lagman noodles; plov, a hearty plate of buttery, carrot-studded rice dotted with a few chunks of lamb; and oversize dumplings called manty stuffed with tender ground beef. Much of the food is subtly seasoned and meat-centric, so cut through it with the spicy Korean carrot salad and plenty of hot tea.
content.property: BYOB Cheap (entrees under $10) Good for groups Late-night dining

content.description: We were as game as anybody to check out the latest foodie fave import, and Michiganers had us chomping at the bit to try the legendary Coney dogs, chicken-finger pita sandwiches and Greek salads at the first out-of-state location of the legendary diner chain. But maybe the fact that were not from Michigan made us less patient with the painfully rookie wait staff thatamong many transgressionsforgot our cutlery and stiffed us on the change we were due when we paid the bill. The chili cheese dogs were good, but in this hot-dog town, we can do better.

content.public-transport: El: Red, Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Fullerton. Bus: 8, 11, 74

content.description:
The hotel is a thoroughly high-tech operation, from the ergonomically designed furniture to the 42nd-floor state-of-the-art fitness center offering jaw-dropping views of Lake Michigan. In fact, each of the 632 rooms was designed to provide a lake or river view. Carnivores take comfort in prime beef at Chicago’s version of the Palm.
*High-speed internet ($9.95 wireless & via cable in rooms).

content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 8, 22, 77, 156

content.description: The classy loft look of this spacious River North club balances out the sexed-up, usually hip-hop–fueled parties that happen from Thursday nights on. Unfortunately, it closes at 2am, driving party traffic to nearby RiNo, Moda or Stone Lotus.
content.public-transport: El: Red, Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Chicago. Bus: 66, 156

content.description: Tucked behind the loud, buzzing hair stations in this spa/salon's front area, you'll find a peaceful, contemporary sanctuary that puts you right at ease. Every treatment under the sun is available in the stone and steel outfitted-space—from manicures to massages to waxing to body glows. But folks in-the-know come for the expert facials. We love the new Beyond Botox service ($130), which totally elimated our forehead wrinkles and blemishes and left us with a glow that lasted for days. Two complimentary rain showers are available for all guests, so plan ahead and schedule some time in one before or after your treatment.

entry.name: Stahl Family Theatre (formerly Saint Patrick Performing Arts Centre)

version.name: Stahl Family Theatre (formerly Saint Patrick Performing Arts Centre)

content.description: The calendar is anything-goes at this straightforward neighborhood lounge. It’s got a late-night license and has room for live rockabilly music, hip-hop and juke DJs on the weekends, and periodic house and techno marathons. The cover is usually low.

content.public-transport: El: Blue, Red to Monroe; Pink, Orange, Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Quincy.

content.description: Located just a block away from the Blue line Austin stop, this adorable one-room yoga studio is certainly no trek at all. It's just 20 minutes away from the Loop, but since you're out of the city, you may find it much easier to unwind (especially because there are no mirrors inside, so you can concentrate on your practice rather than your body image flaws). The studio moonlights occasionally as an art gallery, and the cheerful paintings hanging on the exposed brick walls should put you in a good mood. If the scenery doesn't do it for you, simply relax in the very able hands of the instructors, who wander around the room to adjust you and put you in the right position for each pose.

content.public-transport: Bus: 49A, 112. Metra: Rock Island to 111th St

content.description: Toujours is French for “everyday or always,” and that’s just what this salon-spa delivers: a cornucopia of beauty and spa services available every day (many spas are closed Sundays and Mondays). This Andersonville spot’s first floor is for hair and nail services and has all the hustle and bustle of a busy salon. But head downstairs to the cavernous spa area and you’ll find tranquility and silence. Four subterranean spa rooms are low-lit and fully equipped for massage, facials, waxing, laser services and the one-of-a-kind Raindrop Technique (a healing massage with essential oils). Shop the high-end selection of skin- and hair-care products (including Phyto and Privé) on the first floor before you hit the door.)
content.public-transport: El: Red to Bryn Mawr. Bus: 36, 92

content.description: Directed by accomplished aerialist Shayna Swanson, this popular spot for off-the-floor dance and graceful circus arts recently moved (June 1) to this spacious new facility. It’s your one-stop shop for training in bungee dancing, body conditioning, trapeze, stilt dancing and burlesque.

content.description: This cozy, immaculately detailed Irish pub (formerly Four Corners) might be the last thing youd expect on the spaghetti strip of Taylor Street, but soon itll be first on your places to swig pints and shovel eats from across the pond list. Just ask any of the UIC doctors who are regulars.

The crew behind Green Eye and Underbar purchased the former Bar Vertigo space and gave it a bit of a face-lift, and, seemingly overnight, its already packed. The owners salvaged the Art Deco back bar from the old Lava Lounge space and somehow made it fit in these new narrow digs, but the real eye candy here is the never-ending parade of tattooed hipsters who seem to travel in packs to this bar familys watering holes.

content.description: If all youve ever done at Fox & Obel is seek out espelette pepper and single-origin chocolate, youll be surprised to wander into this new wine bar, where well-heeled older couples linger over wine flights and charcuterie plates. Though theres a full menu available, its best to stick with a generous glass of wine and a view of the lake inlet.

content.description: For most folks, getting a spa treatment is a special occasion—a once in a blue moon treat. Continuum Studio owners Johnnie Grozenski and Paul Hasenwinkel aim to take that splurge-feeling out of their Andersonville spa and teach clients that frequent services are like therapy for the body—essential and carthartic. That's not to say you won't luxuriate in your surroundings. You will. The rooms are dim and warm and the selection of hand-picked, decadent products (like the French skincare line Creme Pou Les Mains), near the front desk is staggering. As you're being blissfully rubbed, scrubbed or steamed during one of a plethora of reasonably-priced massages and skin care services on offer, don't be surprised if you develop a healthy addiction for this friendly spot.

content.description: The original cro in the dance-club franchise (there are now crobar outposts in Miami, New York and South America) was remodeled a few years ago with a South Beach–meets–industrial materials look. These days, the club hosts everything from a midweek Latin night to visits from big-name techno, house and trance DJs. But a typical weekend night features residents hammering with au courant dance tracks while girls on platforms demonstrate the finer points of deca dancing.

content.description: Founded to house the biological and anthropological collections assembled for the World’s Columbian Exposition of 1893, this massive museum of natural history still packs ’em in with more than 30 permanent exhibitions covering more than 300,000 square feet. Inside the permanent displays, you can get glared at by glowering dinos, marvel at ancient artifacts from a royal Egyptian tomb, undergo a lesson in cannibalism in the “Pacific Spirits” gallery or take a stroll through the Halls of Gems and Jade. Buzzworthy permanent exhibitions have made the Field their home in the last few years: “Ancient Americas” explores 30,000 years of history in North, South and Central America, and the glass-fronted “DNA Discovery Center” shows scientists at work tracking animal gene-sequences in order to protect the Earth’s biodiversity.
content.public-transport: El: Orange, Green, Red to Roosevelt. Bus: 12, 130, 146

content.description: Bringing a Harry Carays Tavern to tourist haven Navy Pier is almost as long overdue as a Cubs NL pennant. But this chain outlet does so many things right, even locals should feel at home. The bar is big and handsome, the beer list includes brews from Half Acre and Bells, and the Holy Cow Potato Chips arrive warm with blue cheese crumbles. Plus, theres this pro tip for the IMAX theater crowd, courtesy of one of the friendly bartenders: Depending on whos working the theater, theyll let you take drinks in with you. And we have to-go cups.

content.description: Designed in cool grays and browns by local master of stylish interiors, Suhail, as a kind of futuristic listeners’ lounge, this West Town club has lively and often risky bookings, which have made it a favorite of neighborhood hipsters. The audiophile jet set loves the spectacularly clear sound system, and it’s hard not to fall for the reasonable price of beer and often high-end wines. Monthly Dark Wave Disco night (usually the third Thursday) and visits from touring DJs such as Philly faves Diplo and Rich Medina are packed solid with lubricated, in-the-know dancers. On Sunday nights, there’s a reliably thumping reggae/dub event curated by former Deadly Dragon Soundsystem instigator, RikShaw.

content.description: This former meatpacking plant is now a tony lounge filled with designer midcentury furniture. Lately, it’s been booking Chicago house and Euro expat nights with a bondage bash thrown-in for variety’s sake.

content.description: When this institution opened in 1961, African-American history was suffering serious neglect at the hands of the city’s—and for that matter the nation’s—cultural institutions. The Hyde Park cultural hub is now one of the oldest and most respected African-American–focused museums in the country. On display are documents and artifacts from the lives of overlooked or unjustly marginalized movers and shakers, plus a collection of vibrant African-American art.

content.description: The local-eating revolution has been homogenized and corporatized, and the outcome is this swank happy-hour bar with a list of local libations. We applaud the effort, particularly when it comes to the 40-strong beer list, which has plenty of the Two Brothers and Three Floyds variety to choose from. The cocktails still skew heavily toward mass-market vodka, a fitting match for after-work drinks beneath sterile sepia tones, if not for ardent localvores.

content.public-transport: El: Red to Lake; Orange, Pink, Green, Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Randolph. Metra: Elec to Millennium Station. Bus: 3, 4, 6, 10, 14, 26, 143, 144, 145, 146, 147, 151, 157

content.description: The phrase vegan fast food may conjure up images of lettuce with a side of wheatgrass, but the grub here has more in common with your neighborhood burger joint than it does with a salad barexcept unlike at the neighborhood McDonalds, the food tastes better than the photographs behind the counter would make it appear. The Bite burger combo comes with super-crisp fries and a Jarritos soda, and while the milkshakes are thinner than your average lactose-filled ones, the situation is easily remedied by the addition of crumbled cookie dough and chocolate chips.

If youre playing the lottery, stop by this Filipino lunch counter/market, where you can pick up Lucky Me Noodles (ramen) and a lucky bamboo tree in one stop. For immediate gratification, head for the steam table filled with tender vinegar-splashed Adobo chicken, fried milkfish and humba, pork slathered with a sweet soy glaze. Excellent pancit bihon (fried vermicelli noodles sauted with cabbage, onion, carrot and pork) and tusilog (reddish-tinted pork mixed with fried egg and rice) are made fresh to order. The stogie-shaped lumpia Shanghai eggrolls are some of the best in Chicago; wash them down with Sarsi, sarsaparilla cola.

Theres little at this Italian BYOB that you havent seen (or, in all probability, eaten) before. So if youre looking for innovation, stay away. If, on the other hand, youre looking for a good plate of sausage and peppers, or a piece of tilapia cooked in white wine and mushrooms, this may be your place. The basics are handled solidly all the way through dessert, where a housemade tiramisu and apple crisp inspire overeating. But the pizzathough topped with a sprightly sauceis undercooked and soggy, so if pizza is what you want, stay home and get it delivered from someplace else.

This addition to Broadways Ethiopian strip is often overlooked, maybe because in comparison to the tomes found at the nearby competition, the menu seems small at just under a dozen options (plus five more if you get there early enough for breakfast). The Abyssinia special, a pureed stew of beans, onions, garlic and peppers, is the best of the vegetarian dishesit has layers of flavors that betray its pedestrian looks. But the earthy yellow peas, spicy lentils and juicy lamb are nothing to sneeze at. And because theres not much else to order, theres no excuse not to order it all.

Big is the key word at Randy Zweibans eco-modern spot, but thats a reference to the flavors, not the serving sizes. For winter, Zweiban turns to the comforts of meatballs (slow-braised and seved with piquillo-ancho sauce), rabbit confit (brightened with salsa verde) and pork (slow-roasted into ropa vieja and paired with a roasted-corn cake).
content.public-transport: El: Green, Pink to Clinton. Bus: 14, 20, 38, 56
content.property: Good for dining at bar Outdoor seating Private party room(s)

content.description: The generic name is hardly promising, but hidden DaVinci Codelike in the logo is the clue that unlocks all the secrets of this small taco stand: the letters LP. This is an undercover branch of La Pasadita, Ashland Avenues legendary trio of late-night grilled steak taco shrines. And when you taste the freshly charred, subtly spiced carne asada or lengua served simply with cilantro and onion on tacos or rolled in a burrito, youll be glad the mini chain has reached this part of town.
content.public-transport: El: Blue to Jefferson Park. Bus: 54, 81, 92

content.description: Consider this Lincoln Square stalwart Greektown Northits got the same tangy taramasalata, creamy egg-lemon soup and the same moussaka as the rest of them. Its what this place has that the others dontnamely its signature lemon-and-oregano rubbed chicken and its selection of zimarika (cheesy Greek-style pastas)that makes it worth venturing out of Greektown for. That, and the fact that its not nearly as crowded, which means shorter waits, fewer people andmost importantless flaming saganaki.

Claiming to date back to 1927 (though the truth is it was closed for several years), this all-night beef stand certainly channels the true spirit of the old-school Chicago workingman's lunch. In an atmosphere a couple of steps below no-frills, you can accompany the excellent fresh-cut fries with the gutbomb of your choice: mild but perfectly decent Italian beef, a solid natural-casing hot dog done Chicago-minimalist style (mustard-relish-onion), or best of the bunch, a damn good Polish with hefty smoke. Eat it quickyoure not getting paid to loaf around.

Eating in a health club is a little like praying at an atheists convention. Maybe thats why the food here leans toward the simple, food-as-merely-sustenance variety. A trio of sliders (turkey, tuna and beef, each one well cooked and exhibiting a nice pinch of herbs) come without any condiment whatsoever; a piece of tender whitefish has a noticeable lack of salt; a tenderloin salad leaves much to be desired in both the tenderloin and the salad. Surprisingly, the carrot and apple-walnut cakes arent bad at all. Maybe the kitchen figures if youre ordering dessert, abstaining from salt and fat is just pointless.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Merchandise Mart. Bus: 65, 156

content.description: John Winslow (formerly general manager at Blue Plate Catering) is behind this all-day caf, which serves a little bit of everything, including egg sandwiches for breakfast, panini for lunch and an eclectic lineup of dishes ranging from gnocchi to bouillabaisse for dinner. Lines snake out the door and onto the sidewalk during brunch hours, but we think the real treasures here are the dinner dishes, like the crispy fish-and-chips and the hearty shepherds pienot the least bit because many of them hover around $10.

Its a coffee shop with vegan tendencies, but de.li.cious doesnt have that kumbaya vibe of spots such as Heartland Caf. Instead, it appears to be just another coffee shop. The vegan breakfast sandwich (tofu, vegan sausage, soy cheddar) will never pass for what it tries to emulate, but its a respectable (and filling) attempt; the vegan muffins do a better job of standing in for the real thing. But at the end of the day, its not the food youll come here for: Its the Chemex coffee, brewed so smooth and silky its well worth the eight-minute wait to get it.
content.public-transport: El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 11, 50, 80

content.description: Two decades old and still bustling, this Thai stalwart sits under the shadow of the Lincoln Square Brown Line station, thumbing its nose at the chowhounds running around town for ant eggs and crispy caterpillars. No need for secret menus herea broad range of staples are done well and at a good price. Wine-toting couples swap forkfuls of sweet-and-sour mee krob (a heap of crunchy noodle threads with sauted shrimp), tart nam sod (minced chicken tossed in a limey dressing with peanuts and raw ginger) and a filling and flavorful rendition of pad ped pla dook (hunks of crispy catfish sauted in red curry paste with green beans and eggplant). Tip: The divey liquor store two doors north has a surprisingly good beer and wine selection.
content.property: BYOB Vegetarian-friendly Good for groups Cheap (entrees under $10)

content.description: The second outpost of Billy Dec and pals River North madhouse (ahem, bar/restaurant) opened in the former Tuscany space in Wrigleyville, replete with their signature brie-topped Kobe burger with truffle fries and a tree-lined outdoor patio.

This is the sibling restaurant of Logan Squares cult favorite Mexican joint, Fonda del Mar. But dont expect the crowds to start spilling in here any time soon. Unlike the Logan Square spot, which deftly puts out wholesome seafood dishes, fdm aims for higher-end Mexican farestuff like tilapia in a grainy walnut-goat cheese sauce. The food never really takes off, and some of it crashes and burns. So go for the cocktails and the sleek dining room, but explore the food with trepidation.
content.public-transport: El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 11, 50, 80

content.description: Tucked into the north end zone of U.S. Beer Co., Tailgate caters to the takeout crowd; a recent visit found the kitchen hopping even as customers were slow to materialize. Cheap, heartily portioned staples (theres nothing priced over $10 except the baby-back slab at $18.95) are grouped under football phrases (apps are the kick-off, etc.). Those looking to bulk up for the gridiron should order the baked mostaccioli with meat sauce, a buttery casserole oozing with cheese. Little else gets past the line of scrimmagewith an overcooked salmon sandwich, nothing-special ribs, watery minestrone, limp fries and inoffensive chicken kabobs, youd be better off grilling in the stadium lot.
content.public-transport: El: Red to North/Clybourn; Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Armitage. Bus: 8, 9, 72

content.description: Marlene Benitezs follow-up to Andersonvilles La Cocina de Frida has the same ambition as her original spot: classic, homestyle Mexican food, some of it with a minor twist. Funnily enough, this new version seems to be doing a better job with the execution. The guac is rich and creamy, the ceviche balanced between sweet and spicy, the chicken immersed in a complex peanut-and-chile guajillo salsa. In fact, anybody who has found themselves disappointed in the Andersonville locale may find checking this one out worth the trip.

Dont be deterred by the bare-bones look of this new Algerian carryout shop. The handful of forlorn items languishing in the steam table come from co-owner Mohammed Djeddour, who also owns the adjacent Tassili, which aims at a cabbie clientele. But grab a paper menu and youll see surprisingly ambitious salads, wraps and sides, courtesy of former Mundial co-owner/chef Kate Garcia. Try a trio of salads: apricot-studded Israeli couscous, spinach and strawberries in mustard vinaigrette and cubed watermelon with cucumber dressed in thin, minty yogurt. Crpelike Algerian-style flatbreads prove perfect for soaking up the mint pesto drizzled on wraps of roasted vegetables or hunks of roasted lamb, and pistachio shortbreads complement the carryout package for a complete dinner at home.

Simple and pleasant, this neighborhood caf is comprised of a quiet room with a corner devoted to Chicagocentric art and jewelry and a back patio so calm and flower-lined youd forget you were in the city (if it werent for the adjacent parking lot and apartment buildings). Steer clear of ho-hum croissant sandwiches in favor of getting full-on lacy crpes slathered with Nutella and sprinkled with banana slices, and wash the whole thing down with a tasty iced latte.
content.public-transport: El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 11, 50, 80

content.description: After 22 years as Cafe Shino, this Gold Coast stalwart got a makeover and has emerged as a sake lounge, complete with two dozen varieties of rice wine, a private karaoke room, and a menu of otsumami, traditional Japanese small plates (were fans of the crispy-edged hot-dog bites, plummy baby octopus, spicy salmon hand rolls and tofu-topped udon noodles). For a primer on sake, ask manager Kerry Tamura, whos happy to steer you in the right direction.
content.property: Private party room(s) Late-night dining Good for groups

content.description: As is to be expected at any place that has an eight-page menu, this Turkish spot has both hits and misses. The good news? The missesoverly simple vegetable fritters, overly smoky eggplant pureesdont miss by all that much. So even if you try only one of the hits, like the vibrant lahmacun and hearty iskender kebab, youll likely have a meal that rises to above-par levels.

Owner Jim Andrews has an edgy sense of humor, thats for sure. And theres no doubt, either, that his providing on-the-job training for ex-offenders at his hot-dog stand is a much-needed and respectable undertaking. Whether youll be entertained by the coyly named eats (Misdemeanor Weiners, Probation Burgers) and theatrical service (youll be asked Are you ready to plead your case? when you step up to the Plexiglas divider) is another story. But heres whats not up for debate: The Chicago-style dogs (supplied by Red Hot Chicago) are merely satisfactory; the fast-food style burgers are vastly improved with the addition of bacon; and Objection Onion Rings, generously battered and fried to a crisp, will actually garner no objections at all.
content.public-transport: El: Blue to Western (Forest Park). Bus: 20, 49, 126

content.description: Maher Chebaro is a man who loves condiments. So while the only thing on the menu at his late-night Lakeview storefront is falafelgreaseless, if a bit dryits the salad bar visit that comes with each falafel pita or bowl that makes this place well worth a visit. There, toum (emulsified roasted garlic), sweet bulghur salad, spicy pickled ginger and creamy tabouli easily hide the falafels minor shortcomingsand then some.
content.public-transport: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Belmont. Bus: 36, 77, 151, 156

content.description: Hot dogs are once again making a go of it in the former Lincoln Park Rockstar Dogs location. Unlike the previous tenant, however, this operation is decidedly no-frills. The Polish char is a better bet than the wimpy hot dog or greasy fries, and puck-tough burgers should be avoided. But dont discount the place entirely when you take into account a 4am weekend closing time and dirt-cheap prices, the food suddenly seems much more palatable.

Most dishes at this south-Serbian restaurant begin with a base of ground pork and beef: In cevapi, the juicy, well-seasoned meat is packed into a patty, then grilled; in sarmice, its combined with rice and stuffed into grape leaves, accompanied by yogurt; and in the restaurants signature dish, leskovacki opanak, the mixture is rolled with ham into a log, wrapped in bacon, then grilled. Fluffy breads; the urnebes salad of creamy feta, sour cream and red-pepper flakes; spright cabbage slaw; and the sweet, smoky red-pepper spread called ajvar help cut through the protein. Dont leave without dessertcrpes spread with Nutella and crunchy cookie-crumblesand a strong, thick cup of Serbian coffee.
content.property: Cheap (entrees under $10) BYOB Good for groups

content.description: Whether or not you find a pizza called Its For My Girlfriend sexist, the version at this new River North slice shop is definitely not for the intended stereotype. No self-conscious eater would tolerate all that mozzarella on top of the otherwise solid combination of sun-dried tomatoes and goat cheese. In any case, a cracker-thin flatbread topped with mild blue cheese and sauted onions is more balanced. Especially when you consider that the only nearby competition for slices is defrosted bar pizza and Sbarros.
Karyn Calabreses third restaurant is in the former Butter space, but her takes on chicken legs, crab cakes and peanut-butter ice cream are all vegan.

content.description: Sick of hiking to the ‘burbs to get your fix on this store’s beauty basics? Save your gas money and head downtown. From Dolce & Gabbana perfume to Neutrogena skincare, Ulta makes beauty accessible for any price point. If you can’t find something among the three floors of more than 21,000 beauty products (cosmetics, fragrances, hair care, skincare, bath and body), good luck finding it elsewhere. The shop even offers brands unavailable at other locations such as hair accessories by Lavender Girl, Colette Malouf and France Luxe. The fourth floor contains The Salon at Ulta, led by David Barnett of the John Barrett Salon in Bergdorf Goodman. Stylists, colorists and skincare specialists offer complimentary consultations.

content.description:
This stunning Beaux Arts building, which started out as a private men’s club in 1929, has been transformed into one of Starwood’s sleek W Hotels. The 369 rooms come with pillow-top mattresses and the option of an in-room shiatsu massage. You can request just about anything (legal) you desire from W’s signature Whatever/Whenever service, which once reportedly hired a helicopter to fetch a guest’s wedding cake.
High-speed internet (free wireless in lobby; $14.95 via cable in rooms).

content.description: Neither the library’s classic architecture nor its patrician setting betray its mission to bring high-brow culture to the plebs. All exhibitions, which generally revolve around a book or lit theme, are free. And anyone can browse the 2-million volume collection that specializes in Chicago history, genealogy, cartography and printing. All you need is a reading card, which will require a photo ID, proof of address and a reason for wanting to search a specific collection.

Or you can be grateful for what it does offer: a $10 manicure-and-martini deal doled out by two beauticians near the door; a respectable DJ lineup that spins to the masses in a back room; and lots and lots and lots of glitter.

content.description: Young trendsetters and stylish moms-to-be rave about Krista K’s impressive collection of women’s clothing and maternity wear—includingdenim from Chip & Pepper, James Preserved, True Religion and Yanuk($125-$175). Also popular are feminine tops, jackets and trousers from Nanette Lepore ($175-$350) and Rebecca Taylor ($200-$400). On rare occasions an intimidating salesperson may make you rethink your purchase, but the well-edited selection usually guarantees a positive, albeit expensive, wardrobe-altering experience.
content.public-transport: El: Red, Brown to Addison. Bus: 152.9

content.description: Even if you already own at least a dozen pairs, it wouldn’t hurt to check out this Lincoln Park boutique. In addition to stocking jeans, the store offers the opportunity to create “2050 Jeanetic profiles,” where in-house stylists will help you figure out which brand (such as G-Star Raw, Diesel and Levi’s Andy Warhol X Project) best suits you. It’s not all about the denim, though. The shop also offers trendy men’s and women’s designer clothing like Sport Max, J. Lindeberg, John Varvatos for Converse and William Rast.

content.description: This off-the-beaten-path vintage shop stocks plenty of looks from the “Me Decade” and beyond, but ten percent of the merchandise is new items by local designers such as screenprinted T-shirts and scarves by Kiyomi Kimble. All resale items are under $100, including a large selection of cowboy boots.

content.description: Local designer Ashley Zygmunt's storefront is mostly used as a studio, where the she works on the staples in her collection, including the Wesley Tunic ($109), Kali Tank ($78), Caroline Dress ($148) and Michelle Dress ($158). But there’s a showroom in the front of the space, so shoppers can make appointments to view and purchase items.
